HEADLINE: Semiconductor Order Index Hit a High in July

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry displayed unexpected strength today, as its leading indicator reached an all-time high in July, driven primarily by a big increase in orders.
The Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.22, setting a new record and exceeding the 1.20 mark set in May. 
 The book-to-bill ratio compares orders with shipments: a number above one indicates positive growth, and a ratio of 1.22 indicates that for every $100 of chips shipped during the month, $122 of chips were ordered.
The closely watched book-to-bill ratio was reported after the stock market closed, but it exceeded Wall Street's consensus estimate of 1.17.
Some analysts predicted that this new sign of strength was likely to send technology stocks even higher. Others cautioned, however, that the rising orders behind July's book-to-bill ratio probably reflected the fact that many computer manufacturers were increasing their chip inventories ahead of the Aug. 24 introduction of the Microsoft Corporation's Windows 95 operating system.
"I think there's a lot of double-ordering going on," said Michael Murphy, editor of The California Technology Stock Letter. "People don't want to get caught short in case Windows 95 prompts a huge demand" for computers.
"People are willing to carry a lot more inventory on their shelves and place orders out a lot further," he added, noting that the book-to-bill ratio did not indicate when semiconductor orders would be shipped.
But Rajiv Chaudhri, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, said the July book-to-bill ratio included orders that were too far in advance to reflect the introduction of Windows 95.
"I think Windows 95, if anything, would cause people to delay their purchasing decisions," he said. "In the near term, the impact of Windows 95 would probably be negative. But, coming out when it does, Windows 95 really does set us up for a very strong fourth quarter." The industry fundamentals remain strong."
Chip orders rose to $4.46 billion in July, up 3 percent from $4.33 billion in June, and up 52.7 percent from $2.92 billion in July 1994. July shipments also reached a new high, at $3.67 billion, although this was only a four-tenths of 1 percent increase from $3.66 billion in June. July 1995 shipments were up 35.8 percent from $2.70 billion in July 1994.

Chip Maker Expands Plant

 
 SANTA CLARA, Calif. Aug. 10 (Bloomberg Business News) -- The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it would spend $300 million to expand its Arlington, Tex., manufacturing plant, to keep up with the demand for its products. The chip maker said the expansion would create 400 jobs. The plant employs 1,150 people. Applications for the integrated circuits produced in Arlington include personal computers and telephones, as well as computer networking and telecommunications equipment. The Arlington plant also has a customer support center and a telecommunications center.

HEADLINE: Little Inflation Seen as Producer Prices Are Flat

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Inflation was virtually imperceptible again at the producer level in July, and new claims for unemployment benefits stayed fairly low last week, the Labor Department announced today.
The reports provided further evidence that the Federal Reserve was meeting its goal of restraining price increases without setting off a recession. 
 Most prices charged by factories, farmers and other producers for finished goods were little changed last month, while falling prices for gasoline and home heating oil offset rising prices for food.
"Inflation has been tamed and the economy, which stagnated in the second quarter, is picking up in the second half," said Rosanne M. Cahn, chief economist for stocks at CS First Boston.
The Producer Price Index for finished goods was unchanged in July and rose only two-tenths of 1 percent when food and energy prices were excluded, the Labor Department said. The index fell by a tenth of a percentage point in June and was unchanged in May.
The slower pace of price increases is already making a difference for businesses across the country. For example, the Dalzell Corporation, which produces handmade glass candleholders, stemware and plates in New Martinsville, W. Va., has benefited from fairly stable prices this summer for sand, an important raw material for glass.
But with relatively little inflation, companies have also found it difficult in recent months to pass along price increases for other materials, like cardboard for shipping boxes. "We've had to, on a competitive basis, either hold prices or discount prices to some customers," said Kenneth B. Dalzell, the company's president.
For Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, the latest inflation figures could indicate new latitude to reduce short-term interest rates. But Wall Street analysts are skeptical that the central bank's officials will do so at their next meeting, on Aug. 22.
"They have conditions right the way they want them, so why should they change anything?" asked Eugene J. Sherman, director of research at M. A. Schapiro & Company, a New York brokerage firm.
Consumer prices could still bounce up a little because of wholesale price increases earlier this year; the Labor Department is scheduled to announce on Friday morning how much these prices rose in July. But Government and private economists were particularly encouraged by the index for raw materials, like grain and iron ore, which fell by eight-tenths of 1 percent in July. The index for goods used in intermediate stages of industrial processes, like flour and steel, was also unchanged last month.
"Inflation at the crude and intermediate level has abated in the last three months, which bodes well for overall inflation for the rest of the year," said Martin N. Baily, a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers.
Higher prices for raw materials and intermediate goods can lead eventually to higher consumer prices, particularly if other business costs, like wages and salaries for employees, also rise. But over the last year, businesses have been unusually successful in restraining the growth in employee compensation to less than the increase in workers' output, helping businesses to hold down the prices they charge to consumers.
For example, Griffith Rubber Mills Inc., a producer of truck windshield gaskets and other products, reduced the size of its administrative staff as prices rose until recently for ethylene, a natural gas product that is a key raw material for synthetic rubber. With customers refusing to pay higher prices, Griffith Rubber Mills also tried to cut costs by changing production schedules to match daylight hours.
"You don't have to have the lights on as much," said Scot H. Laney, the president of the company, which is based in Portland, Ore. But business conditions are improving, he added, because ethylene prices have leveled off in the last three months.
Gasoline prices fell 10.1 percent in July while home-heating-oil prices dropped 2.2 percent. But fresh fruit prices rose 3.8 percent, processed chicken prices climbed 4 percent and fish and shellfish prices increased 2.9 percent.
The Labor Department's index for consumer goods other than food and energy crept up two-tenths of 1 percent for a second consecutive month, led by price increases for soap, books and newspapers.
Capital equipment prices were up just one-tenth of 1 percent in July, as falling prices for light trucks and paper-industry machinery nearly balanced price increases for heavy trucks, agricultural and oilfield machinery, civilian aircraft and machine tools.
In another report, the Labor Department said initial claims for unemployment compensation rose 14,000 last week, to a seasonally adjusted 335,000.
The increase was the first in three weeks, but new jobless claims remained relatively low compared with levels reached in early July. Indeed, the four-week moving average for jobless claims, considered a more accurate gauge of the job market, fell last week to 361,000, the lowest level since May 6.
Last week, the Labor Department reported that the unemployment rate rose in July to 5.7 percent, from 5.6.
Still, economists seem confident that the economy will continue to grow with minimal inflation. A monthly survey of 52 blue-chip corporate and academic economists, released today by Eggert Economic Enterprises Inc. in Sedona, Ariz., showed that the consensus forecast for growth in the third quarter of this year had edged up to 2.1 percent from a 2.0 percent forecast in a July survey, while the consensus forecast for fourth-quarter growth was 2.7 percent, up from 2.6 percent in July.
The consensus for consumer price inflation this year was unchanged at 3.1 percent.

HEADLINE: The Latest Big Boom: Citizenship

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Doing their part in the greatest rush for citizenship in the nation's history, student volunteers are setting out almost every weekend in the Hispanic neighborhoods of this city to fingerprint their immigrant elders, take photographs of them and guide them carefully through Form N-400, Application for Naturalization.
The forms, once completed, become part of a surge of citizenship applications that have poured into the Immigration and Naturalization Service in the last year or so, many from people who lived in the United States for years or even decades before giving citizenship much thought. 
 "We are seeing record numbers of naturalization applications," said Virginia Kice, a spokeswoman for the immigration service in California. "April was the peak, with 2,200 a day in Los Angeles, and the numbers are still high."
Records are being set all over the country, said an I.N.S. spokesman in Washington, Rudolph Brewington. In the nine months through June, nearly 715,000 people applied for citizenship, a 78 percent increase over the corresponding period a year earlier. Mr. Brewington said Congress had approved the hiring of 1,000 new I.N.S. employees to help process the applications.
Several factors are feeding the surge, according to immigration officials and immigrant rights groups alike.
One is sheer numbers: Nearly three million undocumented aliens who were granted amnesty and legal residence under the 1986 immigration reform law are now becoming eligible to proceed with applications for citizenship.
Another is fear: Anti-immigration sentiment, as demonstrated by Proposition 187 in California and Federal legislative proposals, threatens to deprive noncitizens of education, all but emergency health care and other services.
Further, the Mexican Government is preparing to adopt a constitutional amendment that would remove both economic and emotional obstacles to a change in citizenship among Mexicans, by far the majority of California's immigrant population.
The proposed amendment, which is expected to gain legislative approval next month and ratification by the states within a year or so, would change the law to allow Mexicans to retain their property rights, as well as a nonvoting cultural Mexican "nationality," while taking foreign citizenship.
"It is important that they understand that they are becoming citizens of this country but that they keep their cultural Mexican roots," said Jose Angel Pescador, Mexico's consul general in Los Angeles. "People were afraid of being ashamed in Mexico because they changed their nationality. Now they will not change their nationality."
Indeed, among people at a "citizenship fair" at Belmont High School in downtown Los Angeles last weekend, the cultural issue seemed to weigh much heavier than the matter of property rights.
"There's always been rumors in the immigrant community that when you become a United States citizen, people will ask you to spit on the Mexican flag or step on the flag," said Arturo Vargas, executive director of the fair's sponsor, the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials. "These were rumors that people actually believed."
For whatever reasons, Mexicans have traditionally been among the slowest immigrant groups to apply for citizenship. An immigration service study in 1992 showed that just 17 percent of Mexicans who entered the country legally in 1977 had sought to become citizens since, compared with 63 percent of immigrants from the Soviet Union, the group with the highest figure.
Now the amnesty program, anti-immigration sentiment and the Mexican Government's assurances have contributed to a shift in attitudes in the city's vast Mexican community, several Hispanic leaders agreed.
"There's even peer pressure," Mr. Vargas said. " 'Why, you haven't become a citizen yet? What's your problem? What are you waiting for?' This is something I've never seen before, and I grew up in L.A. You'll be talking politics, and someone will say, 'I can't vote,' and it's like, 'What?' "
Antonia Hernandez, president of the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, said political and economic changes both here and in Mexico seemed to have contributed to a social awakening among Mexican immigrants.
"People who have been here 20 years will tell you, 'I'm becoming a citizen,' " she said. " 'I want to vote. I want to vote against Pete Wilson. I want to be heard.' "
Among many immigrants, Governor Wilson is the personification of Proposition 187 and of what they see as a political trend in which immigrants are blamed for the state's problems.
But beyond that, Ms. Hernandez said, a Hispanic voting bloc is harder to define. Republicans claim it, arguing that Hispanic people have strong family values consistent with Republican principles. But the Hispanic vote has traditionally been largely Democratic, a result, Ms. Hernandez said, of a prevailing sentiment that government should be actively involved in promoting the common good.
At the citizenship fair at Belmont High School last weekend, Manuel Jasso, now a 37-year-old telecommunications engineer, said he first came to the United States from Mexico as an illegal worker in 1982 and had not considered citizenship till now.
But so long away from a native land changes a person, Mr. Jasso said. "When you go back, you feel lonely, you feel like a stranger," he said. "You go back to a street that was a two-way street, and suddenly it's one-way. And you realize, 'I don't belong here.' "
Dora Monzon, 40, who sews jumpsuits for race-car drivers for a living, first came here, illegally, in 1969. She obtained legal residency five years ago under the amnesty program. She has not visited Mexico since 1976.
"In my heart, I am Mexican," she said. "I come from there. But my children are here, and for that I have to be an American citizen."
Paula Gomez, an American-born high school student who was helping Ms. Monzon with her application, is a daughter of Mexican immigrants, both of whom, like many Mexicans here, continue to resist citizenship.
"I see myself as more modern-thinking than my parents," Miss Gomez said. "Like, my father is very macho and I am extremely feminist, and I don't put up with his macho stuff.
"When he says these things, I just let loose on him. 'You're a girl, and you're supposed to stay at home and make dinner,' and I'm like, 'Oh, dad, I'm going to college and be a lawyer and be a prosecutor like Marcia Clark, only more professional and not so emotional.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Many immigrants now applying for naturalization lived in the United States for years or even decades before giving citizenship much thought. One is Acetia Cantero, who arrived from Cuba 22 years ago and did not act until attending a "citizenship fair" last weekend at Belmont High School in downtown Los Angeles, where she was fingerprinted and got help in completing her application. (Jan Sonnenmair for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In America;
Good News for The City

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
New York is a tough town to live in. I've often gone in search of a legal parking space late at night and ended up so far from my apartment I had to take a subway or a taxi home.
The weather is wicked. There are only about a dozen really beautiful days each year. 
 The noise is ceaseless. Jackhammers. Sirens. Screaming neighbors. Traffic. Sporadic gunfire.
Crossing a street can resemble Russian roulette. Buses, trucks, bicyclists, Rollerbladers -- all coming at you.
You get used to it. It's not as bad as combat.
The flip side is that when good things happen in New York, the tendency is to savor them a bit more than is usual. A man sneezed in a bodega the other day, and when a stranger said, "God bless you," a huge smile creased the face of the surprised sneezer and he couldn't stop saying thank you.
Like almost everything else, a simple kindness plays bigger in New York.
Right now there is quite a bit to savor in the city; some very good things are happening. So good, in fact, that the skeptics -- traumatized by decades of bad news -- are looking warily about for hidden explanations that might turn the good news upside down.
Let's start with crime. It appears to be plummeting. Compared with the first six months of last year, homicides are down by a third. If the trend continues through December, New York will record the fewest homicides in 25 years.
There are a lot of New Yorkers currently walking around who, if the old trends had held, would have been dispatched to their reward by now. You may know some of them. You may be one of them.
In 1990 there were 2,245 homicides in New York, a record. (The total included 87 people who were killed in an arson fire at the Happy Land club in the Bronx.) In the first six months of this year, there were fewer than 600 homicides. By the end of the year, the Police Department expects to record the lowest number of homicides since 1970, when John Lindsay was Mayor, Nelson Rockefeller was Governor and 1,117 people were killed in New York City.
All other serious crimes have declined sharply as well, with the exception of forcible rape, which is down only slightly from last year.
The blessing of a substantially reduced crime rate is due in large part to the hiring of 7,000 additional police officers since 1990 -- a legacy of the Dinkins administration -- and the much more aggressive and sophisticated approach to policing that has been put in place by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Police Commissioner William Bratton.
The potential political payoff is huge. If the crime numbers continue their precipitous fall, no one will be able to beat Mr. Giuliani when he comes up for re-election in 1997.
The other good news for New York City has to do with the academic performance of the public schools. Math and reading scores are up in every district and Schools Chancellor Ramon Cortines is likely to reveal soon that there has been an encouraging response to his imposition of more stringent science and math requirements in the high schools.
It is very difficult to overstate the benefits to a big city of reduced crime and improved public school performance. If the improvements in New York are sustained, they will dramatically enhance the social and economic life of the city. A very tough town will become a lot more attractive and somewhat easier to deal with.
The irony for New Yorkers is that the two men most responsible for the improvements -- Mr. Cortines and Mr. Bratton -- have both had troubled relations with Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Cortines, belittled and repeatedly assailed by the Mayor, has already announced he is leaving as chancellor. Mr. Bratton, a very proud man who was forced by Mr. Giuliani to adopt a much lower public profile, insists that everything is fine now. Nevertheless, it is widely believed that he will depart as Police Commissioner sooner rather than later.
Mr. Cortines and Mr. Bratton are both popular. What happens if they move on and their replacements are unable to build upon, or even maintain, their successes? The disappointment will be palpable. The impact on the city could be tragic. And questions will be raised that Mayor Giuliani may have a tough time answering.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
What Is China Up To?

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The United States is conspiring to undermine China politically, economically and militarily. It plots to tear Taiwan from China, to stunt Chinese military growth and economic power, and leads a world campaign to punish Beijing for human rights violations.
These accusations are made constantly now by China's Communist rulers. From their mouths to God's ear. But all this is not only untrue but the deliberate reversal of reality. 
 Economically, U.S. policy enriches Beijing. Militarily, it strengthens China's army and national police apparatus. It is also excellent for Chinese family values. From the family chief to the youngest grandson, elite Chinese Communist families swagger with riches from exports to the U.S. of businesses controlled by the party or the army.
The Clinton Administration did cross Beijing, once. Under Congressional pressure, it allowed Taiwan's President to attend an alumni meeting in the U.S. Ever since, exhausted by its spasm of imposed courage, the Administration chants obediently that it will never question that Taiwan must remain part of China.
And China and the U.S. both know that since Mr. Clinton reneged on his promise to use tariff pressure to persuade Beijing to improve human rights a mite, the U.S. cannot do more than look wan when the subject comes up.
But Americans in officialdom, academia, journalism and business, knowing how the U.S. plumps up China, pay humble attention to Beijing's propaganda about The American Threat. China's "conspiracy" blackmail is already paying off in American timidity.
Beijing is echoing the anti-U.S. propaganda campaigns other dictatorships found ominously useful. Hitler screamed about the American danger; so did Saddam Hussein and the ayatollahs. To listen to the Japanese in the late 30's, the U.S. was about to sneak-bomb the Japanese Navy. Stalin put two prices on friendship with America: Siberia, or death.
But at least then there were Americans in public life who understood that the anti-American drives were often the prelude to something extremely unpleasant, a signal of aggression in preparation. They tried to warn other Americans what the charges concealed -- or revealed.
Those Chinese who risk their lives struggling against the Beijing despotism know the reason that the fear-America line is being concocted.
The Politburo and Army want to make sure right now that when Deng Xiaoping dies, the people of China do not believe, act or speak under any illusion that the new government will move into an era of freedom.
And in Beijing, as in other dictatorships, the rash of leaks and threats about how Americans plot to destroy the homeland is not meant simply to be heard abroad. It is meant to be interpreted in China that unapproved association with Americans today can once again be paid for tomorrow with prison or death.
The line about a U.S. military danger to China is particularly important. When dictatorships continuously warn their countrymen about a challenge to sovereignty -- like supporting Taiwanese or Tibetan freedom -- that's when to start worrying that they are cooking up a military or political offensive themselves.
Yet generally the American printed and diplomatic reaction to the Chinese charges is not that they amount to dangerous, pre-emptive fear-mongering but that top Chinese officialdom really deeply worries about an American conspiracy. The lesson preached then is that Washington should pay even more attention to Beijing's sensitivities.
Chinese leaders would be idiots to believe their own charges. China's gulag wardens are thick in the head -- their jobs demand it. But Politburo leaders are as intelligent as Western leaders, at least.
Beijing knows better. While the U.S. tries desperately to create "constructive engagement" with them, the Communists break agreements to halt slave-labor exports and stop missile sales. While the U.S. gives the Communists maximum economic advantage, they arrest more dissidents. With clear intent and exquisite aim Beijing keeps spitting in Washington's humble eye. Then it demands apologies.
The real question facing Americans is not what we should do to placate the Chinese Communists further. It is: What are these boys up to now?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Join the Women in Beijing

 BODY:
Early next month as many as 50,000 people from around the world will go to Beijing to attend the United Nations' Fourth World Conference on Women and a parallel gathering of grass-roots women's organizations. The two meetings will discuss subjects like women's access to health care and education, their role in economic development and politics and problems such as family violence and abuse of human rights.
These issues matter deeply to Americans, and many have been special concerns of the Clinton Administration. The United States should be a conspicuous participant at the Beijing conference, with the First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, leading the official delegation. 
 China's leaders, fearing free discussion of their own repressive policies, have done everything they can to damage the conference's credibility and divert attention from its women's rights agenda. Betraying its host-country responsibilities, China has arbitrarily excluded participants from Taiwan and Tibet, restricted press coverage and exiled the grass-roots meeting to a remote site more than 30 miles from the main conference. It has also placed obstacles like complex special visa requirements in the path of third-world women of limited means who have been saving up for months to attend the meeting.
A number of these issues remain under negotiation, but few now expect China to live up to its pledges of a conference open to all legitimate participants. This week Beijing began using the conference as a pretext for a new roundup of dissenting intellectuals and activists.
It is tempting to consider boycotting the conference to protest China's behavior, its forced abortion and sterilization policies and its detention of an American citizen and human rights activist, Harry Wu.
But United States participation in the world women's conference is not a favor to China. It is a show of respect and support for the efforts of women in this country and around the world. On almost all the issues scheduled for discussion, Washington figures to be a powerful ally of those favoring women's political, economic and human rights. If the official American delegation stayed home, the cause of women's freedom would be weakened, not strengthened.
The same reasoning argues for sending the most high-powered delegation possible. Mrs. Clinton is an especially articulate advocate on these issues. Her presence would enhance the visibility and authority of the American delegation. It could also help thwart Chinese attempts to restrict press coverage and exclude unwelcome voices.
Obviously, the White House cannot agree to any conditions on her attendance that would undermine larger United States policies toward China. She should not, for example, hold meetings with top Chinese leaders while Harry Wu remains in jail. But Washington's differences with Beijing should not be taken out on the women from around the world who have invested their hopes in this important international conference. Nor should they be a reason for abandoning China's more than 500 million women.
It would only hand a quiet victory to China's repressors for the strongest advocates of women's liberty to stay away from Beijing. The United States should be there in force and in full voice.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises to Recent Highs Against the Mark and the Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose to a two-month high against the German mark and to a five-month high against the Japanese yen yesterday, bolstered by expectations of a cut next month in German interest rates and a successful United States Treasury auction.
"Sentiment is bullish for the dollar," said Belal Khan, chief customer dealer at Bank of Tokyo in New York. 
 But the rally in the dollar was surprising, given that the German central bank left key interest rates unchanged at a policy meeting yesterday. And while the Treasury's auction of $11.5 billion of 30-year bonds went well yesterday, buying by Japanese investors did not live up to the market's expectations, analysts said.
Still, the dollar rose as high as 1.4240 marks, its highest level since June 2, when it touched 1.4242 marks, before settling at 1.4192 marks in late New York trading, up from 1.4063 on Wednesday. The dollar also reached 92.94 yen, its highest level since March 7, when it rose to 93.03. It settled yesterday at 92.63 yen, up from 91.63 on Wednesday.
The American currency's recent strength against the mark derives from expectations that the Bundesbank will soon cut interest rates. Lower German rates would hurt the mark by making investments denominated in it less attractive.
While the Bundesbank took no action to cut its discount and Lombard rates yesterday, traders and analysts said the German economy was slowing fast enough to push the central bank to lower its discount rate soon.
"People are looking for a discount-rate cut in September," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, a consulting firm. The Bundesbank last cut the discount rate, the floor for German money market rates, on March 30 by half a percentage point, to 4 percent.
The dollar was also helped yesterday by the results of the United States Treasury's third and final auction of $42.5 billion in securities. While Japanese interest was not as keen as had been hoped yesterday, strong demand for American assets typically indicates that more foreign investors will need to buy dollars to participate.
Traders have been bullish on the dollar against the yen since Tokyo announced a program last week to encourage Japanese to invest abroad. "There is a widespread belief that the dollar has bottomed," said Betsy Reetz, manager of institutional currency sales at National Westminster Bank in New York.

HEADLINE: AT THE MET AND THE MODERN WITH: Richard Serra;
One Provocateur Inspired by Another

SERIES: A periodic series of talks with artists about art in New York City museums.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
THE sculptor Richard Serra, intense and determined, as always, is moving headlong through the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He wants to see Jackson Pollock's big drip painting of 1950, "Autumn Rhythm," and then more Pollocks at the Museum of Modern Art. He doesn't plan to be distracted. "When I come here," he says, "I look at one thing, and then leave."
Navigating the dense crowds in the Met ("a big unwieldy ship," he calls it), Mr. Serra, who is 55, remembers bringing his students from the School of Visual Arts here in the late 60's and early 70's: "We would decide, arbitrarily, to see Room 34, or whatever. We would walk around it for five or six minutes, take a vote about which work in it we liked the best, then stand in front of the work and clap. The exercise forced the students to visit rooms they probably would never have gone to otherwise. At the same time, the clapping broke the sanctity of the museum, which I think was good, and it returned students to the joy of looking and making distinctions." 
 Since Mr. Serra came onto the scene in those years, with works made of torn and bent rubber, and with lead that he splashed, rolled or propped up in big sheets one against another, he has emerged as a major artist, probably the most original and significant sculptor of his generation, certainly the most provocative. Many Americans know him for "Tilted Arc," the 120-foot-long, 12-foot-high slab of curved steel installed in 1981 at Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan, which caused a furious debate about public sculpture; the debate continued to rage even after the work was removed in 1989, over widespread objections by artists and many others, and to Mr. Serra's profound regret.
Opponents of "Tilted Arc" attacked it as aggressive, austere and obdurate, qualities some commentators likened to Mr. Serra's personality. But the criticisms of the sculpture were as skewed as the criticisms of Mr. Serra. He is fiercely intelligent, opinionated and articulate, and in conversation may talk straight over you to make his point. At the same time, he enjoys debate and can be solicitous and warm. The pleasure he takes in looking at art is palpable, contagious. And he's not unbending.
For example, arriving at the room in the 20th-century galleries with "Autumn Rhythm," he permits himself to be distracted by another, earlier Pollock nearby, "Pasiphae," of 1943. It is a dense abstraction of a recumbent figure flanked, or guarded, by standing figures.
"It's watered-down Picasso," Mr. Serra decides. "The issue at the time was: How do we Americans break with European tradition and get away from post-Cubism? And this painting falls back on the usual set-up for a traditional painting. Its brutishness doesn't sustain it. It's clumsily drawn. It's neither fish nor fowl: a mishmash of bad figuration coupled with an abstract surface patterning that Pollock half-digested from Picasso's 'Girl Before a Mirror.' " He is referring to the 1932 Picasso in the Modern's collection, with its mirrored image of a woman set against a brilliant patterned backdrop.
Mr. Serra turns from "Pasiphae" to "Autumn Rhythm." "Here the notion of patterning is gone," he says. "Pollock has rid himself of figuration, meaning lines that enclose or contain or describe shapes. He put his canvases on the floor, came at them from all sides, throwing and pouring paint, hitting the canvas with sticks, letting gravity take over the splatters. His renunciation of the brush means you can't apply the standard criteria. We evaluate artists by how much they are able to rid themselves of convention, to change history. I don't know of anyone since Pollock who has altered the form or the language of painting as much as he did. And that was, what, almost half a century ago?"
Mr. Serra goes on: "He had to have remarkable faith that the process would lead to fully realized statements. After all, he didn't know where he would end up when he started. With a painting like 'Pasiphae,' it's obvious that there was an original intention. But with 'Autumn Rhythm,' Pollock allowed the form to emerge out of the materials and out of the process. For me, as a student, this idea of allowing the form to emerge out of the process was incredibly important."
 
In Paris With Philip Glass
 Mr. Serra was born in San Francisco in 1939. He studied English at the University of California at Berkeley and at Santa Barbara, while working in steel mills to earn a living, then went east to study painting at Yale. There, he came into contact with New York School painters like Philip Guston and younger artists like Frank Stella, and helped edit Josef Albers's famous book "The Interaction of Color." He got his degree in 1964 and spent the next year in Paris, where he met the composer Philip Glass. Mr. Serra drew during the day and at night went with Mr. Glass to La Coupole just to watch his hero, the sculptor Alberto Giacometti, eat dinner. Mr. Serra moved to New York in 1966.
"I remember when I first came here," he says, "there was a warehouse emptying out some rubber and I asked if I could cart away as much of it as I could carry. I got Phil Glass and a couple of other people to help, and we moved the rubber to my loft. I cut it and bent it and punched holes through it. I tied it together and made pieces that hung along the wall. And when I was done, I realized the works were clearly related to Pollock's 'Mural' in Iowa." Mr. Serra's rubber works were his "Belts" of 1966-67, now owned by the Guggenheim Museum. The painting by Pollock, belonging to the University of Iowa, was done in 1943 for Peggy Guggenheim. It is an abstraction whose sequence of twisting, interlaced shapes, figures perhaps, indeed remind you of the "Belts," once Mr. Serra mentions it.
He elaborates: "Pollock made something never seen before that we now know of as a Pollock painting, an interlacing, tumbleweed creation that exists in a space unlike any other. Maybe if you enlarged a fragment of a Monet you might have something like it. But not quite."
Tumbleweeds bring to mind Cy Twombly's paintings of the early 1970's that look like blackboards scrawled with Palmer Method ovals, or with tumbleweeds. "But Twombly had a very definite notion of reproducing handwriting," Mr. Serra says. "If Pollock is handwriting, it's handwriting like I've never seen before. The Twomblys I find interesting are the ones in which he tackles a giant canvas with a hard pencil and crayon, in which, like Pollock, he goes for a heroic statement, but with little ideograms. I find the vulnerability of Twombly's heroicism compelling."
An abstraction nearby by Bradley Walker Tomlin, Pollock's near-contemporary, suddenly catches Mr. Serra's eye. Pollock's drips and splatters weave across "Autumn Rhythm," while Tomlin's patterned daubs blanket his canvas. "It's like going from the art museum to the Kmart when you move from the Pollock to the Tomlin," Mr. Serra says. "The pattern in the Tomlin is so flatfooted and sterile. It's decorative. Decorativeness is a tradition in American painting, and it has produced mediocre art and also great art. Joseph Cornell used a certain decoration to pull off his fantasies. Jasper Johns's terrific Flag paintings are, in some ways, decorative. Decoration means pattern, geometry and repetition as the content of a work. Pollock's intention wasn't to decorate, to pattern, to use a repetitive model."
 
Pollock as Organic
 Mr. Serra is gathering a crowd as he speaks. He talks energetically, the sentences tumbling out, and he moves restlessly up to and back from "Autumn Rhythm," like someone trying to choose the right seat in a movie theater. He points out the cadences of the work's looping lines, puzzles over which parts Pollock may have painted first, which parts last, and marvels at the oddness of the palette. It is, in fact, a little like Mr. Serra's own, in that it is often made from industrial materials (in Pollock's case, house paints) that have a raw beauty, unconventional, even unintended. Mr. Serra notices, as well, some curious circular patches that look like the dried, wrinkled remnants of pigment from the bottom of paint cans, stuck to the canvas by Pollock to create effects different from the drips and splatters.
"I don't think it's wrong to talk about the organic quality of Pollock's line, with its swirls and rope-laden spatters," Mr. Serra says. "It points to a likeness to nature without being depictive or illustrative of nature. It seems to me to be soaked, just as nature is soaked. It has a wetness and it's formed the way nature is formed, not analytically like a Cubist picture or a Mondrian, but organically."
The analogy with nature, or landscape, harks back to traditional views of the drip paintings from the 1950's, as does, in general, Mr. Serra's heroic image of Pollock. Mr. Serra has a reputation for embracing radical politics, but he has always separated his political beliefs from his artistic ones. At one point he says: "What Pollock was confronting was the orthodoxy of a kind of regionalism, meaning the work of artists like his teacher Thomas Hart Benton. And in some sense, multiculturalism, while not being exactly regionalism, seems to me to suffer from the same provincial attitude that regionalism did."
At another point he says: "Gender analysis knocks all the notions traditionally associated with Pollock. There may be a lot of reasons to crucify bombastic, overblown art. But Pollock is not bombastic or overblown. And when critics today use words like male and heroic as kneejerk putdowns," Mr. Serra continues, sounding as if he just might be thinking of his own critics as well as Pollock's, "that doesn't seem to me to have anything to do with really seeing and analyzing his work. If I sound elitist, it's O.K. by me. Some things are better than others. Picasso is better than Dubuffet; Pollock is better than Tomlin. We know that."
Mr. Serra is finished with "Autumn Rhythm." He notices a pair of Barnett Newmans, and is immediately distracted again. Pollock's technique of painting on the floor helped pave the way for Mr. Serra's early floor pieces. Newman's big paintings of blocks of color divided by lines, or "zips," did the same for Mr. Serra's later steel sculptures and recent paint-stick drawings, which involve large slabs or blocks that divide and reorganize the spaces they're in. Like the Newmans, they invite a viewer to walk around or across them, to experience them not in a single glance but over time, physically. "My own work is more related to Newman than to Pollock," he acknowledges, "although I have much more admiration for Pollock because I admire what I lack."
"Concord," of 1949, is a greenish picture by Newman with a loosely painted, dusky stripe down the center that Mr. Serra considers too "theatrical." He prefers "Shimmer Bright," of 1968, a hard-edged painting of adjacent blocks of flat color.
"It's about dividing and placing spaces next to one another, not about illusionism. I like Newman's paintings when they're even larger than this. They're great when you have to walk by them and immerse yourself in the divisions of their spaces. Then time becomes a factor: the physical time it takes you to see it and walk across it. That's why you get nothing from photographic reproductions of Newmans. They're reduced to decorations."
 
Matisse the Sculptor
 Mr. Serra is ready to move on to the Museum of Modern Art. It turns out that he hasn't seen the room of Pollocks installed there several years ago. When he arrives, he makes a few detours first. He enthuses over a Bonnard. A Giacometti leaves him, for once, speechless. He declares Matisse's sculpture "La Serpentine," of 1909, "one of the very best works of the 20th century."
"Can you give me another example of figurative sculpture that has followed it in terms of suggesting open vertical volume?" he asks. "It's a kind of work I know I could never do."
Then he becomes startled by the German painter Gerhard Richter's cycle of blurry black-and-white images from the late 1980's, 15 paintings based on the deaths of members of the West German Red Army Faction, the so-called Baader-Meinhof gang, in Stammheim prison in 1977. "I don't think there's an American painter alive who could tackle this subject matter, and get this much feeling into it in this dispassionate way," Mr. Serra says.
He compares one Richter of a dead gang member to Goya, then late Rembrandt: "At the end, Rembrandt painted himself as meat. It was about him confronting his own mortality, and the paintings became smelly and foul and really great. These paintings aren't like late Rembrandts, exactly, but they're disturbing in a way the Rembrandts are. There's a despair in them. And both the Richters and the late Rembrandts are about people recognizing their own solitude through the paintings, which is what we respond to in them."
Mr. Serra arrives at the room of Pollocks. It faces Newman's "Vir Heroicus Sublimis," of 1950-51, and the juxtaposition delights him. "Vir Heroicus Sublimis" is an immense horizontal red field interrupted at irregular intervals by bands of white, orange and ochre. "They're not really bands," Mr. Serra says. "The white line cleaves the field, it cuts the space, it doesn't wrap around it like a band. The ocher, or maybe it's raw canvas, seems to weight the painting toward one side. Without having any descriptive correlative, you see how Newman gives you this physical sense of time and space and location."
 
A Return to Figuration
 He scans the Pollocks next. "Echo (No. 25, 1951)" is an image of black enamel on canvas in which Pollock verges on reintroducing figures after having eliminated figures in his early drip paintings. "Clement Greenberg said Pollock was finished because he returned to the figure," says Mr. Serra, referring to the influential critic. "But I don't buy it. In terms of sheer drawing, this picture is great. Pollock has learned to use the drip and the stick and to make a kind of drawing that is his alone, unlike what he was doing in that early work." Mr. Serra means "Pasiphae." "If he wants to turn his drawing now into a head or a limb, I'm not going to quibble with him."
He becomes riveted by the big central picture in the room, "One (No. 31, 1950)." " 'Autumn Rhythm' is not one of the dense Pollock drip paintings," Mr. Serra says, by way of comparison. "It's less soul-searching, more open, freer and more confident than a work like this. But 'One' is a much better painting, no doubt about it, because it's more about struggle and much denser." Mr. Serra walks up to the canvas. "Something about this painting, looking at it from here, makes me sick." He laughs. "I mean it in a good way."
He then steps back until the work comes into focus. He notices the rhythm of the spun-sugar lines, the way the mass of them begins to separate itself into discrete parts, with the whites becoming openings, or recessions, and the blacks seeming to push forward. Mr. Serra is excited by the playfulness and sense of movement in the work.
It brings to his mind a show of children's art he recently visited: "What I saw there and what you see here is what you seldom see in American painting: an exuberance in the act of making, in the sheer pleasure of playing with materials. No matter how aggressive you think Pollock is, no matter how much you think his work repudiates what came before it, you can't help but sense this joy in his work."

HEADLINE: The 'In' Iraqi Who Counted Himself Out

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
By the time he was 30, Hussein Kamel had risen from a lowly bodyguard with a grade-school education to become the mastermind behind the development of advanced chemical weapons and the long-range missiles Iraq launched in its eight-year war against Iran in the 1980's.
Today, a decade later, Lieutenant General Kamel, with his knowledge of Iraq's clandestine weapons program, could become more valuable to the West than to the Baghdad Government. 
 The general, now thought to be about 40, is one of two sons-in-law of Saddam Hussein who defected to Jordan this week with their wives and families. He oversaw Iraq's buildup of missiles, chemical and biological weapons, and a nuclear research program. American analysts also credit his managerial wizardry for organizing much of the reconstruction of Iraq after the Persian Gulf war, in particular the rebuilding of bridges and of oil and telecommunications installations.
General Kamel was considered a pragmatist in the Iraqi hierarchy and had urged Mr. Hussein to comply with United Nations resolutions in order to have international sanctions against Iraq lifted.
It now appears that General Kamel fled Iraq largely because of a feud with Mr. Hussein's eldest son, Uday, over the issue of the resolutions.
"If this guy is willing to talk to us, and is on the up and up," it will be easy to determine whether he is telling the whole story, said a United Nations official involved in dismantling the Iraqi arsenal that General Kamel assembled.
But that is a very big if. General Kamel stayed alive by following the tenets of Iraqi politics: absolute loyalty to family and ruthlessness. He is likely to treat the Western intelligence analysts he is meeting in Amman very carefully.
"He's a talented thug with a knack for organization who was born in the right place," said a Defense Department official.
That right place was Tikrit, a city 100 miles north of Baghdad that is home to Saddam Hussein's ruling inner circle. Indeed, General Kamel is Mr. Hussein's cousin.
The rise of General Kamel began with the Iran-Iraq war, when President Hussein put him in charge of his personal security. Five years later, he married Mr. Hussein's daughter Raghad. He was soon promoted to lieutenant colonel and put in charge of intelligence operations.
General Kamel's talents are not as a brilliant technician or courageous warrior, but as a gifted manager who gets things done.
During the war with Iran, he strengthened Iraq's special forces and elite Republican Guard.
He used Iraq's intelligence agents abroad to arrange to buy crucial components and materials for the country's nuclear, chemical, biological and missile programs.
"As Hussein Kamel got progressively more prominent, he was given authority to harness Iraq's industrial and scientific community," said Ken Katzman, a Persian Gulf specialist at the Congressional Research Service and a former Central Intelligence Agency analyst.
The success of Iraq's weapons programs, including developing ways to transform Soviet-made Scud missiles into deadly if not always accurate long-range weapons, buoyed the General's ambitions.
"He was nothing more than a security guard," said Phoebe Marr, a Middle East specialist at the National Defense University. "Having said that, however, this guy is practically an organizational genius."
By 1990, as tensions with Kuwait increased, he was whispering in President Hussein's ear that no nation in the gulf could stop Iraq. "He was building up Saddam Hussein's ego, telling Saddam how powerful Iraq had become," Mr. Katzman said.
General Kamel was named Defense Minister in April 1991, two months after Iraq's defeat in the Persian Gulf war. He crushed the postwar rebellions by Kurdish and Shiite minorities, but senior generals grumbled about his lack of military experience. Seven months later, he was dismissed.
While he waited for the political winds to blow his way again, he served as an adviser on rebuilding the country. At the same time he survived a medical scare: a brain tumor. He was operated on in Amman and the tumor proved benign.
This June, General Kamel's fortunes and power seemed fully resurrected when he was named Minister of Industry and head of the Military Industries Commission. At this point he changed course and recommended reconciliation with the Kurds.
But the old feud with Uday Hussein was rekindled. They vied for control over the lucrative ministries that oversaw Iraq's rebuilding and, ultimately, for the ear of Mr. Hussein, especially on the important issue of how to get international economic sanctions lifted.
"Hussein Kamel is a pragmatist," Mr. Katzman said. "He sees Uday as a know-nothing brat."
General Kamel was ousted from his high-level positions before he left the country this week, which is thought, along with the feud, to be a major factor in his defection.

HEADLINE: Tobacco Growers Bemoan Clinton Smoking Proposal

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 11

 BODY:
"The man's off his rocker," Claude B. French said of President Clinton, and that was one of the milder reactions today among the tobacco farmers who serve on the board of a cooperative representing 180,000 growers in five Southern states.
Tobacco farmers have long been accustomed to attacks on smoking from health groups and Government agencies. But Mr. Clinton's proposed regulations to reduce teen-age smoking, announced on Thursday, provoked an unusual level of anger as the board met here at the Flue-Cured Cooperative Stabilization Corporation offices, where visitors are greeted by a sign: "Thank You for Smoking." 
 Characterizing the plans as illegal, hypocritical, unnecessary and economically harmful to tobacco farmers, the directors voted at their regular monthly meeting, 11 to 0, to join the nation's five largest tobacco companies in a lawsuit filed on Thursday that challenges the Food and Drug Administration's authority to regulate the sale, distribution and promotion of cigarettes.
The regulations proposed by Mr. Clinton, based on the F.D.A.'s finding that nicotine is an addictive drug and thus subject to the agency's control, would prohibit cigarette sales to anyone under 18, eliminate the sale of cigarettes through vending machines and place new restrictions on cigarette advertising.
"The farmers are really down in the mouth about this," said Mr. French, who farms 800 acres in Reidsville, N.C. "It's very discouraging to us. This has been our livelihood through generations of hand-me-down farms."
All the directors are farmers, representing growers in Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia and Florida who produce flue-cured tobacco, curing their leaves by regulating heat and humidity in closed barns. Burley, the other major tobacco type produced in the United States, by about 160,000 growers, is cured by air flowing through open barns. Flue-cured tobacco constitutes up to 60 percent of the tobacco used in cigarettes, about twice as much as burley.
In 1993, the latest year for which statistics are available, 50 million Americans, about a fifth of the population, smoked 485 billion cigarettes, generating $50 billion for cigarette manufacturers and $14 billion in Federal, state and local taxes. Leaf sales generated about $3 billion for farmers -- about $3,782 an acre, according to the Agriculture Department, compared with $352 for cotton, $208 for soybeans and $176 for wheat.
Many of the directors here argued that Mr. Clinton's proposals were just another example of government intrusion into people's lives -- and an illegal one at that, inasmuch as the power to regulate commerce is given by the Constitution to Congress. The F.D.A.'s position is that nicotine, a chemical that occurs naturally in tobacco, falls within a wide group of addictive substances that the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act already gives the agency the authority to control.
Stressing their belief that most tobacco growers oppose teen-age smoking, some board members said state laws already barring the sale of cigarettes to minors made Mr. Clinton's plan redundant.
Beyond that, they insisted that the Government should play no role in a teen-ager's deciding whether to smoke. Andrew Q. Shepherd, a farmer from Blackstone, Va., said any teen-ager who wanted to smoke would smoke, regulations notwithstanding.
His 16-year-old son smokes filter-tipped Camels, he said.
"We are all against smoking by teen-agers," said Mr. Shepherd, a smoker who described himself as "an eighth or ninth generation" tobacco farmer with no other source of income. "Churches discourage kids from smoking. Schools discourage them. With all that community involvement, if parents, peers and community institutions cannot convince kids not to smoke, you're not going to solve anything with unnecessary intrusion into private lives."
As for his son, he said, "I would prefer that he not smoke."
Albert M. Johnson of Galivants Ferry, S.C., said that preaching the ills of smoking to teen-agers, let alone regulating them, was no less daunting than other challenges parents typically face.
"To teen-agers, a no-no is a temptation," Mr. Johnson said. "Smoking is something parents have to discuss with their kids, like speeding, wearing seat belts and using drugs. But it should come from parents, not the Government."
James C. Pate of Rowland, N.C., added: "The American public doesn't like to be told what it's got to do. A lot of people tell me they smoke only because people tell them they can't."
Some directors said they viewed Mr. Clinton's proposals as part of a larger campaign to increase Government restrictions on the tobacco industry, and several criticized the Administration for emphasizing to teen-agers the adverse effects of smoking rather than of alcohol and drugs.
"Tobacco has been in this country 200 years, but they've never talked about it until now," said B. Frank Strickland of Lakeland, Ga. "I don't know why. But I do know tobacco does not do what alcohol and dope do to people. Yet they jump on tobacco. Why don't they jump on the dope crowd?"
Board members also said Mr. Clinton's plan would damage him politically, almost certainly costing him any chance to win North Carolina in next year's Presidential election. Among tobacco-growing states, only Kentucky and Tennessee were carried in 1992 by Mr. Clinton, who lost North Carolina to President George Bush by 20,000 votes.
"As poor as his rating is in the South, he couldn't stoop no lower," said Kenneth Dasher of Live Oak, Fla. "Maybe he figured he had nothing to lose and this would take the heat off some of his other problems -- you know, spreading the misery."
Mr. Johnson, the director who represents all of South Carolina, a state Mr. Clinton lost by almost 100,000 votes in 1992, said he was "amazed and devastated" by the President's proposals for the economic loss they would pose to tobacco farmers.
"But I guess it never ceases to amaze me what the Clinton Administration does, trying to regulate," he said. "You hear a lot of talk about a two-party system; if Clinton keeps on going, it's going to be a one-party system. He has totally destroyed the Democratic Party in our area."
Asked if he is a Democrat, Mr. Johnson sighed deeply.
"I wanted to be," he said.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Bond Prices Slump As Economy Picks Up
Treasury securities fell in price as new Government reports indicated that the economy was somewhat stronger than thought. Market participants said the reports did not bode well for another interest rate cut. The new 30-year bond lost more than a full percentage point in price, bringing the yield to 6.970 percent, up from 6.906 percent on Thursday. The market ignored the dollar's new strength, and focused on a big supply of bonds that dragged prices lower. [36.]
Stocks were rocked by the bond market selloff, which undercut favorable economic reports. The Dow industrials fell 25.36 points, to 4,618.30 -- that was 65.16 points for the week -- but the S.& P. 500-stock index fell less sharply, and technology stocks rose. [37.]
 
Corn and wheat prices rose on expectations that foreign buyers would snap up larger American corps. [32.]
 
A Partner for Westinghouse?
Harcourt General held talks with Westinghouse about joining its $5.4 billion bid to buy CBS, several people familiar with the discussions said. Harcourt General, parent of the retailer Neiman-Marcus, did not proceed very far in the talks, but the fact talks were held indicates that Westinghouse would consider a partner. Harcourt weighed an approach to CBS last year, various people said, but is unlikely to join in this time, partly because of the deal's high price. [35.]
 
City May Privatize Jails
New York City asked for proposals to privatize all or part of the city's jails. When it is clear how much interest private companies show, the city will decide how to proceed. The city spends almost $750 million a year to run the jail system. [1.]
 
Tobacco Farmers Fight Back
Tobacco farmers denounced President Clinton's call for regulations to reduce teen-age smoking. A cooperative in North Carolina representing 180,000 growers in five states joined the nation's five largest tobacco companies in suing to block the plan, that would give the F.D.A. the authority to regulate the sale, distribution and promotion of cigarettes. Farmers said that state laws already barred the sale of cigarettes to minors, and that the Government should not influence a teenager's decision on whether to smoke. The regulations proposed by Mr. Clinton were based on the F.D.A.'s finding that nicotine is an addictive drug and thus subject to the agency's control. [1.]
 
Morgan Stanley Jumps Into China
Morgan Stanley began China's first international investment bank with a Chinese company and other partners from Hong Kong and Singapore. The investment is expected to give Morgan Stanley an advantage over its competitors in winning deals involving project financing, direct investment and equity and bond offerings at a time when China needs to finance enormous infrastructure projects. The new firm has a capitalization of $100 million and is headquartered in Beijing. Ten Morgan executives will be based there, giving Morgan the largest presence in Beijing of any American investment bank. [34.]
 
A Capitalist Farm Thrives in Vietnam
A capitalist showcase is blossoming on a farm in Vietnam. A Dutch farmer recruited by a British entrepreneur is cultivating 75 acres of vegetables and flowers in the highland area. Vegetables are being shipped out almost daily, mostly for export to upscale restaurants in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore and Japan. The company is the first wholly foreign-owned agricultural and horticultural investment in Vietnam. One attraction is that costs are lower than elsewhere in Asia. The farm is headed toward its first year of profit. [34.]
 
S.E.C. Internet Service May End
A service offering free Internet access to S.E.C. filings will be discontinued on Oct. 1. Executives said they hoped the Federal Government would take over the service, known as Edgar. [35.]
 
In Recycling, New York City Pays
While suburban areas around New York make money by selling recycled metal, glass and plastic -- Oyster Bay, L.I., gets $25 a ton and Mercer County, N.J. $9.50 a ton -- New York City pays recycling operators $40 to $50 a ton to take away such material. City sanitation officials call it "a fair deal." [23.]

HEADLINE: In Store Fight, Mayor Got Tough

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
After months of pondering whether to support a hotly contested proposal to build a large Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's aides called the project's developers to a meeting last week and issued an ultimatum:
 Accept the Mayor's terms for closing the deal -- or take the blame for the project's failure. The Mayor's people gave the developers just three hours to decide. 
 "I told them we would do it that day, or there would be no deal," said Clay B. Lifflander, president of the city's Economic Development Commission.
 Suddenly, the deal was done. Later that day, Mr. Giuliani announced that the city would serve as an equity partner for the project until a Hispanic community development group could be found to join in the project with the developers: the East Harlem Abyssinian Triangle Corporation, which includes the Abyssinian Development Corporation and the Community Association of East Harlem Triangle.
 By demanding an immediate decision, the developers say, the Mayor created a tense and angry day for them -- but a perfect situation for him. If the developers agreed to the plan, Hispanic leaders who had lobbied against the project would feel satisfied that the Mayor had addressed their concerns. But if the developers rejected the Mayor's terms, he could blame them for killing the project.
 "It was a win-win situation for the city," said Peter L. Borges, president of the Retail Initiative, a fledgling investment partnership that is an investor in the East Harlem project. Mr. Borges said he had nonetheless been "happy that we were finally in a session where something was going to get done."
 Now another Pathmark deal with similar problems has landed squarely in the Mayor's lap, and his handling of the East Harlem Pathmark controversy might give some indication of how he will approach this one.
 As part of the Harlem deal, Mr. Giuliani struck down a plan for Pathmark to establish a $125,000 fund to assist Hispanic-owned businesses in East Harlem. That proposal had been an attempt to assuage opposing sentiments in the community.
 A similar proposal is part of the negotiations for a large Pathmark store in Springfield Gardens, Queens. Under pressure from Councilwoman Juanita E. Watkins, the company has agreed to set up a $400,000 fund for local merchants if it is allowed to build the store.
 Last Wednesday, the City Planning Commission denounced that idea, and the Mayor appeared prepared to veto the zoning changes needed for the Queens store unless the fund idea was eliminated. But to get the deal Mr. Giuliani wants this time, he will have to handle the City Council, not a small group of community leaders. A strong-arm ultimatum is unlikely to be so effective.
 In the East Harlem agreement, the Mayor's demand for an immediate decision led to a day of angry negotiations. The developers complained that Mr. Giuliani would not give them time to talk to advisers. As a result, the project was nearly killed in the hours before the Mayor's announcement.
 "There was the feeling that this was unreasonable," said Paul S. Grogan, president of Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a Ford Foundation offshoot that assists community development groups.
 The plan to build the East Harlem store, 53,000 square feet at 125th Street and Lexington Avenue, became a political hot potato for Mr. Giuliani early this year when Hispanic business owners began lobbying against the supermarket, saying it would hurt smaller grocery stores and bodegas. Although the project typifies the public and private partnerships that Mr. Giuliani has promoted, the threat that the issue might cost him support among Hispanic constituents caused him to procrastinate on taking a stand until the final moments with the developers early last week.
 Defending the city's negotiating strategy, Mr. Lifflander said later that the Mayor had believed it would be necessary to force an immediate decision to avoid more controversy.
 But for Karen A. Phillips, the Abyssinian Development Corporation's project director, it turned into a difficult day, people who were there said. Ms. Phillips found herself faced with negotiating significant changes in the project's financial structure without being able to confer with her counterpart at the East Harlem Triangle organization. She consulted with the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d instead, in more than a dozen phone calls. As pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, Mr. Butts also has authority over the church's community development arm.
 While Mr. Lifflander conferred with City Hall by phone, Ms. Phillips and Mr. Butts appealed for more time. First, they asked that they be allowed to return the next morning with an answer. The Mayor's office refused. Next they asked if they could have until 6 P.M. that day. Again, they were turned down. Finally, city officials gave the developers two additional hours, moving the deadline to 4 P.M.
 At one point during the talks, Ms. Phillips grabbed her belongings and started to leave, people who were at the meeting said. But Mr. Grogan, afraid the Mayor would stick to his threat to kill the deal if a decision was not made that day, persuaded Ms. Phillips to return. "She was practically held hostage," one person who attended the meeting said. Ms. Phillips declined to comment.
 "Nobody deserves to be treated the way we were treated," said Mr. Butts, who leads one of Harlem's largest and best-known congregations. "It was insensitive, cruel, mean-spirited and small. But we stayed focused because our aim was to get it done."
 The two crucial issues of the Mayor's proposal that had to be worked out were how the revenue from the project would be shared with the new development partner and how control would be divided. Under the city's plan, the East Harlem Abyssinian consortium would hold 51 percent of the equity, the new partner would hold 49 percent and the profits would be shared on that basis.
 Although the developers agreed to split the equity, they countered with a plan to insure that control of the project would remain with them. The two sides agreed that when the city finds a Hispanic community development group to take over the city's share of the deal, East Harlem Abyssinian's investors will have the right to approve that selection.
 The city will sell the land to the developers at its appraised value of $1.5 million and will also provide a 1-percent mortgage for the property. The developers will also get a market-rate loan for $8 million from Chemical Bank to build the store.
 Under the terms of a 25-year lease, Pathmark will pay the developers about $1 million a year to rent the store. After the developers make their debt payments and pay other costs, about $50,000 will be left for the community development groups to split.
 Mr. Lifflander, who represented the Mayor in the talks, insisted that the tough stance with the community developers had been necessary. "It proved to be correct because the deal got done," he said.
 But Mr. Butts called the city's approach "highhanded" and said he believed that the Mayor had been disrespectful of the developers.
 "We have been open and gracious with Mayor Giuliani," he said. "And now this is like, 'Slap, take this.' So I will take it because it's still a good deal. It's just sad we had to do it this way."

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rise Only 0.2%; Sales Off a Bit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose in July, but gently, while retail sales were scarcely changed, the Government announced today.
 But the Commerce Department also revised upward its estimates for sales in May and June, and the revised figures suggested that the economy entered late summer in slightly better condition than some traders had previously suspected. 
 As measured by consumer prices, which rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, inflation appeared under control. Retail sales fell one-tenth of 1 percent in July, suggesting weakness, but combined with the upward revisions for May and June, the figures provided an unclear picture of the economy's health.
 Still, there was concern on Wall Street that renewed economic growth might eventually lead to slightly higher inflation. Both bond and stock prices fell, and long-term interest rates jumped, although many Wall Street analysts attributed that more to large supplies of bonds sold by the Treasury this week than to the economic reports.
 Economists said that the bond market's response was excessive and that inflation was likely to continue to subside in the coming months. "That's what I call the exquisite sensitivity of the bond market to anything that suggests the economy might grow faster than trend," said Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers. "I think it's an overreaction."
 Mr. Sinai and other analysts continued to predict that the central bank's top officials were not likely to reduce interest rates at their next policy meeting on Aug. 22, saying the Fed would choose instead to wait until the following meeting on Sept. 26.
 "We think the Fed is on hold -- they have to be very happy," said Mark P. Vitner, a vice president and economist at the First Union Corporation, a bank holding company in Charlotte, N.C. "We've got moderate growth and low inflation."
 The Labor Department, in announcing the two-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index with seasonal adjustments this morning, said that excluding seasonal adjustments, the index was unchanged. The seasonally adjusted gain compared with one-tenth of 1 percent in June and three-tenths of 1 percent in May.
 Rising food prices offset falling energy prices in July, particularly for gasoline, so consumer prices excluding food and energy -- the so-called core rate of inflation -- was also up two-tenths of 1 percent, the department said.
 Retail sales edged down by one-tenth of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department announced this morning.
 The July sales figure "is telling us the economy is in a sluggish period that has been going on for a few months now," said Robert D. Barr, the deputy chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce. "It does not suggest we're headed for a recession or anything like that, so there's reason to believe the worst is behind us."
 The July figure for retail sales is an advance estimate, and is potentially subject to such large revisions that economists at the Federal Reserve and elsewhere regard it with caution.
 The Commerce Department revised upward its estimate of the June increase in retail sales to eight-tenths of 1 percent from seven-tenths of 1 percent, and pushed up the May figure to 1.1 percent from nine-tenths of 1 percent. Excluding automobile sales, the increases were slightly larger.
 But Darwin L. Beck, an economist and Fed watcher at the First Boston Corporation, was skeptical that the revisions signified a stronger economy. "I didn't see anything in the numbers that would suggest anything other than what we've been seeing, which is an economy moving forward but not at a rapid pace," he said.
 Businesses across the country have been noting the willingness of consumers to shop elsewhere when confronted with higher prices. At the two toy stores of the Alphabet Soup Corporation in Des Moines, for example, sales have leveled off this summer after strong growth early in the year, and Chris T. Wass, the owner and president, said that he was reluctant to raise prices.
"My sense is the consumer is price-sensitive right now, and we're not likely to be aggressive in marking things right now," Mr. Wass said. At the same time, he added, "I don't see anything real dangerous ahead in our business in the near term."
 Consumer prices in the transportation sector fell four-tenths of 1 percent in July, pulled down by a 2.1 percent drop in gasoline prices. The pace of medical care inflation gained last month, as prices rose by four-tenths of 1 percent, compared with three-tenths of 1 percent in every previous month this year.
 Food prices were held down by a drop of three-tenths of 1 percent in fresh fruit and vegetable prices. By contrast, prices for dairy products climbed six-tenths of 1 percent.
