HEADLINE: Poll Shows Disenchantment With Politicians and Politics

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Profoundly disenchanted by politics and politicians, Americans are simultaneously attracted to and leery of the idea of a third party, according to a new New York Times/CBS News Poll.
The poll, which was completed on the eve of this weekend's gathering in Dallas of supporters of Ross Perot's independent political movement, United We Stand America, suggested that Gen. Colin L. Powell would run more strongly than other potential third-party nominees against President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole, the Republican front-runner. In a trial race, the three finished in a virtual dead heat. 
 Although 55 percent said the country needed a new party, 61 percent said a President who was neither a Republican nor a Democrat would have trouble dealing with Congress. And when asked what a third party should stand for, people offered few policy specifics. The most frequent answer was that it should represent the people.
When it comes to the nation's most important problems, the Times/CBS News survey indicated, Americans are just as dissatisfied with the work the Republicans are doing this year on Capitol Hill, where they won control in last fall's elections, as they are with the performance of Mr. Clinton. In each case, only 26 percent said the officeholders involved were doing a good job.
Even in more general terms, neither Mr. Clinton nor his Republican tormentors have been able to win the approval of a majority. What the Congressional Republicans have done since taking power has been good for the country in the view of 48 percent and bad in the view of 33 percent. Similarly, 45 percent approve of the way the President is handling his job over all, while 43 percent disapprove.
The frustrations run deep, perhaps deeper than at any other time in modern American history. These were among the major findings in the poll, which was based on telephone interviews with 1,478 adults nationwide from Aug. 5 to 9:
*Fifty-nine percent said there was not a single elected official today whom they admired. Of the 36 percent who could think of one, Mr. Clinton was named by 6 percent, Mr. Dole by 5 percent and Speaker Newt Gingrich by 4 percent.
*Seventy-nine percent, the highest figure in several decades, said the Government was pretty much run by a few big interests looking out for themselves.
*Seventy-nine percent said they trusted the Federal Government to do the right thing only some of the time.
*And 58 percent said that people like themselves had little to say about what the Government did.
The new poll, which has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, showed the Republicans holding several tactical advantages with the formal opening of the 1996 Presidential campaign, in the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary, only six months away.
Perhaps most significantly, voters see the Republicans as more likely to reduce the Federal deficit, insure the country's prosperity, limit crime and reform the welfare system.
Welfare has been a traditional concern of Democrats, and they have traditionally been more trusted as its stewards, but in a poll a year ago the two parties tied on the issue and now the Republicans have pulled ahead, 50 percent to 33 percent. Welfare reform is currently one of the most hotly debated subjects in the Senate, and it may well emerge as a major campaign issue next year.
Although the Democrats retained an advantage on only one issue, it is a vital one: Medicare. Many more people (46 percent to 32 percent) saw the Democrats as likely to make the right decisions in the heated debate on how to control rapidly rising costs in health care for the elderly.
The two parties finished roughly even on concern for the needs and problems of ordinary people -- a strong showing for the Republicans on long-established Democratic turf.
The political punch packed by Medicare and Social Security (and a potential peril for Republican budget-cutters) is suggested by another set of results. By 60 percent to 36 percent, voters would balance the budget even if that meant their taxes would not be cut. But faced with a choice, they would prefer by 4 to 1 to continue with imbalanced budgets rather than change Medicare. In the case of Social Security, the ratio is almost 3 to 1.
Still, the Republicans at this stage have a more favorable image as a party, with 54 percent of respondents approving and 37 percent disapproving, compared with a roughly even split for the Democrats, 47 percent positive and 45 percent negative.
A trial heat between a generic "Republican candidate" and Mr. Clinton gave the Republican 28 percent and the President 22 percent, with 45 percent undecided. Especially at this very early stage, such questions can be only broadly indicative, but the results certainly suggest Democratic problems.
With Mr. Dole as the Republican candidate, the poll showed 48 percent for the Senator and 42 percent for the President.
But the practical effect of adding General Powell, Mr. Perot or Patrick J. Buchanan as a third-party candidate was to siphon off more Republican than Democratic voters from the major-party candidates, allowing Mr. Clinton to pull even with Mr. Dole in a series of trial heats. Only if Jesse Jackson was substituted did the pattern shift. He pulled many Democratic votes away from Mr. Clinton, allowing Mr. Dole to win the hypothetical race easily.
The Clinton camp, which has similar poll figures, hopes the President's stand on affirmative action and other recent moves have placated Mr. Jackson enough to keep him on the sidelines, but that is not yet clear.
Mr. Dole continues to spread-eagle the Republican field, pulling 48 percent compared with 10 percent for his nearest rival, Mr. Buchanan. But Mr. Buchanan has scored significant gains since February, when he had the backing of only 3 percent, largely at the expense of his conservative rival, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who has dropped to 7 percent from 15 percent. Gov. Pete Wilson of California, a late entrant, has moved up to 6 percent from 3 percent.
General Powell, who begins a highly publicized book tour next month, has promised to make a decision in the fall about whether to seek the Presidency and whether, if he decides to run, to do so as a Republican or an independent. Of the four widely discussed potential third-party nominees, only he approaches a third of the vote, with 27 percent; Mr. Perot pulls 23 percent, Mr. Jackson 11 percent and Mr. Buchanan 8 percent in three-way trial heats against Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole.
In a two-way race, running as a Republican, General Powell bettered Mr. Clinton by 10 points, 47 percent to 37 percent. But many experts consider it unlikely that the general, a moderate on many social issues, could win the Republican nomination.
Although (or perhaps because) most people are still unclear about his views, the general, who retired in October 1993, draws raves from a large segment of the American public, with 41 percent holding a favorable opinion and only 5 percent an unfavorable one.
As for Mr. Perot, he remains a polarizing figure. Although 28 percent of those polled expressed a favorable opinion of him, 36 percent expressed an unfavorable view. By a margin of about 2 to 1, those familiar with his organization, United We Stand America, opposed its establishment as a third party. But Mr. Perot himself won high marks as a gadfly, with 71 percent agreeing that he had good ideas about government and 52 percent saying he had helped focus the political debate.
Others with strong negatives were Mr. Jackson (29 percent favorable, 35 unfavorable), Mr. Buchanan (11 percent favorable, 28 percent unfavorable, and unpopular among members of both parties) and Mr. Gingrich (19 percent favorable, 35 unfavorable, but liked among Republicans, 37 percent to 21 percent).
President Clinton has retained a relatively strong base among Democrats (they favor his renomination, 63 percent to 30 percent), but he has failed to reap an important benefit of incumbency that he might have expected: political credit for a healthy economy. Only 41 percent of the public think he is handling the economy well, only 14 percent credit him with having reduced the budget deficit and only 14 percent say the economy is improving, as against 27 percent who say it is getting worse.
 
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Aug. 5 to 9 with 1,478 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of active residential exchanges in the country. The list of more than 36,000 residential exchanges is maintained by Marketing Systems Group of Philadelphia.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, race, sex, age and education.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

GIULIANI STUDIES PRIVATIZING JAILS
The Giuliani administration has begun soliciting proposals to privatize part or all of New York City's jails. Under the initiative, a nonbinding "request for expressions of interest" was mailed to more than 200 companies that have sprung up across the nation as private operators of jails. [Page 1.]
 
As America's prison population doubled in the last decade, the private, for-profit prison business exploded along with it. But questions and criticism continue to plague the $250-million-a-year industry. [24.]
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
PATHMARK, NEXT CHAPTER
Soon after his administration reached agreement with developers to build a large Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem, another Pathmark deal with similar problems has landed squarely in Mayor Giuliani's lap, and his handling of the earlier controversy may give some indication of how he intends to approach this one. [25.]
 
POLICE SET UP ANTI-GRIDLOCK DIVISION
The Police Department has formed a new traffic division to develop and carry out a plan to better manage gridlock in midtown Manhattan and rush-hour tie-ups on highways around New York City. The police said the division will step up enforcement of double-parking rules and increase ticketing of cabdrivers who clog traffic while picking up fares and drivers who block intersections. [25.]
 
A CAR-PARTS AD STIRS IRE IN THE BRONX
A magazine advertisement that trades on the Bronx's reputation as a center of the car-stripping industry has raised the patriotic ire of Borough President Fernando Ferrer and other officials. [25.]
 
REGION
 
A LIFETIME BUILDING BOATS
Since Earl Brockway was 14 and his father told him it was time to learn the family trade, he has spent most of his days in his backyard in Old Saybrook, Conn., building wooden skiffs. In fact, Mr. Brockway, 74, says he's never done much of anything else. Over the last 60 years, he estimates, he has built more than 5,000 boats. [26.]
 
MEDICAL REFERRAL BILLS DRAW VETOES
Governor Pataki has vetoed two bills that would have prevented doctors from making referrals to radiation or physical therapy clinics in which they, or their families, have a financial interest. [26.]
 
NOW, GREENPORT WILL ABOLISH ITS COURT
Nine months after voting to disband their nine-member police force, residents of Greenport, L.I., have taken another step to reduce the size and cost of government: they decided on Tuesday to abolish their town's court and unseat a part-time village justice whose term does not expire for two years. [26.]
 
INMATE IS MISTAKENLY FREED AFTER MIX-UP
Lamont White is back in the Albany County jail after an unexpected day of freedom, and perhaps he is wondering what to call himself next. Mr. White was captured without incident on an Albany street a day after he was let out of jail by mistake because, among the 825 or so inmates, there was another with the first name Lamont. [26.]

HEADLINE: After Months of Punishment, the Dollar Is Behaving Better

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
After enduring months of abuse, the dollar has begun to strengthen in value on foreign exchange markets in the last few weeks, and many traders and analysts say it may continue to rise.
 At the same time, these experts concede that the dollar had become so cheap in comparison with currencies like the Japanese yen and the German mark that some sort of bounce was almost inevitable. Indeed, yesterday it surged to a five-month high against the yen and a two-and-a-half-month high against the mark. 
 "The dollar feels like it is in an uptrend," said Richard E. Witten, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "There is a feeling in the market that it is time for the dollar to cycle back up."
 But even if the dollar does improve further, these experts added, it remains a fundamentally weak currency. The problems that led to its steady decline over the last decade remain unsolved.
 "Given the size of our merchandise-trade and current-account deficits and the Federal budget deficit, the dollar still has some problems," said Neal M. Soss, a principal at Soss & Cotton Enterprises, an economic consulting firm in New York. "We are a nation that perpetually spends more than it saves, and that is a macroeconomic problem."
 At the moment, currency traders and speculators seem to have concluded that the dollar has been punished enough for those sins for the time being, and that further appreciation is possible.
 If they are correct, it would become marginally less expensive to take a European vacation. Also at the margin, it will make imports a bit cheaper, although analysts said the price effects of a change in currency values could take a year or two to show up. And it would be likely to put a crimp in the profits of companies that do large amounts of business abroad. Here too, though, experts say it is difficult, if not impossible, to say how much they really would be hurt.
 Over the last few days, currency traders have shrugged off the decision by Germany's powerful central bank, the Bundesbank, not to cut official interest rates, as well as two tame reports on inflation in the United States. Those reports will not encourage the Fed to raise interest rates, and may give policy makers the latitude to lower them.
 "American companies do lose some competitiveness," when the dollar appreciates, said Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs.
 But "much of what we export is not that sensitive to currency changes," she added. "We are talking about a nick, rather than a dramatic impact on earnings."
 Participants in the foreign exchange market have been feeling better about the dollar since late June, when the United States and Japan reached an 11th-hour compromise on automobile trade.
 However imperfect, that deal removed the fear that a potentially crippling trade war might break out between the countries.
 But it has been only in the last week, in the wake of Japanese announcements and actions that appear intended to knock down the value of the yen, that the dollar's move has gathered momentum.
 The dollar continued to rise yesterday, surging two pfennigs against the German mark, settling at 1.4396 marks in New York trading, its highest level in two and a half months. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar jumped 1.27 yen, to 93.90 yen, the highest level in five months. That is well above the dollar's low of 79.75 yen on April 19.
 Even with the recent rise, "on a year-over-year basis, we are still very much lower," said Ron Leven, a currency strategist at J. P. Morgan & Company. This time last year, the dollar was worth 103 yen and 1.60 marks, Mr. Leven noted.
 In large measure, the recent move has been in response to last week's decision by Japan's Ministry of Finance to entice Japanese financial institutions to invest abroad, a measure that it hopes will not only weaken the yen but also help to ease the serious crisis that has enveloped its financial system.
 In addition, on several occasions recently the Bank of Japan has intervened in foreign exchange markets to buy dollars and sell yen, actions that have been supported by the Federal Reserve Board.
 "The end of the auto problem was the beginning" of the dollar's climb, said Richard E. Witten, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "But the Japanese Government really started the ball rolling with the changes in investment rules."
 Japan's need to address its dollar problems has been the predominant theme in currency markets in recent weeks, but that has not been the only factor that has contributed to the dollar's improvement.
 Over the last few weeks, economic data have shown that activity in the third quarter appears to be picking up; as recently as late June, it was widely assumed that the United States was moving into a period of much slower growth, and perhaps a recession.
 Also, conditions in Mexico are improving, perhaps more rapidly than anyone had dared hope. The dollar was pounded last winter in the wake of the Clinton Administration's multibillion-dollar rescue package.
 "Mexico no longer looks so bad," said David Buchen, a managing director in charge of North American foreign exchange trading for Citibank. "Maybe we are not throwing good money after bad. Maybe it will work."
 So far, currency traders said Tokyo's new investment initiative had yet to generate big Japanese purchases of dollars, let alone of American stocks or bonds. For the moment, the prospect of such buying getting under way has been enough to satisfy participants in the foreign exchange market.
 Indeed, the sentiment has turned to such an extent that this week the dollar was able to withstand a series of events that in the recent past would probably have sent it reeling.
 "Something fundamental is going on," Mr. Buchen said. "I think that after sitting in a state of denial, or stoicism, for almost a year, the Japanese recognize that the dollar is a problem."
 Mr. Buchen and others said they were not surprised that Japanese investors were not significant purchasers of American Treasury securities at this week's quarterly refunding auctions. But in the next breath they said they expected to see purchases of dollar-denominated assets by Japanese and other foreign investors pick up over the next six months or so.

HEADLINE: Bond Selloff Hurts Stocks, With the Dow Off 25.36

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market was rocked by a selloff in the bond market yesterday and fell despite two generally favorable economic reports.
 The Government reported that the Consumer Price Index rose only two-tenths of 1 percent last month, while retail sales slipped one-tenth of 1 percent. Both reports were viewed, at least initially, as indications of subdued inflation. 
 But bond prices still declined, weighed down by the large supply of new Treasury securities and lingering concerns about future inflationary pressures. The new 30-year Treasury bond dropped 13/32 and its yield jumped to 6.97 percent -- its highest point in three months -- from an average of 6.906 percent at Thursday's auction.
 Stocks followed bonds downward as money managers lightened their portfolios, although there were still pockets of strength on a sluggish summer trading day.
 "The market has gone up quite substantially and there has been no trigger to take it down until recently," said Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist of Kemper Securities in Chicago. "The trigger yesterday was the sloppiness in the bond market."
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which was weaker than the other major averages, fell 25.36 points to close at 4,618.30. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.34 points, to 555.11. But a rally in technology stocks helped the Nasdaq composite index gain 3.50 points, to 1,004.11.
 Declining stocks outnumbered advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,359 to 840. But trading was thin, with Big Board volume sliding to 265.9 million shares, from 306.7 million shares on Thursday and far below the three-month average of 347 million shares.
 Oil stocks fell, as analysts voiced concern over weak crude oil and natural-gas prices. Exxon dropped 5/8, to 69 3/8, and Chevron was down 5/16 , to 48 7/8.
 Drug issues were also lower, apparently because of worries that a stronger dollar would narrow foreign profits for multinational pharmaceutical companies. Eli Lilly closed at 75 7/8, down 1/8; Merck was at 50 1/8, down 3/8; Johnson & Johnson was at 68 5/8, down 1 1/4, and Pfizer closed at 49, down 1 1/8.
 New Federal proposals to declare nicotine an addictive drug pushed down the prices of tobacco stocks. Philip Morris fell 1 1/2, to 72, while RJR Nabisco was down 3/4, to 27 1/8, and the American depository receipts of B.A.T. Industries were off 3/8, to 16.
 Semiconductor issues, however, traded higher, after a report that the ratio of new orders to shipments was substantially above Wall Street estimates. Intel advanced 1 7/8, to 66 1/8; Micron Technology was up 7/8, to 62 7/8, and Texas Instruments rose 2, to 149 1/2. Advanced Micro Devices climbed 1/2, to 33 1/2, and Motorola rose 1 3/8, to 76 3/4.
 Some computer software makers also rose, with Microsoft jumping 2 3/8, to 96 1/2, and Borland picking up 3/8, to 11 5/8.
 Elco Industries surged 11 1/2, to 30 3/4, a day after Illinois Tool Works made a hostile bid at 27.
 But America Online declined 2 7/8, to 62 3/8, after the company warned analysts against overestimating its profits. And Midisoft slumped 1 7/8, to 5 1/4, a day after reporting a second-quarter loss.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bond Prices Fall On New Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Against a backdrop of supply concern, prices of Treasury securities turned sour yesterday after reports on consumer prices and retail sales failed to provide enough evidence of a slowing in economic growth and inflation.
 Market participants feared the reports did not bode well for another interest rate cut; rather, the Fed could put any cut on hold as long as there is a chance that the economy could pick up steam and raise inflation pressures. 
 The new 30-year bond dropped 1 3/32 of a percentage point, to a price of 98 25/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.970 percent, from the average yield at auction on Thursday of 6.906 percent. That means that for every $1,000 of bonds held, holders lost about $11. Shorter-maturity bill rates and yields on intermediate issues also felt the pressure of supply. Some market watchers speculated that Wall Street wound up holding a lot of the new 3-year and 10-year notes auctioned this week. It was likely then that dealers were discounting them to move them out.
 Elsewhere, the July Consumer Price Index and its core figure each rose two-tenths of 1 percent, as expected.
 Retail sales unexpectedly fell one-tenth of 1 percent, but not counting auto sales rose a less-than-expected four-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported. Traders said market forecasts had called for a two-tenths of 1 percent gain in the overall data and a five-tenths of 1 percent nonauto rise. But Ken McCarthy, founder of Economic Intelligence, a market research firm, said consumer spending was not so weak as the retail sales decline suggested, and the pace of spending during the second half of the year would remain solid.
 With the data somewhat disappointing, the market was vulnerable to downside pressures because of the recent large supply of new securities brought on by the Treasury's quarterly refunding this week and the prospects of further supply. Next week, the Treasury will sell $18.25 billion of new 52-week bills and at the same time announce the size of its two-year and five-year note auctions for the following week. The Federal Open Market Committee also meets the following week.
 Eugene J. Sherman, director of research at M. A. Schapiro & Company, said the economy had settled into a moderate growth track while exhibiting, at most, mild inflation. "Against that backdrop," he added, "the broadening view is that the Federal Reserve will maintain a stable monetary policy for the next couple of months at least."
 While the market ignored the dollar's gathering strength, analysts suggested that if the tone of the market changed to positive, the dollar could become a driving factor. But supply was in the driver's seat yesterday and prices dropped.
 Anthony Chan, chief economist for Banc One Investment Advisors, said a news service report yesterday "speculating that the Fed may further delay its easing moves and possibly consider tightening at a later date certainly threw cold water on the market and raised the market's fear of the retail sales report."
 Mr. Chan added: "The behavior of the credit markets this week does suggest that markets remain queasy about supply. Even a favorable 10-year note and 30-year bond auction were not good enough to produce favorable follow-through reaction in the credit markets."
 This suggests that any sort of supply is not likely to be received with open arms by the market, he said, referring to next week's two-year and five-year auctions.
 Looking to next week, Mr. Chan said that the markets had already discounted a large drop in industrial production and capacity utilization as aresult of the 85,000 drop in manufacturing employment. Consequently, he said, the focus of the market was more likely to be on Thursday's August report of the Philadelphia Fed of regional business activity and the Friday Michigan sentiment report, both of which are more forward looking.
 Mr. McCarthy of Economic Intelligence expects growth in the second half of this year to be around 3 percent, propelled by stronger consumer spending. "But growth will not explode, and inflation will remain low," he said. "This is an environment in which the Fed can lower rates, and they will, but not until late in the year."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Germans Are Urged to Let Shops Stay Open at Night

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Aug. 11

 BODY:
For decades, one rule above all others has been inviolate in German retailing: never on Sunday. Thanks to the strictest closing hours in Europe, shops in Germany turn off the lights every weekday except Thursday by 6:30 P.M., are open only one Saturday afternoon a month and, of course, stay tightly shuttered on Sunday.
 But now, in the most serious assault on this famous German tradition and the powerful retailing union that has fiercely defended it, politicians and industrialists appear to have found the ammunition to finally bring about a major change. 
 Today, in a long-awaited report whose recommendations the governing parties have promised to follow, one of the country's most prestigious economic research groups proposed that stores be permitted to stay open until 10 P.M. on weekdays and 6 P.M. on Saturdays. But even the experts, who see the change as part of the broader effort to restore flexibility to the arthritic German economy, were not prepared to go so far as to overturn the prohibition against Sunday selling.
 The study, carried out by the Ifo Institute for Economic Research of Munich, was commissioned by Germany's Economic Minister, Gunter Rexrodt. Leaders in Parliament have said they would carry out its recommendations. A spokesman for Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union predicted passage of legislation before the end of the year.
 Behind the debate over the law governing closing hours is a far-reaching struggle that touches on deeply held cultural beliefs. The battle pits industry against labor and generation against generation over whether Germany's economic vitality has been sapped by decades of encrusted regulations that govern much of daily life. With unemployment still high despite the rebound of the economy this year, business leaders have become increasingly adamant in their insistence that tough labor laws often make Germany an unattractive place for companies to set up operations.
 "This is not really a plan to boost retail sales, but it's an issue of whether Germany is an attractive place to invest," said Bernd Janssen, retail analyst in Frankfurt for UBS Global Research. "You have to put this in the context of an overall discussion of how to make Germany more flexible and competitive internationally."
 Just this week, Volkswagen, the giant German auto maker, began a new round of negotiations with its unions trying to get them to agree to more flexible working hours. Such rigidities, coupled with the highest wages and benefits paid in Europe, have prompted many economists to warn that German industry, over the long run, will migrate elsewhere.
 Indeed, both Mercedes-Benz and BMW are setting up new American auto plants, in part, to escape the high costs of manufacturing in Germany.
 German unemployment, at 8.3 percent, is high by post-World War II standards and is not expected to come down soon.
 The IFO report argued that loosening the store closing hours would generate more than 50,000 new jobs and add about $14 billion a year to retail sales in Germany, a 2 percent increase.
 But even supporters of the change said the direct impact was much less important than the deeper symbolism represented by the assault on the tight restrictions. "You're really talking about people who work until 8 in the evening who don't have time to shop, and that number is not really that significant," Mr. Janssen said.
 Polls here show that Germans are divided on whether they want to be able to shop later in the evening and on Saturday afternoons. The idea of cities that slow to a hush at night and after 2 P.M. on Saturday, leaving the rest of the time for relaxation and leisure, is hard to shake.
 As the country has enjoyed among the highest standards of living in Europe, Germans have also insisted more and more on extending their leisure time.
Germany is now almost alone among European countries that have not tailored their retail hours along American lines. In France and England there are no limits on store hours Monday through Saturday, and in Italy stores can stay open until 8 P.M. during the week, and 9 P.M. in the summer.
 But in Germany, enforcement of the closing hours is well known. Retailers who close late are often sued by their neighboring stores, and customers can find store clerks often refuse to ring up purchases after the closing time.
 The polls have found that mostly young people support the longer hours while older shoppers are satisfied with keeping the tradition.
 The closing hours have been a boon to gas station convenience stores and shops in airports and train stations, where customers often line up to buy milk, bread and cold cuts.
 Even within the retail trade the issue is still debated. The German Retail Association says it does little extra business Thursday evenings, when shops are open an extra two hours. And the retail union has argued that any new jobs that will be created will be mainly part time.
 Moreover, while the politicians in Bonn may want to rush through a change, buying bread after 6:30 may still not be possible until 1997. Current wage contracts do not expire until Jan. 1, 1997, and they also happen to govern the issue of working hours.
 Labor officials contend that to change closing hours, the industry will have to open up the contracts, giving the unions the chance to negotiate further wage increases. And they predict retailers will not want that to happen.

HEADLINE: While Others Sell Recyclables, New York Pays to Get Rid of Them

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Oyster Bay, L.I., sells its recycled metal, glass and plastic for $25 a ton. Mercer County, N.J., sells its for $9.50 a ton, and Middlesex County, N.J., sells its for a minimum of $20.
 New York City, on the other hand, pays recycling operators $40 to $50 a ton to accept the same material. Last year it spent $8 million to get rid of material that some recycling plant operators are willing to pay for. 
 The City Sanitation Department says the disparity exists because too much worthless material is mixed in with the glass, metal and plastic that city residents put in recycling bins, spoiling the value to potential vendors. The department also says that operating costs are higher for recycling vendors in New York than in the surrounding communities.
 "I think they are getting a fair payment," said Robert Lange, director of the Sanitation Department's recycling operations, "I think the city is getting a fair deal."
 But the city's former recycling consultant, and executives at recycling processors, say that New York is throwing money away by paying companies to take the material when it should be making money, or at least breaking even. The potential savings -- $8 million to $11 million -- is only a tiny fraction of the city's $31.1 billion budget, but the city's fiscal problems have produced battles over lesser sums.
 "New York should be being paid for that material," said Lawrence Schorr, president of Resource Recycling Technology, a subsidiary of Waste Management Inc., one of the largest private trash companies in the country. "It is a false assumption that these materials are not valuable."
 Mr. Schorr, whose company runs about 150 recycling plants nationwide, acknowledged that it is more expensive to process material from a city than from a smaller town because of the greater amount of trash usually mixed with the recyclable material. But he said that a well-run recycling facility should be able to make enough money on the material to offer some return to the city.
 He pointed to his company's plant in Syracuse as an example. "The current value of the container stream in Syracuse, which would be substantially similar to New York City, would be $85 per ton," Mr. Schorr said. "That is the sale price of all the materials. The cost of recovering that material, depending on the volume and the kind of system that one would use, can be as low as $30 per ton."
 Even allowing for differences in the New York and Syracuse material, and for the costs of equipment and rent, New York should be able to dispose of the recyclable material for free, Mr. Schorr said.
Across the country, several other big cities earn money from metal, glass and plastic. Los Angeles gets $35 a ton. Dallas and Philadelphia also sell their bottles and cans to recycling vendors, while Boston disposes of its for free. Chicago, on the other hand, pays a vendor $19 per ton to process its recycled waste, but the price is still much lower than what New York pays.
 The disparity between what New York City pays and what other cities and towns get is in part a reflection of the skyrocketing value of what only a few years ago was considered garbage. When the city began its recycling program in 1988, there was barely a market at all for discarded paper, plastic and glass. Now, old newspapers sell for $117 a ton, glass sells for $23 a ton and some kinds of plastic sell for $300 a ton.
 But in a classic case of bad timing, New York awarded five-year contracts to four companies in 1993, just before the market for recycled goods exploded. At the time, city officials decided that if they offered to pay companies a fixed price to accept metal, glass and plastic, recyclers would be encouraged to set up operations in New York.
 In contrast, when the city signed contracts for recycled paper in the early 1990's, it agreed to a price that was pegged to the paper market. As a result of a consistent increase in price, the city now makes $17 million a year from its paper contracts.
 Two months ago, the city recognized the increase in the metal, glass and plastic markets and renegotiated its contracts. But in the negotiation, Sanitation Department officials agreed to continue payments to vendors. The vendors agreed to allow the city to reduce the payments if the market improved.
 For every $1 increase in the market price, the city would be allowed to reduce the payments to the vendors by 35 cents. The contractors and the city agreed to use the prices from September 1993, which was when the contracts were originally signed, as a base to measure increases.
 Mr. Lange said "in an ideal world" the city would have reduced its payments by $1 for each dollar the market increased since 1993. But he said the 35-cent figure was reached through negotiations with the contractors.
 At that rate, the city will probably find itself paying recycling vendors to accept material that both the city and the vendor agree is worth money on the open market. If the city was paying a vendor $45 per ton before the renegotiation -- the lowest bid price among the four contractors that handle the material -- the market price would have to increase by $129 per ton before the city could break even.
 Critics are asking whether the contractors are reaping a windfall at taxpayers' expense. "Obviously in the current market they are making a lot per ton, more money than if they were getting the material elsewhere," said Allan Dickar, an economist with the city's former recycling consultant, the Queens College Center for the Biology of Natural Systems.
 Kendall Christiansen, the head of New York's Citywide Recycling Advisory Board, said the only way for the city to find out if it could sell its recyclable waste on the open market would be to cancel the existing contracts and seek new bids.
 But Mr. Christiansen, who also is a spokesman for Resource Inc., one of four companies with recycling contracts with the city, said that canceling the contracts would be unfair to vendors who signed five-year contracts with the city. Mr. Christiansen also said he doubted whether the city would receive a better deal.
 "They struck a business deal with firms to establish the plants and get into the business," Mr. Christiansen said. "To turn around and rebid the contract, and say we want to rebid it because we think we can get a better deal; if the city did that, they might get fewer bidders."
 Mr. Christiansen's company receives $44.98 for each ton of bottles and cans it takes from the city.
 Mr. Christiansen said the city used the fixed price contract when it originally sought bids from recycling companies in 1993 because it was easy to administer and because it encouraged companies to come forward. He said that for the long term, the city would be better off with a contract that shared revenues between the recycling vendors and the city.
 "It was sufficient for the early years to get companies into the game, but as a long-term strategy it is not up to the task," Mr. Christiansen said. "If the city put a contract on the street that was a revenue sharing contract, or an indexed contract, we would not have a problem dealing with that."
 Mr. Lange said the city will probably seek new bids before the contract expires in 1999. But he said city officials did not want to do it too soon for fear that it could damage the area's market for recycled material.
 "You don't want to send that kind of chaos out into the recycling community unless it is absolutely necessary," he said.
 Mr. Lange said he thought that the current contract was fair to the city because so much worthless material is mixed in with the cans and bottles.
 But managers at recycling companies that do not contract for the city's metal, glass and plastic said New York is undervaluing the material. They said that other municipalities in New York state, like towns on Long Island and upstate cities, are successfully marketing their recyclables.
 Mr. Schorr said a plant should be able to accept New York's material at no cost.
 "Absolutely, no question about it, it could be received at the door of the recycler for little or no charge," he said.
 The Queens College Center for the Biology of Natural Systems has done an analysis of New York's bottle and can recycling program and has concluded that unless the city changes its metal, glass and plastic contract, it will continue to spend millions unnecessarily.
 "Given the situation in the market, there is no question that the city should be gaining considerable income from its recycling program," said Barry Commoner, director of the Queens College Center for the Biology of Natural Systems. "The fact that it hasn't is a result of the kinds of contracts that have been signed."
 Mr. Dickar, the center's economist who performed the analysis, said that if the city were to receive an average of $21 a ton for its metal, glass and plastic, it would earn $3.6 million a year. Mr. Dickar said that the total loss to the city, that income plus the amount expected to be paid to vendors, is $11 million a year.

HEADLINE: The Serbs Show Their Knack for Defeat

BYLINE: By Jack Miles; Jack Miles is director of the Humanities Center of the Claremont Graduate School.

DATELINE: CLAREMONT, Calif.

 BODY:
Defeat, some say, is the Serb form of happy ending. Rebecca West, who loved the Serbs as only a fellow romantic could, devoted the most profound pages of "Black Lamb and Grey Falcon," her study of the South Slavs, to a meditation on "Kosovo Polye," the Serb national epic. In that poem, which recalls a battle of 1389, the Serb leader, Prince Lazar, is betrayed to the Turks by one of his followers.
Yet it is not the betrayal that causes the ensuing catastrophic defeat: In the hour of decision, Prince Lazar chooses defeat because nothing is more poignant, more perfect, more heroic than death for a sacred cause. The Serbs' love affair with defeat, West argued, shaped their entire political culture. 
 Unromantic British and American analysts of the current Balkan war, who were announcing as recently as two weeks ago that "the Serbs have won," should re-read West. As the Croatian advances show, the Serbs have been unable to solidify a victory the West was intent on handing them.
What is most striking is the extent to which, over the past six years, the Serbs have chosen defeat.
It was suicidally romantic nationalism rather than canny pragmatism that led Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic in 1990 to revoke regional autonomy for Serbia's ethnic Hungarians and Albanians. His action won Serbia nothing, but it provided crucial cover for the secession of Slovenia and Croatia from the still intact Yugoslav federation, which Serbia dominated.
The Serbs sought to recover by attacking Slovenia, but they lost. Then they attacked Croatia, but they succeeded only in taking control of some border territory. Much of the Serb-held land in Croatia, the Krajina region, has now been lost in a spectacular but foreseeable defeat.
In Bosnia-Herzegovina, the ethnic Serbs tossed aside one chance after another to have their early gains turned into a permanent victory with great-power guarantees. The British, French and Russians were eager to award them with the larger part of the territory they had "ethnically cleansed" of its Muslim and Croat population. But the Bosnian Serbs held out for a larger victory.
Now, as their leaders turn on one another, victory is slipping away. Months ago, the fall of Bihac to the Bosnian Serbs was said to be only hours away. But that town is still in Bosnian Government hands. For three years, Serb artillery has been softening Sarajevo up for a ground assault that has yet to come. Will it ever?
Mr. Milosevic is the Prince Lazar of his day. The West was prepared to lift economic sanctions against his country and hail him as a statesman if he would but recognize Croatia and an independent remnant of Bosnia-Herzegovina. But he spurned the offers, seeking a larger victory though clandestine support of the Bosnian Serbs.
What, if not a mad romanticism, can have led Mr. Milosevic to expect the Serb 30 percent of the population to hold 70 percent of the territory indefinitely against an enemy who was increasingly well-armed and would fight on indefinitely because he had nowhere to run?
The claim that the Serbs have won in Bosnia can only stick if the major powers make it stick -- that is, if they make Croatia keep its forces outside Bosnia. The West has shown little inclination to do so. The Bosnian Serbs reportedly fear a joint Croatian-Bosnian assault on the Serb-held city of Banja Luka.
What of Sarajevo itself? Speculation about a deal between Mr. Milosevic and Croatian President Franjo Tudjman -- a move that could salvage a Serb victory of sorts, has been undercut by rumors that Mr. Milosevic may be overthrown. Even if he survives and Serbs hold their Bosnian territory, Bosnia's Muslims and Croats would create a classic Balkan quagmire for the one aggressor that might have known better.
In Joseph Conrad's "Lord Jim," an English sailor abandons a sinking ship whose passengers are all Muslim pilgrims. Jim does the realistic thing. After all, the ship is sinking; surely he cannot be expected to save them all. But the ship does not sink and drifts to land, and Jim spends the rest of his life running from the memory of his disgrace.
So it may be for the West in the Balkans. In its haste to end the war, the West may have declared Bosnia-Herzegovina dead only to discover otherwise. Nothing is so irretrievably humiliating as to abandon, in the name of realism, a loser who goes on to win.

HEADLINE: Russia Is Shocked

 BODY:
To the Editor:
John Lloyd's celebration of "How Russia Became a Market Economy," by the Swedish economist Anders Aslund (July 23), brings us full circle on the "shock therapy" policy he helped design with Harvard's Jeffrey Sachs. 
 Shock therapy, which involved the quick-and-dirty demolition of the old system before a new one had been built, was launched in early 1989 with the editorial support of The New York Times. Mr. Aslund now writes a definitive "proof" that the policy succeeded, except that it would have succeeded more if there had been more shock -- defined as "a rapid reduction in the budget deficit." The Times, in turn, assigns the book to Mr. Lloyd, who celebrated the Aslund-Sachs "shock therapy" during his tenure as Moscow bureau chief of The Financial Times of London.
It seems one big happy family. The only reservation Mr. Lloyd has is that while there is now a market in Russia, "the rise in overt crime and corruption (which reform has not caused, but has certainly not cured either) threatens not just the reforms but the state itself." Those of us who fought the Anders-Sachs method from its inception did in fact argue that monetary reform had to precede the destruction of the state's command mechanism or civil chaos would follow. This, in order to permit a private banking system to replace the centralized allocation of capital.
Instead, the "market" economy created is merely a black market that lives according to the law of the jungle. Beijing, on the other hand, rejected cold-turkey capitalism for the careful conversion that is being cheered by its people. The editors of The Times only kid themselves with this rosy review of Mr. Aslund's fiasco.
How is it that the same editorialists who thrill to shock therapy in Moscow are correctly horrified when Republican leaders in the 104th Congress beat the drums for shock therapy at home? Drastic action to balance the national budget in either country is an act of intellectual desperation. It invariably puts the burden of adjustment on the poorest and weakest people in society.
 
JUDE T. WANNISKI
Morristown, N.J.

HEADLINE: THE CAPITALIST;
Ruble Roulette

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEWIS 

 BODY:
ON THE morning of July 20, I was busy ducking requests from the editors of this magazine to write a column about Alan Greenspan when I opened the newspaper and discovered Tatyana Paramonova. The most recent nominee to head the Central Bank of Russia, Paramonova had been rejected for the second time by the Russian Parliament. In her eight months as acting chairwoman, she had cut the annual rate of Russian inflation from around 1,200 percent to 225 percent. But in the end she had run afoul of a superior force -- Russian bankers. "Paramonova has declared war on large Russian banks," a banker was quoted in The Financial Times, "so we have no alternative but to declare war on her." It turns out that Russian banks borrow long-term at fixed rates of interest from the Central Bank of Russia, and lend short-term to their customers. High inflation allows them to repay their debts to the Central Bank with cheaper rubles.
As a substitute for Greenspan, it is true that Paramonova had her disadvantages. She was a long way from New York; she had little immediate effect on the United States bond market; and while the slightest monetary miscue in America is surprising and newsworthy, total chaos in Russia is not. But that's almost the point. The American way of life is now more likely to be screwed up by the Central Bank of Russia than by the Federal Reserve Board. Central bankers in rich countries no longer have the power to commit serious crimes against their economies. Greenspan would be stripped of his authority by American bankers long before he would be allowed to debase the dollar badly. But whoever replaces Paramonova will be in precisely the opposite position: her successor's mandate from Russian bankers will be to hyperinflate the ruble and thereby pave the way for yet another Russian revolution. 
 Back in 1988 at one of the first Fed meetings run by Greenspan, a fellow governor brought up a curious fact. There were fewer $100 bills circulating inside the United States than inside the Soviet Union. So meaningless was the ruble that the dollar had replaced the Soviet measure of value. In early 1991, as the Soviet Union unraveled, the need for a sound ruble became an article of faith among Russian bigwigs. An influential banker named Viktor Gerashchenko claimed that "the Soviet people want a Central Bank that will sometimes say 'nyet' to the Government." That year the Central Bank of Russia announced its first great ruble reform: it froze all savings accounts and declared all 50- and 100-ruble notes worthless, all of which lead a Russian electrician standing outside the bank that had confiscated his life savings to famously proclaim, "First there was nothing to buy, and now there is no money to buy it with. In the Soviet Union, this is economic reform."
BUT THE SUBSEQUENT behavior of the new Russian state made the Soviet reform look like an economics seminar at the University of Chicago. By September 1991, austerity was again out of fashion. One chairman of the Central Bank was tossed out and another dragged in, namely the above-mentioned Viktor Gerashchenko. Fifty- and 100-ruble notes were printed again, together with a new 500-ruble note. In the fall of 1992, after yet another failed attempt at reform, the ruble was allowed to float a bit against the dollar. (The official exchange rate had been fixed so that the ruble appeared to be worth more than a dollar.) It opened at a penny and fell quickly to less than half a cent. In January 1993, with the Central Bank printing money so rapidly that it feared running out of paper, the ruble collapsed to one-tenth of one cent. In July 1993, the Central Bank declared yet another reform: all rubles printed before 1993 were worthless. At the same time, it printed new rubles even faster than before so that they, too, became worthless. Inflation spiraled upward until October 1994, when Gerashchenko resigned and the ruble fell to its low of about one-fiftieth of one American penny (that is, one dollar fetched 5,130 rubles).
AS ANYONE KNOWS who has skimmed The World Book Encyclopedia, the history of Russia can be understood as a struggle between the White Russians and the Slavs, or the Russians with long necks who want to be more like the West and the Russians with thick necks who don't. The long necks may drag Russia westward for a while, but the thick necks eventually drag it back into oblivion. To preserve their dignity and often their lives, the long necks erect a Potemkin village of sorts and then retreat hastily to Paris, until the time comes when the thick necks discredit themselves so much that the long necks are given another chance.
Last month, I think, may be viewed as the moment the long necks gave up and erected their Potemkin village. A few days before Paramonova's telling defeat in Parliament, the ruble was anchored to the dollar. Another reform! The Central Bank of Russia promises that from now until Oct. 1, the ruble will rise no higher than 4,300 and fall no further than 4,900. Supporters of the new move offer two arguments: the first is that it will reduce uncertainty and thus encourage investment; the second is that it "improves discipline." That is, when hungry serfs demand rubles to reap the potato harvest, as they always have at this time of year, the Central Bank chairman, whoever that ends up being, can point to the dollar and say, "Sorry, we need to keep the ruble strong, and so this year you'll have to starve."
OR SO GOES THE THEORY. In practice, the pressures to finance the war in Chechnya, to pay the 1.5 million Government workers who recently took to the streets to demand back pay and to harvest potatoes are what they always were. That is why the behavior of the Russian bankers is so unsettling: Now is the time the Russian bankers are meant to unite and squash the serfs, to preserve the value of their debts to the banks.
Every once in a while some outraged journalist proves once and for all that the Federal Reserve is a conspiracy of American bankers to make the rich richer and the poor poorer. The argument usually turns on the belief that a low rate of inflation helps rich people by preserving the value of their dollars but hurts poor people by slowing the economy. The theory is in many ways ridiculous. For instance, the cost of inflation falls less on the rich than on people with fixed incomes, who tend to be middle class or lower, but it does include at least one indisputable truth: rich people everywhere do indeed loathe inflation. Everywhere but Russia, where the rich have long since abandoned their currency for ours.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By TERRENCE NEILAN

 BODY:

French in the Islands
 Q. Do you know of any French-language schools in the Caribbean islands? -- L. M. B., Somerville, N.J. 
 A. The French islands of Guadeloupe and Martinique, integral parts of France, now provide language and culture programs designed for foreign students, particularly those from the United States.
The Centre International de Recherches d'Echanges et de Cooperation de la Caraibes et des Ameriques, with facilities on both islands has begun a program called Le Francais aux Ameriques (French in the Americas).
Nine-week courses at beginner, intermediate and advanced levels give students 420 hours of instruction, while an intensive two-week course provides 60 hours.
There are also special classes for French teachers from the United States in the Easter break, lasting 68 hours, and during the summer (175 hours).
In Guadeloupe the cost of the courses for an individual student start at 4,500 francs (about $978, calculating 4.6 francs to the dollar) for the two-week course. Lodging is provided at an additional cost.
In Martinique arrangements are similar, but, in general, groups with a minimum of 10 students are preferred. The cost per person drops to 2,200 francs (about $478).
For detailed information about the programs in Guadeloupe contact Cirecca, Post Office Box 44, Petit Bourg 95179, Guadeloupe, French West Indies; telephone (590) 95.64.72, fax (590) 94.36.03.
For information on the Martinique programs contact Cirecca, Post Office Box 393, Fort-de-France 97258, Martinique, French West Indies; (596) 73.45.19, fax (596) 60.51.04.
 
Expo in Portugal
 Q. My wife and I enjoy going to Expos and we understand that there will be an Expo coming up in Lisbon. Can you give me any more information? -- Bernard S. Greenbaum, Kew Gardens, Queens
A. Expo '98, the theme of which will be "The Oceans and the Seas," will open in eastern Lisbon on June 10, 1998, the year Portugal commemorates the 500th anniversary of Vasco da Gama's historic voyage to India.
The Expo, the first to be held in Portugal and the last to be held this century, will be built on a 62-acre site on the banks of Tagus River in an economically depressed area that will be subject to a huge urban renewal project. The exhibition, which will continue for three months and cost an estimated $565 million, will leave a legacy of new parks and housing, road networks, shopping centers and cultural sites. It is expected to attract some nine million visitors.
The exhibition hopes to stress the interdependence of the oceans and the atmosphere and the effects of this on the climate; to build an awareness of the need to safeguard the world's marine heritage, and to provide a forum for the exchange of information and experience.
More information: Portuguese National Tourist Office, 590 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10036; (212) 354-4403; fax (212) 764-6137.
 
To London and Paris
 Q. I know the Changing of the Guard in London has cut down its daily routine. How can I find out what days they march? And as I will be in Paris for Beaujolais Nouveau are there any special events planned for the occasion? -- Dennis F. Curran, Havertown, Pa.
A. As of last Sunday and until Sept. 1, the Changing of the Guard takes place at 11:30 A.M. every other day on even-numbered days (before last Sunday it was held daily at the same time). Starting on Sept. 1 it will switch to every other day on odd-numbered days. Next May 1 it will again be held every day.
The ceremony lasts 40 minutes and takes place inside the railings of Buckingham Palace. The Guards, usually drawn from the Foot Guards of the Household Division, leave Wellington Barracks at 11:27 A.M. and march by way of Birdcage Walk to the palace.
The Old Guard forms up in the palace forecourt, going off duty and handing over to the New Guard. The guard, normally two men at each post, is reduced to a single guard at each post when Queen Elizabeth is not in residence at the palace. The Queen is there if her Royal Standard is flying from the flagpole on top of the palace. The ceremony is canceled in bad weather.
The nearest Underground stations to the palace are St. James's Park and Green Park.
Meanwhile, a separate ceremony is held at Horse Guards Parade on Whitehall. The Mounted Guard Changing Ceremony takes place daily, Monday to Saturday at 11 A.M. and Sunday at 10 A.M. The nearest Underground stations to Horse Guards Parade are Charing Cross and Westminster.
As for Paris, be prepared for a citywide celebration of Beaujolais Nouveau on the third Thursday of November, this year the 16th.
The wine will be tasted and judged in just about every restaurant and bistro. One of the highlights is the awarding of "Les Meilleurs Pots" by the Rabelais Academy, a group of journalists and painters who are wine connoisseurs, to the bistros they consider warm and friendly and which serve good wine and food.
These are a few of the past winners:
Les Pipos, 2 Rue de l'Ecole Polytechnique, (1993 winner), 43.54.11.40; Metro, Maubert Mutualite.
La Tour de Pierre, 53 Rue Dauphine (1992), 43.26.08.93; Metro, Dauphine.
Le Vin des Rues, 21 Rue Boulard, (1989), 43.22.19.78; Metro, Denfert Rochereau.
 
South African Weather
 Q. My husband and I will be traveling to South Africa in late October. What will the weather will be like in Johannesburg, Pretoria and Cape Town? And how formal is dress in these three cities? -- Suzanne L. Ethridge, Farmington Hills, Mich.
A. October is springtime in South Africa, considered by some travelers the best time to visit.
Johannesburg and Pretoria are both in what is called Gauteng, or high veld region, most of it above 4,000 feet, where temperatures are rarely excessive and low humidity and many hours of sunshine make for a pleasant and healthy climate.
In October look for average highs of 77 degrees in Johannesburg and lows of 53, with precipitation at 2.2 inches.
In Pretoria highs average 80 degrees and lows 55, also with 2.2 inches of precipitation.
Cape Town, in the Cape Mediterranean region, is a little windier than the other two and you might need a sweater at night. In October average highs should be around 70 degrees and lows 52, with precipitation at 1.2 inches. In November the highs pick up to 73.
South Africa is not in general a formal country, but for dinner in a good restaurant men would look out of place if they were not wearing a jacket and tie. At night women generally favor a dress with perhaps a cardigan for the cooler evenings. TERENCE NEILAN

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Not Quite on a Spree, but Getting Acquisitive Again

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
MUSEUMS HAVE BEEN Surprisingly active this year in expanding their holdings of decorative arts and design objects through gifts and purchases. While no one is claiming a sharp upsurge in acquisitions, which have been depressed for nearly a decade, a slight but noticeable increase has been reported.
"Such gifts are going up again," said Ashton Hawkins, executive vice president and counsel to the trustees at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. "And the renewed tax deductibility did help." He was referring to a recent easing of tax rules for art donors. 
 The range of objects donated or bought could hardly be broader; they run from ancient African art to modern Japanese design, from an 18th-century chandelier to Tupperware. The Cleveland Museum of Art recently purchased a 2,000-year-old Nok head of a man, a vigorously modeled, footlong work in terra cotta of a type that is little known in this country. Such ceramic sculptures are named after the village of Nok in central Nigeria, where they were first unearthed by tin miners in 1928.
The Cleveland's head is highly expressive, with staring hollows for eyes, open mouth and nostrils, and floral roundels covering the hair. It was produced between 600 B.C. and A.D. 250.
While market forces underlie most purchases by museums, gifts are made for many reasons, or sometimes spontaneously. "I knew about this Japanese wheelchair, and I wanted to see it for possible use in our show," said Paula Antonelli, an associate curator at the Museum of Modern Art who organized "Mutant Materials in Contemporary Design," an exhibition that will remain at the museum through Aug. 27. Ms. Antonelli found out from Kazuo Kawasaki, the designer of the chair -- a fold-up innovation that weighs a mere 13 pounds -- that it was available only in Japan. Rather than just sending the chair as a loan, Mr. Kawasaki donated it to the museum's collection.
Similarly, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, an 18th-century gilded wood chandelier was added to the new Annie Laurie Atkin Galleries a few days before the galleries opened in June. The rare lighting fixture, carved about 1715 in the style of Daniel Marot, was sold in April at Christie's in New York to Jayne Wrightsman, a museum trustee and longtime donor. "Mrs. Wrightsman wanted to acquire an important object for the new English galleries," said William Rieder, an associate curator. The chandelier, which had been expected to sell for at most $500,000, brought much more: it cost Mrs. Wrightsman $717,500.
 WHILE DONATIONS OF Objects and money to museums have rebounded a bit, they have not returned to the record levels of the early 1980's. Gifts of art to all nonprofit organizations were significantly curtailed by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, under which donors could deduct no more than an artwork's original purchase price, which might be substantially less than its current value. In 1991, for one year, donors were allowed once again to claim the market value of the gifts. And in 1993, President Clinton's tax bill made market-value deductions permanent.
"Tax-wise, it was less attractive to give, and then the economy wasn't all that great either," said Graham Hood, the chief curator at Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia. Actually, Williamsburg was able to buy a prize piece of Americana, a colorfully painted dower chest, when it was auctioned by Sotheby's from a Virginia collection in May.
The chest, made about 1800 by Johannes Spitler of Shenandoah County, was expected to bring, at most, $60,000, but went instead for $343,500, a record at auction for painted American furniture. "There will now be a slight hiatus in our buying," Mr. Hood said.
The Virginia Museum of Fine Arts was also active in that sale, paying $57,500 for a towering 1820 clock by Jacob Danner, a German-born Virginia craftsman. And kitchen products by Tupperware Worldwide, the Florida plastics producer, which is celebrating its the 50th anniversary, were donated by Morrison Cousins, the designer of the 1990's versions. He sent 13 contemporary pieces but none of the originals.
This year, the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh received its largest gift ever, "The Chariot of Aurora," an Art Deco wall 18 feet high and 26 feet long from the grand salon of the Normandie, the French superliner of the 1930's. The 32 sculptured and lacquered panels depicting dawn, dusk and the four winds were made by the artists Jean Dupas and Jean Dunand. The donor, Frederick Koch, an heir to a Kansas oil fortune, had bought the wall in 1984 for about $2.5 million.
"We've received scattered gifts and one important bequest of American modernist art this year," said Louise Lippincott, curator of fine arts at the Carnegie. "But the Normandie panels have to take the cake. We're going to subdivide one of our biggest galleries and raise the ceiling six feet. It should be spectacular, like adding a glamourous set from a Fred Astaire movie."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Saving Money on Mortages

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
EARLIER this year, the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development established new regulations for mortgage lenders that could put some cash in the pockets of millions of homeowners.
The new rules spell out the formula that lenders must use to calculate the escrow payments that lenders often require customers to make for payment of real estate taxes and homeowner's insurance. Under formulas used before to the change, homeowners often paid more into their escrow accounts than was necessary. 
 As a result, it is estimated that as many as 6 million homeowners will receive more than $1.5 billion in credits or refunds from their lenders over the next three years as withholding procedures are changed in accordance with a timetable specified by the new rules.
But homeowner advocates say that it is not necessary to wait three years for a refund or credit -- which they say can range from $250 to as much as $2,000. They say that homeowners can have their escrow accounts privately audited to determine whether they are owed a refund and, if so, they can then prevail upon their lender to make the refund sooner rather than later.
At the same time, the advocates say, it is also wise for homeowners with adjustable-rate mortgages to make sure that their lender has been calculating interest rate changes correctly and for homeowners who are required to make private mortgage insurance -- or PMI -- payments, to determine whether it is necessary for them to continue to do so.
"A homeowner cannot just assume that the payment their mortgage company is asking them to make is the right payment," said Richard Roll, president of the American Homeowners Association, a not-for-profit consumer advocacy organization based in Washington.
Mr. Roll said that 50 percent of homeowners who have had their escrow accounts audited have found that they are entitled to a refund or a credit. With most residential real estate mortgages, lenders require borrowers to pay 1/12 of their annual real estate taxes and homeowner's insurance premiums as a part of the monthly mortgage payment. The lender then uses that money to pay the taxes and premiums when they come due. To insure that there will always be sufficient money to make those payments, most lenders require an escrow "cushion" that is usually established at closing.
But while most mortgage documents require a one-month "cushion" -- or no cushion at all -- many lenders have been holding a two-month cushion and have not been paying interest to their customers on the amount they are holding. Under the new regulations, any excess over the amount specified in the loan documents must be returned to borrowers or credited against any pending escrow increases.
In addition, the accounting procedures required by the new regulations are also expected to reduce the escrow payments that many borrowers pay on a monthly basis.
But it appears that escrow accounts are only one area in which consumers can get shortchanged. Four years ago, investigators from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation calculated that between 50 and 60 percent of all adjustable-rate mortgage loans contained some error in the way interest charges were being recalculated. And though new accounting guidelines have been established, some mortgage-industry watchdogs say that interest calculation errors still occur regularly.
"We've found errors amounting to $15,000, $18,000, $20,000," said Larry D. Powers, president of Consumer Loan Advocates, a mortgage-auditing company in Lake Bluff, Ill. "We've seen errors created right at the closing. We've found loans that have a half-point error from the day the loan started." Typically, adjustable-rate mortgages are designed so their interest rate is recalculated after a specified time period in accordance with some widely accepted economic indicator such as Treasury bills.
But, mortgage experts say, those recalculations are often wrong. "Most people don't pay attention to it," said Ian L. Renert, a partner in the auditing firm of Hawthorne-Sterling & Company, in Stamford, Conn. "But every time a change occurs, there's a strong possibility that errors are going to occur."
Errors also occur when loans are sold by one lender to another -- an increasingly common occurrence.
"When a loan is converted from the original lender's computer system to another lender's computer system, errors often result," Mr. Renert said. "It's a rampant problem." One of the most common sources of errors, he said, are computer software- generated "rounding errors" whereby numbers expressed to three and four decimal places are "rounded off" to one. Though such errors appear small, they can result in significant overpayment when large mortgages are involved or when the error is compounded over a period of years.
David Ginsburg, president of Loantech, a mortgage auditing company in Gaithersburg, Md., said that his firm finds errors in about one-third of the adjustable-rate mortgages and in about half the escrow accounts it audits.
Mr. Ginsburg added that even if an adjustable rate mortgage has been refinanced and paid off, the borrower is still entitled to a refund of any overcharge that might have been made. "We tell people that there may be gold sitting in their filing cabinets," Mr. Ginsburg said.
Another area where consumers might save money on their mortgage payments is related to private mortgage insurance. Such insurance is typically required when the down payment made by a buyer is less than 20 percent of the purchase price. "What people are never told are the circumstances under which they can eliminate the PMI payment," said Lawrence Walner, a Chicago lawyer who specializes in handling class-action suits against lending institutions.
Mr. Walner said that what many people do not realize is that the private mortgage insurance premium -- which can run several hundred dollars a year, depending on the size of the mortgage -- should be discontinued when the equity in the property reaches 20 percent.
"Most people forget about it and most lenders forget to remind them," Mr. Walner said.
The 20 percent equity level can be attained, he said, either as the result of the borrower "paying down" the mortgage, or as the result of the property itself increasing in value to the point where the equity has increased to 20 percent.
In some cases, Mr. Walner said, it might be necessary to obtain an appraisal of the property to establish proof of an increase in equity.
Robert M. O'Toole, senior staff vice president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America in Washington, said that the first thing borrowers should do if they suspect they are being overcharged is to call their lender.
Mr. O'Toole said that in most cases lenders will correct errors immediately. "Believe me, no lender wants to make errors," Mr. O'Toole said. "And my sense is that it doesn't happen very often."
Private audits of mortgages and escrow accounts can be obtained from the America Homeowners Association: (703) 892-4663; Consumer Loan Advocates: (708) 615-0024, or Loantech: (800) 888-6781.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: 32 West 40th Street;
At 1907 Engineers' Club, Technology Has Its Limits

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
IN THE EARLY 1980's, probably because of the most prominent features of its facade, an apartment converter renamed the 1907 Engineers Club at 32 West 40th Street The Columns after an extensive renovation.
But the marble is in rotten shape and the co-op board is removing large patches and replacing them with fiberglass replicas, not available to the engineers nine decades ago. 
 At the turn of the century, the American engineer was ascendant -- engineers provided the expertise to build a whole new industrial and architectural empire. Each discipline -- mechanical, electrical, civil and others -- had its own professional organization, setting code requirements, influencing legislation and establishing rules for construction.
They also had a social organization of 968 members, occupying an old house at 374 Fifth Avenue near 35th Street. In 1903, the club decided to buy land for a new building on West 40th Street opposite Bryant Park.
Built up with large brownstones beginning in the 1860's, this block began attracting a new kind of development in 1905, when three clubs began what were then high-rise buildings: the now-demolished New York Club at 20 West 40th Street, the Republican Club, at 54 West 40th, and the Engineers' Club.
At the same time, Andrew Carnegie, the millionaire industrialist, had offered $1.5 million to the engineers' professional associations to build a joint professional center. At first this included the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, the American Institute of Electrical Engineers and the American Institute of Mining Engineers. They threw in with the Engineers Club and bought land backing up to its site, at 25 West 39th Street. The 39th Street building, designed by Hale & Rogers, was a giant Roman-style stone building with meeting rooms, an auditorium, library and offices. But the 40th Street building, for social activities, was designed separately in deep red brick and soft white marble.
"There's democracy for you," Carnegie said at a ceremony in 1905. "No social influence in determining the architecture of this building, but 28 sets of plans, out of which this one was selected by unanimous choice." The one he referred to was that of the two-year-old partnership of Whitfield & King, which had been selected over Carrere & Hastings, Clinton & Russell and other established firms. Henry D. Whitfield was the brother of Carnegie's wife, Louise.
Indeed, their design was similar to the three-story garage they had designed for the Carnegies the year before at 55 East 90th Street -- except that the club is 13 stories high. The most distinctive features of the facade are the giant Corinthian pilasters at the second and third floors and the giant columns at the top.
INSIDE, the club had the usual assortment of rooms, including 66 bedrooms and a 300-seat dining room that covered the entire 11th floor. These attractions nearly doubled the membership, to 1,898. Carnegie ultimately paid $450,000 of the $900,000 cost. Mark Twain spoke at the dedication in December 1907.
New York is littered with elaborate private clubhouses whose owners have had to abandon them, and by 1972 only the engineers remained on West 40th Street.
In that year, an upbeat article in Mechanical Engineering magazine said that the Engineers Club "looks confidently toward the future," even though the professional societies had sold off their 39th Street building in 1960.
In 1979, the engineers left 40th Street for rented quarters, selling to a developer, David Eshagin. He gave his architect, Seymour Churgin, the difficult task of dividing up the large clubrooms into apartment-sized units. Whether for economy or for style, they left the giant open marble stair hall running from the first to the third floors and left several of the large central spaces as giant hallways.
On the second floor, the main club room and the library have been divided into four apartments. A recent visit to one of these found a mezzanine installed in a room that is at least as tall as it is wide and that retains its original mantelpiece and paneling.
The building was converted to a co-op in 1983, and in recent years the horizontal marble elements on the facade have been cracking and leaking.
DENNIS Mele is president of Midtown Preservation, an Oyster Bay, L.I., architectural firm. His company is supervising the replacement of the marble at the fourth and the eleventh floors with fiberglass replicas -- much lighter and much easier to fabricate. Originally, he said, the co-op wanted to repair and re-use the stone "but it fell apart in our hands" despite taking great care in removal.
The projecting cornice at the fourth-floor level has been replaced and similar work is under way at the 11th floor. The resulting change is a good summary of the strengths and weaknesses of modern substitute materials. The new cornice took the mold well and is crisp and clean. But by definition, this leaves it out of sync with the entire building, which is softly worn and aged.
The new cornice is a soft, chalky gray, an interesting color in its own right that in no way shouts out its manufactured character, as is otherwise often the case. But the material it seeks to match is marble, one of the richest and most variegated of our building stones -- the original was soft and mottled, the replacement is uniform.
The whole project, costing $350,000, is a noble effort, compromised not by intent but by the evolution of building practices. The hardest test of the builder's skill is to alter and existing structure invisibly.
Mr. Mele, too, is aware of the discrepancy but hopes that weathering will blend the new with the old.
"Matching colors is one of the most difficult things to do," he said.
