SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2345 words

HEADLINE: Hooked

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
AFTER nearly 18 hours at sea, 90 miles out in the Atlantic, trolling insignificantly along the spine of the continental shelf, Lou De Titta and his crew spotted their first trophy fish. It was a swordfish, a 10-foot, 400-pound monster whose bocce-ball eye registered nothing at the sight of Mr. De Titta or his gleaming boat, the Stress Management, equipped with gear enough to empty the oceans. The fish swished its tail just below the surface.
Let me count the ways that Mr. De Titta, his friend Greg Venturo, a veteran New Jersey offshore fisherman, and the crew of four other men did not catch this magnificent fish: For 45 minutes, they made passes with lures, threw out chunks of oily butterfish, taunted it with a squid looped through a heavy hook. They considered, jokingly, a harpoon. 
 The fish, with a bit of New Jersey swagger, would neither bite nor flee. It was Mr. De Titta who seemed spooked. "I've read about stuff like this," he said.
When the swordfish sounded for good, it was not for any lack of effort on the part of Mr. De Titta, who at 34 is no doubt among the most enthusiastic and obsessive in the state's fleet of recreational fishermen ("I am a weekend warrior," he said sheepishly, standing next to the full-sized fridge and microwave in his boat's air-conditioned cabin). An outlandishly successful entrepreneur and now skilled fisherman, Mr. De Titta is also one of the die-hards who forsake inshore species like bluefish, striped bass and fluke for the occasional trip offshore, blasting 50 or 100 miles out for big game that many in New Jersey do not realize live so close: five species of tuna, including giant bluefin weighing half a ton that can fetch $30,000 from Japanese buyers; marlin that flip mightily through the air; very finicky swordfish.
Going after the big fish is expensive and messy, but part of an industry -- encompassing boat builders to marinas to bait shops -- that contributes some $600 million annually to the state's economy, according to the New Jersey Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife. One expert estimates that offshore fishing alone, done largely by the 600 charter boats and 2,450 private boats with Federal bluefin tuna permits, is responsible for $75 million annually in the state.
Charter boats, a business that began at the turn of the century at the state's seaside resorts, charge between $1,200 and $2,000 for a six-person trip offshore that can last 18 hours or more. Put another way, anyone willing to spend $200 or $300 can experience world-class fishing close to home, even though the number of fish has declined over the last two decades because of overfishing. (The only other requirement is a strong stomach: This reporter spent eight seasick hours curled up on one of Mr. De Titta's two quite comfortable couches.)
"Every trip could be that 1,000-pound fish," said Mr. Venturo, 41, a former charter boat captain who writes fishing advice columns for several magazines. "And what people don't realize is that in the New York area, you don't have to travel a lot. You don't have to go to Australia. It's all here."
Offshore is also a place of spare, singular beauty. On two recent overnight trips -- in a lull in what fishermen are calling a healthy season for tuna in New Jersey waters, and an excellent year for blue marlin -- the Stress Management chugged by fin whales, giant creatures that grow to 79 feet and suck up dense clouds of squid and small fish; a pair of pilot whales; schools of hundreds of bottle-nosed dolphin chattering in the boat's wake, and the unobstructed view of swelling seas 10 miles in every direction. At night, the faint trail of a satellite ticked through the stars. The beauty is a good thing, because as with all fishing, big-game fishing is not always about catching a fish.
On the two recent trips, just shy of 50 hours on the water, Mr. De Titta and his crew caught two small white marlin, a 60-pound yellowfin tuna and one feisty little skipjack tuna. This is not terrible, and like most devoted fishermen, Mr. De Titta is nearly as animated about the ones that get away. "That was really cool anyway," he said of the swordfish that disappeared. "That really was."
Still, offshore fishing can offer superlatives in the size, numbers and fight of the fish. A year ago, for example, Mr. De Titta's boat hauled in 10 mahi-mahi, 8 big yellowfin tuna and a 300-pound blue marlin on a one-day trip. If that sounds like a fish story, Mr. De Titta, who projects a good-natured amazement at what his business success has brought him, will provide proof: A videotape of the trip, which he will happily pop into the boat's audio-visual center (which also houses 250 compact disks) to kill a few hours when actual fish are not biting.
"The chance of catching them is 50-50," he said. "So what's the lure? That's where the beauty of the environment comes into it -- the love to be out in the sea, to be in the outdoors, to see nature."
"If you caught fish every time you went out, it would stink, because everyone would do it," he said. "Everyone would have a boat like this."
 
At Home Afloat
 That is not likely. The Stress Management is an exceptional boat: A Viking made right in New Gretna, Burlington County, it is 45 feet long and 15 feet wide, sleeping six comfortably. Its twin diesel engines each are fired with 485 horsepower. The gas tank holds 550 gallons of fuel, burning 38 gallons an hour, enough to travel more than 300 miles. The boat has a main stateroom with an enormous bed and two full bathrooms, each with a shower and sink. Its radar is so sensitive that it picks up riptides, lobster pots, seemingly everything except the Marlboro Light butts Mr. De Titta flicks overboard every hour or so.
The cost? Mr. De Titta says it is worth $320,000, with another $30,000 or so in tackle.
"That reel there is $950," he said plainly, pointing to one of the 30 or so rods in racks on the cabin ceiling. "I have four of them."
Mr. De Titta, who is married and lives in Denville, has come a long way as a fisherman from the days when he and his brother would fish for fluke with collapsible Pocket Fisherman rods alongside their uncle in Barnegat Bay. As teen-agers in Parsippany, the two built a skiff for fishing in a local pond. As Mr. De Titta's business grew -- he is a partner in Scelba, Scelba, De Titta and Wolfson, a marketing and communications firm in Montville -- he would often pay for charter trips. At 27, he bought his first oceangoing boat, a 32-footer.
Mr. De Titta met Mr. Venturo, who is also a boat broker who outfits boats with electronics and other gear for offshore fishing, when he decided to buy a first-rate boat three years ago. "He was the first guy who asked me: What kind of fisherman am I?" Mr. De Titta said. "All the other guys asked me how much money I had."
"This is my dream boat," he added. "When we got this boat, I said, 'This is not believable that I could have this.' "
A friendship developed. Mr. Venturo taught Mr. De Titta secrets and shortcuts from his own two decades of offshore fishing. They have collaborated on a series of fishing videos that have been shown on cable television. Mr. Venturo often runs the Stress Management, babying it as if it were his own. There is a ongoing joke that Mr. Venturo picked it for himself.
"You're actually running your boat?" Mr. Venturo once asked when Mr. De Titta took the wheel.
"My boat?" Mr. De Titta asked.
"That's right," Mr. Venturo said, correcting himself. "You only make the payments."
 
A Few Nibbles
 The pair left from Manasquan on a recent Saturday at 5 P.M. with a crew of four: Wayne Pinder, an old friend of Mr. Venturo's who is also known as Hook; Tom McConlouge, who bought Mr. De Titta's old boat; Mike Mazzei, a professional diver and video photographer, and Mr. Venturo's 10-year-old daughter, Candace, an experienced fisher of deep waters. Along for the ride were a reporter and a photographer who is a boat owner himself and who claims never to have been seasick. The destination was the Wilmington Canyon, at a spot 102 miles southeast, where the waters drop quickly from 200 feet to more than 4,000.
This is high-tech fishing: Before setting off, Mr. Venturo ran home to grab a fax that a meteorologist friend had sent, showing satellite pictures of water temperatures. The tuna, he said, would be where the temperatures were highest.
"Using the coordinates, we will be able to save fuel and time to run to the exact locations where we will find fish," he said on deck. "Once we find them, it doesn't mean we can make them bite."
Indeed not, but the Stress Management ended up doing better than many other boats on the water that weekend. After nearly six hours of travel, the boat began drifting for the night, and Mr. Pinder and Mr. McConlouge fed the ocean with a steady stream of cut-up frozen butterfish -- a practice called chunking -- to attract tuna.
Nothing. At 4 A.M., nearly everyone had gone to sleep. The sea and sky were black, save the ghostly glow of half a dozen other small boats bobbing above the canyons. The water was squirming with baitfish. A school of porpoises had just swum by, Mr. McConlouge said, and he tossed another handful of bait into the water.
In early morning, the crew began trolling, dragging as many as eight lures through the water at a slow speed. Within an hour or so, Mr. Pinder started and pointed at rod No. 4: Something big with fins was stalking it. The rods were screaming, then an incredible sight: Three white marlin rocketed through the surface, wriggling in electric drops of water to shake free of the lures. A fourth fish was pulling line out quickly.
"I hooked that for you, Lou," Mr. Pinder yelled, handing one rod to Mr. De Titta. "He's on there good."
"You did!" Mr. De Titta said.
"Great job, Wayne," Mr. Venturo yelled. "That's why we call him the Hook."
Two of the fish pulled free, but Mr. Pinder dragged in the first fish, about 35 pounds, then set it free. (Many enlightened fisherman kill only what they will eat). Mr. De Titta worked his fish, roughly double in size, for a few minutes longer, then brought it to the boat shimmering and tossing its head. White marlin have blue backs and fins with silver bellies, but they are also ablaze with indigo and yellow and green. The crew posed for a picture.
"He's staring at me," Candace said, and they set it free. We were 118 miles in the ocean, over the Baltimore Canyon, where the depth is 3,600 feet.
And except for one small skipjack tuna, a 5-pounder that I reeled in (realizing later that politeness dictated the fish should have gone to Candace -- sorry,Candace), the next 10 hours to shore were completely dead.
 
Trying Again
 "We're going to have real good weather," Mr. De Titta said before another trip, eight days later. I heard the fishing's picked up a little bit. Some buddies of mine last night caught six."
Tuna, he was talking about, and to catch them this time the Stress Management was aimed almost due east to the Hudson Canyon, nearly 90 miles out, where the Hudson River once flowed.
The crew this time included Mr. Mazzei; Clay Storer, a friend of Mr. De Titta; Michael Samuels Jr., another friend; and Frank Hutchko, a truck driver who charters trips in his own boat.
At 9:45 P.M., the signs were good: The water was swarming with squid and tinker mackerel, two favorites of tuna. A quarter-mile away, fishermen on a boat called the Fintastic were battling a 200-pound tuna. The water was blue and the moon was the color of mango.
"All right, let's fish," Mr. Venturo barked.
But after a few hours of drifting, everyone but Mr. Samuels and Mr. Hutchko went to sleep. Then around 2:15 A.M., a baited hook set deep for swordfish let out a whine that jolted Mr. Venturo from the flybridge. But the fish did not stay on the line.
Fifteen minutes later, a second reel started spinning, everyone woke, and Mr. Venturo began to fight his fish with no trace of sleep. Mr. De Titta followed Mr. Venturo around the deck with a gaff, a deadly-looking stick with a pointed hook. Mr. Mazzei followed with the video camera.
In a few minutes, Mr. Venturo brought to the boat the 60-pound yellowfin, with gold glinting in the dark from its two lower fins and a band across his body.
"He gave you a little battle, huh?" Mr. De Titta said, aiming at Mr. Venturo's pride.
"He was on the boat in two and a half minutes," Mr. Venturo growled.
"It's our first tuna of the New Jersey season," Mr. De Titta said.
With little ceremony, Mr. Venturo cut off the fish's head, then jammed a piece of wire into its backbone to stop the twitching and improve the meat's quality.
It was only fish of the trip.
That, of course, did not diminish the hunt: In the morning, a pod of two dozen porpoises splashed by the boat, at times rubbing their heads together. At 8:05 A.M., Mr. Venturo spotted the distant spray of two fin whales, gorging themselves on what the electronic fishfinder said were unimaginably huge schools of baitfish. The two whales later turned to four or five, graceful black beasts rolling along the surface often within 30 yards of the boat.
"People don't have a clue," Mr. Venturo said.
"Bait, bait, bait, bait, bait, bait, bait," Mr. De Titta groused. "And nobody's feeding. Except the whales."
At 10:50 A.M., the Stress Management had its battle with the swordfish, narrowly missing a tremendous fight and a wonderful meal. Later it passed a lumbering ocean sunfish, a fish the size and shape of large gong that looks as if its tail has been cut off.
Mr. De Titta wondered for a moment why he fishes like this, boating five or more hours to the canyons, fishing and then turning around, at times empty-handed.
"I just can't picture driving to North Carolina and going to the beach," he said, thinking of an equally long drive. "Going to the beach! Then driving home."
Why, then?
"I don't know," he said. "It's that you never know what you'll catch. You never know what you will see. You never know what will happen."

Some species seen on two recent trips off the New Jersey coast.
 
Four Fish Caught...
 
1. WHITE MARLIN -- Strong lateral line and rounded dorsal fin. Usually found in blue water, but sometimes approaches shore. Can reach 9 feet and 180 pounds; marlins 35 to 70 pounds were caught.
 
2. SKIPJACK TUNA -- Black stripes on belly and sides, short dorsal fins. Can grow to cover 3 feet and 77 pounds; a 5-pound fish was caught.
 
3. YELLOWFIN TUNA -- Golden stripe on side. Second dorsal fin and finlets yellow. Can reach 82 inches and 400 pounds; a 60-pound fish was caught.
 
...And One That Got Away
 
4. SWORDFISH -- Spiny scales and folding dorsal fin. Grows to 15 feet and 1,300 pounds. Swims to 2,000 feet, but surfaces in temperate water. A 400-pounder gave the Stress Management crew the cold shoulder. (Source: Peterson Field Guides Atlantic Coast Fishes)
 
How Hemingway Saw It
 
He woke with the jerk of his right fist coming up against his face and the line burning out through his right hand. He had no feeling of his left hand but he braked all he could with his right and the line rushed out. Finally his left hand found the line and he leaned back against the line and now it burned his back and his left hand, and his left hand was taking all the strain and cutting badly. He looked back at the coils of line and they were feeding smoothly. Just then the fish jumped making a great bursting of the ocean and then a heavy fall. Then he jumped again and again and the boat was going fast although line was still racing out and the old man was raising the strain to breaking point sand raising it to breaking point again and again. -- Earnest Hemingway
"The Old Man and the Sea," 1952

HEADLINE: In Yonkers, Hope Is Chiseled in Stone

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
THE European tradition of stone carving in the open air has been transported to the waterfront here this summer, turning a grassy field along the Hudson River into a sculpture park in progress.
Sponsored by Art on Main Street, a nonprofit group devoted to revitalizing downtown Yonkers through performances, workshops and exhibitions, the two-month project -- called the Stone Symposium -- has put 13 sculptors and students to work hammering out their visions on 40,000 pounds of white stone. 
 The students, who are receiving $600 stipends for their seven weeks of work on the project, were selected by their teachers at Roosevelt High School here to learn the art of stone carving. The program, which will continue in October with "Windows on Main Street," an exhibition of paintings in downtown store windows, is being financed with a $50,000 Federal Community Development Block Grant. The funds are being distributed through the Yonkers Department of Planning and Development.
The sculptures include works for sitting and climbing on, like Barbara Segal's "Couch Cloud" and David Rodas's "Animated Pillow." They are taking shape daily under the curious gaze of onlookers, who stroll by at lunch hour and peer from passing trains to see what is going on.
The attention pleases Ms. Segal, the project's director, who says she wants to liven up the "magnificent site" beside the pier and bring people together in the enjoyment of art. "The public is invited to join in making the sculptures," she said.
Stone chips were flying under a hot sun one recent morning as Susan Abraham, a Manhattan sculptor, hammered away at the bench she was making. "You don't get this chance to work outside on this scale with a design of your own choosing very often," she said. Like the other artists, many of whom wore goggles and face masks for protection, Ms. Abraham was covered with fine white dust. White chips clung to her hair and clothing.
Robert Sampogna and Joe O'Donnell, Yonkers postal workers, were among the onlookers that day. (Ms. Abraham said Metro-North conductors routinely waved at the group.) "It's an excellent idea to see something being built instead of something torn down," Mr. Sampogna said. "To see something positive -- maybe something can happen." His voice trailed off, but Vinnie Bagwell, a sculptor and founding member of Art on Main Street, knew what he meant.
"Yonkers is polarized into little pockets of ethnicities," she said. "This project is not about ethnicities and not about politics. It's about creativity and imagination, and seeing something that you have in your mind become tangible."
A public reception for the Stone Symposium as well as for Windows on Main Street will be held on Oct. 14 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. on Main Street in the Getty Square area and from 3 to 6 P.M. at the stone-cutters' riverside site.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 31; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Satan Won't Go

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Leslie Houlden warns in his review of Elaine Pagels's book "The Origin of Satan" (June 18), "This demon will not go away." Indeed. Poor old Satan is conveniently blamed for illness, madness, pure evil and simple naughtiness, and of course for such disagreeable traits as perversity, refusal to conform and heresy. He is even credited (a clever turn) with supporting the enemy or rationalizing our addictions when that suits our purpose. He won't go away because we don't want him to. 
 This sense of expediency in retaining the fallen angel in our culture inheres in Mr. Houlden's critical study of this unusual book. But it is necessarily one-sided because it concentrates -- as does the book -- on the use of demonology in establishing who the enemy is in Jewish and Christian tradition as well as history. Ms. Pagels may not state her argument with "excessive single-mindedness," as the reviewer asserts, but she does seem to limit her thesis to the strictly religious and to the early Christian period. That is not so much a criticism as an opportunity to apply her argument to the present day, a step I trust she would approve.
Mr. Houlden praises the author for her handling of orthodoxy. Therein lies the critical issue, I believe. For above all, Satan has been employed as a power tool in the enforcement of orthodoxy: religious, political, social, scientific. Maintenance of the orthodox view (that is, control) has been accomplished by burning witches and books, engendering fear of hell and retribution, developing rituals and creating priestly classes, to name the major devices. It has not all been religious in the classical sense; political and economic power have been greatly aided by demonization. I must disagree with Mr. Houlden when he questions the author's belief that demonization has grown over time and at a terrible cost. Regrettably it has.
I am put in mind of all this by a recent reading of a long unpublished manuscript completed in 1927, entitled "His Majesty." In it, William N. Searcy (my grandfather) records a visit to hell for an interview with Satan. His Majesty obliges and describes his origins as a phantom of man's imagination, a vehicle for exerting power and exploiting mankind. It is a nice conceit: Satan himself reveals his secrets, his shallowness, his artificiality. He sneers at the folly of it all and at the thousands of books that have heightened his prestige and made his name feared. Satan, after all, does not exist, so he is in the best position to share that news.
This demon is only waiting for an exit visa. Let's stamp it and let him go away.
 
RODERICK A. IRONSIDE
Chapel Hill, N.C.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
The Lure of the Coffee Bar, the Smell of the Grounds

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
SARAH MEYER works in a coffee bar in Hartford. Her boyfriend works in a coffee bar. She says she has actually been to parties where every person there -- you guessed it -- works in a coffee bar.
Think that's unusual? Consider the story of Johnboy. A 24-year-old aspiring shoe designer with a shaved head and gun-metal grey granny glasses, he moved to New York from Chicago last year and took his first crowded, shared apartment in the East Village. 
 "Five people, four cats, and all of us worked in coffee bars," said Johnboy, who uses only one name. "One of us slipped into it and dragged all the rest."
Coffee-bar jobs, as a category of employment, barely existed a few years ago in most places in the nation. But like the high-end, high-test caffeine craze itself, which exploded out of the Pacific Northwest alongside the Seattle sound in rock music, coffee-bar jobs have become a touchstone of cool for a certain subculture of struggling performers, college students and assorted coffee-bar hangers-on.
Though the pay is usually only a bit above the minimum wage, slinging espresso has somehow been elevated beyond its wage, harkening back perhaps to the romantic days of cafe society or the era of the beat poets. Most economists would say these are fast-food jobs. Most people who work in these places would not.
"This is the bookstore employee," said Bob Goldin, an executive vice president at Technomic Inc., a Chicago-based company that tracks trends in the food industry. "College-educated, upwardly mobile, Generation X."
Nationwide, more than 17,000 people are now employed brewing and serving coffee, according to the Specialty Coffee Association of America. The trade group expects more than 10,000 coffee outlets nationwide by the turn of the century, compared with about 200 at the start of the 1990's.
With its idiosyncratic rhythms, rules and relationships, the coffee bar, these new workers say, has replaced the local bar as a place of socialization. That in turn, especially in coffee bars that encourage lingering over newspapers, books and conversation, has transformed the barista, or coffee brewer, into the 1990's bartender.
Ian Richer, who's only 19, has already worked at seven different coffee bars in New York City -- including six different locations of one chain. He says the central dynamic of the barista-customer relationship is that people are intensely picky about their coffee and will tell you about it at length if given the opportunity.
"You know what people always talk about?" he said. "The worst such and such they ever had -- 'I had an espresso once and the milk was cold' -- stuff like that."
But Mr. Richer says people also desperately want a good listener. He still remembers a legendary barista he worked with at New World Coffee. The man, Mr. Richer said, had an airtight memory for names, faces, coffee-drink preferences and the often tedious tales told by his customers.
"People developed this intense relationship with the guy," Mr. Richer said. "They were giving him like $25 tips a month for being such a spectacular listener."
Jerry Baldwin, the chairman of Peet's Coffee and Tea in Berkeley, Calif., and a veteran of 25 years in the coffee business, believes that the whole concept of the coffee bar is loaded with contradiction and potential conflict in which the workers, by and large, can come out frustrated.
"Here are these people, going to a special place for a special drink and they want it now," Mr. Baldwin said. "They want a friendly bartender to commiserate with them, but there's big long line behind and you've got to move the goods." Especially in the morning, it can get pretty tense. "If you saw a videotape of staff and a videotape of customers, it would be pretty grim on both sides," he said.
COFFEE-BAR workers say, however, that there is a plateau beyond grumpy customers, a realm of the unspoken sealed relationship of barista and patron in which a regular order need no longer be verbalized.
"They don't even have to say what they want -- we just know," said Nitzan Gilady, a 25-year-old actor who works at Jonathan Morr Espresso Bar in midtown Manhattan, where a corporate army charges in beneath the bar's giant coffee-cup light fixtures every morning. "You can see it in their eyes."
For actors like Mr. Gilady, the food-service industry has always been a way station. But he says the stereotypical New York restaurant waiter hoping for his or her big break has given way among many of his friends to the coffee bars. The bars look for attractive people, and actors look for jobs with flexible hours. He just left Jonathan Morr for a one-month film project. At The Coffee Pot on Manhattan's West Side, more than half the staff -- especially in winter when students go back to school -- is composed of out-of-work actors.
Another general coffee-worker type, baristas say, is the "slacker," defined by Sharon Djemal as "people who haven't really figured out what they want to do, people who still want to be in college -- they still want to hang out with the same people."
Ms. Djemal, 26, says she has "a lot of friends," in this category, but that the label does not define her: she is only making coffee for a season in a midtown Manhattan bar before her first year at Columbia University's law school this fall.
There are also some clear occupational hazards to a life of latte.
Ms. Meyer, a 19-year-old biology major at Barnard College who works in a place in downtown Hartford call Zuzu's (named for Jimmy Stewart's daughter in the movie "It's a Wonderful Life,"), said that when she and her coffee friends all get together, they sometimes "start to slip into the lingo -- you know, 'short, tall, grande.' "
And the fact is that, well, you can actually get sick of the product.
"Actually, I don't smell it anymore, and I don't drink it much anymore, either," said Daniel Fiset, a manager at The Coffee Pot in New York.
Some coffee-bar employees also worry that the big chains, like Starbucks, are reining in the anarchic spirit that, they say, makes individual bars interesting.
"They want the cheeriest, chipperist, most saccharine person you could imagine," Mr. Richer said of the corporate chains. He now works at what he calls a "mom and pop" place called Brewbar.
Of all the coffee bars visited for this article, Starbucks was the only one that prohibited employees from speaking to a reporter, referring all questions to the corporate headquarters in Seattle.
"They have a few strange rules," said a young woman at a Starbucks in Westfield, N.J., after the manager told her to say no more. Asked why she worked there, she shrugged, "It's cool."

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

Monday
 
The Commerce Department reports on June business inventories and business sales. Forecast: inventories up 0.3 percent as unsold goods continue to pile up, but at a slightly slower pace than in May, when they rose 0.4 percent. Sales rose 0.5 percent in May.
 
Comcast is expected to report a second-quarter loss of 8 cents a share, and Kmart, a profit of 11 cents a share.
 
Tuesday
 
The Federal Reserve releases industrial production and capacity utilization for July. Forecast: production down 0.1 percent, following a 0.1 percent increase in June. Utilization is expected at 83.2 percent, down from 83.7 percent in June.
 
Dayton Hudson is expected to report second-quarter earnings of 41 cents a share; Rockefeller Center Properties, 13 cents, and Wal-Mart Stores, 28 cents.
 
Wednesday
 
ALC Communications, which owns the long-distance telephone company Allnet Communications Services, holds a special shareholder meeting to vote on its $1.8 billion merger with the Frontier Corporation. The merger would create the nation's fifth-largest long-distance phone company.
 
The U.S. Department of Energy issues its weekly report on petroleum stocks, production, imports and refinery utilization.
 
The Commerce Department reports July housing starts. Forecast: up 3.2 percent, after falling 0.1 percent in June.
 
Mexico's Finance Ministry reports gross domestic product for the second quarter. The country's finance minister recently predicted that the economy contracted 5 percent to 6 percent during the quarter.
 
Thursday
 
The Commerce Department reports the June trade balance. Forecast: down $10.4 billion, after falling $11.43 billion in May.
 
Friday
 
Baker Hughes releases it survey of the number of active oil and gas drilling rigs.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1112 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI 

 BODY:

Automotive
 
The Long Goodbye
General Motors is finally saying goodbye to Electronic Data Systems. After trying for at least the last year to find a way to profitably separate from its subsidiary, G.M. has decided on a stock swap that will leave E.D.S. in the hands of its shareholders. The computer services company has been a continuing source of minor management headaches since G.M. bought it from Ross Perot in 1984. Mr. Perot joined G.M.'s board of directors and spent years criticizing the company's management until it bought him out for $742.8 million. Earlier this year, G.M. contributed its E.D.S. shares to the automaker's underfunded pension plans, meaning the company received little benefit from owning E.D.S. "Parting," Shakespeare wrote, "is such sweet sorrow." Or maybe just sweet.
 
Music
 
Looking for the Door
In what could be another who-needs-the-headaches deal, Time Warner was said to be in negotiations to sell its 50 percent stake in Interscope Records back to the record company's executives. Interscope has such artists as Tom Jones and gangsta rapper Snoop Doggy Dogg. Time Warner has received a lot of grief, especially from the Republicans, for distributing gangsta rap music because of its violent and sexually degrading lyrics. Selling Interscope is probably the simplest way for Time Warner to escape the controversy. It is unclear whether the Republicans ever complained about Tom Jones.
 
Banking
 
Bank Attracts Very Big Investor
Yo! Who just put down more than $3 million to become a major shareholder of a relatively obscure bank in Trenton, N.J.? O.K., that's not fair because you'd never guess. White Eagle Enterprises, a New Jersey investment group, notified the S.E.C. that it bought 23,100 shares of the Yardville National Bancorp and now owns 7.1 percent, or about 165,100, of its shares. The man behind White Eagle is Sylvestor Stallone, who didn't exactly make his name on Wall Street. But analysts said New Jersey banks are prime takeover targets, so owning a hunk of Yardville may be a good move. This is the man who just signed a three-picture deal with Universal Pictures that was said to be worth more than $60 million. Sounds like there may be more Warren Buffett than Rambo in Mr. Stallone these days.
 
Securities Industry
 
Another Victim at Prudential
First, many of Prudential Securities' customers complained. Now it's the brokers. The company in 1993 settled securities fraud charges that it misled investors about the risks of limited partnerships. The company agreed to set up a $1.4 billion fund to repay the thousands of investors who had lost money. Those partnerships had been sold to them by the brokers of Prudential Securities. One of those brokers, Betty S. Allen who had sold about $12 million worth of the partnerships, had complained to an arbitration panel that all the customer complaints about the partnerships made it impossible for her to find other work in the securities industry. Her lawyer said the sales material for the partnerships that was provided by Prudential to its brokers was misleading. But brokers also got prospectuses, which laid out the pros and cons of the investments. Didn't Ms. Allen read them? Ms. Allen wouldn't comment on that last week. And now she doesn't have to. The arbitration panel awarded her $327,000.
 
Wall Street
 
A Good Start, Spoiled
Netscape Communications, the Internet software company, had a stunning debut on Wall Street Wednesday. The initial public offering was priced at $28 a share, but closed for the day at $58.25, up a dramatic $30.25. A lot of people made a lot of money. But a lot of people lost a lot of money. The issue was so hot, that the size of the offering was increased and still many investors couldn't get stock at the offering price. So they had to buy when the stock began trading. The first trade: $71 a share. And it stayed at around $70 until early afternoon before it started to decline. It then fell almost $7 on Thursday and closed unchanged, at $51.375, on Friday. That's a loss of almost $20 a share since Wednesday's first trade. So, Netscape did have quite a stunning week, no matter from where you look at it.
 
Publishing
 
Turn Off That TV
At first it sounded like refreshing news. Two new studies showed that over the next few years Americans would increase their spending on books and would even be spending more to read then they would on recorded music or home videos. The key word here, of course, is spend. Spending will increase because the cost of books will be going up, but the number of books sold is expected to almost flatten out by 1996. It could be because of electronic publishing, as more books go digital. Then again, maybe the reason will be that in 1996, we all could still be stuck in front of the TV watching the O.J. trial.
 
Tobacco
 
The President Sets an Example
President Clinton came down hard on the tobacco companies last week. He proposed regulations to keep cigarettes away from teenagers. He wants to ban cigarette sales from vending machines and wants tobacco companies to stop brand-name advertising at sporting events. "It is wrong to believe that we can take a voluntary approach to this problem," Mr. Clinton said. How true. When asked if he would voluntarily give up the cigars he occasionally smokes, he said, no, he wouldn't. "I try to set a good example," he said. "I try never to do it where people see. I admitted that I did, I did do it when Captain O'Grady was found because I was so happy. It was a form of celebration." Mr. Clinton might have just added to the traditions of smoking. Cigars are expected after a baby is born. Smoking after sex is a classic icon. And now, having a good smoke after resolving a national emergency. Perhaps that's why amid all the turmoil, analysts continue to say that tobacco stocks are still a wonderful buy.
 
Sports
 
Can Nike Be Far Behind?
It's always interesting to watch capitalism crop up in unlikely places: Vietnam, Russia, England. Yes, England. Money, and lots of it, is about to infect the very English, and amateur, sport of rugby. England's national team is negotiating a $2.4 million deal to sell promotional logo space on its team jerseys, with about a third of the money going to players. And more eye-popping in a sport in which the players often perform for nothing, Rupert Murdoch is paying $500 million to broadcast games from South Africa, New Zealand and Australia. "The whole ethos of rugby has been about sport, about a kind of courtesy, decency and manners," one rugby expert said. Yes, and basketball used to be played with peach baskets.

HEADLINE: Slowly, Survivors Sue Japan for War

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: YOKOHAMA, Japan

 BODY:
It took Song Byung Wook five decades to muster the necessary mix of anger, determination and hope, but this summer he finally decided to sue the Japanese Government for the kidnapping and forced labor that tore him from his family in Korea and left him an alien in a hostile land.
Mr. Song is not alone. A growing number of Koreans, Chinese and even Americans are taking the Japanese Government to court for mistreatment during World War II. In the past few weeks alone, dozens of people from six countries representing thousands of victims -- former sex slaves, forced laborers and even American and British prisoners of war -- have come to Tokyo to file suits in Japanese courts. 
 While some suits have been filed primarily to embarrass the Japanese Government, hundreds of thousands of others could follow if there is any sign of that the suits may succeed.
It is unclear whether the Japanese judges will agree to adjudicate these cases, but the hearings are already capturing public attention and embarrassing the Japanese authorities by spotlighting Japan's abuse of Asians and other foreigners during the war.
Like many of the one million or more Koreans who were made slave laborers in Japan, Mr. Song was abducted from Korea and taken to Japan to provide a labor force during the war years, when most young Japanese men were on the war front.
Mr. Song, a 69-year-old South Korean who now lives in the eastern Japanese city of Yokohama, was forced to smelt iron all day. He survived conditions that claimed the lives of many fellow workers, and after the war he married a Korean woman and remained in Japan, drifting among various jobs and small businesses over the years.
"I don't want to renounce the family I love now, so I would not say my life was totally ruined by the war," Mr. Song said. "But my life has been in shambles."
For decades after the war, he thought there was no hope of redress. Then a few years ago, he met with families of other Korean forced laborers, and together they began talking about the idea of a lawsuit in the Japanese courts.
"I'm not doing it for my unpaid wages, for I gave that up long ago," said Mr. Song, who plans to file his suit in September, together with 10 other Korean families, against Nippon Steel and the Government. "It's not just a matter of winning the suit. It's important to tell the Japanese people about all this."
Former slave laborers are turning to civil suits in part because South Korea and China both renounced rights to any further compensation when they established relations with Japan in the 1960's and 1970's. Now, encouraged by political liberalization and growing recognition of the idea of law, a growing number of victims of World War II are turning to the only avenue that still seems available, the Japanese courts.
Americans like Gilbert M. Hair, a former American internee, are also joining the tide to sue. Mr. Hair visited Tokyo recently to help file a lawsuit on behalf of 30,000 former internees and prisoners of war from the United States, Britain, Australia and New Zealand.
"They treated us worse than animals," he said in a statement. "For this I feel the Japanese Government should be held responsible."
Another suit gathering attention is being brought by survivors of an uprising by Chinese forced laborers at the Hanaoka copper mine in northern Japan. Nearly 1,000 of the workers had been seized in China and forced to work in the mine, where they were at times beaten with leather whips and branded with hot irons.
"We knew we would all soon die, but we figured that if we died in an uprising at least we would die with honor," said Zhang Zhaoguo, a 75-year-old Chinese laborer who returned to Japan to file a lawsuit.
The Chinese mounted an uprising in June 1945, two months before the end of the war, and they killed five Japanese. Thousands of troops were brought in and they hung Mr. Zhang and others by their thumbs from the ceiling. While Mr. Zhang survived, 418 of the Chinese workers died from beatings and torture.
Now Mr. Zhang and 10 other survivors have filed suit against the Japanese Government and Kajima Corporation, which ran the mine and remains today one of the biggest construction companies in Japan.
Many of the lawsuits are jointly filed against the Government and a corporation. Lawyers say that the suits against the Government are unlikely to succeed, but that cases against corporations may stand a better chance. Many Japanese corporations, like Kajima, that do business in Asia may feel obliged to settle to avoid tarnishing their reputations in places like China and South Korea. In general, however, the companies have declined to comment on the cases.
A breakthrough of sorts came recently when the Government endorsed a new private fund to compensate the so-called comfort women, young women and girls who were forced to have sex with Japanese soldiers. This has given encouragement to other victims.
Some former slave laborers, however, are still agonizing over whether to sue, partly because they are reluctant to relive a gruesome past.
Chon Woon Mo, who was kidnapped from his home in Korea 53 years ago, was forced to work in a copper mine and was beaten until he lost all sensation. But he remained in Japan after the war and is still debating about whether to bring a suit.
One reason he is reluctant to file suit is that he remembers good Japanese as well as bad. A Japanese supervisor at the mine where he worked took a liking to him and secretly helped him escape from the labor camp.
Mr. Chon is also restrained by his allegiance to North Korea, which does not have formal ties with Japan. And most North Koreans in Japan are hoping their Government will fight for them and get a financial settlement as part of the normalization of relations with Japan.
As many as 10 percent of the Korean laborers in Japan did not survive their service, according to various Japanese scholars. At some labor camps for foreigners, the death rate was nearly half.
The Government has been extremely reluctant to open its files on the issue and many records were burned, so the true number of deaths may never be known.
"They controlled by violence," said Tadashi Kosho, professor of economic history at Komazawa University. "The Japanese Government must make a proper apology and refund unpaid wages. Without this, Japan cannot co-exist peacefully with other Asian countries. This is not just an issue of responsibility. It is also necessary for the Japanese people."

HEADLINE: Dole Defending Middle Ground In G.O.P. Race

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
These days, almost as many roads lead to Bob Dole's office in the Capitol as to that Oval Office down the street.
Bosnia, Medicare, welfare overhaul, the budget, the ethical troubles of his colleague, Bob Packwood -- all of those subjects and many more traced paths through his shorthand conversations with aides on Thursday as he pressed the Senate toward its summer adjournment on Friday. And without missing a beat, he simultaneously told a visitor about his other current preoccupation, the 1996 Presidential campaign. 
 His message was plain: Republicanism with an ideological edge, a la Gingrich, a la Gramm, was not for him and not, he thought, for the American people. In private, he said, they took a balanced view of Federal programs, recognizing that many were beneficial, "but if you ask them in a big group, they all want to get up and shout about how awful the Government is."
He seemed sufficiently confident about his reading of the electorate to suggest that if he was nominated, Gen. Colin Powell, whom he described as "probably moderate on social issues and fairly conservative on economic and defense issues," would be eminently acceptable as a running mate -- even if party conservatives worry about his views on abortion and affirmative action.
"He's a great guy," Mr. Dole said. "I've been out to see him once, hope to go out and see him again. Just to go out and sit down and talk."
Majority leader (and hence chief traffic cop) in the Senate, vocal champion of the Bosnian Muslims, clear front-runner for the Republican nomination to oppose President Clinton, the 72-year-old Kansan is playing a lot of major roles at once. More, in fact, than anyone in recent memory, more even than Lyndon B. Johnson when he was the nearly omnipotent honcho of the Senate.
It is made no easier, of course, by the reality that the Republicans' majority is too thin to override vetoes or close off debate without Democratic help, or by the fact that three members of his flock, Phil Gramm of Texas, Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, are running against him, or that he is trying ever so hard to hold his famously tart tongue, which has gotten him in big trouble during past national campaigns.
"There's no doubt about it," he said. "We're getting a few darts now."
He thought, early on, about stepping down as leader in favor of his deputy, Trent Lott of Mississippi, Mr. Dole said, but he has decided that he has the tactical advantage where he is now: "In my view, I'm running against Bill Clinton. The rest of the Republicans may be running against me, but as long as I focus on President Clinton, I think it's good to do it from right here."
He has not had any problems with Senator Specter, who grew up in the same small prairie town, Russell, Kan., as Senator Dole did. Senator Lugar is a mannerly, low-key man. But Senator Gramm is a needler, and he clearly riles his leader. Mr. Dole tries to sound indifferent to it all, "If he has to go out and take a shot each day, well, I'm the front-runner."
But then he called attention to one of Mr. Gramm's fund-raising letters, in which the Texas conservative suggested that the Senate was becoming "a black hole for the Contract With America" and urged recipients to send money to help him in "putting Bob Dole's feet to the fire." Mr. Dole, it says, completely failed to "get the message" of the Republicans' victories in 1994.
"I think it was over the edge," said Senator Dole, adding in one of the dismissive asides he is famous for, "I don't think he raised much money."
So far, Mr. Dole has mastered the complicated political calculus of his situation, moving far enough to the right to prevent his more conservative rivals for the nomination from gaining traction but not so far as to make himself look unacceptably extreme should he reach the general election, setting himself apart from Mr. Clinton without seeming merely to obstruct.
On Bosnia, for example, he pushed through a bill calling for an end to United States participation in the United Nations embargo on arms shipments to the Muslims. President Clinton vetoed it Friday, and Mr. Dole says he will try to override the veto. But what, he was asked, if the current search for a peace formula was making progress when it came time for the override vote?
"I think that might make a difference," he said, implying that he would wait if asked. "We waited a whole year before, you know. We don't want to blow up a peace process."
What bothers the social-issue true believers and the hard-core supporters of the Contract With America is precisely the sort of balance Mr. Dole has to maintain if he is to make the Senate work, which he must do if his candidacy is to retain its credibility. Referring to Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the faster-moving House, Mr. Dole said, "No doubt I'm the establishment, and he's sort of the revolutionary." But he insisted that the two get along well.
"It's a strong message, reining in the Government, reconnecting Government," he said. "But I don't think you want to leave people in the audience thinking you're some radical that's going to take them over the edge.
"I've started to stand up, look at the audience and say, 'Everybody in this room has been affected, directly or indirectly, by some Government program.' I see veterans out there. I see senior citizens. I see somebody who may have gone to vocational school. The Government has done many good things.
"It's got to be downsized. It's gotten too big. We spend too much money. But you get into Medicare, that's a hot button, Medicaid, that's a hot button, welfare reform, that's a hot button for a lot of people, too. It's not easy to cut spending, not as easy as making speeches. You can be tough as nails when you make speeches. I've heard a lot of good speeches."
But neither Medicare nor Medicaid had been trimmed, nor had welfare been overhauled, as Senators streamed out of Washington this weekend. They will have to be dealt with as part of the so-called reconciliation bill, in which all the loose budgetary and policy strings are tied up, sometime late this fall. It threatens to be a grand mess -- a train wreck, in the lingo of Capitol Hill.
Nor has Congress passed the line-item veto or regulatory reform. Mr. Dole concedes that the public remains frustrated, and that that could hurt him if he comes to look like part of the problem rather than a potential solution.
"People are still looking for leadership," he said. "They're looking for someone they can have confidence in. Maybe they haven't decided who that is yet. They all want the perfect candidate. They'll never find one."
As for himself, he is not about to apologize for his old-fashioned style.
"I'm not one of these 'in your face, it's got to be my way or no way' kind of conservatives," he said. "People are looking for reality. You have to work with Republicans and Democrats, if you're a Republican President. You've got to make the place run. People want to get things done around here."

HEADLINE: The Perfect Place To Make a Good Cigar;
A Trend Revitalizes the Cigar Industry and a Way of Life in Connecticut

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

DATELINE: BLOOMFIELD, Conn., Aug. 12

 BODY:
They call it tenting.
 Since the 19th century, it has been a hot-weather hallmark of tobacco-growing in the sandy loam of the Connecticut Valley. Now, once again, hundreds of acres of white netting have been deployed to protect delicate tobacco leaves so they can fulfill their destiny as luxury cigars. 
 Three years ago, this practice seemed doomed, along with an entire industry and a 96-year-old way of life. One of the nation's legendary tobacco-growing economies seemed near extinction because demand for its esoteric product was declining along with the popularity of cigars in America.
 Enter, miraculously, cigar mania.
 Sales of premium cigars -- those costing more than $2.50 each -- have jumped 29 percent in the last three years. And improbably, at a time when only 25 percent of Americans smoke -- fewer than at any time since the Government began taking surveys, cigar fervor has saved the tobacco industry in the Connecticut Valley.
 "Business here was dying and now it's thriving," said Edgar M. Cullman, chairman of the Culbro Corporation, corporate parent of the region's chief grower, the General Cigar Company. "Only a few years ago, we'd grow our tobacco, and we'd store our tobacco -- and nobody wanted to buy it. Now? We're expanding our acreage and our labor force."
 Demand has exceeded supply in this region, blessed with the mysterious soil and climate conditions that have turned its tobacco into the platinum of the cigar-making world. Called Connecticut Shade wrapper leaf -- or simply Shade -- the golden brown, unblemished cured tobacco is hand-rolled to become the outer jacket of expensive cigars.
 Shade tobacco is essential not only to the look of some premium brands, but also to their taste. Although Shade accounts for no more than 5 percent of a cigar's weight, the wrapper gives it more than 60 percent of its taste, cigar manufacturers and smokers say.
 "What looked like a dinosaur industry has enjoyed a huge turnaround," said Gov. John G. Rowland, who occasionally partakes of a Shade-wrapped cigar himself.
 Sales of premium cigars are surging as a new generation of affluent men (and a few women) have become cigarophiles, puffing at cigar dinners, traveling to dressy smoke-ins and seeking out restaurants that welcome them.
 Even President Clinton, who allows that he smokes a cigar from time to time, gave cigars a boost last week when he said they would be exempted from his new proposed tobacco restrictions because teen-agers do not smoke cigars.
The cigar boom has been ascribed to everything from the yuppie taste for self-indulgence to white-male backlash to the influence of a popular new high-gloss magazine, Cigar Aficionado.
 Whatever the reason, the resurgence is a renaissance for Shade, so called because the tobacco is grown under the shade of the tenting that was once made of cotton but is now a polymer that lasts four years longer.
 General Cigar's entire 1994 crop, which will not even be ready until 1997, is already sold out. Sales rose 45 percent in 1994 and are up 55 percent so far this year.
 The Connecticut Department of Economic Development estimates the value of cigar agriculture, exclusive of wholesaling and manufacture, at $50 million, and cigar-tobacco cultivation is "now one of the fastest-growing of our agricultural industries," said Rick Macsuga, marketing and inspection supervisor for the State Agriculture Department.
 Mr. Cullman estimated the total economic benefit to Connecticut at $100 million, "and it could have been a billion if the industry hadn't declined," he said. As late as the 1960's, 8,000 acres of wrapper tobacco were grown in the Connecticut Valley; today it is down to 1,700.
 Virtually the entire crop is concentrated in a 20-mile-square area north of Hartford.
 About 125 million cigars will be wrapped from the 1995 crop, Austin T. McNamara, president of General Cigar, said. General Cigar grows 400 acres of cigar tobacco, and much of the rest is grown by independent farmers in a cooperative.
 Growers have tried to cultivate Shade in every nook and cranny of the world, but only four places have the right soil and climate conditions: Cuba, Cameroon, Indonesia and the Connecticut Valley. The same seed, when cultivated in Virginia, Wisconsin, Florida and the Carolinas, has a totally different -- and inferior -- taste.
 Many aficionados prefer Connecticut Shade to any wrapper in the world outside of Cuba; it is illegal to import or sell Cuban tobacco, or cigars, in the United States.
 "There are a lot of people in the state who aren't even aware that we have a world-class product here," Mr. Macsuga said.
 Shade is used to wrap General Cigar's Macanudo, the largest-selling premium brand sold in the United States. (They are made in Jamaica.) Other cigar makers that use Connecticut Shade include Alfred Dunhill, Davidoff and Temple Hall.
 There is much speculation about the cigar-friendly qualities of the conditions in the Connecticut Valley; theories about the origin of the rich soil range from tidal-river overflows to glacial deposits of nutrients. Others say the valley traps moisture from the Connecticut and Farmington rivers, forming a humid, foggy bowl that permits higher temperatures during growing season, even as Connecticut's northern location provides the lower evening and winter temperatures that promote curing.
 Tobacco was grown in the Connecticut Valley by Indians before the arrival of the white man. To duplicate the shaded growing conditions under the forest canopy of tropical jungles, tobacco tenting was introduced in 1899 in Windsor, according to the State Agriculture Department.
 In the 1920's, 31,000 acres of Shade were under cultivation, and as recently as 1964, 177 farms cultivated 8,000 acres and produced 12 million pounds. The number of farms now is about a dozen, and 2.3 million pounds were produced last year.
 The cultivation of Connecticut wrapper is believed to be the most labor-intensive activity in all of agriculture. General Cigar sells its premium leaf for $43 a pound, and the cost for growing and processing it is $26,000 per acre, versus $300 for corn.
 "From the time the seed is in the ground until it's smoked, each leaf is touched 100 times," Mr. McNamara said.
 Seedlings are transplanted to the fields in early June and are tented under acres of cloth, which shades the plants from the direct sun, holds in heat and humidity and discourages insects.
 Picking begins the first week in July. There are six "primings" during the 18-week growing season, where the three most mature leaves are picked by hand from the tobacco plants every few weeks. Workers must pick rapidly while handling the fragile leaves gently.
 The green leaves are threaded onto hanger-sticks called laths, and groups of 48 leaves are then hung 36 feet high in tobacco sheds to be air-cured.
 In the hot, dark sheds, the tiers of leaves are heated with gas burners to a temperature of 104 degrees for more than a week to develop their color and taste. "You can lose a whole shed in a day if it gets too hot or too cold too fast," Mr. McNamara said.
 The leaves are shipped to the Dominican Republic, where skilled tobacco labor is cheap and abundant, to be hand-sorted for quality. After they are cured there for a year, the bales are shipped back to Connecticut for two years of natural fermentation, the "winter sweat," during which the leaves develop flavor.
 Finally, the cycle ends when the bales are shipped to be hand-rolled in Jamaica and the cigars are imported to Connecticut for marketing and distribution.
 This summer, General Cigar is employing about 700 people, mostly local residents, during the growing and harvesting season. "Basically we're working from dawn to dusk these days," said Steve Lipsky, manager of the company's 110-acre Farm 28.
 "Picking tobacco is hard work, and you have to be very careful not to break the leaves," said Emanuel Nieves, a 15-year-old from nearby Springfield, Mass., who, like generations of teen-agers from the tobacco towns, has found a sweaty summer job. The workers are paid a minimum of $5.75 an hour, higher than Connecticut's $4.27 minimum wage; the company pays productivity incentives that can earn workers an extra $125 per week.
 "Because General Cigar uses local workers, there is no exploitation of migrants," said Ann Hodgdon-Cyr, who heads the migrant-worker unit of Neighborhood Legal Services in Hartford. But there has been controversy over the use of migrant workers from Puerto Rico and Jamaica by other growers.
 An industry promoting any kind of smoking is hardly politically correct these days, and the tobacco growers have fallen afoul of the anti-smoking movement because cigars present "risks from cancer of the larynx, mouth and esophagus," said Dr. Michael J. Thun, director of analytic epidemiology for the American Cancer Society in Washington. "Cigar smokers have a 2.5-times-higher rate of lung cancer than lifelong nonsmokers."
 But since smokers of premium cigars do not inhale, and since many of them average fewer than one cigar a day, Marvin Shanken, publisher of Cigar Aficionado, argues that cigars do not have the health and addiction burdens of cigarettes.
 Indeed, Connecticut Shade is being treated with benign neglect these days by Connecticut's anti-tobacco activists. Cigar tobacco "has not attracted our attention because cigars aren't what young kids normally get addicted to," said Robert Farr, a State Representative from West Hartford who has introduced anti-tobacco legislation and coordinated campaigns against youth smoking.
 "We don't view the farmers as evil," Mr. Farr said. "It's a cash crop. Look, the Amish don't believe in smoking, yet they grow tobacco as a cash crop."
 The future of the Connecticut tobacco industry is hardly assured, especially if the United States reaches rapprochement with Cuba. If Cuban cigars are legalized again, the demand for Connecticut wrapper could wane, even though many American cigar lovers prefer the milder, mellower taste of Shade to the powerful full-bodied presence of Cuban wrapper.
 In the Connecticut Valley, though, the future is but the span of a season. "I can tell by the texture of the leaves," said Laura DeGray, a shed supervisor who has worked 33 years in the tobacco fields. "This could be our year."

PERSON: COLLINS, GLENN BILL CLINTON (67%);

HEADLINE: State Agencies Pressed to Trim Spending

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The Pataki administration has begun pressing all state agencies to tighten spending amid concerns that Federal aid may be cut, leaving the state with a gaping hole in its budget.
The state Division of Budget has sent internal memos to all state agency heads directing them to reduce spending immediately and to prepare detailed plans for cutting costs over the next two years, with measures that could include layoffs. 
The state Budget Director, Patricia A. Woodworth, has also sought to reduce overall state spending by 6 percent during the first half of the fiscal year by authorizing agencies to spend only a portion of their quarterly budgets. She said the purse strings may be loosened for some agencies during the second half of the year, but others may face further reductions.
Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican who ran on a pledge to shrink state government, said he would have tried to squeeze agency budgets even further if he thought the state was in robust fiscal health.
Now, he said, there is even greater urgency to reduce spending because the Republican-dominated Congress is likely to cut billions of dollars in aid for health care, welfare and education this fall, which could leave the state with a deficit when its fiscal year ends on March 31.
"Obviously it is a concern," Mr. Pataki said on Thursday. "And it's certainly a reason why we have to be prudent in our approach to spending money."
The Pataki administration's biggest worry is Medicaid, a more than $20 billion program in New York State. Because the program is financed jointly by the Federal, state and local governments, cuts in Federal aid could increase the remaining partners' financial burdens.
One leading Congressional plan would reduce projected Federal Medicaid spending in New York State by about $2.7 billion a year, according to the Health Care Association of New York State, a group representing hospitals and nursing homes. Other plans supported by southern governors would reduce New York's share of Medicaid dollars significantly more.
"We have to be prepared, and that means to the extent we can find ways to give ourselves additional flexibility in the spending plan now, that's better than waiting," Ms. Woodworth said.
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who has already predicted a budget shortfall of $2.7 billion for next year, has warned of other fiscal problems. He said the state's projections include many shaky assumptions, including sales of assets that have yet to be identified and savings that are likely to fall short. There is also a possibility that the economy will weaken, reducing tax revenue, he has said. Income from taxes has already declined because of tax cuts enacted this year that will grow substantially next year.
"I applaud what the Governor is doing in terms of aggressively managing the budget process, even if it means cutbacks for agencies," Mr. McCall, a Democrat, said. "On the other hand, it suggests that two months after hailing this as a great budget, the Governor has realized it might not hang together."
To help in the cutting, Ms. Woodworth and two other Pataki aides, Donald G. Dunn, the first deputy secretary, and James G. Natoli, the director of state operations, are reviewing cost-cutting plans from every agency.
In an Aug. 9 memo to agency heads, Ms. Woodworth recommended that they reduce office supply purchases, renegotiate service contracts, limit travel, consolidate work groups and eliminate programs. She also suggested that managers find cuts that can be made without legislative approval.
Ms. Woodworth and Mr. Pataki said layoffs should be a last resort, but would not rule them out. The state has laid off about 2,400 employees this year, including 489 political appointees.
"If it turns out we have too many employees, then we'll look for the most humane way to approach that issue," Ms. Woodworth said.
Though most departments are developing their plans in private, some information has dribbled out. A recent Health Department memo, for instance, instructed managers to find up to 20 percent in cuts this year and up to 20 percent more next year.
Similarly, a Department of Social Services memo recommended privatizing services, consolidating units and laying off 400 workers over two years. It also called for lowering child-support collection goals, to save on personnel, even though Mr. Pataki recently endorsed aggressive new measures to increase child-support payments.
The preparations have sent new waves of anxiety through a work force already shaken by layoffs, agency consolidations and calls for privatization by the new administration.
"They have the feeling that this government is trying to save on the backs of workers," said Danny Donohue, president of the Civil Service Employees Association, the largest state workers' union. "It makes them wonder every day about their jobs."
Predictably, Democrats have accused Ms. Woodworth of holding back spending in Democratic districts first. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said he believes Mr. Pataki simply wants to cut spending so he can carry over a huge surplus into next year's budget.
But some Republicans, too, have reacted testily to Mr. Pataki's initiatives. In recent comments on an Albany radio station, the Senate majority leader, Joseph A. Bruno, a Rensselaer County Republican whose district contains many state workers, complained that the administration had not explained its plans clearly enough to a frightened work force.
"Every day, it appears there is some other news, another shoe drops," said Mr. Bruno, a close ally of Mr. Pataki. "It just creates concern, panic, anxiety."

HEADLINE: In Unusual Partnership, Farmers Help Safeguard New York Water

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: DELHI, N.Y.

 BODY:
In 1955, when he was 23, David Taylor watched his grandfather's 200-acre farm in Delaware County vanish beneath the rising waters of New York City's newly completed Pepacton Reservoir.
He had planned to take over the farm, and until last year had pursued a claim against New York City for the loss of the dairy business. The claim, locked in 1950's economics at $2,500, had become virtually worthless. 
 Now 63, Mr. Taylor has choked back the deep bitterness he feels toward the city 100 miles to the southeast. In a remarkable turnaround, he and other farmers have become unlikely allies of New York environmental officials as they feverishly seek ways to keep the 19 upstate reservoirs clean.
Mr. Taylor is helping administer a pioneer program, paid for by New York City but run almost entirely by farmers, in which farmers are finding ways to cut the flow of pollution and parasites from their pastures, milkhouses and barns into the reservoirs. In recent years, Federal officials have become concerned that New York's water, although still safe, is being significantly degraded by runoff from barnyards and faulty sewage treatment systems.
Forged from the grass roots, the $35.2 million program is one of the nation's first field tests of the theory that local, flexible efforts to cut pollution can be far more effective than top-down, by-the-book regulation. It is also being held out by Federal agricultural officials as a national model for urban-rural cooperation.
"We've proved that a city can sit down with a bunch of hill farmers and cut a deal," said Dennis Rapp, a former state agriculture official. "Nobody believed that New York City, of all places, would be able to deal with farmers. If it can be done here, it can be done anywhere."
For farmers, the incentive is an average of $75,000 per farm for improvements that cut pollution and, in most cases, improve production, like cement liners that keep the manure in barnyards and grassy buffers that absorb nutrients from animal waste. As Thomas Hutson, a farmer from the Cannonsville watershed, put it, "We've made some changes here that are not only an improvement environmentally, but hopefully will help my bottom line."
Even more significant, perhaps, the farm program has become a major talking point in the negotiations among officials from New York City, the state, and upstate communities over the city's efforts to protect its water and avert a Federal order to build a $6-billion filtration system.
The meetings have been organized by Michael Finnegan, the general counsel to Gov. George E. Pataki, who has previously been viewed as favoring upstate development over the city's efforts to protect the watershed. The talks are aimed at generating consensus by Tuesday so that state officials can approve the city's water protection plan by a Sept. 15 deadline set by the Environmental Protection Agency.
Several participants in the meetings have said that the early success of the farm program has provided a crucial stepping stone for rebuilding trust between New York City and the watershed communities that, for generations, have felt bullied and betrayed.
The improbable partnership between city environmental officials and upstate dairy farmers nearly began as open warfare.
In September 1990, under pressure from the E.P.A., the city issued a 104-page "discussion draft" of proposed revisions to its watershed regulations. Many rules focused on farms, which were seen as contributing a significant portion of the unwanted nutrients and intestinal parasites that have threatened water quality in recent years.
"As soon as I saw page 27, I knew it was going to put us all out of business," Mr. Taylor recalled as he thumbed through a well-worn copy of the watershed plan.
He was taking a break two hours into a monthly meeting of the Watershed Agricultural Council, the 21-member body set up to accept city funds and dole them out for pollution prevention projects. Twenty farmers are on the panel with one representative from the city's Department of Environmental Protection. Mr. Taylor is vice chairman.
Grinning wryly, Mr. Taylor pointed out the most untenable regulations in the 1990 draft, which forbade spreading fertilizer or storing manure within 500 feet of any spring or stream. In Delaware County, virtually every barn was built next to a stream. In the past, milk would have been chilled in the running water. And the green hills are laced with streams and pocked with springs -- the very water sources that attracted city engineers in the first place.
Mr. Taylor, who keeps 120 dairy cows on 368 acres a few miles north of the reservoir that swallowed his grandfather's farm, asked county agricultural agents to help him assess how the rules would affect his property. They put out red flags marking the forbidden zones. "I would have lost 39 percent of my cropland," Mr. Taylor said.
Other provisions gave the city the right to inspect private property, apparently without a warrant. "Our own sheriff can't even do that," Mr. Taylor said.
As upstate politicians forged a coalition to fight the plan, Mr. Taylor and hundreds of frustrated farmers hastily met in school auditoriums to rage against the rules. Some farmers threatened to set their dogs on any city officials who set foot on their land.
"The city had made so many promises when they built the reservoirs," Mr. Taylor recalled. "They were going to settle all the claims, maintain the roads. None of that happened, so this time people didn't believe them. People said, 'You whipped it to us once, but we have good memories. We won't stand for it a second time.' "
Mr. Taylor called on the state for help. Mr. Rapp, at the time deputy commissioner for environmental affairs of the Department of Agriculture and Markets, offered to set up a forum where farmers and city officials could seek some sort of "just peace."
In a series of meetings, the ad hoc task force slowly lowered the temperature of the debate, Mr. Rapp, now a consultant in Albany, recalled.
In part, the meetings were meant to show farmers the links between their fields and herds and the drinking water for 9 million people. Agricultural experts from Cornell University gave slide presentations showing how calves, with their immature immune systems, were reservoirs for cryptosporidium and giardia, two of the parasites of concern to regulators.
Federal and county agricultural experts spoke about the concept of the "whole farm plan," in which outside experts tailor recommendations for each farm. They projected that in 9 out of 10 cases, reducing the flow of pollutants would also boost profits. For example, by partitioning a pasture into sections and rotating herds, grass would be eaten more efficiently, requiring less fertilizer and producing less harmful runoff.
A critical juncture was reached in the spring of 1991, when the farmers invited Albert F. Appleton, the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner, and some of his rule writers and regulators to visit Delaware County's dairies. Their first stop was the farm of David Taylor.
Mr. Appleton, now a consultant at the Regional Plan Association, recalled slogging behind Mr. Taylor, a fourth-generation farmer, as he showed them his fields and pastures -- and the little red flags. "It was all factual, not confrontational," Mr. Appleton said. "He showed us how much land he'd lose. It was fairly clear after that that if we had to ultimately force this, this was going to be really messy."
Talk turned from complaints to solutions.
While upstate politicians continued to attack New York City, printing T-shirts emblazoned with diaper-clad cows, the group of farmers and city officials pushed ahead.
The city's point man became Laurence Beckhardt, whose degree in urban planning lost significance as he got a new education in soil science. Mr. Beckhardt began making thrice-weekly trips to the dairy farms of Delaware County from the Brooklyn apartment where he had once tried raising tomatoes and beans on his terrace. But the trips were worth it, he said, because the barriers between upstate and down began to dissolve.
As the watershed program evolved, farmers insisted that it be run locally, be entirely voluntary, and be financed by the city. In return, the city demanded the right to reinstate stringent regulations if the farmers failed to recruit at least 85 percent of the 550 farmers in the watersheds by the fall of 1997. The farmers did not flinch and a deal was struck.
Mr. Appleton said the hardest challenge was persuading New York City's budget office to approve expenditures for things like grass seed, manure-composting pits and pasture fencing. Finally, the first phase of the project began in 1993 with a $1 million investment spread over 10 farms.
Even harder was the task of Mr. Appleton's successor, Marilyn Gelber, who had to persuade the Giuliani administration to expand the pilot project that was begun under the previous administration.
Ultimately, though, New York City signed a $35.2 million contract with the Watershed Agricultural Council, and as of August, the program was ahead of schedule with nearly 200 farms signed.
With the installation of simple systems like willow saplings to hold river banks and additional fencing to guide herds around fields in a way that cuts pollution, both farmers and water-quality experts are finding that their early goals are being met.
Some environmentalists remain uncomfortable with the unquantified nature of the project. Mark A. Izeman, a lawyer studying the watershed for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said the project has goals for numbers of participating farmers, but not for reductions in phosphorus or other major pollutants.
"Farming is a land use that everyone wants to preserve," he said. "But even with this approach, you still need pollution reduction benchmarks to make it a real success."
But program officials countered that the project has monitoring stations at critical points that will document changes in pollutants and hazardous microbes. Federal funds have begun to flow into the agricultural council for detailed studies of parasites in dairy herds.
Officials from other states and the Federal government have begun visiting the farms. Cities as close as Syracuse and as far away as San Antonio and Des Moines, where water supplies are in agricultural zones, are all closely watching the farm program, Federal officials said.
It may well be that, in the end, the most significant aspect of the project will have nothing to do with science, and a lot to do with integrating a region that for so long has been divided by water.
While just four years ago being in the watershed of one of the reservoirs seemed to be the kiss of death for a farmer, now it appears to be providing a new lease on life, said Thomas Hutson, one of the farmers who had once vowed to set his dogs on any New York City inspector.
"What we've all learned is that there isn't that much of a difference between the down staters and people up here," Mr. Hutson said. "We've found a way to humanize the whole regulation business."
