HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
The Fare to Texas And Other Mysteries

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
STEP right up, folks, and test yourself against the Air Fare Dart Board. It's a game of skill, a game of chance, and best of all, you're never sure if you've won or lost.
Thanks to another fare skirmish last week, we've got an invigorating mix of prices and routes on the board. 
 For advance-purchase fares, we've got New York to Harlingen -- that's in the dry, dusty southern tip of Texas -- for $198 one-way. Too rich for your blood? For $157 -- in the off season -- you can fly instead to London from New York.
And for a little variety, we've got some last-minute fares that rarely go on sale. There's LaGuardia to Chicago's O'Hare for $403 one-way on American, or you could fly instead from Newark to Chicago's Midway airport for $282 on Kiwi Airlines. Westchester Airport to Pittsburgh -- $317 one-way on USAir. Pittsburgh to Boston: $89 on Nations Air.
And a new feature on the dart board: American Airlines is testing new "Cable Saver Fares," which it advertises every Wednesday on a local cable station in Las Colinas, Tex., near Dallas. You could have flown from Dallas to New York this weekend for $129, round trip. That little jaunt on a moment's notice normally costs about $1,200 or more.
Those are the choices on today's dart board, ready for the first throw. Or did you want to ask questions first, say, about why some destinations cost more than others, when fares go on sale and why?
So why does it cost more to fly from New York to Harlingen than it does to fly to London, Brussels or Paris?
Remember that old Economics 101 lecture about supply and demand you slept through in college? When vacations drop off in the fall, more airlines will fly more empty seats between New York and these big European cities than between New York and Harlingen, which attracts little competition.
And since an airline seat is a terrible thing to waste, marketing types try to figure out ways to fill every seat. After all, once the airline decides to put a flight in the air, the cost of serving each additional passenger is almost nil. Lower the price for advance-purchase fares and maybe you can fill up the plane. And after the plane is about two-thirds full -- roughly the industry's break-even point, on average -- every extra fare is gravy. That break-even point can change with the type of aircraft, though, and other things like landing fees at certain airports.
Hey, why are some fares on short routes over $300 and others less than $100?
The main reason is upstart carriers that go into a market convinced that if they lower fares, they can move people out of their cars and onto their planes. With lower costs than the big guys, they can turn a profit more easily. But without competition, established airlines often charge whatever they can get away with.
Experts who track air fares, like Robert W. Harrell at American Express, will tell you about the 80-20 rule for short-haul air fares. On some routes, passengers pay about 80 cents a mile, so that a 300-mile hop can cost about $240. But low-fare carriers often charge about 20 cents a mile, so the same distance on a different route might cost you $60 or so. This 80-20 guideline breaks down on longer trips, because the cost of flying one mile drops as an airline is able to spread out the cost of the airport fees and the like over a longer trip.
These fare wars are confusing. What's going on?
Basically, the window they give you to buy the fares is now typically measured in days rather than weeks. But you can buy discounted tickets for travel months in advance -- this last fare sale was for trips right up to Dec. 15. The experts will tell you to jump if the discount is about 35 to 40 percent. Anything less, wait until the weather changes.
Don't be so convinced that you're getting a great deal even with the sale. Tom Parsons, who publishes Best Fares magazine, said he's counted at least 25 fare increases in the last three years.
And then there are all those hidden charges. The fine print in an American Airlines ad last week noted that taxes and fees of up to $38 are not included in the international fares.
Is anything being done to simplify fares?
American Airlines, in a widely reported break with tradition, tried it three years ago with Value Pricing, but that effort crumbled into that wonderful half-off fare war that lasted for weeks.
The latest person to try to add some sense to the system is Kevin Mitchell, who started Business Travel Contractors Corporation. He wants to help big companies cut special deals with airlines for fares based on the length of the trip. Imagine that. Who knows whether that will help the rest of us?
Why do fare sales advertise one-way tickets based on round-trip purchases?
Practically everybody sells things that way. See your shoes? You paid $35 for the left one, but the store made you pay another $35 for the right one. It should make perfect sense.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Fortune Cookie: Your Ignorance Clouds Asian Joy

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
WHEN America ordered Japan 50 years ago to surrender or face "prompt and utter destruction," the Japanese Government responded with the word "mokusatsu."
The Japanese Prime Minister claimed later, perhaps disingenuously, that he meant this to mean an ambiguous "no comment." But American translators took it as a firm rejection, based on the more common definition, "ignore, treat with silent contempt." President Truman immediately gave the go-ahead for dropping the atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and then Japan surrendered on Aug. 15, 1945. 
 If there really was a misunderstanding over "mokusatsu," it was one of the most lethal in the history of miscues. Yet looking back at the half-century of American involvement in Asia since the end of the Pacific war, what is most striking is the pattern of lethal miscues.
 
Gulf of Ignorance
 The Vietnam War in particular is now seen as flowing from a tendency to misinterpret nationalism as largely Soviet-inspired Communism. Americans have traditionally shown a far richer knowledge of the china that they eat on than the China that is the most populous nation on earth.
Half a century later, American ignorance of Asia remains a greater problem than ever. Asia is almost certainly going to be more integral to America's future than it has been during the last 50 years, for it has a weight of population and wealth and arms that are likely to leave the rest of the world in the dust. Even Indonesia, which most Americans think about for approximately 15 seconds a year, now has a population of 190 million and is projected to have nearly as big a population as America by the middle of the next century.
In economic terms, tiny Hong Kong is now richer per capita than its former colonial master, England. Japan has more savings than any country in the world, its banks are the biggest on the globe, and if the yen appreciates 20 percent more it will nominally push the United States aside to have the biggest gross national product in the world. In any case, although the United States has had the biggest economy in the world for more than 100 years, many economists believe that if output is adjusted for international prices, then China will surpass the United States within a generation or so.
"This part of the world is going to grow in importance," said Walter F. Mondale, the American Ambassador to Japan. "It's going to grow in wealth and in strategic and political significance."
Yet while Asia has never been so important to the United States, and by almost all measures will be more important to Americans in the next half-century than Europe will be, Asia remains remote and alien in the American mind, except in pockets on the West Coast that have linked themselves to trade and investment with Asia. Over all, however much America's future lies across the Pacific, America remains psychologically an Atlantic nation.
Mutual ignorance has fostered misperceptions ever since Asia and the West discovered each other. In the 19th century, when the first Japanese visited America, they noticed that American women wear high-heeled shoes. So they wrote home that American women have heels that do not touch the ground, like dogs.
More recently, Vietnam was an American conflict as well as an Asian one. It was not until this year that the United States was able to reach out and recognize the Communist Government of Vietnam -- paradoxically, a regime that has less legitimacy today than in the days when American planes were bombing it. Yet that too has a certain symmetry, for when the recognition came it reflected almost exclusively American reasons, including excitement at the opportunities in Vietnam's economy.
 
'Rorschach Blot'
 "Asia is sufficiently far away and exotic enough to Americans that it becomes a Rorschach blot on which they perceive their greatest hopes and worst fears," said William H. Overholt, a managing director of Bankers Trust who has lived in and followed Asia for a decade.
One gauge of American understanding of Asia is simply the flow of students. Some 250,000 Asians are studying in the United States, while about 7,000 Americans are studying in Asia.
Likewise, most American high schools do not offer Asian languages as an option, and much of American education still seems to follow the thinking of a Texas Governor, James "Pa" Ferguson, who in 1917 vetoed a bill to finance the teaching of foreign languages in classrooms. He explained: "If English was good enough for Jesus, it's good enough for the schoolchildren of Texas."
In contrast, under the rule of Communist hard-liners in Beijing, rundown junior high schools in even the most remote Chinese villages teach English to barefoot peasant students as a requirement beginning in the seventh grade.
To be sure, Americans have never misunderstood Asian countries so disastrously as some Asians themselves. No Westerner ever misinterpreted the situation in China as catastrophically as Chairman Mao did at the end of the 1950's, when he launched policies that produced the worst famine in world history, killing some 30 million people.
China understands even less of the American political process than America understands of its. Chinese leaders periodically make what seem to Westerners to be breathtakingly inane statements about conspiracies by America and Britain to divide, conquer and weaken China. One reason China has repeatedly shot itself in the foot over its policy toward Hong Kong is that it interprets every British move as part of a grand conspiracy to ruin Hong Kong.
China and other countries sometimes do their best to be incomprehensible. The great emperor Qianlong in 1793 ordered, "Be sure to prevent any contact between the barbarians and the population," and it sometimes seems the order has never been rescinded. If Americans know next to nothing about the Chinese peasantry -- who account for one person in six on this planet -- that is in part because the Chinese Government restricts access to the countryside.
In studying how America can prepare for a Pacific century, it helps to consider the one country that has really managed to re-tune itself from Europe to Asia. If America is looking for a model, it is Australia. At the beginning of the 1980's, Australia was a European country that happened to be located at the tip of Asia; now it in many ways is an Asian country of European stock.
The Government made a major push to emphasize the teaching of Chinese, Indonesian, Japanese and Korean, and 180,000 Australians are now studying Japanese -- more than three times the number of Americans who study Japanese. On a per-capita basis, 50 times as many Australians study Japanese as Americans do. In the Australian State of New South Wales, Asian languages are taught even at most elementary schools, and by 2010 every student from kindergarten through high school will be studying foreign languages.
Australia has also recruited Asian university students, so that 10 percent of those studying on Australian campuses are now foreigners. More Indonesian and Singaporean students go to Australia than to any other country.
The economy down under has also been redirected, with 63 percent of Australia's exports now going to Asia. Australian companies are investing in Indonesia and other neighbors, and Japanese now flock to Australia's Gold Coast to play golf, snorkel, and eat beef; you can buy a calf in Australia for the price of a good steak in Tokyo.
Australia shows that it is possible for a meat-and-potatoes country to boost its ties to and understanding of the chopstick belt. Of course, Asia too needs to try to understand the West and especially to make itself a bit more transparent. But the question for America, looking back at the price it has paid in the last half-century for its misunderstandings of Asia, is whether it too is ready to try harder in the next half century.

HEADLINE: New Watchdog Group Ranks Nations in 'Corruption Index'

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Everyone in global business, diplomacy or even charitable organizations is familiar with the problem of corruption. But in a world where one person's bribe is somebody else's commission, corruption can be as hard to prove as it is to combat.
Two years ago a group of people with experience in international agencies and business who saw the need for a worldwide lobby against corruption formed a research and advocacy body they called Transparency International. This year the group published its first Corruption Index, a poll of polls that takes a tentative step toward ranking the world's most corrupt and least corrupt countries. 
 Using seven surveys made by risk analysts and business organizations, Transparency International, based in Berlin, ranked 41 countries -- mostly in Asia, Europe and the Americas -- from least to most corrupt in the opinion of people who have tried to work with them.
Cleanest of all was New Zealand, one of only four countries to score above 9 on a scale from 1 to 10. Close behind were Denmark, Singapore and Finland. The United States, with a score of 7.79, trailed most northern European countries and Chile. But Americans did better than either the French or the Japanese.
At the bottom -- most corrupt -- end of the scale, with scores below 3, were Indonesia, China, Pakistan, Venezuela, Brazil, Philippines, India, Thailand and Italy.
The collation and analysis of the seven admittedly often impressionistic surveys was done for Transparency International by Johann Graf Lambsdorff of the University of Gottingen in Germany. Mr. Lambsdorff, an economist, said in a telephone interview from Germany that Transparency International was beginning its own survey this year and building its own data base.
This weekend the organization is opening an address on the Internet's World Wide Web to solicit personal experiences of corruption from people working for international organizations. (The address is http:// www.gwdg.de/ uwvw/icr.htm -- or Transparency International, Heytstrasse 33, D-10825 Berlin.)
Mr. Lambsdorff said that Transparency International was primarily looking for corruption in government and public life, but that methods of doing business, public or private, were closely related to social and cultural patterns of behavior. He wants to know about these also.
"There are so many different systems of corruption, or cultures of corruption, established in the world," Mr. Lambsdorff said. Sometimes corruption is not measured only in payoffs or kickbacks but also in the way personal, family or ethnic relationships are used. In many places, some of these behavior patterns are not considered unethical, even if a government tries to make them illegal.
The Far Eastern Economic Review, Asia's leading news and business magazine, explores some of these issues in its Aug. 10 issue. Polling 3,000 executives in Asia, it found that more than a third of business leaders in Malaysia, Indonesia, South Korea and Thailand said they would rather bribe a customer than lose a big sale. In Singapore, where anti-corruption laws are tough and effective, about a quarter of executives polled still said they would prefer a bribe to failure.
Despite cultural differences, Mr. Lambsdorff said, "if I compare all the surveys, it is quite striking that they are highly correlated, as high as 90 percent." He said that the surveys he used cannot be seen as statistical proof that one place is more corrupt than another, "but among people with experience there is a certain pattern of ranking."

HEADLINE: Iraqi Defector Says He Will Work to Topple Hussein

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 12

 BODY:
A son-in-law and top aide of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq who defected to Jordan this week vowed today to work to topple the Government in which he played a major role for more than a decade.
The man, Lieut. Gen. Hussein Kamel, was a chief arms procurer and senior decision-maker for the Iraqi Government for more than a decade, during which time Iraq entered wars against Iran and Kuwait. He defected to Jordan this week, along with his brother, who is another son-in-law, and their wives and families. 
 "We will work inside Iraq and in the whole Arab world to topple the regime of Saddam," he said.
Asked whether he has begun meetings with American military and intelligence officials who are reported to have flown to meet him in Amman, General Kamel declined to confirm that such meetings have taken place or that there had been any pledges that he would turn over Iraqi secrets to foreign countries. He contended that his only goal is to bring down the Iraqi Government.
"There have been no American contacts yet," he said. "We will try to get support primarily from Arab nations." He added that "we will not reveal any secrets unless it is in the interest of Iraq."
General Kamel spoke in a calm, self-assured style at a news conference in the Little Palace inside the royal court complex of King Hussein of Jordan. He said he decided to defect after failing to persuade his father-in-law to reform his policies, which the General said had led "to the total isolation of Iraq."
He declined to reveal information about the inner workings of the Saddam Hussein Government or to comment on the reportedly lavish lifestyle of its leaders. But he warned that his silence over personal secrets of Saddam Hussein and the reported financial abuses of his relatives and sons "will be broken" if Baghdad continued to attack him personally, as it has done since Thursday.
Baghdad's official media today described General Kamel as a "traitor," "coward," and a "thief" who stole millions of dollars.
In remarks broadcast live in Jordan and elsewhere in the Arab world, General Kamel said, "We call upon Iraqi army officers and the Republican Guards, the special Guard forces, civil servants and the Iraqi society to get ready for this important change of turning Iraq into a modern state, dealing with the international community with realism and with the Arab world with friendship to remove differences and get rid of whoever is impeding our march toward progress."
He said the Iraqi regime is "dealing with its isolation in a very wrong way characterized by executions, arrests and doing great harm to the people, which further increases its plight." He said that families of soldiers who died in the country's wars were not getting the financial support due them and that other families cannot find basic foodstuffs, clothing or essential medicine.
The country is under international sanctions, imposed by the United Nations since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990, which have apparently caused severe hardship.
"We will work seriously to change the regime in Iraq and we have initiated contacts inside and outside Iraq immediately," Mr. Kamel said. But he did not offer specifics about which countries or Iraqi opposition parties he may have contacted.
The General, denied that he had been an integral part of the decision-making process when Iraq used poisoned gas to kill thousands of Kurdish villagers and Iranians and carried out brutal repression of uprisings by Shiite Muslims and Kurds, saying that he had been a constant critic of such practices.
Mr. Kamel stopped short of condemning Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990, another decision in which he participated as a senior official. In answer to a question on whether the invasion was an error, he said. "We are not looking at mistakes, but we look at lessons from these experiences and to adopt whatever is right in the future."
He said that the various positions he has held in the Iraqi Government, including running Iraq's oil industry, atomic research, missile and weapon acquisitions and reconstruction after the war clearly made him fit to take command of Iraq after his father-in-law was toppled.
The General, who is a cousin of President Saddam Hussein and is married to the Iraqi leader's eldest daughter, Raghad, was joined at the podium by his brother, Saddam, a commander of Iraq's missile force who fled with him. But Saddam Kamel stood silently throughout the conference. General Kamel said his priority now was "to establish contacts with Iraqi officials and nonofficials inside and outside Iraq," adding that he will also initiate contacts with the international community only with the purpose "of lifting the embargo and sanctions."
He seemed to leave a little room for some entente by refusing to attack President Hussein or his two sons, Uday and Qosai, personally despite numerous reports that Uday Hussein had taken over many of the General's responsibilities over the past year.
"I never had bad relations with Uday or Qosai on personal matters," he said. "The sensitivity between us grew from my constant criticism of the management of the country."
General Kamel said he left Iraq for the nearly 700-mile-long trip to Amman in an official convoy of cars and that the escape had been accomplished without a hitch.
"I left naturally because I am a well known person in Iraq," he said. "I don't think any group of soldiers or border guards would even think of stopping me. We had many cars, a large entourage and several security personnel and we entered Amman naturally." His assertion was confirmed by Jordanian officials.
But General Kamel says that things have changed radically since his departure on Tuesday. He said today that he understands that Republican Guards units have been deployed all over Bagdhad.
But he also contended that various segments of the army and the secret police were bound to understand the meaning of his departure and mobilize to fight the regime.
When asked why he did not choose to stay inside Iraq, using his privileged position and immense power to engineer a coup against his father-in-law, General Kamel said he did not want to work in secret because it would constitute treason and conspiratorial behavior. "I preferred to go outside and work in the open," he said.
Arab officials have suggested, however, that General Kamel had lost much of his power and had in effect been dismissed from virtually all his posts before his defection.
 Mr. Kamel dismissed any talk of an Iraqi retaliation against Jordan for granting him and his party asylum, saying the condition of the Iraqi economy and army would not allow any military action against Jordan, which he said would be a suicidal move. "If Iraq could attack Jordan, it would have done so, but the reality is that it cannot," he said.
 He also left the strong impression, which was not confirmed by Jordanian officials, that he has the Jordanian King's support and approval in his effort to topple Saddam Hussein. On several occasions he suggested he may live and work out of Amman, but he also left the door open for a move to another Arab country.

General Kamel, once a senior aide to the Iraqi President, spoke at a news conference in Amman. Standing at right was a security guard. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Flat Wages Seen as Issue In '96 Vote

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Wage stagnation, which has persistently held down the living standards of tens of millions of Americans, is finally emerging as a big economic issue for both Democrats and Republicans as the 1996 election campaign gets under way.
The Clinton Administration, in particular, is pushing the issue, convinced that by emphatically recognizing the problem, the Democrats can win back votes lost to Republicans in last November's Congressional election. And both parties recognize that wage stagnation is at the heart of the debate over the budget. 
 "You need to make wages a major campaign issue," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chief of the President's National Economic Council. She noted that President Clinton frequently refers to wages in his speeches and public remarks. He argues that he has presided over the revival of the economy and the creation of millions of new jobs, and that the task now is to create a strategy to make wages grow again.
"If the Republicans are speaking of this problem, we identified it for them," Ms. Tyson said.
The Republicans are certainly speaking of the problem, and a common response is emerging from party leaders: that Mr. Clinton lacks a solution to the problem. "If he is suggesting that he is politically impotent on this huge issue," said Tony Blankley, a spokesman for Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, "then he is opening himself up to the argument that he should hand over the Presidency to someone who isn't impotent."
The problem with wage stagnation as a campaign issue is that there is no ready solution. And campaign issues without ready solutions do not easily sway voters, says James Carville, President Clinton's chief strategist in the 1992 election, who coined the slogan, "It's the economy, stupid."
It's not that Mr. Carville fails to recognize the importance of wage stagnation. "I defy anyone who studies American history 100 years from now to say that affirmative action or abortion were more important than wage stagnation," he said. "In all honesty, wage stagnation is a hard thing to grasp and blame someone for."
Wage stagnation, actually a 20-year-old phenomenon, means that the wage of the typical, or median, American worker has basically stayed unchanged, once a discount is made for inflation. That has been the case whatever the measure: individual hourly wages, weekly wages, or family income, according to Labor Department data.
When prices go up as fast as wages, Americans are left without the wherewithal to improve their living standards, dashing the traditional American dream. Only upper-income people, those who earn more than $80,000 a year, have kept ahead of inflation, while at the other end of the income spectrum, below $30,000, the typical worker's wage has lost ground.
Although the problem has been plaguing Americans for years, it is just now rising to the level of a major campaign issue, in the absence of other compelling economic problems, like those that existed in 1992, when Mr. Clinton challenged George Bush for the Presidency.
A recession had just ended. The unemployment rate was much higher than it is today, and during the Bush years the work force had failed to grow. Promising to revive the economy and to create millions of jobs, Mr. Clinton hammered away at his opponent for failing on these counts. And he won.
Nearly three years into the Clinton Administration, these issues seem neutralized. The work force has grown by more than 7 million jobs, as Mr. Clinton often reminds the electorate. Economic growth, while not sufficiently robust for Mr. Clinton to claim boom times, is not so weak that the Republicans can easily accuse the President of hard times.
"Absent a recession, which is possible, the economy will tend to create a close election," said Ray Fair, a Yale economist who studies voter reactions to economic issues.
But the economic revival has failed to revive wages. Quite the contrary, four years into the recovery, the wage problem has worsened in some ways.
This year, not only wages but total compensation, including benefits, are failing to keep up with inflation. Before, when companies added up what they paid in wages and benefits, like health care and pensions, the total has usually exceeded the inflation rate. The lag in total compensation is the first since the last recession.
"Middle-class squeeze may be a better descriptive phrase for what is happening than wage stagnation," said William Kristol, a former adviser to Republican candidates and now editor of The Standard, a conservative magazine. He said the 1996 campaign might offer an opportunity to address the problem. "If the economy stays in reasonable shape," he said, "you could get a substantive debate over the competing solutions to wage stagnation and the social problems that go with it."
That would not be an easy debate. Wage stagnation hovers in the background of the budget furor, but voters need skills in economics to connect the two and make a judgment.
The Clinton Administration argues, for example, that wages will continue to stagnate if the Republicans succeed in trying to balance the budget by eliminating such items as federally financed job training, tax incentives for education, Head Start programs and subsidized student loans. All of these programs lead to a more skilled work force, the Administration argues, and eventually higher wages.
The Republicans insist that a balanced budget in itself will push up wages over time. A balanced budget means less borrowing by the Government from the pool of national savings. Less Government borrowing frees up money for companies to borrow, at lower interest rates. And these borrowings, invested properly, generate jobs in an expanding economy and ever-higher pay.
No one knows which approach is right or whether the problem requires some other tonic -- much stronger economic growth, for example, or more powerful unions, or a lower capital gains tax. Professional economists can be found advocating each viewpoint.
"Unfortunately or fortunately, people do not vote on economic theories, but on results, and they are not getting them," said Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, who is working with White House strategists to make wage stagnation a big campaign issue. "They sought results in 1992 and 1994 and they are going to keep looking."
The frustration could bring noneconomic issues to the fore. Senator Bob Dole's strategists think so, and he is the front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination.
"The 1996 election will be a referendum on President Clinton's Presidency," said William Lacey, who is Mr. Dole's deputy campaign chairman. "And in that referendum, Dole will be seen as superior in terms of Presidential leadership and character."
President Clinton, on the other hand, plugs away at making wage stagnation a main issue. Endorsing federally sponsored affirmative-action programs in a speech last month, he argued that rising resentment against minorities is really resentment that incomes have stagnated.
What would be more appropriate, he said, "would be an honest debate about how we all got into the fix we are in, and what we are all going to do together to get out of it."

HEADLINE: Stray Bullet Hits a Girl, 3, Walking Home in the Bronx

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
A 3-year-old girl who was walking home with her mother early yesterday in the Bronx was shot in the back and seriously injured by a teen-ager who was aiming at a man he had argued with earlier in the evening, the police said.
The girl, Aungahne Williamson, who was listed in critical but stable condition last night at Lincoln Hospital, had been taken by her mother, Nicole Woods, to sleep over with Ms. Woods's sister-in-law in the Mott Haven section. 
 But after midnight the girl began to cry, and her mother was called to pick her up, said Stacey Woods, Ms. Woods's sister. As Ms. Woods was walking with her daughter along East 143d Street, she met three men she knew at the corner of Brook Avenue, and they offered to escort her back to her apartment on East 140th Street.
What Ms. Woods did not know, said Capt. Richard Ward, a detective at the 40th Precinct, is that one of the men had been in a heated argument about a woman earlier that evening with a youth from the neighborhood, Jose Rivera, 19.
At about 2:30 A.M. as the men set out with Ms. Woods and her daughter for their apartment, Mr. Rivera happened to walk by, pulled out a .38-caliber revolver and fired at the man he had fought with, Captain Ward said.
The bullet instead struck the girl, who was about seven feet away from the intended target, in the lower back.
Stacey Woods said that seconds before the shooting, as Mr. Rivera stopped on the street, some of the men in the group realized what was about to happen and started to run, as did Ms. Woods and her daughter. Ms. Woods said that Aungahne "was running but then she started to cry." She added, "And then Nicole looked down and saw the hole in her shirt."
Mr. Rivera fled after the shooting. "I felt that Mr. Rivera knew he missed his target and hit the girl," Captain Ward said. "That's why he fled the scene." Following tips about street nicknames, officers from the 40th Precinct arrested Mr. Rivera at 10 A.M. yesterday in his apartment at 605 East 138th Street, where they said he was sleeping with the .38-caliber revolver tucked under his pillow. Captain Ward said that five bullets remained in the six-bullet chamber.
Mr. Rivera, who is unemployed and does not have a prior record, was identified in several lineups and was expected to be charged with attempted murder, felonious assault and criminal possession of a weapon.
Stacey Woods said late yesterday that Aungahne, who was being kept in the intensive-care unit, was conscious and talking, but that she did not understand what had happened to her.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE RICHEST -- The Richest and Poorest Blocks in Queens;
Where the City Looks More Like The Suburbs

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Summer mornings are quiet in Douglas Manor, a hamlet of country living within New York City lines. Crickets chorus, a lawn mower whines and, on this particular morning, a water truck rumbles along the winding narrow streets and stops outside 315 Arleigh Road. The doorbell rouses the McEleavy family just after 9 A.M. 
 The water man unloads the usual: five five-gallon glass jugs of Mountain Valley Spring Water, bottled at the source in Hot Springs, Ark., and delivered at $14.50 a piece in one of the swankiest sections of Queens.
In Douglas Manor, a peninsula on Little Neck Bay and one of a few elite enclaves in Queens, like Malba in Whitestone or Forest Hills Gardens, life seems more Long Island than New York City. But residents pay city taxes, can send their children to city schools and rely on city services, even if some won't drink city water.
According to an analysis of 1990 Census data prepared for The New York Times by the sociology department at Queens College, a rectangular strip in Douglas Manor, framed by Arleigh, Beverly, Shore and Douglas Roads, is the borough's wealthiest swatch. Houses on average are worth more than $500,000. Average household incomes exceed $130,000. In what was once a Protestant community, religious backgrounds now vary.Its residents, almost all white, are mostly professionals and civil servants.
But the strip, with about 140 homes, is indistinguishable from the other three-quarters of the neighborhood. Throughout, the architecture is eclectic: Dutch colonial, Italian villa, Spanish hacienda and more. By Queens standards, homes are palatial. A few face the waterfront, others the lush marshland of the Udall's Cove wildlife preserve. Each household pays $425 a year to the Douglas Manor Association, which owns and maintains the shoreline, employs a security patrol and manages the pier, where any resident can moor a boat.
Residents say what they enjoy most about the neigbhorhood is not its status. It is more of a sanctuary, they say.
Nick Ansanelli, 35, a pharmacist who moved with his wife and parents to Douglas Manor from Astoria last year, says he has seen the best and the worst of his native borough. "The quality of life deteriorated in New York City over the years because of vandalism, theft, graffiti," he says.
Mr. Ansanelli says he watched neighborhoods like Astoria and Jamaica -- which includes the poorest districts, according to the Census data -- lose their splendor as they became rental communities with many absentee landlords. Zoning laws prevent multi-unit residences in Douglas Manor, where only a handful of homes are rented. And there are no sewers -- each house has a cesspool -- so, for now, developing apartments is impossible.
"This is a piece of country in the city," says Bob Unger, 50, retired after 25 years as a city police detective. "If you find something like this, you stay in the city."
Routine life centers around the Douglaston Club at 600 West Drive. Founded in 1918 in a mansion built in 1732, the club has five tennis courts, a swimming pool, a bowling alley and 300 member families. Membership is by invitation; jackets are required after 5 P.M. Monthly dues are $90. Swimming and tennis cost extra.
At the McEleavy home, June McEleavy cares for the children -- ages 18, 13 and 5 -- and studies nutritional counseling. Her husband, Joe, owns a Long Island medical supply company."All the kids here swim, they sail and play tennis," Mrs. McEleavy says. "It sounds very elitist, but it really isn't. I consider this a working-class neighborhood. There are a lot of two-income families." DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

HEADLINE: COPING;
Jury Duty, Part Two: The Fight on Lenox Avenue

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
THE STORY the jury heard began well after midnight one mild morning last February. We were told by Augustine Diaz, 43, unemployed, that he and James Mitchell, homeless, had been thrown out of the Harlem apartment they shared with Rosa Rodriguez, 43, unemployed, after a squabble, perhaps over the crack they smoked. They left with Mr. Diaz's television set in a shopping cart.
On Lenox Avenue, Mr. Diaz and Mr. Mitchell encountered Jonathan Smith, 37, unemployed, who had been socializing and was losing his buzz from at least four beers, perhaps eight. 
 They took a meeting. Mr. Diaz said he need $20 from the sale of the television set -- he told the jury it was for cab fare to his mother's Bronx apartment and a flop for Mr. Mitchell -- and Mr. Smith offered to help him get it for a commission of anything over $20.
The partnership unraveled when Mr. Diaz wanted to accept a $20 offer and Mr. Smith wanted to look for a better deal. They began pulling at the shopping cart. Mr. Diaz is 5 feet 5 inches and 130 pounds and Mr. Smith is 6 feet, 225. During the struggle, Mr. Diaz fell against a restaurant door and opened an eight-stitch gash in his forehead. They moved away from the cart and continued scuffling. Mr. Mitchell jumped on Mr. Smith's back.
Tonya Johnson, 29, unemployed, came out of the shadows and made off with the cart. Mr. Diaz testified he heard Mr. Smith shout something at Ms. Johnson, which Ms. Johnson testified were instructions to take the cart. She said she knew Mr. Smith from seven months of sharing crack once or twice a week. Mr. Smith told us that he did not shout at Ms. Johnson, that he did not know her, and that he did not use drugs.
Mr. Mitchell tried to chase Ms. Johnson, but, according to Mr. Diaz, he was blocked by Mr. Smith -- "held at bay" was how Ms. Johnson described it. In any case, she escaped, and Mr. Smith took off. Mr. Diaz was bleeding profusely, and Mr. Mitchell called 911 for an ambulance. The four came together again within 10 minutes when police officers arrested Ms. Johnson and Mr. Smith.
Mr. Mitchell soon disappeared, but Mr. Diaz, Mr. Smith and Ms. Johnson were reunited two weeks ago in the court of Justice Leslie Crocker Snyder, whose resemblance to Candice Bergen was deliberated by the jury during the period in which we were not allowed to discuss the case. Judge Snyder, brisk, friendly, in firm control without seeming capricious or authoritarian, was one reason jury duty was such a satisfying experience. But it was troubling as a human story.
We were 12 middle-class people, 11 white, most working, making judgments about lives we did not fully understand. Everyone in the case was a drug or alcohol abuser, all but Ms. Johnson said they were on public assistance.
Mr. Diaz had been a long-haul trucker before being shot in a robbery, Ms. Rodriguez had an undergraduate degree in psychology.
They all had police records, and Ms. Johnson was in prison, after pleading guilty to this robbery and another crime. So why was our time, not to mention the scarce resources of the criminal justice system, being spent on a case about some crackheads fighting over a $20 television set?
We never talked about that. It was a thrillingly serious jury that focused on reasonable doubt, credibility and the meaning of the charges against Mr. Smith, two counts of second-degree robbery, which involves force.
We eventually decided that we couldn't speculate that Mr. Smith already had robbery in mind when Mr. Diaz was hurt but that it was in his mind when he prevented Mr. Diaz and Mr. Mitchell from chasing Ms. Johnson and the set. We found him guilty on one charge.
But we were frustrated. There were so many questions we wanted to ask.
Mr. Smith's defense seemed flabby, yet the prosecutor's case seemed less than airtight. Both lawyers floated divertingpossibilities that drifted off like soap bubbles. They were advocates, not truth seekers, and we were accomplices in a system that rewards superior advocacy.
In the Age of O. J., one worries whether the last word is really the jury's or something the jurors were fed.
But we accepted the deal and got into the process and fulfilled our mission. When it was over, Justice Snyder came back to the jury room and thanked us for our time and said she wanted to explain why such a minor event deserved four days and so many people and such effort. As we knew, Mr. Smith had three prior felony convictions. He was someone to whom the system needed to pay serious attention.
A member of the jury appropriately thanked Justice Snyder for being a model of humanity and professionalism, and we all left in time for dinner.
As foreman, I felt good about what we did and how we did it. The bubbles of doubt and guilt the lawyers blew have popped. But the questions about the system float on.

HEADLINE: COPING;
Jury Duty, Part Two: The Fight on Lenox Avenue

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
THE STORY the jury heard began well after midnight one mild morning last February. We were told by Augustine Diaz, 43, unemployed, that he and James Mitchell, homeless, had been thrown out of the Harlem apartment they shared with Rosa Rodriguez, 43, unemployed, after a squabble, perhaps over the crack they smoked. They left with Mr. Diaz's television set in a shopping cart.
On Lenox Avenue, Mr. Diaz and Mr. Mitchell encountered Jonathan Smith, 37, unemployed, who had been socializing and was losing his buzz from at least four beers, perhaps eight. 
 They took a meeting. Mr. Diaz said he need $20 from the sale of the television set -- he told the jury it was for cab fare to his mother's Bronx apartment and a flop for Mr. Mitchell -- and Mr. Smith offered to help him get it for a commission of anything over $20.
The partnership unraveled when Mr. Diaz wanted to accept a $20 offer and Mr. Smith wanted to look for a better deal. They began pulling at the shopping cart. Mr. Diaz is 5 feet 5 inches and 130 pounds and Mr. Smith is 6 feet, 225. During the struggle, Mr. Diaz fell against a restaurant door and opened an eight-stitch gash in his forehead. They moved away from the cart and continued scuffling. Mr. Mitchell jumped on Mr. Smith's back.
Tonya Johnson, 29, unemployed, came out of the shadows and made off with the cart. Mr. Diaz testified he heard Mr. Smith shout something at Ms. Johnson, which Ms. Johnson testified were instructions to take the cart. She said she knew Mr. Smith from seven months of sharing crack once or twice a week. Mr. Smith told us that he did not shout at Ms. Johnson, that he did not know her, and that he did not use drugs.
Mr. Mitchell tried to chase Ms. Johnson, but, according to Mr. Diaz, he was blocked by Mr. Smith -- "held at bay" was how Ms. Johnson described it. In any case, she escaped, and Mr. Smith took off. Mr. Diaz was bleeding profusely, and Mr. Mitchell called 911 for an ambulance. The four came together again within 10 minutes when police officers arrested Ms. Johnson and Mr. Smith.
Mr. Mitchell soon disappeared, but Mr. Diaz, Mr. Smith and Ms. Johnson were reunited two weeks ago in the court of Justice Leslie Crocker Snyder, whose resemblance to Candice Bergen was deliberated by the jury during the period in which we were not allowed to discuss the case. We never talked about that. It was a thrillingly serious jury that focused on reasonable doubt, credibility and the meaning of the charges against Mr. Smith, two counts of second-degree robbery, which involves force.
We eventually decided that we couldn't speculate that Mr. Smith already had robbery in mind when Mr. Diaz was hurt but that it was in his mind when he prevented Mr. Diaz and Mr. Mitchell from chasing Ms. Johnson and the set. We found him guilty on one charge.

HEADLINE: Fish Story

BYLINE: By Bill Kent; Bill Kent's novels include "Down by the Sea" and "On a Blanket With My Baby."

 BODY:

GIANT BLUEFIN
By Douglas Whynott.
242 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $21. 
 THIS ambitious attempt to catch, clean and dress the bluefin-tuna fishing story is a quietly mystical portrait of a group of New England fishermen (and one woman) and the brutal devotion of their work. North Atlantic bluefin was considered almost worthless 30 years ago; a single giant tuna, which can grow longer than 10 feet and weigh more than 1,000 pounds, can now bring its catcher as much as $10,000. Douglas Whynott, a professor of English at Mount Holyoke College whose previous book, "Following the Bloom," dramatized the business of migratory beekeeping, gives us a delicious story: Japan, which still says no to imports of many American products, cannot get enough of the luscious North Atlantic bluefin for its sushi bars.
Because the Japanese reject fish for sushi that have been hauled in by net -- the jostling bruises the delicate consistency of the meat -- the bluefin fisherman must stand on a steel "pulpit" on the bow of the boat, waiting for schools of tuna to rise to the surface, and then harpoon each fish individually.
Mr. Whynott paints this Winslow Homeric style of fishing -- nearly extinct off New England before the Japanese became a world economic power -- with broad-brush action scenes and character studies of passionate fishermen, wild and crazy spotters (pilots who fly planes above the sea to identify herds), smarmy American seafood dealers, fussy Japanese buyers and, though less successfully, National Marine Fisheries Service bureaucrats whose quotas, intended to preserve the dwindling herds by limiting the seasonal catch, spoil the fishing folk's fun. Mr. Whynott's jazzy jargon about the fish themselves could sometimes use an editorial filleting. ("The ram of water through the gills serves the high-oxygen, high-metabolism needs of the bluefin's high-velocity life style.") As in any fish story, the best moments in "Giant Bluefin" are a briny blend of romance and mystery.

HEADLINE: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
How Managed Health Care Will Allow Market Forces to Solve the Problems

BYLINE: By LLOYD M. KRIEGER; Dr. Lloyd M. Krieger is a resident at U.C.L.A. Medical Center.

 BODY:
ONE of the problems that has dogged attempts at health care reform is that the health care sector simply does not follow the laws of economics.
Consumers pay little or nothing for services, so they give no attention to prices. Physicians serve as the buyers of services for patients, but they are not the payers. Insurers pay for the services, yet they have historically had little say in purchasing decisions. Within a small community there is often wasteful duplication of expensive equipment and services, and yet the less efficient provider is almost never forced out of business. With managed care, much of this is changing. 
 Managed care is even correcting one of the medical sector's most intractable market failures: the excess supply of specialty physicians.
By the late 70's, it was clear there were too many specialists in the United States. While the needs of the population called for 60 percent of physicians to be primary-care doctors and 40 percent to be specialists, the converse has been the case.
With an excess of specialists, some, in theory, should go out of business, some change fields and some move to other locations. Those remaining should be forced to lower prices. But in practice, the glut of specialists has prompted more visits to specialists and more specialist procedures -- as well as a paradoxical increase in the price of services as physicians have tried to maintain their incomes. In the end, too many specialists has meant too much health care spending.
When these facts became clear, academics, policy analysts, business people and government planners called for a decrease in the number of specialists being trained. If there were fewer people to do expensive procedures, fewer expensive procedures would be done.
Several steps were taken. In the early 80's, Medicare began to pay specialists less and generalists more, and medical schools changed their curricula to encourage interest in primary care.
None of the efforts made a dent. Medical students continued to find the specialties to be more intellectually rigorous, technologically exciting and still somewhat more financially rewarding than primary care. And academic health centers continued to train large numbers of specialists to provide highly skilled cheap labor for patient care. Besides, specialists continued to find jobs and make a good living.
Enter managed care.
Managed care programs, which create networks of doctors and hospitals to provide care for enrolled patients, have acted to reduce the number of specialists to cut health care spending. The networks are now the buyers of physician services and, since there is an oversupply of specialists, it is a buyer's market.
On a practical level, managed-care plans have limited the number of specialists in their networks and have forced the remaining doctors to negotiate discounts.
MANY specialists now face the decision dictated by the classic laws of economics: switch fields, retire or move. And everyone is lowering fees. Some specialists are retraining to work as generalists. There are not yet many examples of heart surgeons dropping their scalpels to administer flu shots, but some physicians are expanding their practices to see a wider cross-section of patients and deliver primary care.
Things are now tough for a young specialist finishing residency, particularly in the West, where managed care has deeply penetrated the market. In California, many managed care plans are simply not hiring any more specialists.
I, in fact, am a resident in training in California to become a plastic surgeon. When I selected this subspecialty, I had already earned an M.B.A. and worked as a health care consultant, so I knew the havoc managed care would wreak on the medical specialties. Still, with its opportunities for creativity and problem solving, plastic surgery enticed me, and in the end I chose satisfaction over ease of employment.
But I am increasingly in the minority as word of the dwindling demand for specialists filters down to medical students. While a career as a specialist may seem as appealing to them as it does to me, more medical students are electing for residency in primary care.
In fact, the market is already overcorrecting a bit. Managed care plans seek to have half the proportion of specialists in their networks as exist in the current health sector. This proportion is almost certainly too low, and patients are beginning to complain about restrictions on their access to specialists and long waits once that access is granted. With time, the market can be expected to correct these excesses.
The important lesson is that managed care has finally introduced market forces to the medical manpower issue. If managed care networks are equally successful at making the laws of economics apply to hospitals, patients and to themselves, then there is hope that the nation's health care mess might be resolved by the market after all.

LENGTH: 1392 words

HEADLINE: E-Mail Puts Officials In Reach

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
WHEN one Eastchester resident's vacation was ruined this summer by noisy buses idling outside her door, she E-mailed local government officials and gave them a piece of her mind. Another resident questioned the legality of permit parking on a public road in the town, and he too took to his computer to complain. One man only wanted an electronic copy of the proposed master plan of development, but he too addressed his concerns to: cavanauj@nyslgti.gen.ny.us like the others did.
All three notes landed on the desk of Town Supervisor James E. Cavanaugh, one of 73 municipal officials in New York State who now have E-mail addresses as part of a state-financed $2 million grant "to bring local governments into the modern age," said Anthony M. Pascarella, director of the Telecommunications Initiative Project. 
 The project, which is financed by the State Archives and Records Administration, enables municipalities to obtain information from the State Legislature, the State Office of General Services and many databanks through the Internet. It also allows local government officials to communicate with each other and with residents of their communities.
For Linda Gislao in Eastchester, who had planned a simple vacation at home catching up on a few good books, the idling buses and the fumes they gave off invaded the peace and quiet she had hoped for that week.
"Dear Supervisor Cavanaugh," she wrote in her E-mail note, describing the problem and her thwarted plans. "Please explain to me how these buses are allowed to sit along the side of the street (in back of private houses) when this street has signs posted, 'No parking at any time.' "
Two days later, she had a response. "Thanks for your E-mail on the bus problem," Mr. Cavanaugh said, explaining that he was bringing the matter to the attention of the county, which runs the bus service.
"A copy of my letter to them has been forwarded to you (the old-fashioned way, via U.S. Mail)," the Town Supervisor wrote. "We will continue to monitor the situation."
Ms. Gislao and Mr. Cavanaugh have become part of a growing number of constituents and their elected officials who are discovering the joys of electronic mail. Under New York's telecommunications grant, about 250 local governments are expected to have E-mail addresses by the end of the year.
Officials taking part in the project will be able to subscribe to professional discussion groups on the Internet with colleagues in other parts of the state. In some cases, those groups and other on-line seminars could replace traditional conferences that are held for the same networking purposes -- saving taxpayer dollars that might have been spent to pay officials' travel and hotel expenses, not to mention the cost of time spent away from the office.
Mr. Pascarella said the electronic age could signal a time of reduced spending for government. "Think of the money saved by eliminating the paper, postage and handling of regular mail," he said. "That's just the beginning. The possibilities are endless."
In Rye, Town Clerk Frances C. Nugent called the latest developments in electronic communication "mind boggling." Apprehensive at first about the new technology, she said that she has learned quickly "despite being a senior and grandmother" -- although she was put off at first when Mamaroneck's Town Clerk, Patricia A. DiCioccio, sent an E-mail to check if her colleague in Rye was enjoying "surfing the Net."
Ms. DiCioccio recalled that Ms. Nugent responded with "a bit of huffiness and wanted to know if I was pulling her leg." "She said that she had never surfed anything in her life," Ms. DiCioccio continued.
Mostly now, Ms. Nugent says she uses her town's access to the Internet to retrieve information from state databanks and to manage local records, often communicating with other town clerks in the process. Rye, like other municipalities under the grant, has access to state lists of equipment for purchase, state archives and records, and revocation lists of licenses and permits from the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
Ms. Nugent said that minutes of Rye's Town Council meetings from 1660 through 1994 are now electronically preserved, including the proceedings from the acquisition of the land for the town from American Indians on June 29, 1660. Also, assessment information, tax records and other archival data are available for public access.
Many municipal officials see E-mail and the Internet as a significant timesaver in their busy schedules. Ms. DiCioccio said that now her communications go directly to the person she wants, without the need for time-consuming "exchanges of pleasantries and such" on the telephone.
Mr. Cavanaugh in Eastchester agreed, saying that in his opinion, E-mail was "essentially like putting a note right on someone's desk." "It certainly beats leaving messages on an answering machine or waiting on hold," he continued.
"It also beats playing telephone tag all day," said Susan S. Egginton, General Services Administrator for Westchester County. She noted that "hundreds of county employees" regularly use E-mail on the job.
Meanwhile, White Plains' Deputy City Clerk, Anne M. McPherson, said she was using the Internet to track bills through the Legislature. Also, she said, the city receives press releases from the White House, referring pertinent ones to appropriate departments.
White Plains is planning a home page, which is the "front page" on an Internet site, to provide residents with information about events and city services. Demographic and economic data for those who may be considering moving their business to the city will also be available.
Many other municipalities are also planning home pages to help their local business communities, following the lead of Kingston, N.Y., which developed one early this year to promote its historic and scenic virtues. Lowell Thing, a member of the Kingston Landmarks Commission who helped develop the home page, said that there has since been an upswing in the number of tourists coming to visit. He said the city was hoping to add sound bytes of the city and videos of some local scenery to the home page in the coming months.
In Dobbs Ferry, Trustee Brian D. Monahan, who is also a teacher of computer science at Iona College, said his village was considering a home page in conjunction with other Hudson River towns to attract tourists. The county, too, is preparing a home page on the Internet to increase tourism, Mrs. Egginton said. "It's in the works, along with computer kiosks for the public in shopping centers and airports," she said.
Home pages, databases and cost and time savings aside, officials say that the overriding benefit of going on line is the ability to communicate with the people they serve.
"It's a technology that fosters communication," Mr. Monahan said, explaining that for many people, E-mail seemed easier to write and read. "People will sit down to do that when they won't take the time for a traditional letter," he said.
"But we aren't ready to throw out all of the paper," he said. "The new technology isn't for everyone. There will always be some who prefer the old way."
The village is planning on-line community bulletin boards that will list meetings and garbage pickups and also serve as a forum for discussions. "After all," Mr. Monahan said, "we're in jobs as public servants because we like to be involved with our neighbors. And the more they talk to us, the better we'll like it. So we have a stake in seeing this move ahead."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1412 words

HEADLINE: How to Lose Friends and Alienate People

BYLINE: By Richard Lingeman; Richard Lingeman, formerly executive editor of The Nation, is writing a biography of Sinclair Lewis.

 BODY:

A LIFETIME OF RICHES
The Biography of Napoleon Hill.
By Michael J. Ritt Jr. and Kirk Landers.
Illustrated. 241 pp. New York:
Dutton. $24.95. 
 SUCCESS is the great American secular religion, a "drama of economic salvation," as the historian Irvin G. Wyllie writes in "The Self-Made Man in America." The gospel of success, as propagated over the years by authors of hundreds of inspirational books, beginning with Ben Franklin, promises salvation (wealth) through faith (ambition, perseverance) and good works (industry, frugality). Among the sturdiest toilers in the vineyard of evangelical materialism was Napoleon Hill, author of "Law of Success" (1928), "Think and Grow Rich!" (1937), "The Magic Ladder to Success" (1930) and other improving books.
Hill's biography has now been written by Michael J. Ritt Jr., executive director of the Napoleon Hill Foundation, and Kirk Landers, a journalist and freelance business writer.
Given Mr. Ritt's ties to the Hill legacy (the Prophet died in 1970 at the age of 87), this is hardly an objective account, and, as befitting the quasi-religious overtones of the subject, the prose at times acquires the pious inflections of a Life of a Saint. But credit the authors with candidly demonstrating that Hill was no such thing.
In his unpublished autobiography, on which the authors heavily rely, Hill accorded himself a classic Horatio Alger boyhood. He was born in 1883 in the uplands of Wise County, Va., to a family that represented, he said, three generations of "ignorance, illiteracy and poverty." But in fact Hill's grandfather was a printer; his father became a self-taught dentist and treated his neighbors until the state licensing authorities got wind of his activities. He then enrolled in dental school at the age of 40 and went on to practice legally. Hill's stepmother, the widow of a school principal, civilized the wild-child Napoleon, making him go to school and attend church. She also bought him a typewriter, and with it he wrote up news items for rural newspapers. Thus emerged a talent for writing that he would later apply to exhorting Americans to get rich.
Fresh out of commercial college, Hill talked himself into a job with a prominent lawyer. One weekend, the manager at a coal mine the lawyer owned got drunk and became involved in the accidental shooting of a black bellhop. With the boss away, Hill took charge, arranging to have the death covered up. As a reward, his employer made him manager of the mine at the age of only 19.
So far so good, Horatio. But Hill had congenitally itchy feet; he abandoned the mines for law school, supporting himself by composing profiles of successful people for an inspirational magazine. Unable to earn enough to pay for his law course, he moved to Washington as the magazine's correspondent and wangled an audience with Andrew Carnegie, who, according to Hill, took a shine to him and planted with him the idea that changed his life. The steel magnate told him to interview the wealthiest men in America and assemble the secrets of their success in a book, which would be "one of the most enlightening documents ever written." Carnegie cannily did not offer to finance the project, telling Hill that "the rewards from this labor would be far in excess of any payment he might offer," but he did provide him with letters of introduction to fellow tycoons. And so, Hill later wrote, "the Hand of Destiny reached out to me."
This sounds a bit too inspiring to be true. Nor was Carnegie's advice all that original. Compendiums of interviews with great industrialists revealing the secrets of their rise were a staple of success literature. Nevertheless, Hill devoted his spare time for the next 20 years to researching the "laws" of success.
But he also had to earn a living, and in this endeavor he had rather spotty, well, success. For two years he taught advertising at the La Salle Extension University in Chicago, then left to co-found the Betsy Ross Candy Company but soon was quarreling with his partners. Hill seems to have had a complex appropriate to his first name and his stature (5 feet 6 inches). Next, he launched a correspondence course in salesmanship, which folded after America entered the Great War. Hill volunteered as a propagandist for the Wilson Administration. On Armistice Day he was struck by one of his great ideas -- starting a success magazine called Hill's Golden Rule. After a couple of years he lost the magazine in a power struggle with some of his employees, whom Hill darkly accused of a vendetta. He paid back one of the plotters by denouncing him to the F.B.I. as a German agent.
Hill regarded such setbacks as a "test of his faith," but he was not immune to despair. After another of his business failures, he confessed, "I had spent the better portion of my life in chasing a rainbow. . . . I had begun to place myself in the category of charlatans who offer others a remedy for failure which they, themselves, cannot successfully apply." But such moments of introspection were brief; soon Hill was off chasing rainbows. He founded another periodical that featured ads for Hill-conceived organizations like the Peptomists and the Co-Operative Club, a Rotary clone that helped its members make business contacts and find "happiness through constructive service." (The periodical went under.)
But Hill was ever distilling his laws of success. Finally he found a self-help book publisher willing to back him. Working furiously, Hill delivered himself of his magnum opus, the eight-volume "Law of Success," which set down his 15 principles ("A Definite Chief Aim," "Self-Confidence," "Habit of Saving," "Initiative and Leadership," "Imagination" and so on). Soon he was raking in royalties of $2,500 a month, the authors say, and he was at last able to buy his neglected wife, Florence, whose family money had bailed him out of business failures, the luxuries he had long promised her. (His letters to her during their many separations show he practiced advertising on his own wife. In one he writes, "The shining pot of gold is almost within my reach.")
As fast as the money rolled in, he spent it, purchasing fine clothes, a Rolls-Royce and a 600-acre Xanadu in the Catskills, where he planned to establish "the world's first University-sized Success School." Unfortunately, the year was 1929, and eight-volume sermons on how to make millions would, as the Depression deepened, seem in bad taste. Royalties dried up, takers for his syndicated success column dwindled and the owner foreclosed on Xanadu.
Unbowed, Hill scrabbled a living by promoting his "Mental Dynamite" lecture series and editing and writing Inspiration Magazine. Through a Congressman friend, he got a job turning out public-relations materials for the Government. Hill claimed that he became a confidant of F. D. R. himself. Maybe so, but I somehow doubt that Hill coined the remark "The only thing we have to fear is fear itself," as he asserted, though he was a prosperity-around-the-corner guy who believed that curing the Depression was a matter of restoring confidence. Macroeconomics has never been the strong suit of apostles of individualism.
IN 1937, with the business climate looking up and self-help primers like Dale Carnegie's "How to Win Friends and Influence People" back in style, Hill composed his biggest hit, "Think and Grow Rich!," which the authors say sold 20 million copies over the next 50 years (Alice Payne Hackett's "70 Years of Best Sellers" suggests the figure was considerably lower). Newt Gingrich lists it among the books that most influenced him. By then Florence had divorced him and he was married to a younger woman of "dazzling beauty and steamy sex appeal" named Rosa Lee Beeland, who helped him write "Think and Grow Rich!" and later produced a self-help book of her own, "How to Attract Men and Money." She spoke with authority: she took Hill for all he had when they eventually divorced.
In his remaining years Hill advised companies with "labor troubles" (union organizers), married a good woman and buckled down to merchandising his books and success courses, with the backing of a wealthy disciple, the insurance executive W. Clement Stone, who made the Master's books required reading for his agents. From Hill's inspiring life I have gleaned another Law of Success: Don't waste your time chasing a rainbow. Package it and sell it to others. Then you'll find a pot of gold.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk
