HEADLINE: Blood in the Board Room: Thrillers of the Capitalist Persuasion

BYLINE: By Colin Harrison; Colin Harrison is the deputy editor of Harper's Magazine. His last novel was "Bodies Electric."

 BODY:
IS it impolite to note that reading the financial pages provides many of the same pleasures as reading comic books? After all, here we find one melodramatic figure after another: the billionaire boy wonder William H. Gates, chairman of Microsoft; the "fugitive financier" Robert L. Vesco, alleged swindler of more than $200 million, recently arrested in Cuba; Kirk Kerkorian, who announced last spring, erroneously, that he was mighty enough to swallow the $18 billion Chrysler Corporation; the billionaire Rupert Murdoch, who seems to pocket politicians around the world like a kid shoplifting gum. And how about the hero-rogues? How thrilling to read about Nicholas W. Leeson, the 28-year-old bond trader who detonated the old British bank Barings from his office in Singapore! And Joseph Jett, who cost Kidder, Peabody and its parent, General Electric, $210 million! Gadzooks -- who can forget the bloated corpse of the media baron Robert Maxwell floating in the ocean, dead possibly by his own hand, leaving in his wake embezzlement in the hundreds of millions?
Such figures may appear larger than life, but in the pre-millennial wired world, we understand as never before that everything is connected to everything else and that the capital being risked by the financial supermen may well include some of our own. More than 50 million American families now own stock, and information about markets and interest rates and stock averages and indexes and earnings reports and government statistics fizzes around us constantly. We worry that we should know what it all means. An army of tired men in their 50's collapses before the Cheshire smile of Louis Rukeyser each Friday night, waiting for sagacities, while younger investors of both sexes hunch over their radios seeking Bloomberg's report on the Nikkei. 
 It is only natural that writers of fiction might find money and its masters to be interesting, and this year has seen a crop of first novels that locate their dramas in the bond-trading department or the corporate suite, most written by people familiar with the jargon and strategies of such places. Among them so far this year are "Bombardiers," by Po Bronson, a former salesman at First Boston; "Free to Trade," by Michael Ridpath, a former fund manager for an international bank; "The Takeover," by Stephen W. Frey, a bank vice president; "Nest of Vipers," by Linda Davies, a former merchant banker; and "Knockoff," by Bill Levy, a former reporter with eight nonfiction books under his belt. With the exception of "Bombardiers," an appealing farce with almost no plot, these books are being marketed by their publishers under the rubric "financial thriller." Like the cold war melodramas that began to appear in the 1960's, the financial thrillers seem to have cut a fresh genre from the headlines. As such, do they tell us something new? Have any of the traders-turned-novelists whispered to us what we might terribly need to hear?
The answer is a resounding no. What happens in these novels looks a lot like writing-by-recipe. Begin with a brilliant young banker or trader, who through dint of hard work and savvy finds himself (or herself, in the case of "Vipers" only) thrust into the pivotal role in an acquisition or stock play or currency-trading conspiracy. Chances are that he is handsome, in top physical condition and knows all the best restaurants. He is also under 35 and unfettered by children or a spouse. (We are given to understand that he is not a promiscuous creep, however.) Specify his salary, to the dollar, as well as the liquor he drinks. Place action in one of the world's financial centers like New York or London. Use dialogue like this: "It's five hundred million dollars, with a coupon of nine and a quarter percent. Maturity is ten years. It is offered at ninety-nine. The yield is nine forty-one. Got that?" ("Free to Trade"). Toss in greedy patrician bosses with names like Granville Winthrop or Hamilton McKenzie and portray them with the subtlety of Mr. Burns, the demonic, hand-rubbing owner of the nuclear power plant on "The Simpsons." These bankers/traders/corporate chieftains are not to be trusted. Add the riff on speed-beauty-horror of the information economy. Work in some good-looking women. They too are under 35, and are not to be trusted. Some of them will die horrible, even misogynistic deaths. Assume the Federal Government is either blundering or wasteful. Be sure to explain obscure details of the trading strategy or merger-acquisition. Toss in a hired assassin, who knocks off minor players with sadistic efficiency. (Same assassin may demonstrate his bona fides by performing fiendish karate moves on gangs of black youths who conveniently cross his path.) Add plot twists and occasional moments of romance with the beautiful untrustworthy women. Make the hero learn he has been entrapped-manipulated-set up (he will use his prodigious mind to unravel the plot set against him and thwart the hired assassin); have somebody chase the hero down an alley or through darkened corporate offices. Be sure that same hero is able to locate usually impossible-to-locate information either by brilliant last-second cognition or through a trusty pal conveniently buried deep in the corporate edifice. (In fact, whenever information is needed by the hero, be sure it arrives with nerve-soothing convenience moments after it is required.) Deploy melodramatic cliches (from "Free to Trade": "My heart was beating wildly"; from "The Takeover": "His heart pounded in his chest and perspiration poured from his body"; from "Nest of Vipers": "Her pulse raced with rage and sorrow, and she felt sweat bead her back"). Now increase frequency of frantic phone calls. Knock off one of the good-looking women. Make hero "lie low" somewhere other than his usual swell digs -- preferably a roach-infested apartment in Harlem -- and patrician overlords nervous as hero-trader confronts-outflanks-reveals them. Bad guys lose, good guys win. Lights up, roll credits. Last shot: hero-trader on beach-avenue-farm with . . . the one woman who could be trusted.
 HAVE we seen these plots before? Yeah -- about a zillion times, in all the usual places (that is, on television). None of the so-called financial novels I've read in the last few months propose to comment on what is really interesting about money: the social inequity it causes, its corrosive action on a human soul, the broader cultural effects of capitalism or simply what it really is like to labor in the dense, well-remunerated seams of corporate power. Even the satirical "Bombardiers" never makes the reader uncomfortable at how and where the gold is piled in our society, though it should be said that the novel's zany observations about bond traders intentionally subvert the culture of money.
It is possible to inscribe an arc from Charles Dickens and "Nicholas Nickleby" to Theodore Dreiser and "The Financier" to F. Scott Fitzgerald and "The Great Gatsby" to Sinclair Lewis and "Babbitt" to John P. Marquand and "Point of No Return" to Louis Auchincloss's early novels to Joseph Heller's vastly underrated "Something Happened" to William Gaddis's "JR" to John Updike's "Rabbit Is Rich" and even to Tom Wolfe's "Bonfire of the Vanities"; that is, each of these older novels successfully investigates some element of capitalism. This recent crop of books is not in that tradition. Their debt, "Bombardiers" excepted, is to Robert Ludlum, Tom Clancy, John Grisham, Judith Krantz and Paul E. Erdman's "Crash of '79."
IN fact, as rude as it may be to say it, I think perhaps we have already reached a familiar moment in the half-life of a genre. Just as, say, the cold war spy books and then the legal thrillers quickly parodied themselves, the financial thriller may now be running the risk of becoming mere electronic rigging and fevered gamesmanship, full of workplace texture but subordinating to plot any attempt at characterization and thoughtful writing and banishing from view the deeper potential of the novel. The publishing industry will quickly move on in any case; doubtless soon we will have the Internet thriller, the purloined movie-script thriller, the war-with-China thriller, the right-wing militia thriller, the virus thriller, the right-wing militia virus thriller and so on.
But capitalism keeps finding new forms, and there is no reason the novel will not chase after them. The American economy increasingly seems to resemble a dangerous casino (which may explain why so many people now seek their fortunes in real casinos, including the ones in Wall Street). Despite the recent vigor of the Dow Jones industrial average, companies are still cutting thousands of jobs or sending them abroad. Were John Steinbeck alive today, he might understand the economic violence of our times and find a narrative that connects the shop floor to the executive. Were John Cheever or Richard Yates writing now, perhaps their short stories might possess a harder, more desperate edge representative of the age. Dickens would see that capital laughs at government. (Shakespeare, strolling the boulevards of the 1990's, would set "Richard III" in Time Warner -- if he did not, that is, end up being Hollywood's highest-paid screenwriter.)
More to the point, perhaps there are young unpublished novelists out there who intuit what 21st-century global capitalism will be, or is already -- who can narratively connect the suffering in American-hired, Korean-run, Japanese-owned, Malaysian-staffed sweatshops to the billions flickering on screens to the secret hearts of the supermen in limousines. Perhaps there is a young writer who will show that we are all now bound upon the wheel of postindustrial capitalism and that the social and political implications of this historical process are disturbing, if not for us, then for our children.
But until then, the bright publisher-hyped moment of the "financial thriller" seems undeniable, ascendant. Not long ago, I sat at lunch in Manhattan with a friend and we discussed the phenomenon of novels whose plots move like roller coasters along the world's fiscal ganglia. "Yes!" he exclaimed, his eyes wide. "I've been thinking about this, I have an idea myself, actually. You take a guy -- some sort of global corporate guy with a lot of power -- and he realizes that the dollar is no longer the world's reserve currency, the yen is stronger, whatever, and he comes up with a new form of digital money that only he can control. . . ."
Yes, yes and so on. No doubt such a novel is being written, even now.

HEADLINE: Rome Journal;
Hot Off the Presses: Videos, Combs, Necklaces

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Movie buffs pick up L'Unita on Saturdays, when the old Communist Party newspaper virtually gives away videos of Italian movie classics. Hypochondriacs prefer La Repubblica, which for months offered installments from an illustrated medical encyclopedia. Corriere della Sera, the Milan-based grand old lady of Italian journalism, scored a big hit this year with a world atlas that came wrapped inside the paper.
This is what newspaper competition in Italy is all about these days -- gifts, games and gimmicks, anything to increase circulation in a country where newspaper readership, historically low compared with most of Europe, is on the wane. 
 Popular magazines have also been drawn into the game, loading down newsstands with perfumes, combs, necklaces, gardening tools and cooking utensils. Italy's news magazines also dabble in the gimmicks, although their strongest pitch is the weekly parade of naked women on their covers, complemented this summer with a sudden outbreak of male nudity on the inside pages. In a recent cover story on Italy's beach culture titled "Slaves of Summer," the weekly Panaroma featured a picture of a bare female bottom set off by two hands in pink handcuffs.
But it is the war of the "gadgets," as the promotional freebies are called here, that draws the most laments from purists. The war, which has been going on for several years, shows no sign of abating.
This fall L'Unita will come forward with classics of American cinema while La Repubblica and Corriere will find themselves in an embarrassing head-to-head collision, as each offers readers installments from rival encyclopedias.
The fact is that gadgets work. Ever since L'Unita, now the paper of the Party of the Democratic Left, began issuing its Saturday videos, for which readers pay an extra 4,500 lire, or nearly $3, sales have soared from an average Saturday circulation of 120,000 to 450,000.
Marco Ledda, who heads the newspaper's marketing department, said that advertising was up 25 percent and that sales in regions like the south of Italy, where interest in left-wing newspapers is minimal, have jumped by as much as 800 percent.
"Gadgets are the easiest way to gain readers, the best way to beat competitors and the best way to make your name known," said Antonio Pilati, director of the Institute of Media Economics. "But it is like pumping adrenaline into a weak body."
Corriere's successful marketing of its atlas, which followed popular teach-yourself English and French courses, has helped the paper surge ahead of La Repubblica to again become Italy's top-selling daily. On the first day of the atlas campaign in January, the paper sold an extra 400,000 copies, and by mid-1995, its average daily circulation was 790,000, well ahead of La Repubblica's 610,000, said Enrico Gervasi, of the TBWA advertising agency, which handled the campaign.
But the surge in numbers poses the obvious question: If people buy newspapers to get something else, where does that leave the newspaper? The answer is often the nearest trash bin, said several newsstand owners who have monitored Saturday readers as they reach for the videos and toss away L'Unita.
A more telling example is that of L'Informazione, a Rome newspaper that won readers with real-life detective series until last spring, when the series ended and the paper folded.
Alberto Ferrigolo, who wrote a series of articles for the far-left paper Il Manifesto criticizing the gadget craze, said readers did a weeklong "slalom" at their newsstands, alternating between papers depending on what they have to offer -- besides the news -- on any given day.
"It is a drug," he said, "and a lot of journalists feel frustrated because newspapers are no longer the focus of interest."
In fact, the gadgets have only slowed the decline in newspaper readership, which Mr. Ferrigolo says has fallen from 6.7 million to 6.2 million, leaving Italy above only Portugal and Turkey in the region in terms of readers per population.
Experts cite a number of causes for such a poor showing, like bad distribution and an even worse postal system. But above all, the experts point to the powerful draw of Italian television, which captures more than half of Italian advertising revenues.
But another reason for the troubles of the Italian press stems from its long history as a voice for political and business interests. Some newspapers are directly linked to political parties, and as such receive subsidies from the state. But most are owned by Italy's industrial barons.
La Stampa, based in Turin, has long been part of the Fiat industrial empire, which for the last decade also has controlling shares in the Rizzoli publishing house, which owns Corriere della Sera. La Repubblica is owned by the De Benedetti family, which owns Olivetti, and Il Sole 24 Ore, a financial newspaper, belongs to Confindustria, the lobbying group for Italian business.
The result is a highly partisan press that in its devotion to internecine political intrigues often surpasses even the prodigious appetite for political gossip here. "The papers are a little too political, and far from the interests of the people," Mr. Pilati said.
Proponents say inserting books, dictionaries, films, compact disks and maps into newspapers gives readers more information and attracts young people.
"If the Corriere is becoming a defender of the Italian language, I see that as a very noble thing," said Mr. Gervasi of the TBWA advertising agency. "And if the dailies are being attacked by television, protecting themselves through promotion is something very positive."

Despite the campaign, newspaper readership has fallen from 6.7 million to 6.2 million, leaving Italy above only Portugal and Turkey in the region in per capita readership. (Carlo Lannutti/Daylight, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bosnian Serbs, Angry at Setback And Tired of War, Blame Leaders

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BANJA LUKA, Bosnia, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Accustomed to bragging of victory rather than swallowing defeat, the usually self-assured Bosnian Serbs here are saying they feel betrayed and are fed up with the war they have conducted with seeming invincibility for so long.
A sense of shock and bewilderment descended on this city, the largest the Serbs hold in Bosnia, as the truth sank in that the Serbian-held Krajina area had caved in without a fight to the Croatian forces. 
 For the first time since the Yugoslav conflict began, soldiers and ordinary citizens are questioning the motives of the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, and the Bosnian Serb leaders who, for the time being, make their headquarters here: Radovan Karadzic, the political leader, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the commander of the military.
"We feel betrayed by everyone," said a 35-year-old soldier who was home from the front for a five-day break. "Karadzic is accusing Milosevic, Milosevic tarnishes Karadzic, and we are only the pawns in their game."
Adding to the confusion is the spectacle of a cold-blooded public brawl between the once-unified Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic. Last week, Dr. Karadzic demoted the military chief, but when General Mladic refused to step aside and all 20 of his generals backed him, Dr. Karadzic unceremoniously reinstated him.
Each has accused the other of being mad, said officials who were present while the accusations were flying.
Dr. Karadzic, a psychiatrist by profession, said last week that General Mladic was certifiably crazy, an official who was present said. And General Mladic told Dr. Karadzic recently that he had "spent too long with his patients," one of the general's aides said.
What this demoralized spirit in the ranks and the cracks in the hierarchy will mean on the battlefield or at the negotiating table as the United States pursues new peace proposals is hard to discern.
Dr. Karadzic said in an interview published on Saturday in the Bosnian Serb government newspaper Glas Srpski (Serbian Voice), "I prefer that the international community spits at us while we win and we fulfill our aims than the international community pities us and spits at our enemies who, God forbid, would be winning."
General Mladic, who was said by his supporters to be at the battlefront for the last two days, knew that public support for the war effort was very low, an aide said.
The general will try to restore confidence by gaining a battlefield victory in the coming days, the aide said. When that is achieved, he said, General Mladic will settle his score with Dr. Karadzic.
But while the two leaders were getting back to business as usual, at least publicly, the tone was completely different among the people in the cafes, restaurants and homes of Banja Luka.
In this city, the site of some of the most vicious "ethnic cleansing" by the Bosnian Serbs, many Muslims and Croats have fled, leaving behind Bosnian Serbs very loyal to their cause.
On the main street today, a jeep bore a grisly hood ornament -- a human skull with a blue United Nations helmet propped on top.
But beneath such shows of defiance, there was plenty of evidence that faith in the war has been ruptured.
A medical assistant who has worked in the surgery wards of the Bosnian Serb military field hospitals for the last four years said all his army colleagues and civilian friends in Banja Luka wanted the war to end immediately.
"If it's not over in a month, we've all said we are leaving and going away as far as possible -- to New Zealand," he said, showing badly bitten fingernails. "Karadzic has no support; people turn off their television sets when they see him."
An official who accepted the entreaties of Dr. Karadzic to come from Belgrade to help run a governmental department here said that he had set a deadline, Jan. 7, the day Serbian Orthodox Christians celebrate Christmas. "If the war is not finished by then, I will be out of here by the following Christmas," he said.
The economy has crashed so badly, the official said, that the average wage in Banja Luka is now the equivalent of about $60 a month. The embargo imposed by President Milosevic on Serbian-held areas of Bosnia a year ago has worsened an already weak economy, the official said. Factories are at a standstill and jobs are scarce, he said.
Apparently in response to the people's desire to leave -- an estimated 200,000 Bosnian Serbs have fled to Serbia since the war started -- Dr. Karadzic said in a speech in the town of Prijedor last week that further emigration would be banned. He criticized local Serbs who had smuggled themselves into the columns of refugees from Krajina who passed through Banja Luka on their way to Serbia.
"In the future, no one will go anywhere," Mr. Karadzic said. "People must share the common destiny with their army."
But soldiers, who a month ago were being told that the Bosnian Serb fighting machine was strong enough to take on NATO, were openly dispirited, and cited the failure of Serbia to intervene and help Serbs hold on to Krajina.
"The fall of Knin had catastrophic effects on the army," said a soldier, referring to the capital of Krajina. "We are afraid we may be betrayed in the same way Knin was. Then we'll have no control over our destinies."
Another soldier, asked if he was ready to accept a peace plan, said he would have voted to do so last year, but the leadership had told them to vote against it in a referendum. The soldier, who was also on leave for five days, said he found it insulting that the Serbian soldiers in Krajina were forced by their military leaders to give up without a fight.

Thousands of refugees from Croatia's attack on its Serbian-held Krajina region are pressing into Yugoslavia while others are streaming to Serbian-held areas of Bosnia. (Reuters) (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: Some Republicans Are Wary Of Balanced-Budget Promise

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
The Republican-led Congress that left town last week for its summer recess heads home rightly boasting that it has made as much progress toward setting a Federal budget as Democrats made by this time of year when they ruled Capitol Hill.
But this is no ordinary year, or garden-variety budget. Rather, it is the cornerstone of Republican fiscal policy, the first of seven budgets intended to erase the annual Federal deficit by 2002. Yet despite some progress in cutting spending this summer, even some Republicans are beginning to fear that their first year's effort on the budget will fall victim to the clock and the irresistible pressures of re-election politics. 
 The fear swirls around a single piece of legislation that the House and Senate will begin writing next month. It folds into one immense package the Republican plans to curb spending in the most popular and politically sensitive benefit programs, including Medicare, Medicaid, welfare and Federal pensions.
In Capitol Hill parlance, it is called the reconciliation bill. But that is a misnomer, since the measure is likely to pit irreconcilable political forces in the most bitterly fought political battle in years, if not decades. If the Republican leadership can pass it -- and there is no assurance that they have the votes to do so -- President Clinton must decide whether to veto it, and, without major changes, he almost certainly will.
Mr. Clinton's veto is a trump card. While vetoes of spending bills can force Federal agencies to close their doors for lack of money, a veto of a reconciliation bill merely prevents Congress from trimming the benefit programs in the bill. That means the benefit checks continue to flow to recipients -- and the longer they flow, the more their budgets balloon above Republican targets.
Because of that, some Republicans predict that Congress will try to play its own trump, attaching the reconciliation bill to legislation raising the Federal debt ceiling -- in effect the Government's credit limit -- which is expected to come to a vote this fall. That could present Mr. Clinton with the distasteful choice of signing the legislation containing the cutbacks or bringing the entire Government to a halt for lack of money.
At stake is more than just the solvency of the nation, as if that were not enough. The outcome of the standoff may be crucial not just to Republican hopes of retaining control of Congress, but to Mr. Clinton's chances for winning a second term in the White House. The victor in the budget dispute would be able to claim a majority of political support for its budget policies, as well as the high ground in the 1996 campaigns for the White House and Congress.
There is always the chance, of course, that the two foes will compromise early on a single deficit-cutting budget. But no one rates those chances as high.
"I've tried every scenario I know to figure out a way to avoid a meltdown this fall, and I've not been able to find one," a senior budget analyst for Senate Republicans said last week. "The question is not so much how to avoid it, but what to do the morning after."
In interviews last week, Republicans cast the impending budget battle as almost a test of manhood, a fight they must win if only to prove their political mettle.
"We've made such a big issue out of balancing the budget that it would be absolutely irresponsible for us not to reach that goal," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican on the Finance Committee. "Eventually, Republicans have to conclude, 'Are we going to govern or not?' And I think we'll conclude that we have to."
In fact, Congress has already taken real votes for deep spending cuts. Before its recess, the House passed 11 of the 13 major spending bills that set 1996 budgets for the bureaucracy, and the Senate passed 6 of them, all rolling back many popular programs and abolishing others.
Leaders in both chambers say they intend to pass compromise versions of all 13 bills by the start of the new fiscal year, Oct. 1. If they do, they will have reduced discretionary spending -- for Cabinet agencies, the White House and most other purposes besides benefit checks and interest on the national debt -- by 4.4 percent below the 1995 level.
Mr. Clinton has promised to veto some of those bills. But Republicans are basically united, public reaction has been muted and analysts widely anticipate that most will prevail.
Still, those 13 bills represent only a third of Federal spending. The real struggle is over the remaining two-thirds, most of which will likely wind up in the House or Senate reconciliation packages -- and in the thick of the 1996 campaigns.
In the reconciliation bill, Congress will try to pare the growth of benefit programs that have been virtually armor-plated for decades. The order of battle is huge: overhaul Medicare; replace most welfare entitlements with block grants to the states; revise Medicaid, cut billions in crop subsidies, and, perhaps, change the federally guaranteed student loan program.
Most, if not all, of those efforts will reach a climax in the reconciliation bills that the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee will try to write next month. In many Congresses, overhauling just one major program could consume an entire season of lawmaking; this Congress hopes to finish work on the reconciliation package by mid-November.
In this process, there lies great political peril.
House members, all of whom face re-election next year, began to hear the first notes of worry about changes in Medicare when they returned to their districts for town hall meetings with voters during the first week of August. But the House is relatively united under its right wing; the Republicans' greatest potential for division lies in their more moderate and independent-thinking majority in the Senate.
There, jockeying for position in the 1996 Presidential race has already caused stress fractures in Republican unity.
One harbinger of trouble surfaced last week when Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, was forced to pull his own proposal to overhaul welfare from the Senate floor. Mr. Dole was not just done in by an unusually united Democratic minority, but also by his own party's right wing, which is lined up behind his rival for the Republican Presidential nomination, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas.
That pushes welfare into an already frantic September, and raises the question of whether the Senate's 54 Republicans can hang together long enough to push a reconciliation bill into law.
Some analysts suggest that will be tough. "They've got problems with Medicare cuts to begin with," said Stanley Collender, the chief budget expert for Price-Waterhouse in Washington. "Throw welfare in there and you may have enough Republican votes to defeat it."
The senators could ease the pain of some cuts by taking some money from the seven-year, $245 billion tax cut that the House and Senate tentatively agreed to in June. But that would very likely rankle the House, where conservatives are demanding an even bigger tax cut.
Other money-raisers, like lengthening the seven-year path to fiscal balance or lowering cost-of-living indexes for pensions and other benefits, might anger the House or parrot Mr. Clinton's own plan, two unacceptable choices from the Republican perspective.
Many Republicans nevertheless predict that the Senate will bite the bullet. Senator Slade Gorton, a Washington Republican who sits on the Budget Committee, predicted a "titanic struggle" that would end in passage of the bill. Senator Grassley agreed. "Reconciliation is a tough vote any way you look at it," he said. "But I suppose that by folding a lot of issues into one vote, you avoid a lot of tough votes later on."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Russia Seek Balkans Accord

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Russia and the United States, which have separately proposed new diplomatic initiatives to halt the widening war in the Balkans, sought to coordinate their approaches at a meeting here today.
Moscow is eager to play a larger role in bringing an end to the fighting, but its support for Serbia, a traditional Russian ally, has often put it at odds with Western diplomatic efforts. 
 Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev met with Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser, in the Russian resort town of Sochi today. Mr. Lake sought to enlist the Russian Government's support for Washington's newest proposals, which take into account the latest developments on the battlefield.
Mr. Lake left the two-and-a-half-hour meeting without comment, but his hastily scheduled stop, which was added to a round of private consultations in France, Germany and England, indicated that Washington is increasingly aware of the need to address Russia's concerns over the Balkans.
Alarmed by Croatian troops' recent successful attacks on rebel Serbian troops in the Krajina border territory, Moscow said on Friday that it wanted to be host to an international peace conference in Moscow, and President Boris N. Yeltsin offered to personally mediate preliminary talks between Serbia, Bosnia and Croatia.
Mr. Kozyrev did not discuss the American proposals with reporters. Instead, eager to paint Russia as a major player in negotiations, he said after his meeting with Mr. Lake that he believed that Washington did not object to Mr. Yeltsin's recent call for an international peace conference in Moscow.
Saying Russia's idea for an international conference preceded by three-way talks among the warring sides "finds recognition with the U.S. side," Mr. Kozyrev added: "This is very important. We have them on board now in search of a political solution."
But he acknowledged that Washington did not look favorably on Russia's insistence that the United Nations lift its military and economic sanctions against the rump Yugoslavia. "In American thinking," Mr. Kozyrev said, "it looks like lifting or suspending sanctions is not the immediate task we want it to be."
There are few details on the plan Mr. Lake is presenting. Mr. Clinton has denied that it is an altered version of a 1994 peace-plan map that would give 51 percent of Bosnia to a loose Muslim-Croatian federation and 49 percent to the Bosnian Serbs, who now hold more than 70 percent of it. But a review of the plan, drafted by Russia, France, Britain, Germany and the United States, has been mentioned.
Some American and Western diplomats say that the American plan includes a proposal to persuade the Muslim-led Bosnian Government to swap the surrounded enclave of Gorazde, the last remaining United Nations "safe area" in eastern Bosnia, for territory near Sarajevo.
There have been reports that the United States is considering threatening Bosnian Serbs with more NATO bombing and that Bosnian Muslim fighters might be joined by troops from other Muslim nations.
Russia, which complained about not being consulted about NATO air strikes in the past, is unlikely to approve of a larger role for NATO in the region.
Russia has been openly unhappy with what it sees as thinly veiled American and German approval of Croatia's recent blitz against rebel Serbs.
Washington is backing its initiative by sending Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke to Sarajevo, Zagreb and Belgrade this week to discuss the proposals with leaders in the region.
After meeting in Moscow with the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, on Thursday, Mr. Yeltsin on Saturday sent 90 tons of relief supplies to Serbian refugees fleeing the fighting in Croatia.
American and European negotiators have been seeking to persuade President Milosevic to recognize Bosnia, and possibly Croatia, in exchange for lifting international economic sanctions on what remains of Yugoslavia. Moscow strongly supports freeing Yugoslavia of the sanctions.
At a special session of the lower house of Parliament on Saturday, Russian deputies, in a nonbinding ballot, voted to release Russia from its pledge to uphold sanctions against Yugoslavia.
Although Mr. Yeltsin is not obliged to act on it, the resolution reflected both the strong pro-Serbian sentiments in Russia, and the pressure Mr. Yeltsin is under from nationalists and Communists to distance himself from the West and take a strong stand in the Balkans.

Clinton Phones British Leader
 WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (Reuters) -- President Clinton telephoned Prime Minister John Major of Britain today to discuss new United States proposals to end the Balkan conflict, an Administration official said.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Major spoke for half an hour about the United States delegation that has been holding talks in Europe and a follow-up team that will tour Balkan capitals starting Monday for talks with the parties to the war.
"Prime Minister Major was generally supportive of the efforts," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But he gave no substantive details of the discussion or of the plan.

HEADLINE: Murdoch-Led Newspaper War Threatens to Crush Britain's Independent

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Conceived in secret just nine years ago by a band of ambitious journalists from the right-leaning Daily Telegraph, The Independent was born in a rush of optimism and excitement at the height of the big-spending 1980's in Britain. Its ringing challenge of an advertising slogan -- "It is. Are you?" -- summed up the newspaper's mission nicely: to publish a paper free from the political and financial obligations that so often attend news coverage here.
For a few heady years, it all seemed to work. But now, plagued by Britain's recent recession, the rising cost of newsprint, defecting readers and, above all, by a price war instigated by Rupert Murdoch, The Independent is floundering. Circulation has slipped to about 300,000 from a high of 423,000 in 1989; more than 70 editorial employees have quit or been dismissed in the last year, and analysts say the newspaper and its sibling, The Independent on Sunday, are losing $1.6 million a month. 
 Perhaps most alarming to its once-idealistic founders, The Independent is no longer independent. Instead, it is owned by three newspaper groups that keep an anxious watch on its bottom line. Two hold stakes of 43 percent each: Mirror Group P.L.C., the owner of two leading tabloids, The Daily Mirror and The Mirror on Sunday, which are sympathetic to the Labor Party, and Independent Newspapers P.L.C., which owns a chain of Irish newspapers and is run by Anthony F. J. O'Reilly, chief executive of the H. J. Heinz Company in Pittsburgh. Prisa, the Spanish company that also owns El Pais, Spain's leading daily newspaper, owns 12.6 percent.
The result is a paper that many Britons feel has lost its way. "It's a competent newspaper," said Stephen Glover, one of The Independent's since-departed founding editors. "But what is it trying to do?"
The answer is complicated. In the last few years, it has often seemed the paper's only goal was to hang on for dear life. "The paper should by all accounts have lain down and died a long time ago," a media analyst said, speaking on condition of anonymity, and acknowledging that he had too often predicted The Independent's imminent demise.
Jostling with The Independent at the newsstand are several other broadsheets, known in Britain as quality newspapers, all with strong party philosophies. They include The Times of London, a Murdoch-owned paper that has been the traditional voice of the establishment; The Daily Telegraph, which reflects the views of business and of the Conservative Party's right wing, and The Guardian, the paper of the left, which more or less supports Tony Blair, the current Labor leader.
However well these papers do -- The Daily Telegraph's circulation in June was 1.07 million -- none does as well as the most popular tabloids. In June, for example, The Sun had a daily circulation of 3.99 million.
At The Independent's offices on the 18th floor of a tower in Canary Wharf, a renovated commercial section on the outskirts of London, staff members say they live in fear of what will happen next. "We're all incredibly gloomy," a longtime editor said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "We've spent the last three years with all the other papers mocking and deriding us, we've just had 43 redundancies, and we're all been asked to do a lot more. It's incredibly disruptive."
Last month, when the paper's editor, Ian Hargreaves, announced the most recent round of dismissals, he also outlined overall budget cuts totaling about 25 percent of the paper's costs. Among other things, The Independent has merged its back-office operations with those of the Mirror Group, shut a number of overseas bureaus and reduced its staff in the United States.
The trouble for The Independent probably began as early as 1990, when the paper decided to stretch by starting The Independent on Sunday. Though the Sunday paper sold well and was considered a journalistic success, it was introduced at the end of the worst advertising recession in memory. The Sunday paper lost money and began to drain resources from the daily Independent.
In September 1993, Mr. Murdoch, whose News Corporation already owns London's most successful tabloid, the weekly News of the World, and Sunday broadsheet, The Sunday Times, decided to make an all-out circulation push for his daily broadsheet, The Times of London.
The Times had always been outperformed by The Daily Telegraph, and Mr. Murdoch had never liked the free-thinking Independent because the paper presented itself from the beginning as a direct challenger to his own partisan newspaper style. Indeed, many of The Independent's readers came from disenchanted enthusiasts of the pre-Murdoch Times.
He decided to cut the cover price of The Times by one-third, to 30 pence, or about 48 cents, from 45 pence. The Times's rivals had no choice but to follow suit. Last summer, The Telegraph reluctantly cut its price to 30 pence, though The Guardian held firm at 45 pence. Mr. Murdoch responded by going down to 20 pence. The Independent, which could ill afford it, tried to keep pace by dropping its price part way.
Circulation went haywire. By January 1994, The Independent's circulation had fallen 17.7 percent, to 290,804 from 353,198 in January 1993. "It's been bloody murder," Mr. Hargreaves said.
The price wars began to subside this July, when The Times raised its price to 25 pence and The Telegraph and The Independent each went to 35 pence. But the prices are still artificially low, which benefits Mr. Murdoch, who has the resources to offset the losses from The Times.
Editorially, The Independent is at an interesting crossroads. About half the paper's readers are younger than 35. Many of them are politically skeptical, Mr. Hargreaves said, in tune with a newspaper that has made its way by taking issue with the policies of both the Conservatives and the Labor Party.
"Of all the troubles that we've had and all the pressures that we face," he said, "none of them have anything to do with anyone saying what the paper's agenda should be, or what it should cover."
But, Mr. Hargreaves acknowledged, independence can be relative. "We do have a particular form of independence," he said. "We're independent only as long as we stay in business, and we're only going to be in business in the long run if we stop losing money."

HEADLINE: Low Ranking for Poor American Children

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Poor children in the United States are poorer than the children in most other Western industrialized nations, as young Americans suffer the brunt of several trends toward greater economic inequality, a new study shows.
Only in Israel and Ireland are poor children worse off than poor American youths, according to the study, an analysis of 18 nations by the Luxembourg Income Study, a nonprofit group based in Walferdange, Luxembourg. 
 The results are the most comprehensive of several recent analyses, and are particularly striking because the United States has the second highest level of economic output per person of the countries examined, after Luxembourg itself, and has the most prosperous affluent children of any of the 18 nations.
It may not be surprising that childhood poverty is worse in the United States than in Scandinavia, where governments have racked up huge national debts while trying to maintain elaborate social safety nets. But the United States also ranks below countries like Italy, which has a considerably smaller economy per person and has less generous social policies than many northern European nations.
The United States appears to have sunk through the rankings over the last 30 years, although no conclusive data are available now, said Timothy M. Smeeding, one of the study's authors and director of the Luxembourg Income Study. The American lead in overall prosperity has dwindled since the 1960's, income inequality has risen briskly in the United States and child poverty spread here in the 1970's and 1980's, although it may have leveled off in the early part of this decade.
Child poverty has also risen in Britain and Israel, while showing relatively little change in Continental Europe, according to the latest study.
Some conservative economists have questioned the validity of studies that attempt to compare levels of income and distribution of wealth among nations with somewhat different economic systems and societies. There is general acceptance within the field, however, of the idea that the United States has proportionately more of its children in poverty than other affluent countries. The debate revolves instead around what to do about it.
The results of the Luxembourg Income Study report, which is based on census survey data from the various countries, are consistent with less statistically detailed work by other social scientists.
The study comes as Congress is deciding whether to limit Federal spending on various welfare programs. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, tried to push welfare legislation through the Senate last week, but ended up postponing action until after Labor Day following strong resistance from Democrats and from conservatives within his party.
During a press conference on Thursday, President Clinton expressed strong concern about stagnant incomes, particularly for less-affluent Americans. "We've got to grow the economy and raise incomes," he said. "That's why I want to raise the minimum wage, that's why I want to give every unemployed worker or underemployed worker the right to two years of education at the local community college, that's why I'm trying to have a tax cut that's focused on child rearing and education: to raise incomes."
Mr. Smeeding said there appeared to be several reasons why the United States had such extreme poverty among children.
The United States has the widest gap between rich and poor, he said. The United States also has less generous social programs than the other 17 countries in the study, which are Australia, Canada, Israel, and 14 European countries: Austria, Belgium, Britain, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland. The study did not include several Western European nations like Greece, Spain and Portugal that have very poor children but limited data.
American households with children tend to be less affluent than the average American household, a pattern that is not true in many other countries.
This trend may reflect that American mothers are less likely than European mothers to return to work quickly after childbirth, partly because inexpensive, high-quality child care is more widely available in Europe, said Lee Rainwater, the research director of the Luxembourg Income Study and the co-author with Mr. Smeeding of the latest report. The Luxembourg group sent copies of the report to prominent social researchers last week and will make it more broadly available in the coming days.
Some conservative analysts question whether international comparisons of prosperity should even be attempted. They point to the many differences among nations' economies and societies.
There are more poor children in the United States than in many affluent countries, but that partly reflects the high number of poor immigrants and unwed teen-age mothers here, said Douglas J. Besharov, a resident scholar at the American Economic Institute, a conservative research group here.
"Is there more poverty in a big, diverse country like ours than in Western Europe?" he asked. "The answer is yes."
He and other conservative economists argue that the price the other countries pay for avoiding extremes of childhood poverty may be slower economic growth, which, they assert, leads to lower living standards for all. A large chunk of European social assistance to young families takes the form of generous unemployment benefits that have eroded incentives for people to work, Mr. Besharov said.
The Luxembourg Income Study is financed by the National Science Foundation in Washington and similar agencies from 18 other governments. Its staff has been working for the last decade to develop ways to make reliable international comparisons. The group is a repository for computerized data on income distribution from 25 countries around the world, which it makes available for free to social researchers.
In addition to his work with the study, Mr. Smeeding is an economics professor at Syracuse University and one of the nation's leading experts on income calculations. While he personally favors expanded social spending in the United States, he is generally regarded in the field as an undogmatic thinker. Mr. Rainwater is a professor emeritus of sociology at Harvard University and the author of many books on poverty.
Their study is critical of Republican efforts to cut American social spending now.
The study compares incomes of poor and affluent households with children. The figures include not only after-tax wages and other personal income but also cash benefits from the government, like food stamps and the tax credit on earned income for low-income working parents with children. The calculations take into account differences among countries in the size of families and in the cost of living.
The figures do not include free government services, like the free medical and child-care services available in many European countries.
Sheila B. Kamerman, a professor of social policy and planning at Columbia University, said that for this reason, the latest analysis may have underestimated the extent to which poor American children lag in income. "If you were looking at in-kind benefits as well as cash benefits, the situation in the U.S. would look even worse," she said.
Professor Kamerman and Alfred J. Kahn, another Columbia University social policy professor, published a lengthy study two weeks ago reviewing social programs in Britain, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Italy and the United States and found that American poor children received the least help.
Poor children in Denmark do particularly well in comparison to poor American children. Vita Pruzan, the director of the children, youth and family research division at the National Institute of Social Research in Copenhagen, said in a telephone interview that in reducing child poverty, the Danish Government had found it particularly effective to provide free obstetric and nursing services.
Denmark also makes a particular effort to help single mothers who do not receive child support payments from the fathers of their children. "If the father is absent and doesn't pay, the state will pay what he is supposed to pay," Dr. Pruzan said. "The state tries to collect the money from the father, but that is not her problem."
Poor children in Italy are also better off than poor American children, even though the median income in Italy is considerably less than in the United States. Free child care for some poor children and a low-cost health care system have helped, said Patrizia Ghedini, the head of the family issues department of the regional government for the area of northern Italy around Bologna.
But in Italy, the gap separating rich and poor is also smaller than in the United States. According to the Luxembourg Income Study report, a poor household with children near the bottom of the income scale in Italy earned $12,552 in 1991, while an affluent household with children near the top of the scale earned about $44,280. For the United States, the comparable figures that year were $10,923 and $65,536.

HEADLINE: 50 Years After V-J Day, the Memories Are Sweet

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
Squeezed in a neon canyon of billboards touting Sony, Samsung and Suntory, thousands of veterans made a sentimental journey to Times Square yesterday, remembering a delirious V-J Day celebration that spontaneously erupted in the same spot 50 years ago.
A half-century had naturally dulled the euphoria; this crowd kept to their chairs, humming softly to Glenn Miller, laughing at Henny Youngman ("I said, 'Doctor, how do I stand?' He says, 'That's what puzzles me.' "), leafing through memories of when they were lean, fearless and 19. 
 "I'm here because I missed the original party 50 years ago," said Alfred Kempski, 71, of Deer Park, L.I., who spent the real V-J Day on a crowded wooden troopship steaming toward Japan.
What he missed on Aug. 14, 1945, was a crowd of more than a million people celebrating a two-word news flash: Japan Surrenders. The block party in Times Square stretched from 40th to 52d Streets, a frenzy of hugging and dancing that came to be symbolized by a Life magazine photograph of a young sailor's passionate kiss of a nurse in a crisp white uniform.
Yesterday's anniversary celebration, which was hurriedly organized by the city, was considerably smaller. The crowd, which city officials estimated at more than 8,000, was truly big enough for a block party, filling Broadway between 44th and 45th Streets.
"It seemed like the only people who cared were the vets themselves," said Marty Algaze, a spokesman for the Mayor's Office. "The problem has been pulling it together and raising money from corporate sponsors. I think a lot of them were saying it's not such a big deal."
With two giant black and white posters of the Life magazine kiss for a backdrop, Julie Wilson, Margaret Whiting, Mr. Youngman and Celeste Holm volunteered to perform for the anniversary. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his wife, Donna, also took part, trying mightily to demonstrate a 1995 version of the V-J kiss.
It was a different world then, said the Mayor, who was a year old at the time. The Brooklyn Dodgers were in third place, the New York Giants in fourth. The Times Square billboard advertised Pepsi-Cola. And men like Milton Hirschberg cradled carbines instead of canes.
"I was on guard duty when surrender came and we were greatly relieved," recalled Mr. Hirschberg, 80, of Flushing, Queens. He came to the V-J anniversary wearing a yellow Hawaiian shirt of palm trees and blazing suns. He opened it to reveal a faded T-shirt, some 50 years old, which he wore while serving in the 10th Army. To prove his military service, he brought along a leather album of black and white photographs of Japan. They were taken, he said, with a smuggled camera.
There was something about the soft breeze blowing through Times Square that made old men sentimental. Everywhere there a veteran digging in his pockets for a memento.
Herbert Brown, of North Miami Beach, Fla., produced the small salmon-colored card certifying that he had witnessed the surrender of Japan.
"Oh, I was only 19 then. It's hard to believe it was 50 years ago," he said.
Kenneth Johnson, 75, fished in his pocket and found black and white photographs with ruffled edges of a lean young soldier, darkly handsome. "That's me," he said.
Like other veterans at the event, he said he found it strange to live in a time when the enemies he fought are now his country's allies. "A Japanese man came up to me before this started and said, 'What's going on today?' I said, 'If you guys had won the war we wouldn't have been here today.' "
Daniel S. Fruchter, of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association, was even more blunt: "We've won the war, but we've lost the peace, and this country is losing its way. We're now a debtor nation to Japan. War is economic and we've become beholden to them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bill Schramm of Pasadena, Tex., says he is the sailor in the famous Alfred Eisenstadt photograph of the V-J Day celebration in 1945. Back in Times Square yesterday, Mr. Schramm and his wife, Dale, happily obliged any and all photographers who missed the shot the first time. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cable TV's Quiet Victory

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
In the rush before the House passed its sweeping communications bill this month, Gerald Waldron was amazed.
Mr. Waldron, who represents network television affiliates, was among the legion of lobbyists prowling the halls of Congress. The local phone companies were out in force, as were the long-distance carriers, and every other conceivable sector of the communications industries. 
 Every group, that is, but the cable television industry, whose conspicuous absence was startling to Mr. Waldron.
Startling, that is, until he stopped to think about it. For cable businesses, the best policy was to avoid drawing attention to the legislation's exceedingly kind treatment of their industry.
While the House bill, like the Senate version passed earlier this summer, would grant new freedoms to all of the leading communications businesses, only cable television would be deregulated without long delays or steep hurdles.
Cable operators managed to gain all this while lying low because of Congressional misgivings about the mixed results of the 1992 attempt to regulate prices.
But now consumer advocates and Democratic lawmakers fear steep price increases as the House prepares to reconcile its bill, passed on Aug. 4, with the Senate legislation passed in June.
"Consumers have no protection against rate gouging," said Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat who tried unsuccessfully to limit the House bill's deregulation of cable rates.
The House bill would lift rate caps on cable networks like CNN and MTV after 15 months. Smaller cable systems would be deregulated immediately. The Senate bill would lift rate caps on all systems, except for those that Federal regulators deem to be charging "substantially more" than the national average. President Clinton has threatened to veto the legislation, in part because of the deregulation of cable. But it passed both the House and Senate by margins that would appear to be veto-proof, or a two-thirds majority vote. And if something resembling either the House or Senate version becomes law, consumer activists predict that cable operators would soon raise their average monthly rates by $5 to $7 -- an increase of 22 percent to 32 percent over current rates.
"They have every incentive to raise rates quickly, because they face no competition right now," said Bradley Stillman, director of telecommunications policy at the Consumer Federation of America.
Mr. Stillman said that a cable company would have to charge an additional $5 a month to make up in one year the revenue it lost in the three years since Congress voted to re-regulate cable rates. The Federal Communications Commission, which slashed basic rates by an average 17 percent in 1993, estimates that consumers have saved roughly $3 billion in that period.
Cable executives, who acknowledge that they kept a low profile during the House debate, insist that it is ludicrous to suggest that they would increase basic rates at a time when competition is escalating and they are seeking to enter the local telephone business.
"Cable companies learned their lesson the last time around," said Marc B. Nathanson, the chairman, president and chief executive of Falcon Cable Systems Company, a midsize cable operator based in Los Angeles. "I think the companies will act more responsibly now. Rates will go up gradually, stabilize, and then come down."
For now, though, competition in cable seems more theoretical than real. Direct-broadcast-satellite providers like DirecTV and Prime Star are signing up customers at a good clip. But direct-broadcast satellite still has fewer than 2 million subscribers -- compared with 61 million for cable.
While the Bell telephone companies could emerge as cable competitors, technological and regulatory snags have slowed their progress.
The Bell Atlantic Corporation and U S West Inc. both recently withdrew applications to the F.C.C. to upgrade their networks for video services. Moreover, many analysts say that since the Baby Bells can now compete in the long-distance market, they will train their guns on the AT&T Corporation and the MCI Communications Corporation, rather than on cable giants like Time Warner Inc. or Tele-Communications Inc. Long-distance is a much bigger business than cable, and the Bells already own much of the equipment needed to provide that service.
And just as the phone companies plan to offer cable service, cable operators are gearing up to provide local phone service. This prospect, legislative experts said, helped cable gain such favorable treatment.
Republicans in the House and Senate hope that cable -- by competing with local phone service providers -- will act as a counterweight to the Bell companies, preventing them from quashing competition in new markets.
Consumer advocates acknowledge that the cable industry has struggled on Wall Street in recent years. But they said that even this does not justify a wholesale increase in cable rates.
Gene Kimmelman, the co-director of Consumers Union, said that over the seven years that rates were deregulated, from 1986 to 1993, cable ratcheted up its rates at three times the rate of inflation.
On the local level, large cable operators like Tele-Communications Inc. and the Cablevision Systems Corporation used to face protests from customers angry over rate increases. Now nobody is picketing the headquarters of Cablevision in Woodbury, L.I., said Peter Wunsch, a Long Island resident who once organized such protests.
"Most people seem resigned to the fact that their rates are going to go up," he said.
The prospect of rising cable rates also stirred few emotions during the House's recent debate on the telecommunications bill. With little fanfare, lawmakers rejected Mr. Markey's cable amendment by a substantial margin of 275 to 148.
But the cable issue is far from dead, said several legal experts.
President Clinton has threatened to veto the House bill, citing its lax treatment of cable as one of the reasons.

HEADLINE: It's Not Quite Paradise;
Running an Inn on Block Island Teaches Owners All About Beauty and Balance Sheets

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: BLOCK ISLAND, R.I.

 BODY:
You discover things about life out here in your first season running an old Victorian inn on a windswept speck of tidal moors and bluffs. Sheets, for example. Brad and Anne Marthens can tell you a lot about sheets.
It was their first week in business in late April when the Marthenses discovered that the innkeeping guidebooks were wrong about linens. On Block Island, because of the vicissitudes of the ferry schedule -- and the fact that the nearest commercial laundry is on the mainland -- an inn needs three full sets of linen, not two. Dirty sheets go out on the 12:30 P.M. ferry to Point Judith, R.I., and they do not come back until the 9 A.M. boat the next day, at the earliest. 
 "We needed a lot more," Mrs. Marthens said with a sigh. "Of all the things we didn't realize."
Mrs. Marthens's words provide an apt coda for the couple's first year as innkeepers. The things they didn't realize, for better and worse, have formed the texture of their lives since they came to this island, nearly two hours by ferry off the tip of Montauk, L.I., last fall.
They had never run an inn before or lived on an island, but here they dived in head first, life savings and all, pursuing their dream in a 116-year-old, 21-room hilltop retreat called the Atlantic Inn, leaving friends, jobs, routines and familiarity all behind them.
They have not found paradise or perfection. Life here, they said, has been confusing and invariably challenging. But unlike the thousands of people who only dream of tossing aside the workaday world, the Marthenses have done it.
The saga began last September, when they signed papers selling their home in Cheshire, Conn. Leaving their lawyer's office, the Marthenses drove directly to the ferry, their car loaded with what they could carry.
The rest of their belongings, which followed later, could not fit in their small upstairs managers' apartment, so it has been scattered through various rooms of the inn or put into storage.
Through the winter, with the inn closed and empty, the couple painted, changed fixtures and doorknobs and made lists. Now, in late summer, they race to keep up with the seasonal crush, gratified that the inn is full most nights, but staggered by the burden as well.
Like one long shakedown cruise, they said, the year is ending as it began: complicated, noisy, chaotic, at times profoundly moving, but always new. They keep a stack of letters perhaps six inches high from strangers all over the country who wrote to wish them good luck and courage after the Marthenses' story was told in an article in The New York Times last fall.
"We certainly have questioned ourselves many times, saying, 'What have we done?' " said Mr. Marthens, a 35-year-old former advertising executive for Times Mirror cable television.. "But I can honestly say we've never been happier. I'm convinced we made the right decision, even though it has not been an easy road."
Some moments, the Marthenses said, will be etched in their minds forever. They both speak of the day last spring, about a month before opening day, when the dining room was still a mess of dust and dirt and uninstalled carpet. Out of nowhere, their chef and first employee, Lawrence Busteed, announced that dinner would be served. He spread a white tablecloth and put out the good china, and they all sat down together in the silent, empty, dirty inn and dined.
"Sometimes they get to a point where they just don't know what to do," said Mr. Busteed, who grew up in an innkeeping family (his parents once managed the Atlantic Inn) and knows the business's inherent anxieties well. Mr. Busteed, 33, said part of his role was to provide a calming influence. "I just keep telling them, 'It takes time; it takes years,' " he said.
It also helps to have emergency financial reserves, as the Marthenses were repeatedly told in the innkeeping course they took before the purchase.
One morning in mid-March, for instance, after a weird but typical Block Island spring -- alternating periods of icy cold fog and blazing sun -- the Marthenses realized that the paint applied just last summer by the previous owners had begun to bubble and peel. It was a month before opening day, and the whole exterior needed painting. That crisis, along with the sheets and a few lesser bumps, have pushed the couple's first-year expenses about 15 percent to 20 percent higher than they had planned, although still within the amount they had set aside. Most of their other assets -- including the proceeds from their home in Connecticut and almost all their savings -- have been put into the down payment on the inn, which they bought for $1.1 million.
The real bottom line of innkeeping, however, is not the money but the workload: as the summer season reaches its crescendo, from mid-August through Labor Day, and the inn is full almost every night, the Marthenses say they are working harder than they ever have.
Forget the genteel charm of the inn's croquet-field front lawn, the wide-beamed wicker-strewn front porch and the melodic tinkling of the early evening cocktail hour. You cannot hear the hushed, distant thunder of the surf when you are behind the front desk, or at the computer, paying the bills at 5 A.M.
What's worse, the Marthenses have found that in order to spend time with their 5-year-old son, Brad Jr., and minimize his hours in day care, they must work separate shifts, which means less time together as a family. One of them must always be on duty by 6:30 A.M. to help get ready for the breakfast buffet, and one -- usually Mr. Marthens -- also works in the evenings, helping out in the dining room.
"We've lost dinner time together," Mrs. Marthens said.
At crush times, like Sunday morning checkout time, they work side by side behind the front desk, beaming at the compliments and listening with solicitous earnestness to the complaints, while their son plays on the front foyer carpet.
The Sunday scene at the front desk epitomizes the Marthenses' juggling act: One woman wants to check out but worries about her bags. Two tennis players, who are not guests, saunter in, wondering why they were kicked off the court. That forces Mr. Marthens to play the heavy; the courts, he tells them, are reserved for guests.
Meanwhile, Brad Jr., with a glue stick, cotton balls and paper, is creating art and playing peekaboo with guests through the grandfather clock's glass window. When the traffic clears, Mr. Marthens steps out from behind the desk, absently picks up scraps of waste paper, approves his son's project -- all the while engaging another guest in conversation -- then heads back behind the counter.
Want a day off? If it's August, it's probably out of the question. An old inn full of guests cries out at every turn with its endless wants. If you do not consciously drag yourself away, it will suck you back in. Even slipping away for just a few hours is an act of will.
"Not caving in -- that's the hard part," said Mrs. Marthens, 37, a former office manager who quit her job when her son was born. "You just have to say, 'I'm going.' " Block Island's summer economy works on the same principle -- that a whole year's worth of commerce can be crammed into one season. In high summer, 15,000 people might be on the 11-square-mile island -- whole battalions in running shorts and roller-blades, sweatbands and swimsuits. There are two seasonal movie theaters, and you can get a plate of calamari at Rebecca's until 2 A.M.
In winter, almost all the inns, including the Atlantic, close, along with many of the stores, and the population plummets, to about 500.
But island life also has a continuity the Marthenses said they had not anticipated. Lives get bound up in places like the Atlantic Inn. Old properties like this attract orbits of people who love them, and they sometimes cannot tear themselves away.
When Mrs. Marthens's father died in June near Providence, R.I., for example, she said her grief had been immediately tinged with panic. How could they leave the inn? Who would cover for them?
From out of the blue, the previous managers -- Mr. Busteed's parents, Ken and Linda -- called from their home in Vermont. They had heard from their son and through the Atlantic Inn network that the Marthenses were in trouble. Did they need a couple of pinch-hitters for a week, at no charge?
"Innkeeping is such a commitment," Mrs. Busteed explained. "You put so much of yourself into it, 15 hours a day, every day you're open. There's like a loyalty, an esprit de corps as things blossom -- it's hard to leave."
Bill Keogh is another member of the Atlantic Inn cast. A 45-year-old carpenter and handyman with a ponytail and a beeper, he came for a couple of weeks of work, putting up siding for the previous owners. That was 16 years ago, and he's still here.
"I was still in my radical stage -- my hippie stage, maybe," said Mr. Keogh, who had bounced around much of the country before landing here. "I'd found a lot of New England difficult, but this place was different."
Mr. Keogh, known to all as B. K., eventually started his own construction business on the island and started a family. But when the Marthenses arrived, he returned to help them paint the inn's rooms throughout the winter.
And the Marthenses say they will never forget one of their first guests, a librarian from New York City. For a time, in fact, she was the inn's only guest. Sometimes in the mornings and afternoons, she and the Marthenses would sit together and chat. She learned their story and met their son, who will enter kindergarten this fall, and when the islandwide town meeting was held during her stay, she went as a sort of amateur anthropologist, intrigued by island politics. She also brought back all the literature she could find about the island's school system, while the Marthenses stayed at the inn and worked.
"She was just the nicest woman in the world," Mr. Marthens said. "It was exactly the right way for us to kind of ease into innkeeping."
Atlantic Inn veterans like Mr. Keogh say they believe the island and the inn will also fold the Marthenses in its embrace so they will never want to leave. Standing on the croquet field as fog swirled around the inn's yellow porch lights, Mr. Keogh said that even if things do not quite work out, island life gradually takes you in and keeps you, and you're better for it.
"I've been broke, and I can't think of a better place to be broke," he said.

HEADLINE: Pulp Nonfiction: When Textbooks Refuse to Die

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

 BODY:
It would take a close reading of McGraw-Hill's all-time best-selling college text, the $61 "Economy," to understand why publishers sometimes have to destroy textbooks to save them -- or to make more money on them. But it does not take too close a study of the company's current civil lawsuit against the publishing industry's garbage man to know that the same people who turn wood pulp into ideas expect equal diligence when it comes to turning ideas back into pulp.
When expensive texts on child psychology or chemistry hit the used-book market, sales of new editions dip, along with profits for the publishing house and royalties to authors. So publishers would rather get rid of excess inventory than let it show up as bookstore discounts. 
This wrinkle in the laws of supply and demand underlies the McGraw-Hill lawsuit against a book-disposal company and a mix of shady characters and reputable used-book sellers.
The suit, filed last December in Federal District Court in Newark and amended in June, offers a window into a world that sounds more like pulp fiction. It is a world where cartons of unsold books, scheduled to be destroyed, are spirited away to secret hiding places in warehouses, and where button-down book distributors are portrayed as willing henchmen of a disposal company -- with the fitting name of Guaranteed Destruction Inc. -- in a plot to make books come back from the grave.
McGraw-Hill, a leading publisher in the $1.6 billion wholesale college textbook market, contends in the suit that Guaranteed Destruction, hired by the publisher in 1993 to destroy tons of unwanted new or damaged books, secretly sold trailer-loads to intermediaries who funneled them into the campus book trade.
In the suit, Michael Emposimato, the president and owner of Guaranteed Destruction, was portrayed as the central figure in what McGraw-Hill called a $12 million book diversion scheme. Among the 19 other defendants were distributors with ties to two major retail and college bookstore chains, the Follett Corporation and Barnes & Noble Inc.
As any college student knows, the cover price of a new textbook is high and fosters a huge -- and legitimate -- market in used books that can be sold the next semester to a whole new group of students, usually at a sizable discount. But a revised version of a textbook, ostensibly undertaken to update material, cuts short the resale life of a previous edition.
College divisions, in planning press runs, are generally spared the "best seller or bust" ordeals of publishing but must deal with such variables as student enrollments, shifting trends in course studies and professors' changing preferences.
Publishers like McGraw-Hill prefer to destroy many overstocked, damaged or out-of-print books rather than let them enter the discount market and compete with its titles at full retail price, although "the books we destroy represent less than 4 percent of total units printed," Frank Lawton, a McGraw-Hill vice president, said.
In the past, the big publishing houses had employees "chop" the unwanted books -- strip the covers and spines -- and had the remains carted to landfills. But as landfill fees shot up along with the cost of employee benefits, publishers began looking for other solutions.
Enter Guaranteed Destruction Inc. of Parsippany, N.J.
"If you are going to protect inventory, then protect it right up to the finish," Mr. Emposimato said in an article in Publishers Weekly last October. He said his company had foolproof methods to prevent overstocks of books from "going out the industry's back doors."
McGraw-Hill executives at the company's operations in Hightstown, N.J., winced at these words. The company had hired Guaranteed Destruction in 1993 to remove and destroy tens of thousands of unwanted books. But a month before the Publishers Weekly article appeared the company received an anonymous letter stating that several warehouses in northern New Jersey were stuffed with McGraw-Hill books illegally diverted by Guaranteed Destruction.
McGraw-Hill turned the matter over to the corporate director of security, William Fernhead, who assigned two private investigators to watch Guaranteed Destruction's main warehouse in Union, N.J.
Mr. Fernhead said an electronic tracking device had been inserted in the scooped-out pages of a book sealed in a 22-ton shipment of cartons picked up by a Guaranteed Destruction tractor-trailer at McGraw-Hill's Hightstown plant on Nov. 15.
The detectives followed the truck to the Union warehouse, where the books were unloaded. A few days later, they noticed a large number of McGraw-Hill cartons being loaded into a beige van at the rear loading dock of an adjacent structure.
The investigators trailed that van about 10 miles to a parking lot in Denville, where the books were transferred to a parked red van. Hours later, two men arrived and drove the red van to Newark, where about 75 cartons were unloaded at New Jersey Books, a distributor of used and new books.
The driver of the red van was later identified as John P. Golden. He and the owner of New Jersey Books, Edward Mueller, had already served prison terms after pleading guilty in 1989 to Federal charges of conspiring to steal books.
Last December, McGraw-Hill filed suit against Mr. Emposimato, Mr. Golden, New Jersey Books and Hector Bido, a Guaranteed Destruction employee identified as the driver of the beige van. In January a tip led investigators to 21 Guaranteed Destruction trailers at a garage a few miles from the company's warehouse. The trailers held nearly one million books owned by McGraw-Hill and other publishers, including Simon & Schuster, HarperCollins and Harcourt Brace.
In court papers, Mr. Emposimato, who sold Guaranteed Destruction earlier this year to a company called Books Into Books, denied any wrongdoing and said McGraw-Hill "does not take sufficient precautionary steps to insure that its books do not re-enter the marketplace."
But through his lawyer, Robert F. Dato, he refused to comment on the case. Mr. Dato said: "The publishers think they have an easy target here because he is the garbage man of the industry. But it's the publishers who have been caught with their pants down because of their practice of overproducing too many books."
Last week, McGraw-Hill settled with a distributor named in the suit, MBS Textbook Exchange Inc., whose majority owner and chairman is Leonard Riggio, chairman and chief executive of Barnes & Noble. MBS admitted no wrongdoing but agreed not to participate in any future book diversions.
The suit contended that MBS paid $3.5 million to a middleman fronting for the Guaranteed Destruction diversion. Last week's settlement with MBS disclosed no details of the supposed transactions. "We're happy to get this behind us," Robert Pugh, president of MBS, said. "The books in question represent only a fraction of the books we sell."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Guillermo Ortega separating the pages of books from their covers at Books Into Books in Union, N.J. Textbook publishers often prefer to destroy unsold books, rather than let them get on the market. (Sam D'Amico for The New York Times)
