HEADLINE: Israelis and Others Feel the Sting of a Cellular Phone Bug

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
A software bug inside one model of Motorola cellular phone, coupled with the voracious appetite of Israelis for cellular calling, has demonstrated an area of vulnerability in the growing web of digital communications systems -- and prompted Motorola to issue a worldwide recall.
Motorola introduced the Alpha digital phone in December, and sporadic problems were reported in Hong Kong in February. By April, after about 65,000 Alphas had been distributed in Israel by Cellcom, the second-largest cellular provider there, the Alphas were being blamed for sound quality that made voices inaudible, a lack of reception in areas where reception was promised, the cutting off of calls and long periods when the phones simply did not work. 
 Motorola wound up asking 150,000 Alpha users in six countries to return the phones to have the software changed.
"The problem was not exhibited by all phones, but we took out all of the phones that had the potential to exhibit the bug," said Jim Caile, vice president of marketing for Motorola's cellular systems group. "It was all taken care of in a matter of six weeks."
The problem seems to have been worst in Israel because so many residents use cellular phones.
The Alpha adheres to an emerging standard for digital cellular telephones called time division multiple access, or T.D.M.A. Its software, embedded on a read-only-memory, or ROM, chip, switches its radio signal from one channel to another at frequent intervals. The bug caused the phone to lock on to one channel and stay there indefinitely, blocking other users in a particular cell from sending or receiving calls until its batteries died or it was switched off.
Cellular service in Israel is inexpensive -- less than 3 cents a minute, charged to the caller only, compared with, for example, about 65 cents a minute in the San Francisco area, where owners pay for calls received as well as made. As a result, people often leave their phones on all the time. Studies show that Israelis' use of cellular telephones is eight times that of the average American, said Moshe Pearl, a spokesman for the Israeli Communications Ministry -- but no studies have explained why.
"People in Israel live from hour to hour listening to the news and then need to share the information or act on it immediately," Mr. Pearl said, and cellular phones are also a status symbol, carried everywhere, always turned on.
In most other nations, cellular phone users tend to turn the phones on only to make calls, often using pagers to screen incoming messages first, Mr. Caile of Motorola said. When the phones are left on, they periodically call in to "register," and it was during this automatic connection that the Alpha phones were locking up a given frequency, blocking the channel to other users.
Mr. Caile said the total costs of replacing the software in all 150,000 Alphas would be $10 million to $20 million and would be covered by Motorola's normal reserves for warranty repairs. Motorola and Cellcom both remain the subjects of several class-action lawsuits in Israel.
Some computer security experts said the problem with Alpha, while short-lived in itself, should send a warning about the rush to digital telecommunications. Digital cellular phones convert speech to the ones and zeros that computers understand, which can easily be compressed, enabling many more conversations to be sent over a given amount of radio bandwidth than with conventional analog signals. But digital phones are prey to the same kinds of software bugs that cause cursors to freeze and computer networks to crash.
"There are tremendous risks as soon as you put something in software," said Peter Neumann, a computer security specialist with SRI International in Menlo Park, Calif. "If you change a bit here or there you can bring the whole system down."
The cellular industry "has foisted a disastrously insecure technology on the public," he said.
But other analysts said the Alpha flaw had more to do with simple quality control than with more fundamental risks in a new technology. The pressure to be first to market in a business as competitive as cellular telephones prompts the release of products before they have been adequately tested, these analysts said.
"The problem here is really that Motorola's new products, across the board, tend to have problems," said Ira Brodsky, president of Datacomm Research in Wilmette, Ill. "It's not surprising that when the big guys like Motorola and Ericsson feel pressured to get things out quickly, they have bugs. This is less an indication of something that will plague the industry than something that will plague Motorola."
Hanan Achsaf, Motorola's managing director, told a meeting of the Israeli Parliament's Economics Committee that the company did not have time to properly field-test the Alpha before marketing it, The Jerusalem Post reported in May.
Motorola said it continued to sell the phones after problems emerged in Hong Kong because it believed the problem was in the network rather than in individual handsets. When it determined the problem was in the phone, it halted production and began replacing the faulty software, Mr. Achsaf said.


GRAPHIC: Officials at Motorola have discovered a glitch in some of their phones that disrupted and halted service in several parts of Israel. How it happened:
 
CELL PHONES IN ISRAEL
Graph: "Cellular Anarchy"
 The Government has encouraged cheap cellular phone service to combat the relatively poor installation network for normal phones. Israelis pay two to three cents a minute for cellular phone use, while people in the U.S. can pay upward of a dollar a minute.
 
PHONE USAGE IN ISRAEL
 Because the service is so cheap, many Israelis leave thier portable phones on constantly.
 
WHAT THE PHONES DO
 While on, portable phones emit a signal to cells that identify the phone so that it can receive calls. Normally, the phone, after locking in a call that allows it to transmit and receive calls, switches rapidly through channels in that cell, allowing other users to also end and receive calls by not monopolizing the cell.
 
THE PROBLEM
 Because phones are on at all times, they would periodically lock into a cell. The software glitch would not allow the phone to change channels, but would monopolize entire cells so that other phones in the area could not send or receive calls. The portable phone would not release the cell until its batteries ran down.

HEADLINE: MEDIA: TELEVISION;
With its Olympic megadeal, NBC sees itself as the network of big-time sports.

BYLINE: By Bill Carter 

 BODY:
AFTER NBC made one of the most expensive sports deals in history last week when it agreed to pay $1.27 billion for the television rights to the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, and the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, the usual attacks by rival networks decrying the economic folly of overpaying for sports events were surprisingly muted.
In fact, executives from the other networks generally praised the pre-emptive strike by NBC. Peter Lund, for example, president of the CBS Broadcast Group, said, "It was a very shrewd, opportunistic get on NBC's part." 
 Mr. Lund calculated that in the worst case NBC would lose no more than $100 million on the seven-year deal, which he broke down to about $15 million a year. "That's negligible," he said, especially when measured against the long-term value NBC is likely to see from the deal.
Long-term value and strategy were what NBC's executives said the deal was all about.
The president of NBC, Robert C. Wright, who made the decision to circumvent the usual Olympic bidding process by making a "take it now or leave it forever" offer for the two Olympics, said the strategy was "technology driven more than anything else."
NBC, he explained, wants to position itself as a provider of free programming that will serve as a continuing attraction to viewers, who in the next 5 to 10 years will have access to more and more programming delivered by cable lines, phone lines and satellites -- all of which will cost money to receive.
"The next few years are going to be hard years" for networks, Mr. Wright said. NBC's hedge against becoming an afterthought to what he called the "new navigational systems" that will deliver television signals is to offer programming available nowhere else.
"There is a great deal of value in a marketing plan that includes identifying yourself as the network of the Olympics," he said.
That identification is very much in NBC's plans, because networks are increasingly looking for ways to "brand" themselves. And big events are an essential part of such a strategy, Mr. Wright said.
To Dick Ebersol, president of NBC Sports and the architect of the network's ascension to leadership in sports among the broadcast networks, the Olympics are a "brand" that reaches more than 90 percent of television viewers.
"That's how many people see at least one hour of the coverage of the Games," Mr. Ebersol said. "In the old days other shows on television brought all or most of the country together, shows like Ed Sullivan or Jack Benny. Now it takes a big sports event."
Big sports events are also critical to advertisers looking to reach all or most of the country at one time. "They need to launch new product lines," Mr. Ebersol said. "They have to have events like these."
NBC will also try to benefit from its ties to the Olympics by putting the ringed Olympic logo ( "one of the most identifiable symbols in the world," Mr. Ebersol said) onto all NBC sports telecasts for the next seven years. The rings will also be shown on the network's two domestic cable channels, CNBC and America's Talking, and its European-based cable service, Super Channel.
Part of the deal calls for NBC to farm out extensive coverage of the two Olympiads to CNBC and America's Talking, a move that will surely prompt more cable systems to add the channels to their offerings.
By the time the deal is complete, Mr. Ebersol said, the asset value of the channels, especially America's Talking, which is only two years old, will have increased enormously. At the same time, NBC has enhanced its relationship with its affiliated stations, which stand to make enormous profits when the Olympics are shown.
In 1990, NBC was considering how to profit the most from an imminent change in cable regulations that would let broadcasters gain some compensation from cable systems that carry their broadcast signals.
"We talked about what it was that we put in front of people that no -cable system would dare take away from its viewers," Mr. Ebersol said. "And big sports was the answer."
So NBC committed itself to retaining as many big sports events as it could. The result in the next year will be perhaps the biggest season any network has ever had in sports, with telecasts of the World Series, the Super Bowl, the National Basketball Association playoffs, Wimbledon, the United States Open Golf tournament and the Summer Olympics in Atlanta. (CBS will telecast the Winter Olympics in 1998.)
"Don Ohlmeyer has done a fantastic job finding the entertainment shows that NBC needs to bring in viewers," Mr. Ebersol said, referring to the president of NBC's West Coast division. "My job is to bring in the big events."
In the late 1960's, Mr. Ebersol and Mr. Ohlmeyer were proteges of Roone Arledge, then president of ABC Sports, who turned the Olympics into the colossus of television events.
Mr. Ohlmeyer was a sports director and producer of the Olympics. Mr. Ebersol, while still in college in 1968, was the first Olympics researcher Mr. Arledge hired.
One lesson Mr. Ebersol learned from Mr. Arledge at ABC was how to manipulate the Olympic bidding process to his network's advantage.
In 1972, just days after completing coverage of the 1972 Games in Munich -- which included the murder of 11 Israeli athletes and became the most-watched news event of that year -- Mr. Arledge presented the Olympic organizers with a pre-emptive $25 million "take it or leave it" offer for the 1976 Games. They took it.
Mr. Ebersol said he remembered that precedent. "Like father, like son," he said.

HEADLINE: In America;
The Fantasy Coup

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT; Anthony Lewis is on vacation.

 BODY:
Retired Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, a respected former President of Nigeria, was taken from his home one morning last March by henchmen of the Nigerian dictator, Gen. Sani Abacha. General Obasanjo was accused, along with about 40 others, of plotting to overthrow General Abacha.
A farcical set of proceedings was held before a secret military tribunal and convictions were handed all around. General Obasanjo, it is believed, was sentenced to 25 years in prison. His onetime deputy, Gen. Shehu Musa Yaradua, was also given a long prison term. Many of the alleged coup plotters were sentenced to death. 
 Among the weirder things at work here is the peculiar kind of gratification General Abacha has managed to derive from these developments. By imprisoning and threatening to liquidate his perceived enemies, the tyrannical Abacha has drawn the respectful attention of major world leaders. President Clinton, Pope John Paul II and President Nelson Mandela of South Africa are among those who have urged him to be merciful. General Abacha says he may seriously consider those requests.
Now consider this. There was no attempt at a coup in the first place. The arrests were bogus; the secret trials were cruel exercises in make-believe. As Randall Robinson, executive director of TransAfrica, has said many times, there is not "a scintilla of evidence" that any of the so-called defendants had plotted to overthrow General Abacha.
The "coup" was a fantasy concocted by General Abacha as justification for a brutal crackdown on his political opponents. General Obasanjo, who had been trying to bridge the differences between the many ethnic and political factions in Nigeria, has not even been allowed contact with his wife or his attorney. When the attorney held a press conference to declare that his client was innocent, he, too, was arrested.
Meanwhile, General Abacha continues to pursue his policies of ruin in Nigeria. He is the latest and the worst in a succession of corrupt and brutal military leaders who have managed to bring near total devastation to a country that has 100 million people and is rich in natural resources, including oil.
"Nigeria is a country that is about to break apart now," said Mr. Robinson. "They have disbanded all democratic bodies. They have suppressed all imaginable freedoms. The generals have emptied the coffers. They've siphoned off billions and stashed them in foreign accounts."
Nigeria is a billion dollars in arrears in its payments to oil field operators. Its inflation rate exceeds 100 percent. The per capita income of its people -- despite 25 years of oil exports worth $210 billion -- is about $240, even lower than in Haiti.
Worse, the deadly blight in Nigeria is spreading to other African nations. Nigeria is one of the world's great transshipment and money-laundering centers for illegal drugs. Nigerian couriers are distributing drugs throughout Africa (and to many other places as well, including the United States). In South Africa, where Nelson Mandela's noble experiment is beating the odds against a miracle, a troubling rise in drug consumption is the direct result of the availability of drugs from Nigeria.
The situation in Nigeria has deteriorated to such a degree that some form of violent upheaval seems all but inevitable, perhaps even civil war. Calls are growing for increased international pressure to try to thwart such a disaster, which would threaten the stability of all of western Africa.
Amnesty International said recently, "The international community must muster any and all pressure on the government to prevent what would be a catastrophe of an unseen magnitude."
Mr. Robinson, who is leading a campaign of prominent African-Americans against the abuses in Nigeria, warned that an "explosion is awaiting." He would like the United States to lead an oil boycott aimed at undermining the Abacha regime.
Some 20 African countries, including Uganda, which endured the hideous experience of Idi Amin, have been making tremendous strides toward real political freedom and economic development. Those efforts will be completely overshadowed if a tragic meltdown occurs in Nigeria, which, with more than twice the population of South Africa, is the true colossus of the African continent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Turner's Quest for Network Now Leads to Microsoft
The media world is watching yet another effort by Ted Turner to acquire a network. In his quest to assemble financing for a bid for CBS, the head of the Turner Broadcasting System recently met with William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, to discuss an investment in Turner, according to a person with knowledge of the talks.

HEADLINE: Welcome, Nouveaux Riches

BYLINE: By David Frum; David Frum is a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute.

 BODY:
Is something weird happening at the top of the American class system? Newsweek magazine, heavily borrowing from more serious works by writers like Michael Lind and Nicholas Lemann, has gone so far as to complain of the birth of an irksome new "overclass" -- a self-congratulatory new class of arugula-eating, nanny-employing, laptop-carrying former antiwar protesters.
It's always tempting to roll one's eyes at trend journalism. But in fact, something -- if not weird, then at least peculiar -- is happening, and all the distress gives us our best clue as to what it is. Just as writers and social critics savaged the vast new middle class that emerged in the 1950's -- its vulgarity, its banality, its taste for cars with tail fins and bungalows in the suburbs -- so writers and social critics are now expressing their discomfort with an even more unprecedented and outlandish social phenomenon: history's first mass upper class. 
 Until recently, virtually everyone in America was, by contemporary standards, shockingly poor. The median male income in 1950 ($13,768 in 1994 dollars) did not reach up as far as today's federally defined poverty line ($15,141 for a family of four).
Prosperous towns had a small, affluent elite made up of doctors, lawyers and bankers. A few thousand genuinely wealthy people hugged the edges of the continent in their Boston, Newport and Manhattan enclaves. Otherwise, people congratulated themselves if they could claw their way into a solid working-class job.
Then the great postwar boom exploded. Between 1945 and 1975, tens of millions of families moved into the middle class. By 1970, more than half of all American households earned between $25,000 and $75,000 (in contemporary money).
We now look back on those years with nostalgia, but at the time this extraordinary surge of affluence provoked disdain. Scan the important books of the boom years, and one is confronted again and again by the hostility to the new mass middle class. Pete Seeger complained in one of his songs that they lived in "boxes made of ticky tacky," and people who flew over them on their way to Europe emphatically agreed.
Then, sometime around 1975, the great exodus out of poverty stopped. The proportion of American households earning less than $25,000 -- 40.3 percent in 1993, according to Census Bureau data -- is almost exactly the same as it was 20 years ago. Stranger still, the growth of the middle class reversed itself. Between 1980 and 1993, the proportion of American households earning $25,000 to $75,000 a year dropped from 50.7 percent to 47.1 percent.
Where did all those formerly middle class people go?
They didn't join the ranks of the poor: remember, the under-$25,000 proportion hasn't budged. Instead, just as the American economy pulled its most talented people out of poverty in the 1950's, it pulled the ablest of its middle class into affluence in the 1980's.
In 1950, fewer than one million American families earned as much as $60,000 in today's money. So rare was real wealth that the Census Bureau did not even keep numbers on incomes greater than that. As recently as 1967, only slightly more than one million American families earned more than $100,000 a year (in 1993 dollars).
But by 1980, 2.7 million lucky households counted incomes of more than $100,000. And by 1993, this group had doubled again, to 5.6 million households. And nearly one million American households were enjoying incomes over S200,000. The growth of high-income households accounts for virtually all of the shrinkage of middle-income households.
Nothing like this immense crowd of wealthy people has been seen in the history of the planet. And, unsurprisingly, writers and social critics have reacted with the same dyspepsia with which they once greeted the mass middle class. The millions of new rich are said to be vulgar. They are self-absorbed. They are smug.
Well, perhaps they are. Why wouldn't they be? But they are also the latest manifestation of the great miracle of modern American life, the long 20th century tidal roll of ever-increasing abundance. Some may find it amusing to abuse the big new upper class. Fair enough: mocking the recently rich is a tradition that dates back to Petronius.
But the mockers should remember two things. America's wealth is not concentrated in the hands of an elite caste. Some economists are alarmed by the recent enrichment of the top 1 percent. But the top 1 percent is not getting rich by itself. On the contrary, the new money is finding its way to a population that is not only rapidly growing but also heterogeneous.
More important, the expansion of the upper class cannot fairly be blamed for the apparent stagnation of incomes in the middle class.
Those troubles are real -- the median household income has grown by only 10 percent in 20 years -- but they originate in the turmoil of American society as much as in the economy. About 40 percent of all married couples earn incomes of more than $50,000, according to the Census data. Unfortunately, while 61 percent of American households were made up of married families in 1980, in 1992, only 55 percent were.
This is not to deny that the efflorescence of wealth confronts a country with serious new problems. Of course it does. The Bible describes them in grisly detail. But these problems are not socioeconomic; they are moral.
More than a century ago, worried by the new rich of post-Civil War America, educators like the Rev. Endicott Peabody founded a network of preparatory schools (in his case, Groton) to instill in the children of the Gilded Age rich an ethic of self-control and social responsibility. A mass elite will need to absorb Peabody's ethic in a new way.
But elites are inevitable. If we want to civilize a new and mass elite, we must accept the fact of their existence in a rather more realistic way than we have until now done.

HEADLINE: Jordan's King Speaks of 'New Era' for Iraq

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 14

 BODY:
In his first public comments on the defections of the Iraqi President's sons-in-law and daughters to Jordan, King Hussein called the episode "a very hard blow" to Iraq's leadership and expressed hope that it would "usher in a new era" for that country.
The King's remarks, published today in an Israeli newspaper, were the clearest indication yet of his break with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, reflecting a widespread perception here that Baghdad's power is waning and that it cannot retaliate against Jordan. 
 While not mentioning Saddam Hussein by name, the King said that any change in Iraq would "only be a change for the better."
The Jordanian monarch's comments to the Yediot Aharonot newspaper followed his decision to allow one of the defectors, Lieut. Gen. Hussein Kamel, to hold a news conference here on Saturday, at which the former Iraqi official vowed to work to overthrow his father-in-law.
Even the fact that the King's first comments on the defections were made to an Israeli newspaper is bound to be seen in Baghdad as a hostile act.
Israel and Iraq are bitter enemies. Iraq targeted Israel with missiles during the 1991 Persian Gulf war, and only strong American pressure restrained Israel from a major air retaliation. Furthermore, the King's remarks follow several gestures over the past two years distancing himself from Saddam Hussein.
The King's increasingly critical stance towards Iraq, an ally from 1980 through the gulf war, was underlined by two other developments in the past two days.
One was an unannounced visit on Sunday by Prince Turki al-Faisal, the chief of Saudi intelligence, who is said by Jordanians to have met with General Kamel with to try to organize a more active opposition to the Iraqi Government.
Jordanian officials also confirmed today that preparations were under way for a meeting soon between King Hussein and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia in Riyadh. The two have not been on speaking terms since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
These moves represent a significant shift in relations between Jordan and all the Arab countries on the gulf, which resented what they perceived as Jordan's support for the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and attempt to dominate the region.
While Jordanian officials continued to insist that General Kamel would not be allowed to use Jordan as a base to oppose Iraq, the King's actions suggested that Jordan is prepared to take a more active role.
"The Jordanian interest now is to see the Iraqi people in good shape under whatever regime that can achieve that," Kamal Alshaer, a member of the Jordanian Senate, said in an interview.
Jordanian officials also suggested in interviews that plans for the defection may have been communicated to the King in mid-July, when General Kamel met the monarch during an official visit to Jordan.
In the King's interview in the Israeli newspaper, he noted that he had met with General Kamel then, adding that "What he told me was in total contradiction with the official accounts, allowing me to appreciate to which point the situation has become difficult in Iraq."
That the King had failed until then to appreciate how far conditions have deteriorated is open to question. Jordanian intelligence services are well aware of the worsening social and economic situation brought about by international sanctions against Iraq since the gulf war.
Rather, it suggests the King's sense that Iraq has weakened and may be ripe for a new leadership.
Arab diplomats here pointed out that the defection has also provided the King an opportunity for reconciliation with the Arab gulf states.
With the loss, due to the gulf war and its aftermath, of what had been an extremely lucrative relationship with Iraq, earning Jordan billions of dollars in the 1980's, Jordan is eager to resume agricultural and industrial exports to the Gulf states, which have largely boycotted Jordan's products since 1990.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Miracle Worker Turned Fugitive

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

 BODY:
Few people were prepared for the finale to Gerardo de Prevoisin's ruinous attempt to build Aeromexico into Latin America's biggest airline: out of the blue, the former insurance executive quit as Aeromexico's chairman, emptied his office, purged his computer files and fled Mexico, apparently with his young secretary.
Nobody seems quite sure where Mr. Prevoisin is today, and those who may know are not telling. 
 Before his fall, he was held up as a stirring example of Mexico's efforts to put state-owned enterprises into the hands of the country's best entrepreneurs. He was admired on Wall Street, and his reputation won him the presidency of the International Air Travel Association, a club of airline chief executives.
But since his disappearance last fall, Mexico has issued a warrant for his arrest on fraud charges, and Aeromexico's new management has sued him in Mexico and the United States, accusing him of embezzling $72 million. Last week, Mexican newspapers were dominated by headlines about Mr. Prevoisin's claim, discovered in Texas court documents, that he had donated $8 million last year to Mexico's ruling party.
The emerging details of Mr. Prevoisin's tempestuous tenure, and new information about the circumstances of his departure, are etching a portrait of a self-dealing, sometimes childish and perhaps criminal corporate autocrat.
Just when Mexico is approaching a new wave of privatizations, the revelations are providing a cautionary tale of the dangers of moving too fast from state control into the uncharted waters of free enterprise.
In the six years that Mr. Prevoisin ran Aeromexico, he emitted a cacaphony of warning signals -- and all were ignored. He moved into a saturated international market and neglected his domestic routes. He made ill-considered acquisitions, saddling Aeromexico with crushing debt. And he racked up mounting losses at the company, even as he was displaying a healthy taste for luxury -- and a proclivity for scandal -- in his private life.
"He was acting like a fantastic 7-year-old child," said Julio Cesar Margain, who worked closely with Mr. Prevoisin at Aeromexico as an aviation planner.
Today, both Aeromexico and Mexicana, a domestic airline that Mr. Prevoisin took over in 1993, are being run by a group of banks. The banks are struggling to rework $2 billion in debt and to find new investors for the carriers, which control 70 percent of the Mexican market. Last Wednesday, Ernesto Martens, who succeeded Mr. Prevoisin as Aeromexico's chairman, told a news conference that "our finances today are viable, and they will permit us to continue serving Mexico."
But just avoiding bankruptcy has not been easy. Mr. Prevoisin (pronounced pray-vwah-SEEN) left the companies in such disrepair that creditors seized a Mexicana jet on a Miami runway and even slapped a lien on Aeromexico's headquarters building. Since the peso's December devaluation, the airline's dollar costs have surged and the Mexican economy has plunged into recession, making passengers scarce.
So far, a few foreign investors, including Continental Airlines, have held talks with Aeromexico, but the future is hardly secure. The Government might be reluctant to sell an airline so identified with Mexico to a foreign buyer, and some people speculate that a rich Mexican family might take control with a foreign carrier as a minority partner.
If Mr. Prevoisin's stewardship of Aeromexico ended in near disaster, it began with great hopes in late 1988, when the airline was Government-owned, bankrupt and known derisively among passengers as "ErrorMexico." President-elect Carlos Salinas de Gortari decided to sell, and Government officials persuaded Mr. Prevoisin, then a 46-year-old insurance executive and the scion of a prominent Mexican banking family, to assemble the investor group to buy it.
At first, he seemed to be making all the right moves, even though he had no experience in aviation. He hired capable managers who helped him trim the carrier's fleet by more than a third and reduce its work force of 12,000 by two-thirds. Putting emphasis on shuttle flights from Mexico City to the industrial hubs of Monterrey and Guadalajara, he established Aeromexico as Mexico's business airline. A year after he took over, more than 90 percent of Aeromexico's flights were arriving on time, compared with about 50 percent previously. Aeromexico's market share climbed to 40 percent, from 27 percent.
But then, many analysts say, Mr. Prevoisin overreached. Emboldened by his early successes, he expanded into the international market -- just when he should have been minding the store at home. The Salinas administration's deregulation of the airline industry had generated more than a dozen start-up carriers, making Mexico the most competitive market in Latin America.
Mr. Prevoisin's top aides warned him against diverting resources from the domestic market, but as on many other matters, he brushed their objections aside. His imperious style rubbed some of his fellow executives the wrong way; in two years, two chief operating officers resigned after bitter clashes with him.
"Gerardo was an abrasive autocrat, and he insisted on expanding too fast," said Guillermo Heredia, Aeromexico's chief operating officer from late 1990 through 1992. "He didn't have the resources. He should have worked to consolidate the domestic side first."
He insisted on starting new routes to Frankfurt, Rome and Paris, ignoring market studies that showed little demand, Mr. Heredia said. He ordered 18 Boeing jets for $1.2 billion, though his subordinates later canceled orders for 12. Then he became preoccupied with airline takeovers.
Allied with Charles E. Hurwitz, the Houston financier who made headlines with his efforts to chop down the virgin redwood forests he acquired in a takeover of the Pacific Lumber Company in California, Mr. Prevoisin sought during 1992 to buy Continental Airlines, which was then bankrupt. Rebuffed, he moved to acquire Mexicana, Aeromexico's main competitor, and Aeroperu, the ailing state-run airline of Peru.
Mr. Heredia argued against the purchases, and quit after his warnings were spurned. Three months later, Aeromexico purchased controlling shares of both airlines. Though they would later sap Aeromexico's finances, the takeovers initially brought Mr. Prevoisin international glory.
Later in 1993, Mr. Prevoisin's fellow airline chief executives elected him to the presidency of the International Air Travel Association, and Salomon Brothers shone Wall Street's spotlight on him at an annual transportation conference at the World Trade Center in New York.
In his personal life, Mr. Prevoisin was also flying high, assembling a fleet of luxury cars and buying a high-security vacation compound in Vail, Colo., valued at $5 million. He was also raising eyebrows in Mexico by carrying on a not-very-discreet relationship with his secretary well before his wife died of cancer, according to two close associates who insisted on anonymity. The associates said the secretary fled the country with him, and this spring, Aeromexico lawyers referred to Mr. Prevoisin's former secretary in court papers as his mistress.
Meantime, financial clouds were gathering. Aeromexico's losses widened from $37 million in 1992 to $49 million in 1993. Also in 1993, Mexicana showed a loss of $95 million.
Mexicana officials today blame Mr. Prevoisin for the worsening finances, saying that despite promising to raise $50 million from investors to help modernize Mexicana, he instead cannibalized its best routes for Aeromexico and shifted some of its planes to Aeroperu's fleet.
"Prevoisin pillaged Mexicana," said Robert D. Papkin, a Washington lawyer for Mexicana.
The Government had retained a 34 percent stake in Mexicana, and in August 1994, after the airline defaulted on several loans, Guillermo Ortiz, who was then a Treasury Under Secretary, stepped in, along with creditor banks, and demanded that Mr. Prevoisin invest $200 million in the airline or step down.
He missed their Sept. 2 deadline, and the next day, Aeromexico announced his resignation. Mr. Prevoisin "immediately removed everything from his office, had the computer records regarding his primary activities purged, and had records regarding his activities -- other than basic Aeromexico accounting records -- removed," Aeromexico's lawyers said in a civil suit the company has filed against him in Federal court in Texas, where he had conducted various business transactions.
He fled Mexico on Sept. 8, according to court papers. Mr. Prevoisin has dual French-Mexican citizenship, and Mexican authorities, though conceding uncertainty about his whereabouts, requested his extradition from France in April.
In the Texas suit, Aeromexico accused Mr. Prevoisin of embezzling $72 million, using some of it to buy his Vail properties and some of it to buy additional Aeromexico stock to increase his control.
"This guy stole money and used it to improve his equity in Aeromexico, thereby gaining additional power to steal more money," said John H. Barr, a Dallas lawyer who is representing Aeromexico in the suit.
Mr. Prevoisin's lawyers have argued in court that the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo, who took office Dec. 1, is harassing Mr. Prevoisin because of his ties to the Salinas Government. "With the recent change of administration in Mexico and the beginnings of Mexico's current political, economic and social crises, Mr. Prevoisin's prominent ties to the programs of the previous administration became a decided detriment," one defense document stated, saying he was "one of a number of prominent Mexican citizens targeted as scapegoats for the country's daunting problems."
Kenneth R. Wynne, the Houston lawyer coordinating Mr. Prevoisin's legal team, said Mr. Prevoisin had worked closely with the Government in trying to invigorate Mexico's airlines. "It would be inaccurate and unfair to portray the acquisition of Mexicana and other business decisions as only his," Mr. Wynne said. "They were the result of a lot of collective input."
Aeromexico's 1994 losses, which were made worse by the peso devaluation, were catastrophic: $453 million on revenues of $814 million. This year, Aeromexico has retreated from the brink of bankruptcy, and last week it announced the completion of a debt revamping.
"It was a step in the right direction," said George B. Pearson, an aviation consultant with extensive Mexican experience. "But it doesn't mean they are out of the woods."

Revamping Approved
 MEXICO CITY, Aug 14 (Reuters) -- A Mexican Government agency said today that it had approved, with conditions, the financial revamping plans of Aeromexico and Mexicana airlines.
A consortium of banks will control both airlines, but they must be split up within three years, the Federal Competition Commission said.
Aeromexico's restructuring plan, under which creditor banks may end up with as much as 90 percent of the airline, has already been put into effect. Mexicana's plan has yet to be formally announced.
The commission said the plan assured "that in a brief period healthy competition will be restored in the commercial aviation market."

HEADLINE: Conference Board Chooses a Harvard Dean as New Chief

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Richard E. Cavanagh, the executive dean of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, was appointed president and chief executive yesterday of the Conference Board, a worldwide organization of 2,500 leading executives, yesterday.
Mr. Cavanagh, 48, succeeds Preston Townley, who died last year. 
 The Conference Board conducts seminars, runs private forums for senior executives, publishes about 100 studies annually and surveys business conditions, including publishing a help-wanted index that measures the job market in newspapers and a monthly survey of consumer confidence.
The Conference Board is enjoying double-digit growth in attendance at its conferences and seminars. Mr. Cavanagh will lead a staff of 222 with a budget of more than $32 million.
He said that he hoped to expand the Conference Board's influence in North America and Europe into Latin America and Asia. "There will be a lot of frequent-flier miles," he said.
"What I hope to do is internationalize the Conference Board more," he said, "because business is more global these days. The second thing is that business changes and keeping relevant is a full-time task."
Mr. Cavanagh said he chose the Conference Board over offers to head large companies because "this is an organization whose whole purpose is ideas and information."
John R. Hall, the chairman of Ashland Inc., and the Conference Board chairman, said, "In Dick we found someone, out of more than 1,000 applicants, who had a background in the worlds of business through McKinsey & Company, in Government from when he was in Washington and in nonprofits from Harvard."
Albert Carnesale, provost at Harvard University, said that Mr. Cavanagh "has the rare combination of a strategic thinker and a skilled implementer," adding, "He not only gets things done, but gets the right things done."
Although Mr., Cavanagh's Harvard duties were administrative, Mr. Carnesale said, "he always tried to remember that this is a school," and he taught business ethics.
James R. Schlesinger, the Defense Secretary from 1973-75, who is chairman of the the Mitre Corporation, said that at Harvard, Mr. Cavanagh was "superb." At the Conference Board, he said, Mr. Cavanagh "should combine a degree of intellectual excellence with a pragmatism that should appeal to the business leaders who are its members."
Marjorie Kelly, publisher and editor of Business Ethics magazine in Minneapolis, said she was delighted with the appointment. "I think that there is a role for the Conference Board board to step out and speak more forcefully about business ethics and to do it in their customary way, which is with good statistics and good research," she said.
Mr. Cavanagh, who calls himself "a free-enterprise Democrat," graduated cum laude in 1968 from Wesleyan University, where he has been a trustee since 1988. He earned an M.B.A. at Harvard in 1970 and then joined McKinsey. From 1977-79, in the Carter Administration, he was an executive director of the Office of Management and Budget, where he instituted cash management improvements that the General Accounting Office said had saved the Government $12 billion annually.
He returned to McKinsey in 1979 as a partner and left in 1988 to become executive dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
Earlier this year Mr. Cavanagh married Patricia Ann Sypher, a Boston business consultant.

HEADLINE: Cigarette Vending Machine Debate Is Broadened

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
President Clinton's proposal to ban all cigarette vending machines is broadening a debate that has been unfolding in recent years in cities and towns across the nation.
Since the late 1980's, more than 120 municipalities have banned cigarette vending machines in an effort to discourage smoking by children and teen-agers, said Robin Hobart, a spokeswoman for Americans for Nonsmokers' Rights, an anti-smoking group in Berkeley, Calif. At the same time, a further 137 communities, including major cities like New York, Chicago and Seattle, have restricted where machines can be placed, often in areas where only adults are allowed, Ms. Hobart said. 
 Mitchell Zeller, a special assistant for policy at the Food and Drug Administration, said the President's proposal, part of the Government's overall effort to curtail underage smoking, could be modified after agency officials heard comments from industry executives and others. But, he added, past research indicates that only a total ban on cigarette vending machines will help stem the supply of cigarettes to the youngest smokers, those around 10 years old.
"What we have learned from tobacco control experts is that when you try limited measures, they don't work very well," Mr. Zeller said.
Whatever the case, any move to limit machine sales of cigarettes would be another blow to a steadily shrinking segment of the cigarette and vending machine industries.
Sheldon Silver, a spokesman for the National Automatic Merchandising Association, a trade association in Chicago, said Commerce Department statistics indicated that sales of cigarettes through vending machines represented only 1.2 percent of all cigarette sales in 1993. That is down sharply from the early 1970's, when Federal data indicated that vending machine sales represented 17.8 percent of all cigarette sales.
In terms of revenue, vending machine sales of cigarettes have also been declining steadily, falling to $2 billion in 1994 from $2.9 billion in 1991, according to Vending Times, a trade publication in New York City.
Still, officials of companies that operate vending machines expressed outrage over the Federal proposal, arguing that it would have little impact on underage smokers.
"It's a Band-Aid," said Jack Kerner, president of Melo-Tone Vending Inc., a vending machine operator based in Somerville, Mass. "It's going to make Mr. Clinton look like a savior with the do-gooders, but to say that this is going to stop kids from smoking is ridiculous."
Mr. Kerner also said a total ban on cigarette vending machines would have a striking economic impact on vending companies. But Mr. Zeller disputed this.
He said information collected by the F.D.A. indicated that few new cigarette machines had been shipped since 1990, and that operators were in the process of converting older cigarette machines to those that sell other products.
"The average cigarette machine sells less than five packs a day," he said.
As the dispute over cigarette vending machines has hopscotched around the country in recent years, the question of how often underage smokers use cigarette machines has been at the heart of the debate.
Mr. Silver, the trade association spokesman, said a survey commissioned five years ago by his organization found that only 9 percent of teen-agers 13 to 17 bought cigarettes from machines. Of those interviewed, the largest group, 43 percent, said they bought cigarettes from convenience, while the second-largest, 29 percent, said they made their purchases at gas stations, Mr. Silver said.
Those results are at variance with others collected by the F.D.A. A 1989 survey of 10th-grade students in Minnesota, for example, found that 71 percent had purchased tobacco from vending machines. In addition, vending machines apparently appeal to the youngest smokers. The F.D.A. said that one vending industry study had found that while only 2 percent of 17-year-olds used cigarette machines, that figure went up to 22 percent for 13-year-olds.
"A 10- or 11-year-old kid can't pass for 18 even if they have a fake I.D.," Mr. Zeller said. "They are going to do everything they can to avoid a face-to-face transaction and that is the appeal of a machine."
In efforts to counter local efforts to curtail machines, vending industry officials have argued that so-called lock-out devices can effectively prevent the sales of cigarettes to underage smokers. Essentially, a lock-out device requires a clerk, for example, to set off a mechanism that unlocks a vending machine before a sale can occur.
"Lock-outs put us on the same footing as over-the-counter sales," Mr. Kerner said. "We have taken an iron monster will no brains and said we can monitor age."
But just how effectively lock-out devices work or whether vendors use them is in question. Last year, for example, the Journal of the American Medical Association published a study of minors' access to cigarette vending machines in communities in Texas. It found that in Arlington, which has required lock-out devices since 1991, that only one of 17 machines inspected had such a mechanism.
An underage buyer sent in by a research team was unable to purchase cigarettes from that machine, but purchases were made at the 16 other machines, the study found.

HEADLINE: Takeover Bids Made for Two Big Utilities

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Two big power-company takeovers -- one hostile, one friendly -- were proposed yesterday, providing an early sign that the coming free market for electric power will lead to a major consolidation among utilities amid a struggle to cut costs.
In an attempt to unite the two companies that serve eastern Pennsylvania, Peco Energy Company, the parent of the Philadelphia Electric Company, made a hostile offer of $3.8 billion, or $24 a share in stock, for PP&L Resources Inc., the parent of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company, which serves a number of cities outside the Philadelphia area. 
 At the same time, the Union Electric Company of St. Louis and Cipsco Inc., a power company in central Illinois, agreed to merge in a stock deal valued at $1.2 billion. The companies said they expected to generate cost savings of $570 million over the next 10 years by eliminating duplicate jobs and combining other overlapping operations.
After decades of operating as government-regulated monopolies with total control over their designated service areas, electric utilities are being driven to become larger and more flexible as big industrial customers have developed the ability to generate their own power at lower cost or to go outside their local areas to buy electricity from cheaper suppliers. In response, the Federal Government and several states have moved to deregulate the industry.
"Each of these mergers is different, but the general theme is that utilities have to cut costs to become more competitive," said Barry M. Abramson of Prudential Securities Research. "Most of these companies have done a lot of cost-cutting and are as lean as they are likely to be, so a merger gives them the opportunity to cut costs again."
One of the big issues that has emerged from the various deregulation proposals is whether the benefits of a freer market in electric power will flow mostly to big industrial users at the expense of small business and residential users, who may be asked to shoulder additional costs for maintaining the vast distribution networks needed to deliver electricity.
State regulators, who must also deal with the question of who pays for investments in existing power plants that may no longer be competitive, are being forced into a difficult balancing act.
"Regulators will try hard to see that small customers will suffer no increase in costs," Mr. Abramson said, "although most of the savings will be passed on to large customers." He noted that transmission systems would remain local monopolies subject to regulation, even as competition spreads in the business of generating electricity.
Earlier this year, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved a proposal that would force electric utilities to open their transmission systems to power generated by competitors. That will allow big industrial customers to negotiate for lower rates by threatening or actually importing power from lower-cost generators in other areas.
The proposal would also give low-cost independent power companies access to the distribution grids owned by integrated utilities and allow them to compete with those utilities for desirable big customers.
Given the new rules of the road, utilities are being forced to seek combinations with neighboring systems to gain strength with their big customers and achieve economies of scale, said Robert Guberman, a vice president of A. T. Kearney, a consultancy. "The industry is not burying its head in the sand," he said. "This is the beginning of a flurry of actions -- some agreeable, some not agreeable."
The two utility proposals yesterday followed on the heels of a planned merger between the Northern States Power Company and Wisconsin Energy Corporation, two big Midwestern utilities. On May 1, they announced the intention to merge into a company to be called the Primergy Corporation, based in Minneapolis. The companies provide power to 1.3 million customers in the upper Midwest and gas to 350,000 customers. All the pending deals are subject to approval by shareholders and state regulators.
In making its hostile bid for PP&L yesterday, officials of Peco said they were doing so because months of discussions had not produced an agreement.
Joseph Paquette Jr., the chairman of Peco, in a letter to his counterpart at PP&L, said the stalemate "makes clear the need to present a specific proposal now so you and your board can fully evaluate the potential benefits a combination provides to PP&L Resources and shareholders and customers."
Mr. Paquette said the companies had adjacent service areas and would be a "natural fit." He predicted that the combined companies would be able to lower rates for electricity and save $2 billion over 10 years, with the benefits divided between shareholders and customers.
PP&L, which had been informally discussing a merger with Peco since November, expressed reservations, although it promised to "fully evaluate" the offer.
In a letter to Mr. Paquette, William F. Hecht, PP&L's chairman, said his company was concerned about Peco's "high cost structure" and whether the combined company could recover Peco's "considerable past investment costs." Moody's Investors Service recently estimated those costs above $4.86 billion, Mr. Hecht said, adding that Peco's rates were 55 percent higher than PP&L's.
In an interview, Mr. Paquette noted that the $24-a-share offer was 27 percent above PP&L's previous price and said the combination was "too good to ignore and too good to delay."
The price of PP&L's shares rose yesterday in response to the offer, closing at $21.50, up $2.625. Peco's shares declined $1, to $26.75.
If the merger is completed, the combined company would be one of the largest utilities in the nation, covering most of eastern Pennsylvania. Peco provides electricity to the city of Philadelphia and its suburbs, and supplies natural gas to the suburbs. PP&L provides both services as far west as Williamsport. The deal includes nuclear power plants, but not the Three Mile Island plant near Harrisburg, which is owned by General Public Utilities.
Union Electric and Cipsco have adjacent service areas on the Missouri and Illinois sides of the Mississippi River. "We have contiguous territories and are similar in the way we treat costs, so we will have a seamless transition," said Clifford L. Greenwalt, Cipsco's chief executive.
Part of the savings generated by a merger would be returned to customers under legislation adopted in Missouri and pending in Illinois, executives for the companies said in telephone interviews. Some of those savings will come from the elimination of 300 jobs through attrition rather than layoffs.
Under the terms of the merger, neither company would retain its current form. Instead, a new holding company would be formed, with shareholders of Union Electric getting one new share for each one held and Cipsco shareholders receiving 1.03 shares. The companies said they expected the combination to qualify as a tax-free exchange.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Prices Are Firmer in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were firmer yesterday in thin volume, despite last week's heavy supply of new issues and prospects of fresh supply just ahead.
The only new economic data out was the report on June business inventories, which was more a rear view of the economy than a forward one, and the July Atlanta Fed regional survey of manufacturing conditions. Most of the day's market activity was attributed to technical trading. 
 Dealers and traders yesterday appeared to be more focused on today's report on industrial production and capcity utilization, and tomorrow's housing starts, and Thursday's jobless claims and the Philadelphia Fed report.
The 30-year bond rose 9/32 , to a price of 992/32 for a yield 6.95 percent, down from 6.97 percent on Friday.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said: "Quite frankly the feedback from the street was quiet trading and not much volume. That's called summer."
There was a little pressure on prices, he said, because of left-over supply from the refunding last week, a lot of asset back securities and additional supply from the corporate bond side.
Mr. Donne noted that there had been a rise in Japanese money in the market since the relaxation of regulations by the Japanese Ministry of Finance a couple of weeks ago, "but not enough to disturb the market from where domestic economy and Federal Reserve policy would ordinarily take us."
He added, "I expect the market will get through this supply all right, but rates could rise a little."
"At these price levels, Treasury securities are looking more interesting," Mr. Donne said. "Everything we have seen is consistent with the modest growth and contained inflation." He said the long bond would draw considerably more interest from the market at a 7.10 percent yield, with current yields probably in a range considered fair value. "We're close to turning bullish," he said.
Yesteray's June business inventories firmed at two-tenths of 1 percent, slightly lower than the three-tenths of 1 percent that had been forecast. Retail inventories were unchanged in June and were also revised lower in May, which contributed to the overall weakness in the inventory number.
Economists noted that business sales were up seven-tenths of 1 percent, and that put the inventory to sales ratio at a fairly lean 1.30, boding well for third- quarter economic growth.
The July Atlanta Fed index of regional manufacturing conditions moved into positive territory in July at 6.1 from a negative 5.0 in June. James Hale, an analysts at MMS International, a San Francisco-based market research and analysis firm, said that would translate "into a National Puchasing Management index adjustment of 54.8 percent, up from 49.9 percent." "And," he added, "that is consistent with the gradual return to expansionary manufacturing levels that other indices have signaled."
Mr. Hale also noted that the Atlanta price index fell 7 points, to 20.3 in July, in line with other signs of moderating inflation at the intermediate level of production.
At yesterday's regular weekly bill auction, rates were slightly higher, with the three-month maturity up one basis point, to 5.42 percent, and the highest since July 31, when the rate was 5.44 percent, while the six-month issue was two basis points higher at 5.42 percent and the highest since July 24, when it was 5.46 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Growth in Inventories Is Slower, In Adjustment to Lower Demand

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Stockpiles of unsold goods grew in June at the slowest pace in 15 months as American businesses adjusted to weaker consumer demand for autos and other big-ticket items, the Commerce Department reported today.
Growth in business sales also slowed. 
 The Commerce Department said inventories increased two-tenths of 1 percent in June, to a seasonally adjusted $958.46 billion. While the monthly increase was the 15th in a row, it was the smallest during that period. In May, inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent.
Economists had expected a gain in June of three-tenths of 1 percent, a survey by Bloomberg Business News found.
In the slowdown that has followed last year's burst of economic growth, many businesses have been saddled with excess supplies of goods, ranging from autos to cellular telephones.
In June, companies "went a long way to eliminate their inventory overhang," said Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York. "But they still haven't reached a point where they want to start restocking."
If companies do not restock, the economy may slow further. But many companies may be close to the point at which they are ready to increase ordering again. Last week, the Federal Reserve's survey of nationwide economic conditions said inventories were at manageable levels in many parts of the country.
A separate report today from the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta suggested that the economy might be gaining momentum. The Atlanta Fed reported that manufacturing production rose in July in the Southeast.
Still, consumers are being stingy. "Increased debt and slower job growth will limit improvement through the end of the year," said Scott Brown, an economist at Raymond James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla., referring to spending. Preliminary Government figures released last week showed that retail sales fell one-tenth of 1 percent in July.
The inventory gain reported for June reflected increases in stockpiles of wholesale and manufacturers' goods. Retailers' inventories showed no change. Supplies decreased at auto dealers because of discounting and promotions.
The report from the Commerce Department also showed that business sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, to a seasonally adjusted $683.08 billion, after increasing eight-tenths of 1 percent in May.
The inventory-to-sales ratio, a measure of how long it would take to sell goods currently stockpiled, fell to 1.40 months in June. That was the lowest ratio since January and a decline from 1.41 in May, a Government spokeswoman said. In June 1994, the ratio stood at 1.39.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Strong Rally in Japan Fades Later in Europe and U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar's rally stalled yesterday as a bout of profit taking in the United States and Europe weakened earlier gains in Asia and left the currency little changed.
"Today's been pretty much a non-event," said John McCarthy, a foreign-exchange manager with ING Capital Markets. 
 In Tokyo, there was unconfirmed speculation that the Bank of Japan was buying dollars at an exchange rate of 94 yen. That helped the dollar surpass the five-month high it hit against the Japanese yen on Friday in New York.
But the dollar started losing ground during European trading, narrowing its gains. The dollar ended unchanged against the German mark and barely down against the yen. Once trading commenced in New York, the dollar-selling expanded as traders locked in profits from the currency's recent strong advances.
"We've come a long way in a fairly short time with the dollar, ' said Dennis Pettit, a foreign-exchange manager with the New York branch of Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.
In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 93.66 yen, down from 93.90 in New York on Friday. The dollar fell to 1.4360 German marks from 1.4396 marks. The British pound rose to $1.5720 from $1.5709.
On Friday, the dollar reached a two-and-a-half-month high against the mark and a five-month high against the yen.
Those highs were the culmination of several weeks of intervention by the Japanese central bank and two joint interventions by the central banks of Japan and the United States on behalf of the dollar.
The dollar has also been bolstered by the Japanese Government's announced program to encourage Japanese investors to invest abroad.
In addition, the market's optimism has been fueled by speculation that the German central bank will lower interest rates next month and that the Federal Reserve will not reduce rates anytime soon. Lower interest rates tend to weaken a currency by making bank deposits denominated in it less attractive.
Since July 6, the dollar has gained 10 percent against the yen and 4 percent against the mark.
Traders said yesterday that the markets ignored economic data from the Commerce Department showing that businesses held their inventory growth to the smallest gain in 15 months. Some analysts surmised that the economy entered the second half of the year with little risk of recession.

HEADLINE: When a Hard-Nosed Producer Insists on New York

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
Dick Wolf, executive producer and creator of "Law and Order," was "pouring" money, as he puts it, into the economy of New York City. He had rented the parents' association room of the Collegiate School on West End Avenue in Manhattan for an actors' run-through. (Cost of room rental: $200 the first three hours, $25 each additional half-hour.)
A few blocks away, on West 81st Street, another episode of the show was being shot with a cast and crew of nearly 100 and some 22 trucks and cars. All night long, two "parking P.A.'s" (parking production assistants) had sat alone in their cars in the darkness, holding spaces for "Law and Order" vehicles. (Cost, $85 per man per 12-hour shift.) 
 Sometimes, especially on the Upper West Side, residents get so mad about losing parking spaces to "Law and Order" crews that they throw bottles or try to ram the P.A.'s with their cars. Still, Mr. Wolf says, every day he shoots in New York, he spends $70,000 to $75,000. And every year he shoots at least 22 episodes of "Law and Order," produced in association with Universal Television. Each episode costs $1.4 million, $1 million of which is spent directly in the city.
A record number of films and television shows are being shot in New York City this summer, including five prime-time dramatic network series -- among them "Central Park West" and "New York News" -- and about 20 feature films. Last year, said Patricia Reed Scott, Commissioner of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater, and Broadcasting, film and television companies spent about $1.7 billion in the city. By far the biggest proportion of that revenue came from television production, at just under $1 billion. But the economic impact, Ms. Scott said, is actually 2.3 times the amount spent directly.
Movies and television shows are now the country's second-largest export, after aircraft and aerospace. And New York City has now become the second-most-important venue for television production after Los Angeles, with more than 100 programs, including studio shows, currently on television produced here.
One reason for the boom, Ms. Scott said, "is the persistence of Dick Wolf," who has insisted that his shows be shot here. Another is the success of "Law and Order," now entering its sixth season, making it the second-longest running dramatic series currently on network television. (Only "Murder, She Wrote" has run longer.)
"Dick Wolf makes brilliant use of New York's great acting pool," Ms. Scott said. "He's brilliant at capitalizing on the headlines."
At the run-through at the Collegiate School the other day, two actors were discussing a plot development: growing romantic tension between the assistant district attorney, Claire Kincaid, played by the Canadian Jill Hennessy, and her boss, Jack McCoy, played by Sam Waterston, who like many actors in "Law and Order" is a veteran of the Broadway stage.
"I don't think it's gone that far," Ms. Hennessy said of the on-screen relationship.
"If it had, we wouldn't tell any of you!" said Mr. Waterston, drawing a laugh from the crew.
"The more of us who don't know, the better it's going to play," said Mr. Wolf.
"I know where it can come out -- the Hugh Grant episode!" said Michael Chernuchin, the writer of that script and an executive producer of "Law and Order," referring to a forthcoming episode reminiscent of Mr. Grant's recent legal difficulties.
The show's "bible" -- the source of many of its stories -- is "the front page of The New York Post," said Mr. Wolf. "There is a tabloid sense to the show. When something major happens, we can be on the air in 10 weeks." There have been episodes based on the deaths of Lisa Steinberg, the heiress Anne Scripps Douglas and Libby Zion, daughter of the journalist Sidney Zion.
There was a time when "Law and Order" was just about the only prime-time dramatic series being shot in New York City, because of the high cost of filming here. In 1991-92, producers boycotted the city because of a dispute with local craft unions over pension and welfare payments.
Mr. Wolf, who already had a contract with the unions, stood his ground and continued to film here. Still, in 1992, with shows fetching lower prices in syndication, he was under pressure to cut costs by pulling "Law and Order" from New York City. This time, Mr. Wolf sat down with the craft unions and won changes in work rules.
The next year he won further concessions to produce "New York Undercover," which stars Malik Yoba and Michael DeLorenzo and is now going into its second season on Fox Television. Mr. Wolf's contract has become a model for other contracts between television producers and unions.
Mr. Wolf, a large, rough-spoken man of 48, was born and reared in New York City. "I moved to California because that's where the business is, but I've been trying to get back ever since," he said. During his childhood the Dodgers were still in Brooklyn, and there was the Roxy theater to delight a boy.
The son of an advertising executive, Mr. Wolf followed in his father's footsteps. He wrote the slogan, "I'm Cheryl, Fly Me," for National Airlines, and "You Can't Beat Crest for Fighting Cavities." In 1977 he moved to California to write feature films, among them "Masquerade," "No Man's Land" and "School Ties." But the struggle wore him down. "Getting a script on film is basically like getting hit by lightning on a sunny day," he said.
Out of frustration, Mr. Wolf turned to television, where the route from script to production is faster. He worked on "Hill Street Blues" and "Miami Vice." In late 1988 he pitched the idea for "Law and Order" to network executives. The series is a "catch 'em and cook 'em show," as Mr. Wolf puts it -- meaning the cops hunt for the killer, and the district attorneys then try to bring the criminal to justice.
He insisted that "Law and Order" be shot in New York City. Universal Television balked, but then, Mr. Wolf said, the president of Universal Television, Kerry McCluggage, "bit the bullet and let us come into New York."
Every episode of "Law and Order" shot in New York City costs about $25,000 more than it would in California -- "and that's still too much for the bean counters," Mr. Wolf said. The city is not hospitable to film crews, and every time his trucks get stuck in traffic it costs "thousands of dollars" in overtime.
His crews sometimes block traffic and tie up elevators. The rumble of generators and the blast of floodlights on night shoots keep people awake. "It's one thing we constantly apologize for," Mr. Wolf said. "You know how annoying it can be when a film crew is in your building." Nevertheless, he insists, "98 percent of the reaction has been positive."
Besides, he said, New York City has an ineffable something -- an almost overwhelming atmosphere -- that has made him insist on shooting here rather than in California. "The light in California is different," he said. "It doesn't have that gritty, grainy quality." Mr. Wolf also wants to be able to see high rises through the windows of the rooms in his scenes.
And then there is weather: he wants to be able to shoot in rain and snow and boiling sun. "In Toronto, they 'dressed' an alley with garbage to try and make it look like New York," he said, "but the city came and cleaned up the alley."
"Everything else supposedly shot in New York doesn't look like New York," Mr. Wolf said. " 'N.Y.P.D. Blue' is one of my favorite shows. But I can tell you every scene not shot in New York. When you hear a cop talk on 'Law and Order,' you know it's a New York cop."
"There is a different type of actor in Manhattan than in Los Angeles," he continued. "Manhattan actors are predominantly stage actors. They are used to looking at the totality of the show, rather than just their scenes."
Over the years Mr. Wolf has availed himself of actors with experience on Broadway, like Jerry Orbach, who plays Detective Lennie Briscoe. (His sidekick, played by Chris Noth, has been replaced this season by Benjamin Bratt, who will play a new character, Reynaldo Curtis, "a smart young Latino police detective." Mr. Bratt has a California background.) Broadway actors who have made guest appearances on the show include Ron Leibman, James Earl Jones and Elaine Stritch.
At the moment Mr. Wolf is developing two new shows that he insists must be shot here. One is "Swift Justice," "a kind of Batman without the mask," he said. The other is "Feds," about the United States Attorney's Office in Manhattan.
"Anything that's ever happened on the planet can happen in New York City," Mr. Wolf said. "There are eight million stories in the Naked City. And we've only done 112."
