HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
City's Plan To Improve Stadium Criticized

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
An expert hired by the Yankees to assess the latest proposal by New York City to keep the team playing in the Bronx has said the improvements are inadequate and will not speed traffic flow to and from Yankee Stadium.
George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, has regularly cited heavy traffic, poor access to garages and inadequate parking as some of the reasons for his dissatisfaction with Yankee Stadium. 
 The expert's analysis is not an automatic rejection of the plan, said David Sussman, the team's general counsel. "We look to meet again with the city soon to see what direction this must take," he said, although no meeting has been scheduled. "It will take time for the city to digest the report."
But he added, "There isn't much additional time to get this thing going."
The Yankees' 30-year lease at Yankee Stadium expires in 2002.
The city and the team have been squabbling for two years about where the Yankees will play after 2002. Forrest Taylor, chief of staff to Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson, said:"The city recognizes Yankee Stadium as one of the many jewels in New York City's crown and is therefore committed to keeping the Yankees there. We'll continue to aggressively pursue solutions to the concerns raised by the Yankees."
Taylor would not discuss the findings of the Yankees' expert, nor would a spokesman for Clay Lifflander, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, which hired Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum to draw up the stadium plan.
The expert, Vollmer Associates, was hired to assess Hellmuth's architectural plan and made its findings known July 24 at a City Hall meeting.
Hellmuth proposed building three garages with 6,000 parking spaces adjacent to the stadium and enlarging an existing one; building a new bridge across the Harlem River and building new ramps from the Major Deegan Expressway and the 145th Street Bridge. The plan also calls for adding retail stores, entertainment attractions and a new outer wall around the stadium for concourses.
Sussman said Vollmer reported that "the highway system and infrastructure that supports it has so many fundamental problems that the introduction of new garages and roads leading there doesn't change the traffic impediments to the site."
Although the proposed new and expanded garages provide the parking required by the Yankees, Vollmer said the new roads and bridge "do not alleviate the overriding impediment, which is it takes an hour and a half to three hours to get out of the stadium."
The consultant did not make any recommendations to modify the proposal.
"That's not the role of the expert or of the Yankees," Sussman said.
Vollmer also raised questions about the city's ability to manage the costs of the project and get the necessary approvals to proceed with the work, which would also include converting local streets to dedicated access roads.
"Approvals aren't only about whether, but when," Sussman said. "If it can be approved, what's the duration of construction and what is the cost?"
Sussman added, "With the end of the lease seven years out, and trying to be as realistic about the construction and approval times, there isn't much additional time to get this going."
The expert's opinion may be one step away from the team's rejecting the city's latest plan, which was excoriated at a community hearing last February as overly favorable to the Yankees and an insult to the neighborhood. Several people criticized the plan as creating an enclave around the stadium while shutting out local residents and causing parks and playing areas to be moved.
Separately, the city has also met recently with Fred Wilpon, the Mets' co-owner, about plans to build a new stadium and entertainment complex on the site of Shea Stadium. "It was very positive," Taylor said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
World Bank Cancels Nepal Project Loan

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
The World Bank's new president, signaling that the institution is taking a more cautious approach to lending, has withdrawn $175 million in credits promised to a hydroelectric project in Nepal, canceling the $1 billion development.
James D. Wolfensohn, who has been the international lending agency's president for about two months, said Nepal was too poor for the power project to succeed. The decision was announced last Friday. 
 The withdrawal of the promised credits from the project, known as Arun 3, was a sign that Mr. Wolfensohn wants the World Bank -- which spent $10.4 billion on development last year -- to become more cautious in financing big infrastructure projects.
It also means that a borrowing country's ability to manage a development project, and to profit from it, is likely to become an increasingly important consideration when the World Bank decides whether or not to offer financial backing.
"Canceling Arun 3 signals a very rigorous approach to evaluation," said Jan Piercy, the United States representative on the World Bank's executive board.
In announcing the cancellation, the bank said that the increase in domestic electricity rates needed for the project's success, along with expensive new social and environmental programs, was "beyond what Nepal could realistically have achieved at present."
Bruce Rich of the Environmental Defense Fund said, "We've not previously seen the bank put such public stress on insuring projects are properly implemented."
The bank also said it doubted that other donors would provide additional funds after a finding last year by the Federal Audit Office of Germany that Arun 3 "is not ripe for decision at this stage, especially in regard to its economic viability, sustainability and the minimization of risk."
The Nepalese project had been opposed for years by many private environmental and antipoverty groups. They saw it as an example of World Bank lending for big projects that in some cases had backfired, increasing poverty and harming the environment instead.
Opponents of the power project argued that it was too large and costly for a country whose population, they said, had an average income of only $180 a year. Instead, they favored building many smaller hydroelectric stations.
"This was a 200-megawatt plant costing $1 billion, when the rule of thumb is $1 million per megawatt," said Patrick McCully of the International Rivers Network, a California environmental group. "It was too expensive and would have undermined other development priorities."
In making its announcement, the bank promised to develop "alternative approaches to meeting Nepal's energy needs."
As a result of the protests, Arun 3 last year became the first development project to be referred to an independent inspection panel that the World Bank created, under Congressional pressure, to evaluate complaints about projects. The panel initially sided with the project's critics, but reversed that position after the World Bank proposed "remedial measures."
Ultimately, however, Mr. Wolfensohn canceled the planned credits after a review carried out by Maurice Strong, a Canadian businessman who organized the United Nations' Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro in 1992.
Within the World Bank, concern about big projects began in 1992, when a report by a former bank official found that 37.5 percent of projects backed by the bank were performing badly, often because of mismanagement by the borrowing country. The growth of World Bank lending had already begun to slow as a result.
Later this year, Brazilian environmental groups plan to ask the inspection panel to rule that the Rondonia state government is mismanaging a project intended to repair damage to the Amazon rain forest caused by road building.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Advance Despite Loss Earlier in Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The bond market yesterday showed the resiliency that it has displayed many times this year, recovering from early losses to end with modest gains.
Bond prices fell early in the day following comments by Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, which indicated that the Fed was unlikely to cut interest rates anytime soon without evidence that the economy is slowing. 
 But as the price of the 30-year bond fell and its yield approached 7 percent, buyers began to emerge, traders said.
The rebound was helped by a report on industrial production and capacity utilization, which was weaker than expected.
The price of the 30-year bond settled up 24/32 of a percentage point, to 99 26/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 6.89 percent, from 6.95 percent on Monday.
The Federal Reserve said yesterday that industrial production rose one-tenth of 1 percent in July after a revised one-tenth of 1 percent drop in June. Industrial production was unchanged in May. Capacity utilization fell to 83.4 percent, the sixth consecutive monthly decline. While capacity use was a little higher than the 83.1 percent forecast, that was largely a result of increased use of electric power during the heat wave in July.
"Indeed, were it not for the heat wave, industrial production would have dropped in July," noted Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities. Manufacturing output dipped two-tenths of 1 percent, with motor vehicles the weakest sector and computer and office equipment the strongest.
Bond prices opened lower after Mr. Blinder, in an interview Monday night, indicated that economy would have to weaken from current levels before the Fed would again push interest rates lower.
Eric Hamilton, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said Mr. Blinder's comments "spooked traders who were still factoring in the chance for another easing at next week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting." The committee sets Fed interest rate policy.
But bonds soon recovered, rising in the late afternoon after the release of a Johnson Redbook report showing lackluster store sales in the first two weeks of August.
Bonds were also bolstered by a surge in the dollar. The currency rose to its highest level in six months after the Fed and the Japanese and German central banks bought dollars on foreign exchange markets.
Mr. Hamilton of Technical Data said the stronger dollar prompted those who were selling short, or betting that bond prices would fall, to cover their positions, pushing the market higher.
"Looking ahead, the stronger dollar intervention seen today should continue to have a positive impact on the market," he said. "Those central banks now holding a fresh supply of dollars typically look to put these funds back into the Treasury market." This, he added, should be enough to keep the downside of the market protected over the next couple of trading sessions.
Mr. Fine of Chase Securities, however, noted that the market could soon have other concerns. "Lurking in the minds of bonds market participants is tomorrow's announcement of two-year and five-year Treasury notes," he said. "Both issues are expected to be increased in size, and will temporarily add to the market's supply distribution woes." .
In the municipal bond market, where states, cities and their agencies sold $1.089 billion in new securities through negotiated and competitive sale, Los Angeles priced one of the larger issues.
The city sold $229 million in general obligation bonds through competitive bidding won by BA Securities. The serial bonds are insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company and are rated triple-A by the rating agencies.
Underwriters said the serial bonds were priced to yield from 3.75 percent for a bond due in 1996 to 6.30 percent for those due in 2015.

HEADLINE: Utility Output Offsets Weak U.S. Industry

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Hot weather kept utility companies busy and bolstered national industrial output in July for the first time in five months, the Federal Reserve said today, offsetting widespread weakness among manufacturing businesses.
Total production by the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose a slight one-tenth of 1 percent after a revised one-tenth of 1 percent drop in June. But capacity-use rates edged lower for the sixth month in a row, so that industries ran at 83.4 percent of their maximum, the lowest since February 1994, when they were at 83.2 percent. 
 Analysts said the industrial sector was slowly pulling out of a slump caused by big stockpiles of unsold goods. Consumer caution about buying new cars and other costly goods diminished the positive impact of steady business investment in new machinery.
"It looks like companies were trying to keep everyone cool in July and increase their computing power, but aside from that, not much else was happening," said Lynn Reaser, an economist at the First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. "Clearly the economy does not appear to be in recession, but it's quite weak."
In fact, production at manufacturing companies fell for a fourth month in a row as the year's second half opened, down two-tenths of 1 percent after drops of one-tenth of 1 percent in May and June and a seven-tenths of 1 percent decline in April.
"The decline in manufacturing was led by a 3.2 percent drop in the output of motor vehicles and parts, but the output of many other industries also decreased significantly," the Fed reported, especially for suppliers to auto makers.
"Gains at producers of electrical machinery, industrial machinery and computer equipment and paper helped stanch the decline," the central bank said. Computer output rose 3.7 percent and electrical machinery output was up 2.2 percent.
The key factor that kept overall industrial output from sagging was a 3.6 percent jump in production by utility companies, which strained to generate enough power to keep air- conditioners working in an exceptionally hot summer. Utility output had fallen nine-tenths of 1 percent in June.
Mining industries' output rose 1 percent in July because of coal mining and oil and gas production. Their output was up a slight three-tenths of 1 percent in June.
The economic expansion slowed to a five-tenths of 1 percent annual growth rate in the second quarter of this year, from 2.7 percent in the first quarter as inventories mounted in the face of fading consumer demand.
As auto makers retooled for 1996 models and closed some plants temporarily in July, assembly rates for new cars held steady at 6 million a year, but the rate for light trucks fell to 4.8 million from 5.3 million a year in June.

HEADLINE: TRACK & FIELD;
Out of Banishment and Back in Race

BYLINE: By MARC BLOOM 

 BODY:
For four years Danny Harris, the 1984 Olympic silver medalist in the 400-meter hurdles and the runner who ended Edwin Moses's 10-year unbeaten streak, led a double life.
Competing on the Grand Prix circuit in Europe, Harris won most of his races, set records and, in 1990, was ranked No. 1 in the world. At home in Los Angeles during the off season, Harris was a cocaine addict. 
 Now Harris, who turns 30 next month, has only one life to live. And in Zurich tonight at the Weltklasse track and field meet, he will face his biggest challenge since returning to competition after a drug suspension.
Harris, the only track and field athlete in the world ever suspended for cocaine use, will compete against Derrick Atkins of Atlanta, the gold medalist at last week's world championships in Sweden.
"My goal this summer is to beat all the medalists from the world games," said Harris, who did not make this summer's United States team because of a hamstring muscle injury.
Last month, after the injury cleared up, Harris won a race in Nice, France, in 47.98 seconds, the same time run by Atkins in Sweden. Harris also won in Stockholm and was a close second to Atkins in London.
"It's exciting to be running again," Harris said. "Staying healthy is the most important thing."
The London meet, in Crystal Palace, was especially poignant for Harris. It was there a year ago when he was denied entry on the eve of the event. Despite being reinstated months earlier by U.S.A. Track and Field, the American governing body, Harris was still considered ineligible by the International Amateur Athletic Federation, which rules the sport worldwide.
Harris had tested positive for cocaine use in February 1992 at the United States National Indoor Meet in Madison Square Garden. He was given a four-year suspension.
In 1994, following successful drug rehabilitation, Harris's ban was cut to two years by American authorities, who permitted him to compete immediately. But the I.A.A.F. did not concur with the United States' ruling until the end of the season.
Harris first turned to cocaine while on the threshold of becoming one of the sport's superstars. As an 18-year-old Iowa State freshman, he was considered the baby of the 1984 Olympic team, coming within a stride of Moses in Los Angeles. That year, he broke the world junior record five times.
After winning three successive N.C.A.A. titles, Harris left Iowa State to compete on the international circuit.
"It was an economic decision," said Harris, the youngest of six children who was raised by his grandmother in Perris, Calif., after both his parents died.
Harris earned money from races and received a shoe contract with Nike. He was considered Moses's successor when he stopped Moses's streak at 107 straight victories during 1987 and ran 47.48 to finish a close second to Moses at the world meet in Rome.
In 1988, Harris was the Olympic gold-medal favorite but was crushed when he did not make the United States team. "That's when I started experimenting with cocaine," said Harris, who now lives in Ames, Iowa.
Harris insisted he did not use the drug while competing abroad. He said the overall effects of cocaine, however, may have contributed to his fifth-place showing at the 1991 world meet in Tokyo.
While banned substances like anabolic steroids are considered an aid to performance, for their muscle-building tendencies, cocaine can be a hindrance, especially in technical events like the 400 hurdles.
"Cocaine can impair neurological function, and upset your stride pattern between the hurdles," said Bob Adams, a sports medicine physician, who was with the American squad in Sweden.
"Because of cocaine," said Harris's coach, Steve Lynn of Iowa State, "Danny probably lost a world record."
When the positive test was announced, Harris also lost his new home and his shoe contract. He was broke.
"It was devastating," he said. "But at the same time I felt relief. My secret was out. I did not have to protect it any longer."
Harris completed two drug rehabilitation programs in California and still attends counseling sessions regularly.
"I've been clean for a couple of years," he said. "Have I licked it? Cocaine is not something you lick. It's something you respect and are on guard about every day."

HEADLINE: University Admits Depriving Workers Paid as Contractors

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The Texas A & M University System admitted yesterday that it had illegally paid 400 farm laborers as independent contractors rather than as employees, cheating the Government out of about $86,000 in payroll taxes and depriving the workers of unemployment, disability and Social Security benefits.
The university decision was remarkable not only because a large institution publicly acknowledged its error and accepted responsibility, but also because it illustrated how organized labor and advocates for the poor can use existing laws to protect workers who are denied legally required benefits. 
 The Internal Revenue Service said that eight years ago it estimated that 3.7 million employees were illegally being paid as independent contractors, but that the number has ballooned since then following huge layoffs by corporations and Government agencies. The I.R.S. said it could not give a precise number because it has not had the funds to update its survey.
In recent months the I.R.S. -- with the aim of increasing Government revenues -- has intensified its audits of large employers, notably I.B.M. just last month, which make extensive use of contract workers. Often companies, after huge layoffs, have hired outside contractors to replace the laid-off workers, but in some cases the very workers who were discharged have been brought back as contractors.
House Republicans have been supporting a bill that would liberalize the use of independent contractors, and in June delegates to the White House Conference on Small Business voted worker classification laws those most in need of clarification.
The issue of contractor versus employee is a complex one under I.R.S. rules, but the essential test is whether the employer exercises control over the work. Companies often prefer to use contractors because not only do they save on taxes, which become the sole liability of the person hired, but also they are much freer to use people intermittently without having to pay severance or unemployment benefits. But when an employee is misclassified as an outside contractor, the employer may be liable for all the back taxes owed.
The Texas A & M infractions occurred in 1990-93, and were discovered by Texas Rural Legal Aid, an advocacy organization for the poor, which brought a class-action suit on behalf of Berene Murillo, a farm laborer in Plainview, Tex., and others.
The university then asked the I.R.S. to audit it to determine any tax liability. William J. Helwig, a lawyer for the university system, said the audit found illegally paid workers at 10 of the university system's 18 agricultural experiment stations, which grow crops and test farming techniques.
"We have instituted a system of management controls and audits" to prevent a recurrence, Mr. Helwig said.
Lawyers for the Texas Rural Legal Aid said the impact of the admission and settlement should extend beyond Texas and beyond farm laborers.
William H. Beardall, litigation director for Texas Rural Legal Aid, said, "We really expect that the example set by Texas A & M in admitting what it did was illegal, in taking remedial steps and its promised efforts to educate farmers will go farther in suppressing this practice than any other effort which has been undertaken in Texas or the nation."
Marc Grossman, a spokesman for the United Farm Workers of America, said he was pleased that an institution would acknowledge its errors, but said, "The practice is pervasive and widespread across the country despite what the law says." He added that the Government had "never done anything serious to stop this abuse."
The Texas A & M University system, which comprises eight campuses with 76,000 students and seven state agencies, including 18 Texas Agricultural Experiment Stations, held a joint news conference with the Texas Rural Legal Aid yesterday. The university promised to pay all back taxes, which it estimated at $86,000, to pay $120 to each affected worker and in the future to pay all farm laborers as employees.
"When one of the nation's largest educational institutions can fall into a practice that cheats ordinary workers out of their Social Security benefits," Mr. Beardall said, "it illustrates how widespread the problem is."
The system will also pay Texas Rural Legal Aid $30,000 to cover legal fees and spend $20,000 for advertisements in Spanish language newspapers to announce the settlement and advise laborers how to collect the $120 payments.
Bob Merrifield, deputy director of the Texas Agriculture Experiment Station, said the university system would also publish a pamphlet telling farmers that farm laborers must be paid as employees.
"Of course we acknowledge that mistakes were made," Mr. Merrifield said, "but there was never any overt attempt to defraud these workers. We have moved to correct these mistakes and implemented controls to insure that they do not re-occur."
Mrs. Murillo, the only named plaintiff, said at the news conference in Austin, the state Capitol, that she sought help from Texas Rural Legal Aid because the I.R.S. was demanding taxes, penalties and interest and she was denied jobless benefits.
"I have always hoed cotton and harvested vegetables," Mrs. Murillo, who is 55, said through an interpreter. "I am very proud of my work. But what really bothered me, angered me, was that my bosses never paid into my Social Security, because when I reach my old age and I won't be able to work, I won't have any way to support myself." With the settlement, she should be eligible for Social Security benefits.
In an interview later, Mrs. Murillo said: "I feel good about the settlement because now this won't happen to me or other people. It's good for all the workers, so they won't be treated as self-employed."
The lawsuit contended that the Agricultural Extension Service fraudulently paid Mrs. Murillo as an independent contractor to save 51 cents an hour in payroll taxes.
Mrs. Murillo, the suit said, should have been paid $3.80 an hour. Under Texas law, employers must pay the entire Social Security taxes for farm laborers, Kay E. Drought, a Texas Rural Legal Aid lawyer, said. Because she made so little money, Mrs. Murillo would have just 7 cents an hour deducted for Federal income taxes and should have netted $3.73 an hour.
But as an independent contractor, Mrs. Murillo would have been liable for the full amount of Social Security, which together with income taxes would have netted her $3.22 an hour.
From the employer's side, the agricultural extension service would have paid $3.80 in wages plus 51 cents in disability, unemployment and Social Security taxes for a total cost of $4.31 per hour.
Individuals like homeowners have no obligation to report payments to the I.R.S. when they hire an outside contractor like a plumber or electrician, because they could not deduct these payments. However, businesses, including institutions like Texas A & M, must report these payments on a Form 1099.
Gilbert Cardenas, a labor economist at University of Texas-Pan American in Edinburg, Tex., who studies farm workers, said the settlement "is a victory for the migrant farm workers because it's bringing the issue into the open and people are admitting mistakes."
"For the Texas A & M system, a particularly proud institution, to admit responsibility for errors and to move to correct those errors as humbly and contritely as they did in the press conference should be an example to other employers who violate the law," Mr. Beardall said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Texas A & M has admitted illegally paying 400 farm laborers as independent contractors. The university settled a class-action lawsuit brought on behalf of one of the farm workers, Berene Murillo, right. The settlement was announced yesterday in Austin, Tex., by William J. Helwig, left, a lawyer for the university, and by Kay E. Drought and Joaquin Amaya Jr., lawyers for the farm workers. (Associated Press)(pg. D4)

HEADLINE: 3-Nation Effort Propels Dollar Sharply Higher

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Moving with rare unity, the United States, Germany and Japan today sent the dollar soaring to its highest levels in nearly six months by buying more than a billion dollars in currency markets around the globe.
The Bank of Japan bought dollars for yen in Tokyo, the Bundesbank purchased dollars with marks in Frankfurt and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York spent yen and marks alike to buy dollars in New York. When it was all over, the dollar had risen 2.9 percent against the mark, to 1.4778 marks, and 3.5 percent against the yen, to 96.99 yen. 
 Coming on top of earlier gains this summer, the dollar has now recovered most of the losses it suffered against those currencies during its deep slump from January through April, when it briefly touched a low of 79.80 yen.
[The dollar continued to climb in Asian trading Wednesday, rising as high as 99.05 yen.]
A senior Treasury official in the United States said that today's intervention showed that the world's seven leading economic powers were successfully coordinating their currency policies. The finance ministers of those nations, known as the Group of Seven, announced in a communique after a meeting in April that they wanted an "orderly reversal" of the dollar's decline.
"What has happened since is a function of the agreement that all of the seven nations had when they sat around the table," said the senior Treasury official, who insisted on anonymity.
Yet international coordination is always easier when it means doing what countries already need to do for domestic reasons. Both Japan and Germany are struggling with stagnant economies, and driving down the value of their currencies will make their goods cheaper and easier to sell in foreign markets.
The United States and Japan tried repeatedly to brake the dollar's slide last winter, with little success. Several rounds of intervention this summer, coming after the dollar had begun to recover, have proved much more effective.
While American officials kept to their policy today of refusing to discuss where they want the dollar to go in the future, traders predicted today that the dollar could break through the psychologically important level of 100 yen to the dollar in the coming days or weeks. The dollar last traded at 100 yen in early January.
Today's intervention was notable not for its scale, but for the vigorous participation by the Bundesbank of Germany, which had previously played a secondary role or abstained. The new level of coordination, and a strategy of trying to ambush the market when it least expects it, has proved more effective in steering currency markets, where the daily volume of trading dwarfs the sums spent by governments in interventions.
Nor have currency interventions alone been responsible for the dollar's rise. The Japanese Government has made it easier for financial institutions there to take their money out of the country and buy dollars, while the strengthening American economy and rising financial markets have made the United States an attractive place to invest.
Still, the dollar remains well below its levels of even five years ago, when it was trading at around 160 yen, and even further below its peak in 1985, when central banks began large-scale efforts to drive the dollar down after it peaked at 263 yen.
When the dollar buys more yen, marks and other foreign currencies, then imported products, from Japanese cars to German beer, may become cheaper or rise in price less quickly than otherwise. In addition, many American tourists overseas find their vacations less expensive.
But the effects of currency shifts are often muffled, particularly for Americans buying foreign products, as companies tend to wait and see if the currency rates represent a genuine trend. That might be particularly true this time, because many foreign companies, notably Japanese car makers, never passed along to consumers the full cost of the dollar's fall earlier this year.
A few economists today questioned whether a strong dollar was in the interests of the United States. C. Fred Bergsten, the head of the Institute for International Economics here, predicted that the trade deficit, already headed for a record of as much as $180 billion this year, could widen to as much as $250 billion in a couple of years as the dollar rises.
Still, a stronger dollar does give the Federal Reserve more leeway to cut short-term interest rates, which stimulates the American economy but also makes short-term investments in the United States less attractive, thereby weakening demand for the dollar.
And American officials have long contended that the main problem is not the United States' trade deficit but rather Japan's trade surplus. And that surplus dropped sharply in July, the Japanese Government said today, as Japan's imports rose while exports to the United States fell for the first time in 32 months.
The greater Japanese demand for foreign goods means that Japanese companies have more need of dollars and other foreign currencies, which caused the dollar to begin rising today.
In a slight departure from usual practice, Bundesbank officials were the first to announce today that interventions were under way. In the past, they have preferred to confirm their participation in international interventions already announced by other central banks.
Adding to the effectiveness of today's intervention was the fact that many senior Wall Street executives and wealthy speculators were vacationing away from their computer terminals, so there were few traders around with the authority to place large bets against the success of the central bankers' effort.
Swiss officials announced today that their central bank had also intervened in currency markets, buying dollars with Swiss francs. But international monetary officials said the Swiss had acted on their own.

Dollar Up in Tokyo
 TOKYO, Wednesday Aug. 16 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- The dollar rose above 99 yen for the first time in six months in trading today, bolstered by expectations that central banks would continue to buy dollars.
The dollar rose as high as 99.05 yen -- its highest level since Feb. 10 -- before retreating to 98.40 yen in afternoon trading. The dollar was trading at 1.4873 marks.
The retreat in the yen, whose strength has hampered efforts to revive the Japanese economy, accelerated a rally on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 706.01 points, or 4.05 percent, at 18,158.73. On Monday, the Nikkei rose 536.15 points, or 3.17 percent.

HEADLINE: Compaq Cuts Its PC Prices In Effort to Widen Its Lead

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
In the opening gambit of what is expected to be a fierce competition among personal-computer manufacturers, the Compaq Computer Corporation reduced prices yesterday on its line of office and home computers by as much as 25 percent.
Compaq also introduced several new models featuring the Intel Corporation's most powerful Pentium microprocessor and said that it would offer more storage capacity on its commercial machines to make room for the new Windows 95 operating system and the heftier new application programs that run on it.
 Price cuts are not unusual this time of year in the personal computer industry, as manufacturers try to reduce inventory to make room for their new fall lines. Apple Computer recently lowered its prices, and most other Compaq rivals are expected to announce their own price cuts within days. 
 But competition is growing fiercer by the month, new products are being introduced and prices are being cut at an increasingly rapid pace, squeezing profits.
Overshadowed lately by aggressive newcomers like the Hewlett-Packard Company and Packard Bell Electronics Inc., Compaq, which is the world's biggest seller of PC's, set out to reclaim its image as the industry's leader.
"The objective here is real straightforward," said Ross Cooley, Compaq's senior vice president and general manager for North America. "We intend to widen our lead over the No. 2 market share leader, wherever they are in the world."
Compaq first started its rise to the top of the industry by sharply cutting prices in 1992. The move effectively eliminated the price difference that had existed between high-end brands like Compaq and I.B.M. and less well-known discount machines. That set the stage for Compaq, with its up-to-date manufacturing and strong management to gain market share. Last year, the company surpassed I.B.M., No. 1 in sales.
Since then, other companies have followed in Compaq's footsteps, challenging the company on both price and features, while Intel has aggressively lowered the cost of its microprocessors, the electronic brains inside personal computers.
Hewlett-Packard, the $25 billion computer giant based in Palo Alto, Calif., has been the most aggressive new challenger. In the last 18 months, it has risen to become the sixth-largest seller of PC's worldwide. Earlier this week, the company introduced a new line of home computers.
The competition has driven many companies to introduce new models as soon as new technology becomes available. "The pace appears to be moving faster and faster," said Richard Zwetchkenbaum, an analyst at the International Data Corporation, a market research firm in Framingham, Mass. "There is no end to it."
Nowhere is this more true than in the market for home computers, where Packard Bell, the privately held company based in Sacramento, Calif., has become the leader. Several top manufacturers, including Compaq, will introduce two lines of home computers, one in late summer and the other in early fall. The fall models will be equipped with more advanced telephone and multimedia features.
By refusing to be undercut by its competitors, Compaq makes life even more difficult for already struggling rivals such as AST Research Inc., AT&T Global Information Solutions, a unit of the AT&T Corporation, and the Digital Equipment Corporation. Without a large volume of sales, those companies do not have the advantage of economies of scale to boost profits.
But lower prices hurt Compaq as well. "It isn't a margin enhancer," Mr. Cooley acknowledged, speaking of the latest round of cuts. As a result of yesterday's announcement, Eugene Glazer, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., cut his estimate of Compaq's third-quarter earnings to 83 cents a share from 93 cents.
Compaq stock closed yesterday at $53.625 a share, down 50 cents on the New York Stock Exchange.
In its announcement, the company said that it would now charge $1,599 for a 75-megahertz Pentium machine with 8 megabytes of memory and 630 megabytes of storage space compared with $1,650 and $1,799 currently charged by the Dell Computer Corporation and Hewlett-Packard for similarly configured machines with less storage capacity.
Compaq's 75-megahertz Presario home computer with 725 megabytes of storage would be reduced 18 percent, to $1,799 from $2,199.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Treasury Chief Says Strong Dollar Isn't a Threat to Trade

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
As the dollar continued its climb today, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said that the Government was committed to maintaining a strong dollar and did not see it as a threat to the ability of American business to compete abroad.
In an interview, Mr. Rubin gave no hint of what level he wanted to see the dollar maintain in the future. But the overall tone of his remarks -- one of the clearest reviews of American currency policy since he took office in January -- suggested satisfaction with the dollar's recovery this summer from its plunge in the spring. 
 Mr. Rubin's remarks came the day after the central banks in the United States, Japan and Germany intervened together to push the dollar to a level it had not seen in almost six months. The dollar, which had hit a low of 79.75 Japanese yen on April 19, jumped 3.5 percent against the yen and 2.9 percent against the German mark on Tuesday, and rose slightly today to close at 97.93 yen and 1.48 marks.
[In Tokyo, the dollar was little changed Thursday afternoon, trading at 98.08 yen and 1.4768 marks.]
The vigorous intervention on Tuesday had led some economists to question whether the Clinton Administration, and Mr. Rubin in particular, was running the risk of helping to push the dollar so high that it might begin to choke off American exports. A stronger dollar, while enhancing the international buying power of Americans and helping to curb inflation, also tends to make American goods more expensive for foreigners.
When asked about these concerns today, Mr. Rubin responded with a carefully couched but forceful defense of his currency policy.
"If you talk to people who run businesses in this country today, and I do, I don't think there is much question that we are competitive in most industries today," Mr. Rubin said over a lunch of turkey salad, carrot sticks and fruit salad in his private dining room overlooking the White House. "I think it is the height of unsound policy to devalue yourself into competitiveness."
Private economists have estimated that virtually all American industries can offer lower prices than their Japanese rivals in international markets with the dollar at 85 yen and that most would retain an edge even at 100 yen to the dollar.
While Mr. Rubin did not say anything that appeared calculated to startle or move currency markets -- Treasury secretaries have historically favored a strong dollar -- he still provided his most detailed explanation yet of why he believes a strong dollar is in the nation's best interest. Beginning when the dollar was plunging against the yen and the mark in the spring, Mr. Rubin has repeatedly said that he supported a strong dollar but was cautious about outlining his reasons.
Mr. Rubin, who once traded currencies on Wall Street at Goldman, Sachs & Company, has noted before that Government intervention in currency markets depends on good timing. Fighting a powerful market trend is usually fruitless, but a well-timed intervention can be highly effective in reinforcing a trend. And that seems to be exactly the strategy the Administration has pursued.
The stronger dollar has made Treasury officials more willing to discuss their actions; one senior official held a telephone conference call with several reporters Tuesday soon after the intervention.
In defending the stronger dollar against those economists who contend that it will widen the American trade deficit, Mr. Rubin was careful today to avoid language that would give any explicit signal of how high he thought the dollar should be.
Mr. Rubin also repeated his calls for Congress to raise the ceiling on the Federal debt and to pass resolutions allowing current Federal spending to continue while Congress and the White House resolve their dispute over budget policy. While there is no risk that the United States will have trouble paying its debts, he said, even the appearance that the Government is running out of money could affect the value of the dollar.
The value of the dollar must be protected to safeguard the buying power of Americans, Mr. Rubin said. A strong dollar makes imported goods less expensive in the United States, and also puts pressure on American producers of comparable goods to refrain from inflationary price increases, Mr. Rubin said.
"It means our terms of trade are better, which means that American consumers are able to consume less expensively," he said.
By limiting inflation, the stronger dollar also tends to reassure financial markets and hold down interest rates, Mr. Rubin added. Investors in Treasury bonds and other financial instruments that pay fixed sums of money at regular intervals tend to demand higher interest rates when inflation threatens to erode the value of their holdings.
"It takes pressure off interest rates in this country because if the dollar is strong, there will be less concern; inflation will be less of a concern," he said.
Mr. Rubin went out of his way to point out that he was not talking about the short-term interest rates set by the Federal Reserve. The Administration, and Mr. Rubin in particular, has a policy of not commenting on Fed monetary policy.
A strong dollar is also needed to insure that central banks continue to hold large sums of dollars as part of their foreign exchange reserves, he said. Moreover, it also helps insure that the United States can continue to finance its budget deficits by selling bonds denominated in dollars, Mr. Rubin said. The Carter Administration sold bonds denominated in Swiss francs and German marks in the late 1970's when the falling dollar made it hard to persuade foreigners to buy American bonds.
As long as the dollar is strong, business transactions of all types, notably for oil, will continue to be done in dollars, Mr. Rubin said. While Mr. Rubin did not elaborate, many economists have noted over the years that if oil had been priced in other currencies, as the ministers of some oil-producing countries have periodically threatened to do, then the price of oil in the United States would have risen steeply in recent years as the dollar lost value.
Taken together, Mr. Rubin said of the points he had raised, "These are good, hard reasons that relate to the welfare of the American people."
Mr. Rubin dismissed the suggestion made on Tuesday by C. Fred Bergsten, a Treasury official in the Carter Administration and now the director of the Institute for International Economics here, that the Administration might be pursuing political gain by seeking a strong dollar.
"The decisions that we have made with respect to our views on the dollar, and anything that we have done with respect to the dollar, are motivated entirely, 100 percent, by what we think is best for the economy of this country, and zero, or no percent, by any political considerations," Mr. Rubin said.

HEADLINE: Hurricane Stalls in the Atlantic, Pounding 1,000 Miles of Beaches

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Aug. 16

 BODY:
Hurricane Felix hovered more than 150 miles off the Atlantic coast this evening, its ponderous progress toward the shore nearly stalled as it churned a vast sweep of the ocean like a giant eggbeater. But in seaside communities from Florida to New England, mountainous surf from the distant storm was already wracking up a growing toll of damage.
In Sandbridge, an affluent seafront community here, clawing surf since Sunday has shredded sections of the metal sea wall built seven years ago to hold back the tide, leaving steel ribbing twisted like a kite that had been battered by the wind. In several places, the surging seas have already breached coastal defenses, tearing wooden decks from ocean-view homes and flooding roads. 
 By most estimates, the storm, whose winds slowed to 75 miles an hour, or barely hurricane strength, will not make landfall until sometime Thursday. Officials said the storm was nearly stationary for six hours this evening. For many here, the greater fear is not when or where Felix will storm ashore, but rather how long it will continue to meander somewhere off the coast, relentlessly grinding away at beaches and shore-front resorts along more than 1,000 miles of coastline.
David Basco, a professor of civil engineering who has studied beach erosion in Sandbridge for five years, said he was stunned by the force of the water at high tide today.
"For this early in the storm, and for a storm that far away, there was a lot of water over the wall," said Mr. Basco, director of the Coastal Engineering Center at Old Dominion University in Norfolk, Va.
With the water surge expected to reach as high as five feet when the storm peaks, a record level for the Virginia Beach area, he also said he was not sure how many homes on the ocean -- with or without a sea wall -- and in the low-lying areas beyond could withstand relentless pounding. "This one will be quite devastating on the dunes," he said, "and most of the people without walls will get a pretty good hit. They are not designed for such a big storm."
His assessment echoed a survey this week by the Virginia Beach Fire Department, which predicted that at least 40 houses along the ocean in Sandbridge "could fall like a zipper opening up from the weak and missing sections" of the sea wall.
"This one will not do the spectacular damage to buildings that Andrew did," said Orrin H. Pilkey, a professor of geology at Duke University who studies shoreline erosion, referring to the devastating hurricane of 1992 that caused a record $30 billion in damages mostly in South Florida.
"But this is hitting early in the hurricane season," he said, "and that is going to set up many beaches for more damage from storms through the rest of the season, leaving them naked and unprotected."
As a Category 1 hurricane, the tamest rank given by the National Hurricane Center in Miami, Felix is far weaker than most of the hurricanes that have battered the East Coast in recent years, including Andrew, Emily in 1993 and Gloria in 1985.
But experts say Felix is covering a staggering amount of territory, -- almost 107,000 square miles These circumstances make it distinctive in its own right, working like an oceanic eggbeater to churn wind and waters toward shorelines for a longer period of time than most hurricanes. The effects of Felix are expected to linger over some beach areas for as long as 30 hours.
Most other hurricanes have traveled straighter, swifter paths.
"This one is not crossing the shoreline quickly, the way Hugo did in 1989," Mr. Pilkey said. "It's just standing out there, pounding, pounding, pounding, pounding. I expect replenished beaches to take a big hit. They are more unstable than other beaches."
Replenished beaches are those where sand has been added to fortify an eroding coast line. Mr. Pilkey cited Monmouth, N.J., Ocean City N.J., Ocean City, Md., Virginia Beach and Wrightsville Beach, N.C. among areas that could expect significant beach erosion as a result of Felix's loitering -- not to mention the economic losses of vacationers evacuating for safer ground.
John S. Bone, the executive director of the Outer Banks Chamber of Commerce in North Carolina, said local businesses were losing $4.5 million a day this week in rent, lodging and retail sales. "It's devastating economically already," he said, "and it hasn't even hit yet."
For residents of Sandbridge, at the south end of Virginia Beach, if problems of beach erosion are decreasing it is only because there is not much beach left to erode. Some of the homes are still protected by metal sea wall bulkheads, which are illegal in some states, like North Carolina, South Carolina and Maine.
But the surf has ripped away sea walls in many spots and eaten away much of the beach in front of homes, whether the sea walls stand or not.
Janet Peterson, a 49-year-old high school English teacher, was planning to evacuate this afternoon, to join friends inland. She said when she bought her house in 1985, it faced 100 yards of beach. Almost none of it remains, and noting the unusually ferocity of the surf today, she said she would not be surprised if Felix claims her part of the wall.
"When I bought this house, I had a beautiful free-standing deck over the back. That washed away in '87," she said. "Now, we've got less buffer than ever before.
Dr. Steven W. Lyons, a meteorologist with the National Hurricane Center in Miami predicted the possibility of a "long scouring of the beach area."
But that much force could jeopardize much more than ocean-front properties, he said, threatening many inland areas so well.
"This isn't the catastrophic type, where a large number of people drown from a huge storm surge or a huge number of buildings are leveled," Dr. Lyons said. "But it's still going to be nasty. The wind will have more time to loose and break things, and flooding can be a major disaster with storms that stall."

HEADLINE: Low Interest Rates Reviving Housing Starts, U.S. Finds

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Though falling interest rates have done little to perk up car sales this summer, they are reviving the housing industry, figures released by the Commerce Department showed today.
In a surprisingly robust performance, the nation's builders broke ground for homes in July at the fastest clip so far this year, a 1.38 million annual pace that represented the biggest monthly surge in 16 months. 
 As a result, analysts said, the Federal Reserve seemed likely to defer any further cuts in interest rates.
"Housing's starting to do pretty well," said Robert Van Order, chief economist for the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. "When rates drop from over 9 percent to under 8, you get some kick from it."
The 6.7 percent jump in housing starts last month was the fourth advance in a row. The results were even more impressive because the department revised upward the totals for both June and May.
"This is really a very strong gain," said Robert R. Davis of America's Community Bankers, a trade group for savings institutions. Such strength, mirrored in a 5.3 percent jump in permits issued for construction, further diminished chances that the Federal Reserve would further ease monetary policy at a meeting of its Open Market Committee next Tuesday, analysts suggested.
"This pretty much guarantees that there will be no change in policy," said Paul L. Kasriel, chief domestic economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
On Monday, Alan S. Blinder, the Fed's vice chairman and an official somewhat more inclined toward lower interest rates than most colleagues, indicated reluctance to seek a reduction now.
But while the housing rebound embraced both single-family homes and multi-unit dwellings last month, the report was somewhat marred because the strength was highly concentrated in the South, which has long accounted for more than 40 percent of the new-home market.
Starts in the South soared 15.5 percent, to a 656,000 annual pace, or 47.5 percent of the total, while the West managed only a 2.2 percent rise, the department found. And starts actually declined 4.8 percent in the Northeast, where activity is lowest, and fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in the Midwest.
But David F. Seiders, economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said he was not much disturbed by this. He noted that the South contained some of the fastest-growing markets and said he had to believe that the Northeast was stronger than the figures, which are subject to significant revision, showed.
Mr. Seiders also cited the latest tabulation of the association's housing index, compiled from a survey of builders about their model-home traffic, their current sales and their expectations for the next six months. The index climbed another two points in August, to 53, its fourth straight advance from April's low reading of 38.
"Builders feel pretty comfortable with the inventory level" of unsold homes, Mr. Seiders said.
The revision in June starts lifted the pace to 1,293,000 from an initially estimated 1,263,000, while May starts are now put at 1,282,000, up from 1,264,000, the department's report showed.
The actual number of homes started last month, with no adjustment for seasonality, was 125,000 -- 1.1 percent above the June level but 2.2 percent below that of July 1994.
Permits, the report also showed, were at a pace of 1,343,000 in July as all regions except the Northeast showed increases.
Shipments of mobile homes, reported with a one-month lag, ran at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 329,000 in June, unchanged from the May pace but 11.5 percent above that of June 1994.

HEADLINE: 2 Sides Nearing Agreement on Water Pollution, Pataki Says

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Four months into an effort by Gov. George E. Pataki's office to broker peace talks between New York City and the upstate communities whose streets, waste-water plants and cow pastures drain into the city's 19 reservoirs, the Governor said yesterday that "conceptual agreement" had been reached on many aspects of a plan to cut pollution of the city's drinking-water supply.
Drafting of a detailed written agreement could begin by Sept. 1, Mr. Pataki said in a written statement. Such an agreement would help the city avert a Federal order to build a $6 billion filtration plant. 
 Federal environmental officials said they were optimistic about a resolution of the long-festering dispute.
"The talks have been surprisingly positive," said Richard L. Caspe (pronounced KAS-pee), director of the regional water-quality division of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, which will ultimately rule on the workability of New York City's plan to keep its water clean without filtration. The Federal agency grudgingly agreed last spring to push back its deadline for a filtration-avoidance plan until Sept. 15.
Mr. Caspe said the negotiators had reached agreement on many aspects of what he called "about 20 blockbuster items." He said he was prevented from discussing details by the ground rules of the meetings, but added that the closed nature of the talks had helped break major impasses.
"Progress to date has been a function of the frank, freewheeling nature of these discussions," he said, adding, "There hasn't been the fear that what I say today will wind up in the paper tomorrow."
The state has been in a position of power throughout the talks because state environmental and health officials must approve key provisions of the plan.
But all along, the challege for Mr. Pataki has been to balance the frustrations of upstate communities, which are the heart of his political base, with the needs of New York City, whose economic engine largely propels the state economy, officials in the Governor's office said.
The talks have been focused on three main areas, Mr. Caspe said. One is New York City's proposed revisions to its watershed regulations, which have had the force of state law since 1909 but have not been updated since 1953.
Another is a proposal by New York City to invest millions of dollars in the watershed towns to help them find ways to grow without further degrading water quality. The city is also being called on to honor past promises to maintain certain roads and bridges within the watersheds.
The third, and perhaps most contentious, topic, has been New York City's plan to buy up to 80,000 acres of land around its reservoirs to act as a pollution filter. Several participants in the talks said this is one of the issues that is closest to resolution.
Marc Moran, a senior assistant to the Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, said that the land-purchase debate has been particularly complicated because Westchester, eager to preserve open space, has supported the city purchases, while towns west of the Hudson River have opposed them. The Coalition of Watershed Towns, representing dozens of communities in the Catskills, had been demanding the right to veto any land purchase.
Hopes of a comprehensive deal could still easily founder on efforts to work out the fine print, various participants said. Despite progress in some areas, said Jeffrey S. Baker, a lawyer for the Coalition of Watershed Towns, "We're going to need agreement on all of them to make any of them fly."

HEADLINE: Dr. Robert Hoppock, 93, Pioneer In Field of Vocational Guidance

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Dr. Robert Hoppock, who had such a tough time finding his niche in life that he devoted his career to making it easier for others to find theirs, died on Aug. 5 at a nursing home in Vista, Calif. As the first professor of counselor education at New York University, he is widely regarded as a pioneer in the field.
Dr. Hoppock was 93. His daughter announced his death this week. 
 Trained guidance counselors are such a staple at high schools and colleges that it is easy to forget they are a comparatively new feature of the education landscape.
When Dr. Hoppock was growing up, they simply did not exist, not at his high school in Lambertville, N.J., or even at Wesleyan University, from which he obtained a degree in economics with no notion of what to do with it.
Among other things, he once recalled, there was no "Directory of Occupational Titles" and no "Occupational Outlook Handbook," voids he eventually helped fill through his own extensive research and voluminous writings, including the books "Job Satisfaction," and "Occupational Information."
In his own quest for a career, Dr. Hoppock was given so much bad advice, followed so many false leads and worked at so many jobs he loathed that when he finally stumbled onto something he enjoyed -- teaching -- and discovered the embryonic field of vocational guidance, he vowed to make it his life's work.
As he put it in a 1967 essay, "I decided that if other people had as much trouble as I had in learning what occupations were open to them, maybe there would be a place in the world for someone to make it a little easier for future generations to get this kind of information."
The field was so new and so undeveloped that when he finally got a job in 1927 teaching a ninth-grade course called vocational guidance in Rahway, N.J., he organized the New Jersey Vocational Guidance Association to provide a semblance of professionalism.
His work with the association led to a job as assistant to the director of the Carnegie Corporation's National Occupation Conference, an organization whose pioneering work in studying and forecasting employment trends in the 1930's has been largely taken over by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Dr. Hoppock, who received a master's degree in educational psychology and a doctorate in educational research from Columbia, became a major figure in the study of occupations.
It is a measure of his precocious social thinking that in 1937, a generation before Betty Friedan, he made headlines by observing: "There is no sound psychological reason why women should cook meals, wash dishes, launder clothes and clean house."
After helping to organize the N.Y.U. department of guidance in 1939 and becoming its first chairman, he made headlines again when he took his counselors-in-training on field trips to offices and factories so they could learn about the world of work firsthand.
Dr. Hoppock was a consultant to the Department of Labor and the United States Office of Education, as well as to major corporations and several state education departments and the school system in Manhasset, L.I., where he lived for 50 years.
He retired in 1972.
He is survived by a daughter, Margaret Joan Bedell, of Vista, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Alchemist's Dream Come True

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind.

 BODY:
When the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation bought control of the world's biggest maker of lead additives for gasoline six years ago, the product itself was almost an afterthought.
After all, leaded gasoline was banned in Japan, it was in the last stages of being phased out in the United States and it was scheduled for elimination from Western Europe. The lead content of gasoline was under attack all over the world not only because it fouls the catalytic converters that reduce pollutants in car exhaust, but also because it is suspected of contributing to brain damage in children and other ailments. 
 What Great Lakes really wanted from Octel Associates was the British company's capacity to produce bromine, a chemical that Octel used to make the additives but that Great Lakes sells in other products ranging from fire retardants to color stabilizers. To get the bromine, Great Lakes was willing to take on the last years of the production of lead additives -- as well as an ethical, and public relations, challenge.
It is a problem faced by many industries, including tobacco and asbestos producers and agrichemical and drug companies: under what conditions should legal products that are being phased out of the developed world to protect people's health or the earth's environment be sold to poorer nations?
For Great Lakes, that question has hung around longer and become more important to the company's image than it had anticipated. Far from petering out, demand for leaded gasoline, while shrinking, has remained far stronger than anyone predicted, especially in the third world. Meanwhile, every other major producer has stopped making the additives, known as tetraethyl lead, or TEL. That has left Great Lakes with an unexpected flood of profits and 90 percent of a market that no one else will enter because of the environmental problems associated with lead and the huge capital costs of building a new plant.
So far, Great Lakes has been able to deflect most critics by arguing that there are sound environmental and economic reasons for continuing to produce TEL. Meanwhile, the Octel cash cow has bankrolled a huge expansion that shows no sign of ending soon. Indeed, Great Lakes told Wall Street analysts early this year that it expects to more than double its size by the year 2000, to $5 billion in annual revenue, and to maintain healthy 15 percent operating profit margins while doing it.
"Octel was a good financial surprise," said David A. Hall, the senior vice president who oversees its operations for Great Lakes.
The latest indicator of just how good: Standard & Poor's this month raised its credit rating for Great Lakes to AA- from A+.
Wall Street had grown used to pleasant surprises during the years Great Lakes was led by the charismatic Emerson Kampen, who died this summer. The company grew from a chemical pipsqueak with $50 million in revenues when Mr. Kampen became chief executive in 1977 to a multinational with $1.8 billion in sales when health problems forced him to step aside in late 1993.
It was Mr. Kampen who in 1958 discovered the huge bromine-rich brine deposits in southern Arkansas that vaulted Great Lakes into the forefront of the bromine business, which had once been dominated by giants like Dow Chemical. The company processes bromine into a huge variety of industrial and consumer products. Its bromine compounds, for example, dominate the $600 million market for chemical additives that retard fires in plastics and textiles.
Mr. Kampen viewed Octel's unique process for extracting bromine from sea water in Wales as a beachhead for Great Lakes' further expansion into Europe. Those plans were quickly put on hold, though, when Great Lakes discovered the size of the TEL gold mine it was sitting on.
Octel has accounted for well over half Great Lakes' total operating profit every year even as its share of sales has declined. Last year, the contribution came to $259 million, or 59 percent, of Great Lakes' total operating profit of $439 million. In a recent research report, Mark Gulley of Morgan Stanley projected that Octel's share of profits from current operations would not fall below 50 percent before the turn of the century, despite an 8 percent annual decline in pounds of TEL sold.
The job of exploiting those profits to continue Great Lakes' growth record is now the primary challenge for Mr. Kampen's successor as chief executive, Robert B. McDonald.
The 58-year-old Mr. McDonald endorses Mr. Kampen's strategy of using a big chunk of Octel's profits for acquisitions. Some $375 million has been spent on 15 deals since 1989, including $90 million early last year to purchase an Italian producer of ultraviolet light-absorbing plastic additives. In 1993, about $72 million went to four acquisitions for Great Lakes' fast-growing water-treatment business.
"We are being treated as a vehicle to intelligently reinvest cash flow," said Marshall E. Bloom, chief executive of Bio-Lab Inc., a Decatur, Ga., subsidiary that makes recreational and industrial water-treatment chemicals.
Some of the diversification is within Octel itself, which now gets about 15 percent of its revenues from non-TEL additives.
The availability of so much cash is also a morale booster for Great Lakes executives. "It's a fun place for managers to work because of the cash flow," Mr. Gulley said. "Managers have a rich uncle to fund growth in their groups while their competitors have to self-finance."
Shareholders are also getting their due. The company has spent $386 million on stock repurchases since April of last year, helping to calm Wall Street's jitters about the management transition and a slowdown in earnings growth that largely reflected heavier-than-normal capital investments in existing businesses. After falling by a third from a peak of nearly $75 in late 1993, the price has climbed back to $67.
So far, Great Lakes has capitalized on Octel without running into much flak from environmentalists. That probably is due in part to its much lower profile as an industrial middleman than Octel's former owners, a consortium of oil companies including such giants as the British Petroleum Company, Texaco Inc., Mobil Inc. and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. The last major oil company partner, Chevron, owns a 12 percent stake that Great Lakes hopes to buy soon.
But Great Lakes is also working hard to avoid confrontations. Unlike tobacco companies, Great Lakes readily concedes that its biggest profit spinner can be harmful and ought to disappear eventually. But it argues that calls by some environmental groups for a world-wide TEL ban as early as the end of the century are unrealistic. To start with, Great Lakes says, there are too few refineries equipped to produce unleaded gas and too many cars outside the industrialized world without catalytic converters.
Great Lakes argues that such cars get fewer miles per gallon and spew out increased amounts of cancer-causing pollutants like benzene if forced to run on lower-octane unleaded gasoline. Thus, leaded fuel may be an "economic and environmental bargain" in many developing countries for years to come, according to Mr. Hall, the senior vice president in charge of Octel.
Some critics, like Dr. Joel Schwartz, a former Environmental Protection Agency official who is now a professor at the Harvard University School of Public Health, argue that Great Lakes and the oil refiners who use TEL underestimate its environmental impact. And the Alliance to End Childhood Lead Poisoning, a Washington-based group that sponsored an international conference on leaded gasoline last May, says Octel's suggestions that burning unleaded fuel may create even worse problems amount to a "disinformation campaign."
Such accusations are ignored on Wall Street, where Great Lakes is seen as one of the chemical industry's environmental white hats. Many of its products are substitutes for more noxious chemicals made by others; its largest nonbromine business recycles agricultural wastes into a metal processing chemical.
But business ethics experts say that the biggest problem for a compnay like Great Lakes is that it faces overwhelming incentives to delude itself when it comes to handling a product like TEL. Thomas Donaldson, a professor of ethics at Georgetown University, said making sure that customers using hazardous products were fully informed about the consequences was the "bare minimum" of ethical corporate behavior. Both he and Dr. Schwartz made the point that technically backward third world countries that are overwhelmed with economic and environmental problems are unlikely to be able to make sophisticated judgments about something as arcane as leaded gas, especially when the refineries are often in the hands of governments or ruling elites whose financial incentives are to stay with the status quo.
Mr. Donaldson said Great Lakes should consider contributing some of Octel's profits toward subsidizing a more rapid transition away from tetraethyl lead. The model for such an action, he said, would be the substantial payments infant formula producers have made to programs promoting breast feeding as preferable to formula.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bond Prices Recover After Losses Early in Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday as traders continued debating the prospects of an interest rate cut at next week's meeting of the policy-making panel of the Federal Reserve. Supply concerns lessened when the Treasury left unchanged the size of its auctions of two-year and five-year notes.
Bonds rebounded from early losses as the Fed tried to do some damage control regarding a Dow Jones news service report Tuesday that suggested that the Fed's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, would oppose cutting interest rates until the economy showed further signs of weakness. 
 The Fed's spokesman, Joe Coyne, said, "The quote used to back up the lead in the story was taken out of context." News that the Fed was taking issue with the report of Mr. Blinder's stance helped pare early losses in the 30-year bond, which had sagged after the data on housing construction in July showed more activity than had been expected.
The market, which had been nervous for days about the supply of Government debt and had been bracing for the Treasury's note sales next week, was relieved yesterday when the Treasury did not raise the amounts of the two-year and five-year auctions. It left the auctions at $17.75 billion of two-year notes and $11.5 billion of five-year notes.
Tony Crescenzi, head of government bond trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company, a New York brokerage firm, said the early losses in bonds were pared further as talk emerged that the Fed was in the market buying short-term intermediate securities.
Looking ahead, the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, will meet on Tuesday to consider another cut in the Federal funds rate. The Fed cut the rate on July 6, the first easing in three years. Although most analysts do not expect another rate reduction, some say the possibility cannot be ruled out.
The 30-year bond rose 4/32 , to a price of 9931/32 , for a yield of 6.88 percent, down from 6.89 percent on Tuesday.
Bondholders initially took to the exits yesterday morning when the Commerce Department reported that houses were built at an annual rate of 1.38 million in July, up 6.7 percent from June. The general expectation among economists had been for an increase of slightly more than 3 percent.
"The revival of the housing sector indicates that consumer spending is likely to increase steadily in the second half of the year," said Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Corporation, a market research and analysis firm. "Housing tends to lead consumer spending upward and has a huge multiplier. Stronger growth in consumer spending means more solid overall economic growth. This is the strongest evidence yet that the second half will be significantly stronger than the first half, with growth averaging 3 percent."
"The economy has revived nicely," he added, "and inflation is under control. What does this mean for the Fed? The Fed will wait before easing again late this year to make certain that growth continues along the 2.5 percent to 3 percent trend."
Elliott Platt, director of research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said, "The strength in the housing starts provides yet another reason not to cut rates at this time."
Still the market overcame the effects of the housing data yesterday and managed to close on an uptick. Discussing the reasons, Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said, "Institutional investors have a little more cash sitting around, and they're willing to put it to work." He added that the market benefited from the fact that the Treasury securities from last week's refunding had been mostly distributed.
Municipal bond yields were little changed as some investors sought out shorter maturities. Some dealers said that a lack of new investment money in municipal bond funds was affecting the market. If the funds are not growing, there are few reasons to buy, some fund managers said.
In one of the day's biggest offerings, Austin, Tex., sold $387 million in airport revenue bonds yesterday through a negotiated offering led by the Smith Barney Inc. unit of Travelers Inc. The bonds, which for some investors are subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax, are insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation and are rated triple-A.
Underwriters priced the issue to yield a maximum 6.45 percent for a bond due in 2020; shorter-maturity issues were priced to yield from 5 percent in 2001 to 6.15 percent in 2011. Other longer-term bonds were offered at prices to yield 6.36 percent in 2015 and 6.43 percent in 2025.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Compaq Cuts Prices; Industry War Is Likely
Compaq Computer reduced prices on its complete line of office and home computers by as much as 25 percent and introduced several new models, in the opening move of what is expected to be a fierce competition among personal computer manufacturers. 
 The company said it cut prices to maintain its lead as the world's biggest maker of personal computers, a position threatened as competitors aggressively reduced prices and introduced products in advance of the holiday gift-buying season. Analysts said the move was likely to cut profit margins. [Page D3.]
 
Salomon Offering Fizzles And So Does Its Debt Rating
Salomon Brothers suffered a one-two punch as Normandy America, a reinsurer Salomon had taken public, withdrew its offering, and Standard & Poor's downgraded Salomon's long-term debt and preferred stock. [D2.]
 
F.T.C. Cracks Down on Phone Sales
The Federal Trade Commission announced a series of tough rules intended to clamp down on fraudulent or deceitful telephone-marketing practices, including giving state prosecutors more power to sue fraudulent telemarketing companies. [D3.]
 
Housing Starts Rise 6.7%
Housing starts rose 6.7 percent in July to an annual pace of 1.38 million units, the biggest surge in 16 months. Analysts said the report was a further indication that the Fed was likely to defer cutting interest rates. [D5.]
 
Hewlett-Packard Profit Up 66%
Hewlett-Packard's third-quarter earnings increased 66 percent to $576 million, or $1.09 a share, buoyed by strong demand across all its product lines. Its stock price rose. [D3.]
 
Mastercard in Card Venture
Mastercard International and 11 large banks formed a company to issue cards with computer chips that will store cash, the biggest effort so far to create an electronic alternative to cash. Among the banks that will own the company are Chemical Bank, the Bank of America, Nationsbank, Banc One, First Union and Wachovia. [D2.]
 
Hasbro in Dreamworks Deal
Hasbro said it had formed a joint venture with Dreamworks to develop games and toys based on the entertainment company's projects. The venture would include all creative ideas that come out of Dreamworks, such as interactive media. [D5.]
 
Shakeup at Elizabeth Arden
Unilever United States said it was replacing Kimberly A. Delsing as president and chief executive of its Elizabeth Arden cosmetics unit with Peter W. England, chairman of Elida Gibbs-Faberge, the company's European mass-market cosmetics and toiletries business. [D3.]
 
Mexico's Economy Falters
Mexico's gross domestic product fell 10.5 percent in the second quarter as the crisis set off by last December's steep devaluation of the peso continued. The decline was greater than expected and suggested that the economy could drop more than expected this year. [D4.]
 
Absolut Sponsors Film Magazine
In an innovative advertising and media partnership program, Absolut vodka, which is marketed by Seagram, is becoming the lead sponsor of a quarterly publication created by a unit of Entertainment Weekly, which will be devoted to independent films. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
Ex-Utility Chairman Is Acquitted
The ousted chairman of Orange and Rockland Utilities, James F. Smith, has been acquitted of charges he spent $45,000 in company money on his family and friends. He was dismissed from the company in 1993. [B6.]
