HEADLINE: Liberties;
A Capitalist Fantasy

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

 BODY:
I step out of a silver Rolls-Royce, dripping in Harry Winston, teetering on Manolo Blahniks, sipping a 1988 Roederer Cristal from a Tiffany flute. I have come to Istanbul on the Orient Express in search of the perfect kilim. At the bazaar I inform Hasan, the tall, mustachioed carpet dealer, "Price is no object" . . .
The ringing phone snaps me back to reality. I am in my New York office, surrounded by a clutter of Maalox, Advil, Seldane, fat-free pretzels and three-month-old American Express bills. In my lap is a copy of Forbes FYI, the sleek supplement to Forbes magazine that tells the well heeled where to play and shop, where to find the best salmon-fishing camp in British Columbia ($3,462 a week), the best sterling silver shaving brush ($300) and the best library globe ($40,000). 
 You can easily imagine a layout in Forbes FYI on the ultimate grand tour for billionaires sated with the opera in Verona and quail-hunting in Florida: a thrill-packed jaunt to Iowa and New Hampshire that could be had for as little as $25 million.
Almost everyone seems to agree that Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., the 48-year-old head of the Forbes media empire, is loopy for thinking about pouring his own millions into a bid for the Republican nomination. He's Walter Mitty with a platinum card. And why not? The Presidency is the perfect gift for a man who has everything.
His late father, Malcolm Sr., owned the adjective "flamboyant" for years. He lived his magazine's motto, "Capitalist Tool," with his 151-foot yacht, his 68 motorcycles, his collection of Faberge eggs, his coast-to-coast hot-air ballooning trips and his friendship with Elizabeth Taylor. Besides the palace in Tangier -- he flew in 1,000 guests for his $2 million 70th birthday party there -- he had a chateau in Normandy and an island in Fiji.
Though Steve Forbes, as the eldest son is known, seemed far more sedate than his dad, it turns out that his shy Mittyesque exterior hides a wacky streak.
I went down to Mr. Forbes's Greenwich Village office to ask him about his notion of becoming a kinder, gentler Ross Perot, a man who treats himself to a Presidential race and pushes business experience rather than political experience. Unlike the Texas computer mogul, the New York magazine mogul cannot even claim to be self-made.
While he is seen as a smart businessman who assisted his neighbor Christie Whitman in devising the tax-cutting plan that helped her win the New Jersey State House, his friends worry that his bland personality, pro-growth message and flat tax do not make a compelling package. They fret that his head has been turned by the economist Jude Wanniski, who is still on the rebound from Jack Kemp.
Over coffee with Mr. Forbes, I got right down to substance. I asked if he still owned that island in Fiji.
"Yes, but unfortunately, I don't get there very often," he replied. "It's a small community, a couple of hundred people, called Lacaula."
It was difficult to imagine, with Presidential candidates always vying to make their pasts more appealingly humble, how a guy with an island in Fiji would fare.
Pierre (Pete) DuPont talked about his immigrant roots without mentioning that the immigrants were multimillionaires by the time he was born. George Bush desperately tried to conceal those giveaway preppy signals -- wearing striped watchbands, asking for "a splash" more coffee, having the most impressive ocean view in Kennebunkport -- behind a pork-rind facade. What if Bill Clinton brags on being a boy from Hope and Bob Dole reminisces about his farm days in Russell, Kan., and Steve Forbes has to say he's Richie Rich from hunt country?
And if this Princeton grad, who lives with his wife and five children in a horsy New Jersey community, simply admits that he's no man of the people, how does he avoid playing the capitalist fool? "I think what people would look for is, do you have the character, do you have the integrity, do you have the assets and qualifications that will enable you to not only occupy the office, but enable you to move ahead with what you talked about in the campaign," he said. "Is there a core?"
If Mr. Forbes proves he has a core, that would be a novelty in today's politics. Otherwise, he's just Huffington and puffington.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A mystery bankers love: How do credit cards stay so profitable?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
HAD any "pre-approved" offers for credit cards in the mail recently? If not, you must be a hermit or a notorious deadbeat: The average household received two solicitations a month in 1994.
The reason all those nice banks are lining up to lend you money is no mystery. The profit on credit card operations, according to research by Lawrence Ausubel, an economist at the University of Maryland, is almost five times the overall profit rate in banking. Last year, eight of the top nine commercial banks ranked by return on assets specialized in credit card loans. 
 In a free market, this isn't supposed to happen. If the business is immensely profitable -- and that profitability is no secret -- why hasn't wide-open competition forced banks, at best, to offer lower interest rates to consumers or, at worst, at least to dissipate their excess profits in ever greater spending for promotion?
Professor Ausubel's latest paper, presented last month to the National Bureau of Economic Research, buttresses his earlier finding that banks can charge uncompetitive rates on credit cards because consumers don't really believe that they will end up paying them. This, however, must be only part of the answer to the broader question of how competition can coexist with stunning profits in an industry offering a rather conventional service.
Mr. Ausubel first made waves inside his profession with a 1991 article in the American Economic Review that explained the high and "sticky" interest rates paid on credit card balances as a byproduct of consumer myopia. Credit card rates have since edged down, Mr. Ausubel says, and new cards are generally issued with variable rates. But the "spread" between what the banks pay for their own funds and the average rate they charge for credit cards -- typically, 10 percentage points -- has barely budged.
Equally striking, there is no erosion in the profitability of credit card operations. Indeed, notes Lawrence White, a former bank regulator who teaches economics at the Stern School of Business at New York University, credit cards generate much of the profit for banks now squeezed by competition from all sides.
New data support Mr. Ausubel's hypothesis that consumers do not expect to use their cards to borrow, and often do not even admit it when they do. Extrapolating from surveys, he discovered that Americans claimed they owed a total of $70 billion on their credit cards in 1992 when in fact they owed $182 billion.
Smart banks have learned to exploit this wishful thinking. While their interest rates remain uncompetitive compared with other loans, successful cards are now marketed with flashy extras -- below-market teaser rates, product discounts, insurance, frequent-flier miles, even cash rebates -- and rarely charge annual fees.
Robert Frank, an economist at Cornell University, notes that Mr. Ausubel's findings are consistent with other research on behavior in the face of temptation -- of impulsive consumption of food, alcohol and tobacco. "You know it's stupid," he explains, "but the pain comes later." It follows that borrowers cope with the guilt of compulsive shopping by forgetting the after-effect.
Still, what's more puzzling is that the excess gains are not burned up in the competition among card issuers to corral a bigger share of the highly profitable shopping addicts. Despite spending billions each year trying to lure new credit card customers and keep old ones, issuers still managed to earn 30 percent-plus returns on equity in the last decade. That is more than double the average return on investments by corporate America, with no greater risk.
Mr. Ausubel speculates that these persistent "supernormal" profits are a result of rapid innovation in marketing, much the way supernormal profits are the norm in markets dominated by rapidly changing technology -- electronics, computer software, pharmaceuticals and the like. Consumers sign up for cards that offer the cleverest gimmicks, and then pay excessive interest for years before being seduced by an even more clever gimmick. There is fierce competition. But the prize goes to the creator of the flavor of the month -- not to banks that deliver more service for less money.
This is not a pretty picture of free markets at work. Nor, for that matter, is it a particularly plausible one: Could the skills in marketing credit cards really be so specialized -- and so difficult to imitate -- that they account for most of the profit of one of America's most profitable industries?
If anything, there's a lesson for the economic profession itself in this tale. Much as they don't like to admit it, economists don't know as much as think they do about what makes markets tick. "At some point," Mr. White of New York University concedes, " you've just got to say, 'I don't understand this thing.' "

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexican Recession Worse; Output Off 10% in Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Mexico's economy plunged deeper into recession in the second quarter as the crisis set off by last December's peso devaluation continued, the Mexican Finance Ministry reported.
In a quarterly statement to Congress on Tuesday night, the ministry said that the gross domestic product -- essentially, the nation's output of goods and services -- fell 10.5 percent in the April-June quarter, compared with the similar period of 1994. 
 Economists had expected a sharp contraction, but the 10.5 percent drop was steeper than their estimates. Indeed, less than a month ago Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz said that the second-quarter decline would be around 6 percent.
The depth of the recession, partly orchestrated by the Government as it slashed public spending and attacked inflation to stem the financial crisis, suggested to analysts that the economy may drop more this year than they had predicted.
The belt-tightening has already carried a wrenching toll in human terms. About a million people have lost their jobs and tens of thousands of small businesses have closed, broken by plummeting sales and unpayable debts.
But economists said the second quarter data also had a positive side. "It shows the political system and Zedillo has been able to do more than survive," said Gray Newman, economist at Interacciones Brokerage in Mexico City, referring to the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo. "They've managed over the course of one of the most serious contractions in modern Mexican history to maintain relative stability."
In the first quarter of the year, as the economy teetered until a United States-led international rescue effort assured Mexico of nearly $50 billion, the economy contracted just six-tenths of 1 percent.
For the first half of 1995, the Finance Ministry said, economic output fell at a 5.8 percent rate.
The ministry tried to put the best light on the data for the second quarter, noting that the economy in the similar period of 1994 had been very strong. And, the ministry said, the figures for the latest quarter may have distracted attention from a realization that the economy had bottomed out.
After the widespread loss of jobs in the early part of the year, the report said, unemployment in June was no worse than in May, suggesting that the jobless rate might now be stabilizing.
The Finance Ministry also noted that inflation had slowed, and that the devaluation and floating of the peso in December had helped Mexico swing from an $8.8 billion trade deficit in the first half of 1994 to a $3.9 billion surplus in this year's first half.
The economic report pushed down Mexican stock prices today, but the market rebounded from its lows. The main Mexico City stock index closed down 20.01 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent. Earlier in the day, the index was down as much as 1.4 percent. The peso also weakened, closing here at 6.17 to the dollar, its lowest level since early July. Before the December devaluation, the peso traded in a semi-fixed range, selling at 3.46 to the dollar.

HEADLINE: Bradley Says He Won't Seek 4th Term

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey announced today that he would not seek re-election next year to a fourth term, depriving the Democratic Party of one of its most respected thinkers at a time when the party's loss of Congress is forcing it to re-examine just what it stands for.
In a speech here, Mr. Bradley gave no reason for his decision, but he left the impression that he had grown weary of working in a political system that he called "broken." He castigated both major parties, accusing them of being more interested in feuding than in addressing the needs of the nation. 
 "Neither political party speaks to people where they live their lives," said Mr. Bradley, who was almost defeated in 1990 and faced another tough fight next year. "Both have moved away from my own concept of service and my own idea of what America can be."
Mr. Bradley's withdrawal sent tremors through the local and national political landscapes and raised questions about whether he wanted to run for President. Some politicians speculated that from the tone of his comments, Mr. Bradley, who has never been much of a party stalwart, might be mulling whether to abandon the Democrats altogether and become an independent.
Mr. Bradley, 52, who throughout his career has often been mentioned as a Presidential candidate, declined to answer questions after his speech, saying that he would do so at a news conference on Thursday.
But people who have talked to him in recent days said he would announce on Thursday that he had no plans to challenge President Clinton in the Democratic primary in 1996, though he would not rule out running as an independent.
Mr. Bradley's friends and advisers suggested that he himself was uncertain about his next steps and, that his goal at this point was to keep his options open. He hinted at that in his speech when he vowed that, even though he was giving up his seat, he would remain active.
"I will continue to speak out and call it like I see it," he said.
Though Mr. Bradley only alluded to his dissatisfaction in his speech, his friends said that in recent months he had often spoken of his frustration in trying to push his ideas in a Senate that is now run by Republicans.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who serves with Mr. Bradley on the powerful Finance Committee, said the shift in the Senate to Republican control had often relegated Mr. Bradley to the sidelines on issues that he cared about deeply.
"That is not a very exciting way to live, and it is a not a very cerebral way to live," Mr. Moynihan said.
So Mr. Bradley, long considered one of the chamber's experts on matters like taxes and foreign policy, apparently did not want to spend six more years being shunted aside as a minority member. Mr. Bradley also has a strained relationship with both the Clinton Administration and the Democratic leadership in the Senate.
Mr. Bradley was apparently expressing these tensions today when he lashed out at both parties.
"The political debate has settled into two familiar ruts," he said. "The Republicans are infatuated with the 'magic' of the market and reflexively criticize government as the enemy of freedom, and the Democrats distrust the market, preach government as the answer to our problems and prefer the bureaucrat they know to the consumer they can't control."
By stepping aside, Mr. Bradley begins a new course in a life that has long been in the public spotlight. Before he reached the Senate, he distinguished himself as a scholar-athlete who attended Princeton University, earned a Rhodes scholarship and then helped lead the New York Knicks to two National Basketball Association championships.
Though he has a reputation as one of the Senate's best minds, he also has been attacked for neglecting the more nitty-gritty aspects of a politician's job, like obtaining money for local projects or maintaining services that help constituents navigate their way through the Federal bureaucracy.
Despite his denials, rumors have been swirling around Mr. Bradley for months that he might not run again. It was a surprise, though, that he would choose to withdraw so early, with nearly 18 months left in his term.
Leaders of both parties in New Jersey quickly began jostling for position after word of the announcement circulated. The Democrats, weakened in recent years by a revolt over taxes that has cost them the governor's office and control of the Legislature, now must regroup to defend the seat, which the National Republican Senatorial Committee had already focused on.
The prospect of a bruising race against Representative Dick Zimmer, the leading Republican candidate, might have influenced Mr. Bradley's decision. In 1990, flush with campaign cash and nationally known, Mr. Bradley barely eked out a victory against Christine Todd Whitman after he was criticized as aloof and refused to pass judgment on the unpopular tax increases advocated by Gov. Jim Florio. Mrs. Whitman later defeated Mr. Florio in 1993.
Nationally, Mr. Bradley's withdrawal further diminishes the Democrats' chances of regaining control of the Senate in 1996. In addition to Mr. Bradley, five other Democrats have said they will retire next year. If the Republicans, who have a 54-to-46 edge, can increase their majority to 60 seats, they will wield even more clout because they will able to block filibusters.
President Clinton, who is on vacation in Wyoming, telephoned Mr. Bradley this morning to express his regret over the Senator's decision.
"I will miss his leadership in our efforts to deal with the critical issues of race, crime and violence and America's opportunity in the post cold war era," Mr. Clinton said in a statement.
Mr. Bradley's wife, Ernestine Schlant Bradley, a German language and comparative literature professor at Montclair State College in New Jersey, had breast cancer a few years ago, and some politicians in New Jersey said he might have wanted to spend more time with her. But Mr. Bradley's staff said she had made a full recovery, adding that her health had not affected his decision.
Mr. Bradley has often said in recent years that the close call of the 1990 campaign was a shock to him, a liberating experience that has led him to be more candid about his feelings. One of his close friends said today that, by not running for re-election, Mr. Bradley sensed that he would have even more room to discuss issues that meant something to him.
That would also position him better for a possible campaign for President in 2000, said this friend, speaking on condition of anonymity.
"He really believes that for him now, the best platform is not the Senate, that it's better to be out with people," the friend said. "If he were going to make a step for 2000, he believes it would be much better and easier to do that from outside. He wants the freedom to move around."

A front-page picture caption about Senator Bradley's announcement misspelled the first name of his daughter in some copies. She is Theresa Anne Bradley.

Chronology: "SNAPSHOTS: From Oxford, to the N.B.A., to the Senate, to . . ."
Bill Bradley, the three-term New Jersey Senator and former New York Knick, said he would not run for re-election. Here are key moments from his life in his 52 years in and out of politics.
 
PUB-DATE: July 28, 1943
 
1952 -- At age 9. he begins playing basketball at the Y.M.C.A.
 
1961 -- Graduates from Crystal City High as a two-time All-American in basketball and a straight-A student. After receiving offers of athletic scholarships from 75 universities, he decides to go to Princeton, which offered no financial assistance. Majors in history.
 
1964 -- An outstanding college basketball player and member of the gold medal-winning U.S. Olympic basketball team, he works as a volunteer in the unsuccessful campaign of Gov. William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania for the Republican Presidential nomination.
 
1965 -- Named college player of the year by the National Association of Basketball Coaches. Graduates from Princeton with honors in history. Turns down a $20,000-a year-contract from the New York Knickerbockers and accepts a Rhodes Scholarship to study at Oxford University. Before beginning his studies in England, leads the United States basketball team to victory at the World University Games in Budapest.
 
1967 -- Joins the Knicks.
 
1968 -- Obtains his M.A. cum laude from Oxford, where he studied politics, philosophy and economics.
 
Jan. 14, 1974 -- Married to Ernestine Schlant, a German-born professor of comparative literature at Montclair State College.
 
 
1975 -- Named by Time magazine to its list of 200 young leaders.
 
1976 -- Becomes a father, with the birth of a daughter, Theresa Anne.
 Becomes an author, with the publication of his memoirs.
 From his book "Life on the Run" -- "The point of the game is not how well the individual does but whether the team wins. That is the beautiful heart of the game, the blending of personalities, the mutual sacrifices for group success . . . "
 
1977 -- Retires from basketball after 10 seasons in which the Knicks win two championships (1970 and 1973). His salary reportedly reaches $325,000 and his modest ways prompt his teammates to call him "Dollar Bill," because, they maintain, he still has the first dollar he ever made. Averaging 12.4 points a game, the forward has scored 9,217 points. Off-seasons have been spent in public service activities ranging from assistant to the director of the Office of Economic Activity in Washington to teaching reading at an Urban League street academy in Harlem.
 
PUB-DATE: June 6, 1978
 
Nov. 7, 1978 -- Defeats Jeffrey K. Bell, the Republican candidate, in the general election with 56 percent of the vote.
 
Jan. 15, 1979 -- Sworn in as the youngest Senator.
 
1981 -- Becomes chairman and spokesman on tax policy for the Senate Democrats' Economic Advisory Group.
 
1983 -- Elected to the NBA Hall of Fame.
 
1984 -- Wins second term, defeating Mary V. Mochary.
 
1990 -- Nearly loses his seat to Christine Todd Whitman, winning by a 50 to 47 percent margin over an opponent who began the campaign all but unknown.
 
Aug. 16, 1995 -- Announces his retirement from the Senate.(pg. B10)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Comments at Fed Point To No Change in Rates
The Federal Reserve's interest-rate policy committee appears likely to leave rates unchanged at its meeting next Tuesday. Senior Fed officials expressed satisfaction this week with the current economic outlook.
Lawrence B. Lindsey and Edward W. Kelley Jr., Fed governors, said in interviews that they were pleased with the economy's direction. Mr. Lindsey added, "We're in a situation where we're going to have exactly what the doctor ordered, which is slow, moderate growth." Analysts said they did not expect the Fed to push rates up before the committee meets in September. [Page D2.]
 
The yield on 30-year-Treasury bonds rose to 6.90 percent, from 6.88 percent on Wednesday, despite economic reports showing the economy growing at a moderate pace with inflation under control. [D4.]
 
Dell Earnings Exceed Forecasts
Continuing to cash in on a boom in personal computer sales, Dell Computer said that earnings more than doubled in the second quarter to $65.1 million, or $1.32 a share, surpassing analysts' expectations. Even more of a pleasant surprise were Dell's strong gross profit margins, which increased to 21.8 percent, compared with 21.4 percent in the first quarter of this year. [D4.]
 
Russian Hacker Cited at Citibank
A hacker in St. Petersburg, Russia, penetrated Citibank's computers and stole $2.8 million from corporate accounts in New York, United States officials told a British court. Valdimir Levin, 34, a mathematician, was said to have electronically transferred the money to bank accounts in California and Israel. [D6.]
 
Net Up at Deere and Navistar
Deere and Navistar International posted higher earnings, but Wall Street was unimpressed, focusing more on signs that the companies' markets were weakening. Deere said fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 14.2 percent to $180.1 million, or $2.07 a share. Navistar's earnings jumped nearly 95 percent to $39 million, or 43 cents a share. [D4.]
 
Inquiry Into Psychiatric Centers
Community Psychiatric Centers said it was the subject of a whistle-blower lawsuit that has led to a Federal investigation of its billing practices. Federal authorities plan to file an amended civil complaint by Sept. 29, and the F.B.I. seized records on Aug. 4. [D2.]
 
Intervention Heartens Japan
The intervention in the currency markets this week by the central banks of the United States, Japan and Germany, which has helped strengthen the dollar against the yen, could expand Japan's corporate profits and lead to a resumed economic recovery. [D3.]
 
The dollar retreated to 97.25 yen and 1.4747 marks, weighed down by profit-taking and by a wider than expected United States trade deficit. [D13.]
 
Stocks Mixed in Dull Trading
Stocks were mixed in directionless trading as the Dow Jones industrials fell 8.45 points, to 4,630.63, while the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index reached a new high for the third time this week. It closed up 3.49 points, to 1,029.24. The S.& P. index fell. [D6.]
 
Davis Polk Lands RJR, Again
The law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell lost RJR Nabisco as a longtime client after the Kohlberg Kravis Roberts takeover, but in a highly unusual arrangement, one of the law firm's partners is now serving as RJR's general counsel. [D20.]
 
Crazy Eddie Pitchman Is Back
Jerry Carroll, the man who made those Crazy Eddie commercials so famous, is back doing ads for another consumer electronics company, but this time he's being a lot quieter. Mr. Carroll, 48, is appearing in a distinctly low-wattage spot for Willoughby's, his first for a consumer-electronics store since 1992. Advertising. [D5.]
 
Microsoft to Use Stones' Song
Microsoft has paid some $2 million for the rights to the Rolling Stones' song "Start Me Up" for use in an advertising campaign for its new Windows 95 software. [D5.]

HEADLINE: New Orleans Conjures Old Spirits Against Modern Woes

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 17

 BODY:
The voodoo priestess used a mix of gunpowder and old graveyard dirt to draw a magic symbol on a crossroads in the Bywater neighborhood, opening a spiritual door through which a fearsome deity could pass and save her community from the evil of crack cocaine.
For two hours on Wednesday night, as drums pounded along Piety Street and orange flames of fire-eaters and torch carriers danced in the dark, the white-gowned priestess, Sallie Ann Glassman, enticed Ogoun La Flambeau, a voodoo god of war and fire, to prowl among the rows of shotgun houses and punish the dope peddlers and other criminals. 
 She offered rum, cigars, incense and music, and called out to him in French, respectfully but firmly, since it is unwise to appear weak-willed in the presence of spirits. "Great gods cannot ride little horses," she said.
Sometime after 10 P.M., as a circle of sweat-slick dancers and voodoo drummers seemed about to collapse in the sticky heat, Ogoun showed himself to her, the priestess said.
"I can see him and feel him. He is here," said Ms. Glassman. His feet, she said, were on the street, and the rest of him rose up, high into the dark. "I can see him now, hovering over us," she said.
Even in New Orleans, where there is magic in many things and weirdness in most, this does not happen every day.
The ceremony was born in the frustration of residents in the racially and economically diverse neighborhood on the edge of the French Quarter, said Ms. Glassman and others who live here. They said the New Orleans Police Department had been ineffectual at best in dealing with blatant drug traffic, burglaries, prostitution, robberies and assaults.
"This is not frivolous," said James Smith, a writer who lives in Bywater, who came to lend his support to the ceremony.
"It has to work better than the legal system," in frightening away some of the criminals who make a living here, Mr. Smith said. "Because New Orleans is a very superstitious place."
Ms. Glassman, who was assaulted two months ago and whose home was burglarized two weeks ago, said the only avenue left for residents was an appeal to old spirits, called loas, that once held such sway in this old city.
"At night, the whole neighborhood is lit up with crack pipes," said Ms. Glassman. "I called it our thousand points of light."
In daylight, "people were exchanging drugs for money on my steps," she said. "I decided that what we needed was an urban loa."
She decided to call forth Ogoun, the baddest spirit in the voodoo otherworld. She does not want Ogoun to harm anyone, only to frighten them, badly enough to cease their evil.
But as Ms. Glassman invoked the spirits, it was clear that not all of the hundred or so onlookers had fear of Ogoun, or any voodoo god. Occasional taunts throughout the ritual, and the fact that most of the people who joined in the ceremony were whites, showed how the religion had slipped and shifted in the life of New Orleans.
Voodoo, a gumbo of African religions and Old World Catholicism, came to New Orleans as it came to Haiti and other places in the New World, in the holds of slave ships.
Two hundred years ago, voodoo drums echoed from Congo Square along the New Orleans riverfront, and priests and priestesses performed eerie rituals in the bayous outside town. Well into the 20th century, priests and priestesses held tremendous respect in the neighborhoods.
There are still shops where a dwindling number of voodoo believers can buy a charm, potion or a hex, still places to find a black cat bone to seal a lover's affection for eternity.
Believers still wander dark cemeteries, which people here call Cities of the Dead, and search for the graves of the mighty priestesses, called voodooiennes, to take a little dirt. The dust, called goofer dirt, is mixed with other ingredients to make their own magic more potent.
But voodoo no longer holds the influence it once did over the people of New Orleans, and many of its devotees seem to be white people -- nose and tongue piercers, middle-aged intellectuals and men with foot-long pony tails -- who enjoy the religion's drumming and cultural aspects.
Ms. Glassman herself is white and came here from Kennebunkport, Me. But Ms. Glassman, who works a second job at a New Orleans nightclub, says she has been a voodooienne here for more than 20 years and that voodoo is not fashion to her: She goes to the Mississippi River some mornings to feed the spirits honey and flowers, and spirits visit her in dreams.
"This is not going to make me popular with the crack dealers," she said of the ceremony, adding that she would not attempt it if she did not know the spirits would shield her. "These are bad people."
Others here do not feel the arms of the spirits wrapped around them.
All during the ceremony, young men, women and some children laughed and jeered and pantomimed the voodoo dance, hopping in and out of the sacred circle.
One young man spent an hour trying to provoke the dancers, but -- except when a fire-eater blew a fireball at him -- he was ignored. When a young man pulled his car to the intersection and blasted it with thundering gangsta rap, the voodoo drummers just pounded harder.
But the ceremony also showed the lingering respect, and fears, that this old religion still holds. From the four directions of the crossroad at Piety and Rampart streets, people stood in half-open doors and stared toward the ceremony.
Some said they simply did not want to get involved, but others, older ones, said they feared the ceremony itself. One middle-aged woman said it was dangerous to dabble in magic, and closed her door.
It is dangerous, said Ms. Glassman. Once one uncorks the stopper on the spirit world, they are at the mercy of the god they summon, she said.
"You can always regret something that you set in motion," she said. "This is a little precarious, like setting off an atom bomb. You hope Ogoun will play fair. But who knows what his morals are."
What she is counting on is that he is a fierce god, a warrior, a master of the forge who can hammer out a better community. That is what she asked as she touched a burning stick to the sacred symbol, or veve, she had drawn on the street, and watched the gunpowder burst into flame.
"Normally I'd use cornmeal to draw the veve," she said, but this ceremony needed a little theatrics.
At its foundation, what happened here was just a New Orleans variety of a community watch, said Dawn Green, a 22-year-old student at the University of New Orleans.
"It is a public prayer," said Tina Girourd, an artist.
Of the 100 who came, most were respectful, and watched quietly. It being New Orleans, some showed up with gin and tonics in their hands.
The New Orleans police also showed up, late.
It will be a while before Ms. Glassman knows how Ogoun will respond to Bywater's need.
She only knows he is here, hovering.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Grew in June As Exports Fell

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit widened in June as exports eased from record levels and consumers and businesses maintained a surprisingly brisk demand for imports, the Commerce Department reported today.
The $11.31 billion deficit brought the total for the first half of the year to $63.8 billion, or 28 percent more than the deficit in the comparable period of 1994. 
 Currency traders responded to the report by bidding down the recently buoyant dollar. It slipped to 97.25 yen, from 97.93 yen on Wednesday, and to 1.4747 marks, from 1.4800. [Page D13.]
Economists had expressed varying degrees of concern that the dollar's recent rise -- accelerated this week by coordinated purchases by the Treasury and the German and Japanese Governments -- would further expand the trade gap. But the Clinton Administration, boasting of export success, brushed aside such fears and attributed the mounting deficit to slow growth by America's trading partners, especially Japan.
"Our exports are growing dramatically," said Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade. The deficit, he added, "has nothing to do with a lack of competitiveness" and will shrink when European and Japanese economies rebound.
The Administration has invested much political capital in trade, including the fight to win ratification of the North American Free Trade Agreement, but it still anticipates charges by Republicans that it has allowed the deficit to balloon at the cost of American jobs. With this no doubt in mind, Mr. Garten distributed to reporters today a chart showing that the trade deficit now amounts to 1.5 percent of the gross domestic product, about half the proportion that prevailed in the late 1980's.
The deficit with Japan -- the amount by which American purchases of Japanese goods surpassed American sales to Japan -- declined for the third straight month in June, according to today's report. Still, analysts said they could not yet discern a trend. Among other things, the decline could reflect slack shipments of luxury cars after an early-spring surge intended to beat the threatened imposition of American tariffs; the punitive tariffs were averted by a last-minute agreement.
The deficit with Japan narrowed to $5.3 billion, from $5.5 billion, with imports of new cars from Japan falling nearly $400 million.
The deficit with Mexico, however, remained at $1.6 billion, bringing the total for the first half of the year to $8.6 billion, in sharp contrast with last year's $1.1 billion surplus. Mexico's economic crisis and peso devaluation last winter has led to higher American imports and left Mexico less able to buy exports from the United States.
And the deficit with China, a growing source of trade friction, climbed to $3 billion, from $2.8 billion. Figures for individual countries, unlike the totals, are not adjusted for recurring seasonal variation.
Over all, exports of goods and services fell 1.2 percent in June, to $64.48 billion. The largest factor was lower shipments of motor vehicles, parts and engines, mainly to Canada. For merchandise alone, exports moved down 1.6 percent despite a surge for advanced technology products. Exports of capital goods, however, climbed to a record.
Imports declined less than exports, by six-tenths of 1 percent, reflecting lower purchases of artwork, gem diamonds and motor vehicles and their components, the department said.
"A soft economy would typically lead to a decline in imports," said Larry J. Wipf, an economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, referring to the meager American growth rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. He said the continued high level of imports might indicate that the economy was a bit stronger in late spring than had been thought.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said in a telephone interview that the dollar's weakness in the first half of the year had little effect on trade flows, and he contended that the recent advance would prove similarly inconsequential.
"We don't think the strengthening dollar will have any effect one way or the other," Mr. Kantor said.
But some private analysts sharply disagreed. For example, William R. Cline, senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics, a nonpartisan research organization, said that assuming the higher levels held, diminished American competitiveness would help swell the deficit to perhaps $200 billion by 1997.
If the policy is intended to buoy the Japanese economy, a goal the Administration has specifically denied, the extra growth there could not generate enough additional purchases from the United States to make up for the general loss of American competitiveness from its stronger currency, he said.
The institute's director, C. Fred Bergsten, put the complaint more bluntly. "Politically, this is opting for Wall Street over Main Street," he said, meaning that Main Street is concerned with the realities of jobs and production.
In Detroit, Robert E. Lippens, international economist for the Chrysler Corporation, said that he would worry about the auto industry's competitive position should the dollar rise sharply, but that he was "not terribly concerned" about the increases so far.

HEADLINE: U.N. Documents Inequities for Women as World Forum Nears

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 17

 BODY:
The last two decades have seen advances in the education and health of women around the world, yet hundreds of millions of women in both rich and poor nations are still significantly undervalued economically, denied access to political power and kept down by crippling inequalities under the law, according to a report released today.
"We hear and we say that life is unfair, but what this report shows is that life is dramatically unfair to women," said James Gustave Speth, administrator of the United Nations Development Program, which commissioned the study. 
 Seventy percent of the world's poor are women, and women and children make up 80 percent of its refugees and a disproportionate number of the casualties in dozens of small-scale wars.
"Violence stalks women's lives, in peace and in war," the report says.
Violence in personal relationships is a universal fact, according to the report. Women's groups from every region of the world are demanding that some concrete action on this issue be taken in Beijing next month at the Fourth World Conference on Women, said Barbara Arnwine, executive director of the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, based in Washington, D.C.
Workshops about violence at regional sessions preparing for the China conference have been packed to overflowing, said Ms. Arnwine, who will lead a delegation predominantly composed of African American women to the conference.
Madeleine K. Albright, the chief American representative at the United Nations and the leader of the United States' delegation to Beijing, said in an interview that protection against domestic violence and the human rights of women in general, along with their need for economic security, are among the issues she will emphasize at the conference.
While there has been a lot of disparate, anecdotal evidence available, the new study attempts to pull together "in a rigorously analytical way" as much quantitative information as possible to make international comparisons, Mr. Speth said in an interview.
"It is very apparent to everyone in our country offices around the world -- 135 of them -- that the advancement of women, the involvement of women in decision-making, is a critical developmental factor," said Mr. Speth, a founder and former president of the World Resources Institute who is now the highest-ranking American in the United Nations system.
The study is the sixth annual Human Development Report to be prepared by independent experts for the development agency. Each year the report, which ranks 174 nations on a range of social and economic factors, also chooses a different theme for special attention. This year it focuses on the status of women, and it was timed for release before the conference on women, which is held once in a decade.
"The key finding is that gender gaps in human capabilities -- education, health -- have been halved in the last two decades," Mr. Speth said. "There have been huge increases in the capacity of women, including in the Arab states. But when you go on beyond the preparatory phase of life, women overwhelmingly still lack access to economic and political opportunities. They are effectively shut out of the higher reaches of economic and political leadership and decision-making."
The report says that worldwide, women have only 14 percent of top managerial jobs, hold 10 percent of national legislative seats and 6 percent of cabinet-level positions. Only in the Nordic countries, led by Norway, have women reached the level of 40 percent or more in government ministries, in large part because of strong affirmative action policies, the study concludes.
The United States, which is given the world's second-highest overall human development ranking in this report, after Canada, falls to fifth place in a recalculation that focuses on income and health disparities between men and women. Sweden, Finland, Norway and Denmark all move to the top. If the focus is on women's access to political and economic power, the United States falls to eighth place.
Two areas of the report's findings are expected to draw special attention in Beijing: the economic undervaluation of women's work and the legal barriers women face.
On the economic value of women's work, Mr. Speth said that the report looked at 31 countries at various stages of development and concluded that "if you take into account both the uncompensated work women do and the wage discrimination against women, you come up with a figure of $11 trillion."
"The total world economy is about $23 trillion," Mr. Speth said.
In studying the way the laws of various countries treat women, the report's findings were somber.
Among the examples of legal discrimination mentioned were laws that prohibit women from traveling abroad without male permission. In Botswana, Chile, Lesotho, Namibia and Swaziland, women are under the legal guardianship of husbands and have no property rights.
"The starkest reflection of the low status accorded to women in societies everywhere is the discrimination against them in law," the report said. "Unless such legal barriers are removed, no progress can be made toward equal rights."

HEADLINE: Hedging Bets on Democracy, Casinos Offer Cash to Voters

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Aug. 17

 BODY:
In the evolution of democracy, a ballot proposal to allow unrestricted casino gambling in the state of Washington is unlikely to merit anything more than a footnote. But the way that the initiative is trying to sell itself to voters may give it a place in election history.
If Initiative 651 passes, the casino promoters have promised to pay every Washington resident who votes this fall an annual dividend of a share of 10 percent of the profits from slot machines -- an amount that could bring each voter $100 a year. In typical off-year elections in the state, about one million people vote. 
 To critics, the proposal amounts to an outright bribe, although on a mass scale. But supporters, after polling people on the depth of voter cynicism and distrust of government, say they are merely cutting out the middleman -- the tax collector -- and offering to give a chunk of their revenue right back to the people.
"The whole idea is absolute craziness," said Ralph Munro, Washington's Secretary of State, whose office certified the proposal for the Nov. 7 ballot.
The initiative is being sponsored by three American Indian tribes interested in expanding into casino gambling and is being bankrolled, in part, by slot machine manufacturers like Ballys, who are lending the tribes money for the campaign.
Under the initiative, the tribes would pay voters no matter which way they voted on the measure.
Offering a financial reward merely for casting a vote may be illegal in this state, Mr. Munro said. But the measure as it now stands will go on the ballot, though it may face a legal challenge later.
To some people, the proposal recalls the days of big-city party machines, when voters were induced to turn out by offers of free liquor, meals or more.
"The simple promise here is that if you vote for this initiative you will get paid off," said Chuck Sauvage, executive director of the state chapter of Common Cause, a group that monitors campaigns. "You go out and do your duty as a citizen, and you become a shareholder in casino gambling. This is unheard of."
Supporters compare the situation to that of Alaska, where every resident receives an annual dividend check -- now about $900 -- from state oil royalties. The difference, Mr. Sauvage said, is that the Washington dividend is held out as a bonus for voting.
Though early polls show the measure failing, gambling proponents are counting on a simple argument -- and a bit of old-fashioned greed -- to make their case.
"This is a way to cut out the middleman, to cement our financial relationship with the people of the state of Washington," said Herb Whitish, the chairman of the Shoalwater Bay tribe, who is a leader of the initiative.
"I don't view this as any kind of bribe," Mr. Whitish said. "We're just trying to share a resource with the people of the state."
The measure qualified for the ballot after supporters gathered more than 256,000 signatures in a campaign in which workers were paid up to $1 for every signature gathered. Critics said the paid-signature drive raised questions about the initiative process, which half of the states have, though such paid drives have become a reality in recent years as voters have become wary of signing petitions.
"It's bad enough we have people buying their way onto the ballot," Mr. Sauvage said. "But now with this initiative, you've got the logical extension, which is to buy the voters off directly."
The Washington proposal is the latest nuance in the expansion of Indian gambling nationwide, an industry made possible by passage of the Indian Gaming Act in 1988, and has grown to the point where patrons are spending $27 billion a year in tribal casinos.
Under the gaming act, tribes have been able to enter into compacts with states, allowing them to operate casinos on reservations with forms of gambling that are legal elsewhere in the state. Since most states allow charities to run blackjack card games and roulette wheels on certain nights, the tribes have followed suit, although with bigger operations and longer hours.
With a few exceptions, the result has been a bonanza for the tribes. The Tulalips' casino near Everett, about 30 miles north of Seattle, reported more than $10 million in profit last year. A new casino south of Seattle, run by the Muckleshoot tribe, expects to do $150 million a year in business.
Most casinos have used the money to build schools, roads and health clinics, or return a share of the profits directly to tribal members. In some states, a share of the profits is given to state government.
The most profitable casinos have slot machines, which typically provide up to 75 percent of the revenue, but Washington State does not allow such machines.
Three tribes making plans to open big resort and gambling casinos in Washington -- the Spokanes, the Puyallups and the Shoalwaters -- put together Initiative 651 in an effort to change state law to allow slot machines. Under their proposal, any tribe entering into a gambling compact with the state with slot machines must return 10 percent of the profits from slot machines to "all registered voters who voted in the most recent statewide election."
Tribal leaders are projecting enough profit to make a $100 million payout to state voters, although others say that estimate is too generous.
Opponents say the proposal would be the death knell for charitable gambling and open this state to the kind of deregulated casino operations that existed in Las Vegas, Nev., in the 1950's. But, they say, it is the dividend proposal that most troubles them.
"It's a payoff," said Stan Shore, a leader of the opposition to Initiative 651. "The tribes are simply trying to pay voters to look the other way."
Even within the three tribes involved, members have criticized the tribal leaders for allying themselves with slot machine makers and for throwing tribal money into the initiative campaign.
Some of the other tribes in the state oppose the initiative, including those who have seen a decline in crowds as gambling reaches a saturation point and say that allowing newer operations to use slot machines would dry up their revenues.
Mr. Whitish said those tribes could get in on the windfall by changing their compacts with the state. But then, he said, they would have to return 10 percent of the slot machine profit to the voters as well.
Either way, gambling is here to stay as a mainstay of tribal economies. Mr. Whitish called it the "second coming of the salmon."

HEADLINE: U.S. TAKES STEPS TO BOLSTER FORCE IN PERSIAN GULF

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Based on troop movements and warnings from two Iraqi defectors that President Saddam Hussein had considered attacking Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, the Pentagon said today that it was sending ships carrying equipment and supplies to the Persian Gulf, and could ultimately deploy more than 22,000 ground troops.
Although there is no indication that an Iraqi attack is imminent, two senior American military officials told reporters today that elite Iraqi troops around Baghdad have conducted "unusual training activities" in the last five weeks that caused concern among United States analysts. 
 Most Government experts here and in the Middle East say Iraq has neither the will nor the ability to launch an attack. Many Middle Eastern diplomats and even some senior American officers fear that the Administration may be overreacting to the troop movements in Iraq.
Sending American forces to defend the gulf against Saddam Hussein would be an opportunity to make President Clinton look firm in dealing with an international villain.
"Saddam Hussein is an easy whipping-boy," said one diplomat familiar with the Middle East. "It's a no-brainer for Clinton. He's got everything to gain and nothing to lose by acting tough."
But several factors have prompted the Administration to take precautionary steps, including the troop movements around Baghdad, the information provided by high-level Iraqis who defected to Jordan last week, Mr. Hussein's threats to make trouble if the United Nations does not lift sanctions against his country next month, and the memory of military confrontations with Iraq in 1991 and 1994. "We'd much rather be safe than sorry," said a senior Pentagon aide.
Pentagon officials have ordered 13 ships carrying tanks, trucks, ammunition and other supplies, enough for about 22,000 marines and soldiers, to the gulf region. That equipment will arrive within a week. Moreover, the military's Joint Staff has prepared orders to send troops to match up with the equipment, although they will not be issued unless Iraq's forces threaten its neighbors, senior military commanders said. Troops could be flown rapidly into the region.
"I don't think we're deeply worried about Saddam launching a military operation, but there's no harm in reminding him to think it's not a sensible thing to do," a senior Administration official said. "We don't want him to have any doubt in his mind."
The United States already has about 20,000 troops in the Persian Gulf and eastern Mediterranean, including two aircraft carriers, 2,000 marines engaged in a training exercise with Jordanian troops and more than 100 Air Force planes in Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.
Iraq is capable of sending elite Republican Guard armored units with more than 10,000 troops, now south of Baghdad, to the Kuwaiti border in about four days, as happened last fall. At that time, Washington dispatched 13,000 troops, ships armed with Tomahawk cruise missiles and scores of warplanes, and threatened much more, to force the Iraqi troops to withdraw north of the 32d parallel, which is about 160 miles north of the Kuwait border.
American officials this week repeated their longstanding threat to attack any Iraqi troops south of that line. "The difference between this year and last year is that we've declared the right to nail them below the 32d parallel," said a senior Defense Department official.
Administration officials suspect that Mr. Hussein is searching for a way to respond to the predicament he is in as a result of the defections of Lieut. Gen. Hussein Kamel and Col. Saddam Kamel -- President Hussein's two sons-in-law.
These officials say that President Hussein may have ordered the troop movements to divert the attention of his country -- and the world -- from the defections of the two high-ranking military officers. Another possible motive is to flex his muscles to scare his neighbors and win back some respect.
In the month before the defectors fled, Pentagon experts had been watching with growing concern as Iraqi aircraft, air defense, army, Republican Guard and special forces trained or prepared to train. A senior military official said today that concern increased after the defections.
"The problem with these exercises is that they decrease our warning time," said a senior Defense Department official. "The more efficiently they can mobilize, the less time that gives us."
In devising a plan to contain Iraqi military power, the Pentagon is trying to deal with the fact that it is far easier for Iraq to move forces to threaten its neighbor than it is for Washington to dispatch troops from 7,000 miles away.
The actions announced today are the latest in a series aimed at checking Mr. Hussein's military. After Mr. Hussein's two sons-in-law defected last week, Mr. Clinton promised to protect Jordan against any Iraqi reprisal. Senior military officials said today that there were no indications that Iraq's military was posing a direct threat to Jordan.
The Navy last week moved the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt from the central Mediterranean to a position off the Israeli coast. The departure of a second carrier, the Abraham Lincoln, from the Persian Gulf was delayed until its relief arrived. The marines started their long-scheduled exercise with Jordanian troops.
Military officials today disclosed the American ship movements, the likelihood of an exercise with 5,000 Army troops in Kuwait soon, and increased flights over Iraq by U-2 spy planes.
Gen. J. H. Binford Peay 3d, the head of the United States Central Command, which oversees the region, flew to Kuwait today to meet with officials there. The general is expected to go to Saudi Arabia in next few days.
As the military stepped up its activity, the Administration announced that two senior American diplomats were in Amman to learn as much as possible about what the defectors have told King Hussein and Jordanian officials.
The two diplomats -- Assistant Secretary of State Robert Pelletreau and Mark Parris, the National Security Council's senior aide on the Middle East -- met with the King today in an effort to learn more about Mr. Hussein's military intentions and gather information to bolster American efforts to persuade the United Nations Security Council to prolong economic sanctions against Baghdad.
According to the State Department, the two officials once again urged King Hussein to sever economic ties with Iraq, and especially to stop importing oil from Iraq. But Administration officials acknowledge that Jordan is forced to depend on Iraq for oil because Kuwait and Saudi Arabia cut off trade with Jordan after it supported Baghdad during the Persian Gulf war.

HEADLINE: In the Shadow of Atlantic City, a Tribe Wants to Open a Casino

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: WILDWOOD, N.J., Aug. 17

 BODY:
Acknowledging that they faced an uphill battle in hostile territory, leaders of an Indian tribe from Oklahoma signed an agreement with this seaside community today to operate a gambling casino virtually in the shadow of Atlantic City.
Whether they can win state and Federal approval to actually bring the project out of the planning stage is another matter. 
 Gov. Christine Todd Whitman indicated today that she did not look favorably on the project. "The Governor says she has concerns about gaming outside Atlantic City and in the past has expressed opposition to similar projects," said Jayne Rebovich, a spokeswoman.
Such talk did little to discourage those who gathered here today eager to claim their share of the riches that slot machines and blackjack tables can bring. Pacts between Indian tribes and cash-strapped governments have gained in appeal: Detroit would like to deed downtown land to the Chippewas for a gambling operation, and in New York State, the Oneidas want to open a casino at Monticello Raceway, 100 miles south of their homeland.
Here in Wildwood, the tribe and the community want state approval to deed 2.5 acres, now a municipal parking lot, to the Delaware tribe of western Oklahoma. According to the plan outlined today, the tribe would pay Wildwood $8 million a year out of casino profits.
Larry Snake, the tribal chairman, said the Delawares had been driven from New Jersey, their ancestral land, more than a century ago. Now, he added, 250 tribe members live on 10 acres near Anadarko, Okla., while 1,000 are scattered around the nation, a dozen of them in New Jersey.
Mr. Snake, 40, who runs a motorboat repair shop in Anadarko, said he had had no plans to run a casino until Wildwood merchants contacted him two months ago.
He said he had jumped at their proposal because it offered tribe members a road out of an economic backwater. "We can use the money to help pay for the health care, educational and cultural needs of our people," he said.
The casino issue will first be put to Wildwood voters in a referendum, so far unscheduled. The municipality, 26 blocks long, has only 5,000 year-round residents, but it sits on a five-mile barrier beach that on a holiday week like Labor Day may draw 250,000 visitors, mainly from Pennsylvania and Delaware.
Local merchants, who say Atlantic City has hurt more than helped them since the first casino opened there in 1979, were optimistic that the project would be approved -- at least at the local level.
"The people want it," said Giovanna Pullela, 67, a pizza-by-the-slice vendor on the boardwalk, "but there's too much politics at the state level for it to pass."
Her daughter, Janie O'Donnell, 38, added, "The problem is people come to Wildwood on vacation but spend all their money in Atlantic City."
If the necessary approvals were obtained, the tribe and the city would choose a management company to build and operate the casino. Persuading the state to transfer the deed will be left to Wildwood officials who know the political terrain, Mr. Snake said.
"This is their backyard, not mine," he added.
Mayor Fred Wager said the city had been thinking about ways to bring casino gambling to Wildwood for three years and had hired a consultant to shop around for a tribe that could claim New Jersey as its ancestral land.
"It seemed far-fetched at the time," said the consultant, Chuck Worthington, a former assemblyman from Atlantic County. "But the more we talked about it, it became clear the legal groundwork was there to make it work."
The problem, he added, was that two local Indian groups, the Lenni-Lenapes and Ramapoughs, were not officially recognized by the Interior Department. This disqualified them from Federal recognition, which could be the basis for claiming the right to operate a casino.
Actually, the Lenapes and the Delawares are the same people, said Mark M. Gould, the Lenni-Lenape tribal chairman, who was at the signing here today to give the project his blessing.
"The Delawares were the ones who were transported by the troops to Oklahoma," said Mr. Gould, wearing a long ponytail and a blue business suit and accompanied by others in traditional Indian dress. "The Lenni-Lenapes were the ones who stayed behind and hid in the woods." He said there were 1,500 on the Lenni-Lenape tribal rolls, most living in southern New Jersey, and most of mixed blood.
He noted that the casino agreement gave first choice of jobs to "native Americans." Casino backers estimate that the casino, if built, would provide 2,000 jobs on the grounds and 8,000 in related services.
Local officials have said that they want to insure a family market for the casino and that consequently they will not permit alcohol to be served on the premises. In a resort that already has more than 100 liquor licenses, the restriction was interpreted more as a sop to local businesses that did not want a tourist magnet such as a casino to monopolize spending. For much the same reason, the casino will not be able to provide accommodations for the public or high rollers.
A tricky legal question arises if the Governor blocks the deed transfer. The state could not prevent the building of a casino on a reservation if there were one in New Jersey, but whether it can stop one on land deeded to a tribe is a central question in a case now in Federal court in Oregon, Mr. Worthington said.

HEADLINE: Fed Appears Unlikely to Lower Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
With the Federal Reserve's interest-rate policy committee set to meet on Tuesday, senior Fed officials have expressed satisfaction with the current economic outlook, as well as some uncertainty -- assessments that seem likely to lead them to leave the rate unchanged for now.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, said the economy already appeared to be doing fairly well. "We're in a situation where we're going to have exactly what the doctor ordered, which is slow, moderate growth," he said. 
 Edward W. Kelley Jr., another governor, said he was "pleased that it would appear we have begun to grow again." But he added, "It is too early to judge the vigor that growth may have."
Mr. Kelley and Mr. Lindsey spoke in interviews at the beginning of this week, and neither specifically addressed interest rates. But several Government statistics released since then, like the sharp rise in housing starts announced on Wednesday, have shown signs of economic health. The figures might bolster the central bankers' reluctance to reduce the short-term interest rates under their control to stimulate the economy.
Most traders and financial analysts also appear to be expecting the central bank to leave interest rates unchanged at least until the next meeting of policy-making officials on Sept. 26. The rates for three-month Treasury bills are slightly below 5.75 percent, the current target of the Federal funds rate, which the Federal Reserve effectively controls and which banks charge each other for overnight loans.
"The Fed is probably still in an easing mode, but I think people are not expecting anything rapid-fire," said David C. Munro, an economist at High Frequency Economics, a New York consulting company.
To be sure, the Federal Reserve's short-term interest rates remain farther above the inflation rate than the historical average, leaving room for the central bank to repeat its decision on July 6 to shave the Federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point. And while the economy appears to have accelerated from the one-half of a percent growth that it recorded in the second quarter, it remains well below the 2.5 percent growth rate that some Fed officials use as their informal target.
Mr. Lindsey predicted the economy would grow at an annual pace of only 1.5 percent from the second quarter of this year through the third quarter of next year. Mr. Lindsey would not discuss the interest-rate implications of his forecast, but private analysts believe such a growth rate would give the Federal Reserve considerable room to reduce short-term rates further.
Another worry for Mr. Lindsey is the state of many Americans' personal finances, which will influence whether stores continue to sell their backlogs of goods and place fresh orders with factories and other producers. "I continue to be nervous about the amount of consumer debt that is being added on," Mr. Lindsey said.
But with more signs emerging that the economy has rebounded from its slowdown in April and May, the overall mood at the Federal Reserve seems to be satisfaction, with little perceived need to tinker with rates. Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, seemed almost cheerful during his last discussion of monetary policy before Congress on July 19.
The main reason for the good mood at the Federal Reserve is that inflation appears to be under control after the central bank raised short-term interest rates seven times in 1994 and early this year in an effort to prevent a spurt of economic growth from feeding inflation. Consumer prices have risen at an annual rate of only 2.4 percent during the last three months -- extraordinarily low for an economy in the fifth year of an expansion.
Prices for industrial products like synthetic rubber and crude goods like steel scrap have leveled off after rising steeply for more than a year. Mr. Kelley said that could have a dampening effect on inflation in the future.
As a bank regulator, the Federal Reserve was also concerned about the health of the banking system, which appears to be sound. "From all we have been able to ascertain, loan quality continues to be quite good," Mr. Kelley said.
While some Wall Street economists have warned of the dangers for bond prices that lie in a possible collision of Congress and the President on budget policy this autumn, Federal Reserve officials seem less anxious. Even if the Government was to become immobilized, it would not pose a significant problem for the economy unless the problem was to last far longer than those of recent years, Mr. Lindsey said..
"Obviously, if it goes on for weeks and weeks, something will happen," he said. "I doubt the country will notice a shutdown of the government if it's a matter of days."
The dollar's strong rise in currency markets this summer, and particularly this month, has removed another worry for Federal Reserve officials. A falling dollar is a problem because it forces officials to consider whether to sacrifice domestic economic growth by raising interest rates to attract foreign investment and protect the dollar's value.
Most important, Federal Reserve officials see a growing public resistance to inflation, which may be the best weapon against price increases. Mr. Lindsey was particularly impressed that when American auto makers tried to increase prices this year, buyers cut back on purchases.
"It's a sign," he said, "that a low or no inflation psychology is beginning to take hold."

HEADLINE: Regulators to Rub Elbows With Contributors to Pataki

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 17

 BODY:
The invitations for the political fund-raising event came with an offer and a price: Spend Friday afternoon at Saratoga Race Course with Gov. George E. Pataki, for either $250 or $1,000 per person.
But those invitations also carried a subtle prod for the corporate officials and horse-racing people being invited to contribute. Included on the printed roster of fund-raising chairmen were two senior government officials whose jobs are to regulate or grant benefits to many of the people on the guest list. 
 The two are Joseph Neglia, a member of the state's three-member Racing and Wagering Board, which regulates horse tracks and parimutuel betting, and Clarence D. Rappleyea Jr., the new chairman of the state Power Authority, which provides low-cost electricity to businesses.
The practice of having senior government officials solicit campaign donations from the very people they regulate was prohibited during the Cuomo administration because of the potential for ethical conflicts. And indeed, when Mr. Rappleyea, who started his Power Authority job this week, was questioned by a reporter today, he acknowledged the problem.
"I won't be doing this again," he said.
A spokeswoman for the Governor said the administration now recognized the problem. Asked about the invitations this afternoon, Zenia Mucha said: "No commissioner or board member will have their name on an invitation or serve on any fund-raising committee" again.
But she added that Friday's fund-raiser will go off as scheduled.
The involvement of the two officials has drawn sharp criticism from Democratic lawmakers and government watchdog groups, although it is not expressly prohibited under state ethics laws. The critics contend that fund-raising by officials who have regulatory powers pressespeople doing business with the state to contribute money.
"It creates the appearance, at best, that regulated industries are currying favor for future important decisions for them," said Blair Horner, legislative director for the New York Public Interest Research Group. "It clearly smacks of a conflict."
Both Mr. Neglia and Mr. Rappleyea said they had distributed tickets and made phone calls to encourage people to come to the event. Mr. Neglia said he had talked to friends about attending, some of whom are in the horse-racing business. Mr. Rappleyea said he had spoken only to loyal Republican contributors, none of whom have had business with the Power Authority. Both said they had done nothing to press people to contribute.
Mr. Rappleyea, whose annual state salary is $185,000, said he had been asked to be a co-chairman for the event several weeks before he knew that Mr. Pataki would name him to the Power Authority. Still, it has been widely known in Albany since the spring that Mr. Rapppleyea, formerly the Assembly minority leader, was being considered for the position.
In any case, he said, he would not put his name on future fund-raising invitations.
"I got caught in one of those time flips," he said.
Ms. Mucha, too, said Mr. Rappleyea's name had been added to the list while he was still Assembly minority leader. She said Mr. Neglia had been included because he is a longtime supporter of Mr. Pataki. She added that the practice would end there.
Mr. Neglia, whose annual state salary is $76,421, is listed on the invitation as a "general chair" of the event, a job that carries the responsibility of raising $10,000. Though originally appointed to the racing board by former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, he is a Republican who supported Mr. Pataki in last year's race.
Asked whether some horse owners might attend the event to improve relations with him and his board, Mr. Neglia said: "I don't see it at all. I think it's just a reason to get together and meet with the Governor, to get the Governor to help the industry to thrive."
New York State law prohibits state officials from demanding contributions in exchange for government favors. But it does not otherwise restrict their fund-raising activities. By contrast, deputy mayors and commissioners in New York City are prohibited from soliciting campaign contributions for city candidates.
For state officials, "nothing is proscribed" under state law as regards political fund-raising, said Richard Rifkin, executive director of the State Ethics Commission. "There is a line somewhere, and I wish I could better define it, but I can't because the commission hasn't drawn it," he said.
State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat, has proposed legislation to prevent top state officials from participating in campaign fund-raising. He said of the Saratoga event: "It's a way to put the arm on people in the industry. It's going to attract people who say, 'I better come if I'm going to have a good relationship with the Racing and Wagering Board."
The Democrats have also raised questions about the political activities of other Pataki administration officials with backgrounds in campaign fund-raising, including Economic Development Commissioner Charles A. Gargano, who helped raise more than $14 million for Mr. Pataki last year, and General Services Commissioner Peter W. Delaney, who did fund-raising for Westchester County Republicans.
The event Friday was timed to coincide with the 136th Traver's Stakes race on Saturday, which historically draws huge crowds of horse owners, corporate officials and well-heeled fans from around the state.
For a $250 contribution to Mr. Pataki's campaign account invitees can partake of an all-day buffet under white tents at the racetrack's paddock area. For $1,000, contributors will attend a more intimate evening reception with Mr. Pataki in a private room.
The event is just the latest in a string of large and small fund-raising gatherings this year for Mr. Pataki, who does not face re-election until 1998. As of July 11, the Governor had raised more than $1 million and had $937,891 on hand.
The list of chairmen for the Saratoga event also includes several corporate officials and lobbyists, including: Michael Smith, president of the New York State Bankers Association; Allan Dragone, president of the New York Racing Association; James Featherstonaugh, a lobbyist whose clients include soda companies and race tracks, and Kenneth Shapiro, a lobbyist whose clients include hospitals and health insurance companies.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Up a Bit

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
The number of Americans seeking first-time jobless benefits rose slightly last week, the Government reported today, but the closely watched four-week average of claims tumbled to the lowest level since March.
Initial claims for state unemployment pay rose by 6,000, to a seasonally adjusted 338,000 in the week ended last Saturday from a revised 332,000 the prior week, the Labor Department said. 
 The weekly total was just under Wall Street economists' forecasts for new applications of 340,000 in the week.
The four-week moving average for claims, viewed as a more reliable gauge of labor market conditions than the more volatile weekly figure, fell by 19,500 to 340,750 last week. It was the lowest since 340,250 in the week ended March 18.
The number of people receiving state jobless benefits in the week ended Aug. 5, the latest period for which those data are available, decreased by 20,000, to 2,599,000, from a revised 2,619,000 the prior week, the Labor Department said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ebbs vs. Mark and Yen On Profit Sales and Trade Data

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar retreated yesterday, weighed down by profit taking and by a report showing a wider than expected United States trade deficit.
Despite yesterday's decline, the dollar is up 3.8 percent against the Japanese yen and 2.7 percent against the German since Monday. It rose sharply after the central banks of the United States, Japan and Germany bought more than $1 billion in currency markets on Tuesday in a coordinated effort to lift its value. 
 The dollar fell yesterday after the Commerce Department reported that the trade deficit widened 2.4 percent, to $11.32 billion, in June. A larger trade deficit indicates that foreign exporters will have more dollars to convert to their domestic currencies.
"The dollar is coming off because some people thought the trade deficit would be a little smaller," said Earl Johnson, currency adviser at the Bank of Montreal/Harris Bank in Chicago. Economists had forecast a June deficit of $10.9 billion.
Preset orders to sell the dollar when it fell to 1.4730 marks and to 97.30 yen exacerbated the decline, currency traders said. The traders had purchased their dollars at lower levels and placed automatic orders with dealers to sell -- known as stop-loss orders -- if the dollar reached those thresholds.
"There were so many stop-losses," said Charles Spence, director of currency sales for Standard Chartered Bank. The selling of dollars, he said "just kept coming."
The dollar fell to lows of 1.4655 marks and 96.43 yen in afternoon trading in New York before rebounding. It settled at 97.25 yen, down from 97.93 yen on Wednesday, and at 1.4747 marks, down from 1.48. The British pound rose to $1.5460 from $1.5415.
Still, traders remain bullish on the dollar. Dollar-buying by the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan on July 7, and the coordinated action on Tuesday, have convinced many that the Governments of the world's most powerful economies are committed to strengthening the dollar.
"The dollar is well supported by psychology," Mr. Johnson of the Bank of Montreal said
Concern that central banks might start buying dollars on signs of weakness helped the dollar rebound from its lows yesterday, market participants said. "It takes a brave guy to sell dollars at levels where the central banks came in Tuesday," said Richard Koss, strategist for Maria F. Ramirez Inc., a money-management firm. The Fed began its purchases around 96.50 yen and 1.4580 marks that day, traders said.
