HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Deere Income Climbs 14.2%; Navistar Has Gain of 95%

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Two of the nation's largest heavy equipment makers posted higher earnings yesterday, but Wall Street was unimpressed, focusing more on signs that the companies' markets are weakening.
Deere & Company said its net income rose 14.2 percent in its fiscal third quarter. But its results were below analysts' expectations, and its stock fell $2.50, to $83.75. 
 And the Navistar International Corporation said its net income nearly doubled. But although those results exceeded analysts' estimates, its stock closed up only 37.5 cents, to $13.375.
Deere, the world's biggest farm equipment maker, reported net income of $180.1 million, or $2.07 a share, compared with $157.7 million, or $1.82 a share, in the 1994 quarter. Sales rose 17.4 percent, to $2.7 billion from $2.3 billion.
Yet its earnings were well below Wall Street expectations of about $2.20 a share.
Moreover, Deere said it expected its fourth-quarter earnings to fall short of last year's results because of moves planned for the quarter to cut inventories of service parts and dealer used goods.
But the Moline, Ill., company said it still projected record earnings for the 1996 fiscal year.
Deere "spent a lot of time trying to convince everyone that 1996 is going to be O.K.," said Blair Brumley, a Dain Bosworth analyst who participated in the company's conference call with analysts. "They're forecasting a strong farm economy and a soft landing, but I'm not prepared to buy that."
Meanwhile, Navistar reported its net income rose 95 percent in its third quarter ended July 31 to $39 million, or 43 cents ar share, from $20 million, or 17 cents a share. The results beat Wall Street's estimates of 34 cents a share.
The Chicago-based truck and diesel engine manufacturer said its revenues rose 21 percent, to $1.51 billion from $1.25 billion.
But analysts questioned whether demand was sustainable at levels seen during the most recent quarter.
William Cooke, an analyst with McDonald & Company, said there were signs the market for heavy trucks was deteriorating, noting that an independent industry research firm reported that cancellations exceeded new orders for large heavy- duty trucks during the first nine days of August.
"Navistar had a good quarter and will have a good fiscal year," Mr. Cooke said. "The concern is what's going to happen in 1996."
But Navistar said it remained positive, noting that although its industry was slowing down, it should continue to grow.
"We believe the drop in industry orders over the last few months was due to customers' uncertainty about the economy in 1996, and we expect to see good levels of retail sales next year," Navistar's chief executive, John Horne, said in a statement.
The company raised its 1995 fiscal year forecast for industrywide demand for medium and heavy trucks in the United States and Canada.

HEADLINE: America's Plan for Bosnian Peace

 BODY:
Croatian military gains and a newly energized American diplomacy have combined to create an opening for a negotiated Bosnian peace. The odds remain long, but the effort is worth making. Despite criticism yesterday by Senator Robert Dole, President Clinton is right to try.
In a lightning offensive two weeks ago, Croatian Government troops reshaped the Balkan battlefield. They evicted 50,000 rebel Serbian soldiers and 150,000 Serbian civilians from the Krajina region of western Croatia, bordering Bosnia. That left the larger part of Serbian holdings in Bosnia virtually surrounded by numerically superior Croatian and Bosnian troops. 
 The shift created a dangerous equation in which Croatia and Serbia, with the two strongest Balkan armies, could move on to partition Bosnia between them or clash in a full-scale war. But it also created at least a temporary opening for peace. The Clinton Administration has been quick to seize the opportunity, knowing that failure to achieve peace now could lead to American combat troops' fighting to protect a United Nations withdrawal by autumn.
American diplomats have crisscrossed Europe in recent days promoting a new version of the international peace plan that in effect awards 51 percent of Bosnian land to Muslim and Croat forces and 49 percent to Bosnian Serbs. Washington is pushing changes in the peace map that keep the 51-49 ratio but conform more closely to current battlefield realities, awarding the Serbs territory in eastern Bosnia in exchange for land around Sarajevo.
If the Bosnian Serbs reject the plan, Washington proposes that Western countries jointly lift the arms embargo on Bosnia, train Bosnian troops and hold off Serbian attacks with air strikes.
The first part of the plan, dealing with the map, has won general European approval and is now being negotiated with the Balkan countries themselves. The second part, dealing with possible enforcement, seems to have grudging support from Britain and France but is opposed by Russia.
If the use of external military pressure remains as doubtful as ever, internal military pressures on the Bosnian Serbs have sharply increased. Significantly, when Croatian troops swept through the Krajina region, Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, held Yugoslavia's powerful army out of the battle. Apparently he now deems some rebel Serbian losses acceptable to win Yugoslavia relief from international economic sanctions.
If Mr. Milosevic throws his support behind the American plan, the Bosnian Serbs could find themselves in trouble if they persist in fighting. Left to their own resources, they can muster at most 135,000 troops against more than 300,000 available to the increasingly well armed Croatian-Bosnian alliance.
The Bosnian Government has accepted the principle of 51-49 partition for a long time. But it resists proposed changes to the map, particularly giving up its claim to Gorazde, still in Government hands. With the changed military balance, some in the Government may feel tempted to fight on for a better deal.
The United States should never lose sight of the fact that Bosnia is the main victim of this war. If the Bosnian Government rejects the new map, Washington should not try to bully it into acceptance. But Administration diplomats can argue in good conscience that Washington's proposal offers Bosnia a chance to avoid further killing and an alternative to growing military dependence on a Croatian ally that may one day try to swallow it.
After two and a half years of policy gyrations and humiliations culminating in a Congressional revolt last month over lifting the arms embargo on Bosnia, President Clinton has correctly concluded that the United States does better by actively shaping its own Balkan diplomatic initiatives than by deferring to Europe.
Even without American troops on the ground, Washington has more diplomatic influence than any other outside power. Now, at a critical moment, Mr. Clinton has decided to put that influence behind a serious peace plan. That is a welcome development.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
The Pros and Cons Of Call-In Democracy

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

THE ELECTRONIC REPUBLIC
Reshaping Democracy in the Information Age
By Lawrence K. Grossman
290 pages. A 20th Century Fund Book/Viking.
$24.95.
Among Newt Gingrich's first acts as Speaker of the House this year was the unveiling of a vast new electronic archive named Thomas (after that great avatar of direct democracy, Thomas Jefferson), which would make every bill submitted to Congress and every speech made in the House or Senate immediately available to users of the Internet. "There is a pervasive cynicism in the culture of Washington," he declared. "What this is going to do is get information beyond the cynicism of the elite." 
 Disenchantment with Washington and populist efforts to make the government more responsive to the electorate's will are nothing new of course, as the expanding use of ballot initiatives, the growing popularity of term limits and the enhanced visibility of call-in talk shows all attest. In his timely new book, Lawrence K. Grossman -- the former head of PBS and the former president of NBC News -- argues that these trends will accelerate rapidly in the future, as advances in telecommunications technology enable more and more Americans "to participate directly in making the laws and policies by which they are governed."
Mr. Grossman's book, "The Electronic Republic," is partly a historical consideration of the pros and cons of direct (as opposed to representative) democracy, partly an assessment of the consequences that television and newer technology (like the Internet, E-mail, faxes and interactive computers) have already had on voters and partly a set of recommendations for making sensible use of this technology. Although many of Mr. Grossman's observations about the perils of television -- its taste for sensationalism, its emphasis on personality, its susceptibility to spin doctors and demagogues -- are terribly familiar, he does a nimble job of putting these matters in context with broader historical developments and using his own experience in the business to illuminate his points.
Because television appears to give its viewers "an unmediated, firsthand view of the world outside of their neighborhood," Mr. Grossman says, it has encouraged people "to come to their own conclusions about what should be done and which candidates to support" with little help from "political parties, journalists, experts or most other authority figures." Ross Perot -- whose 1992 Presidential campaign initially bypassed the mainstream press and the traditional two-party system -- took advantage of this development to make a big splash on the national political scene, and Bill Clinton, too, tried to incorporate this strategy into his campaign, with appearances on television and radio talk shows.
As Mr. Grossman sees it, the American people are rapidly becoming "the new fourth branch of government." Politicians are increasingly reluctant to take stands on important issues without first consulting with poll takers and professional spin doctors, and now govern in a perpetual campaign mode. As a result, Mr. Grossman argues, policy is harder to carry out: "The President's high public visibility narrows his policy options, limits his 'wiggle room' to negotiate and reduces the time he has to put his programs in place and bring the people on board."
"It is no accident," he writes, "that during the era of television's dominance we have had 'gridlock government,' the first Presidential resignation and three one-term Presidents so far. Only Ronald Reagan, a professional actor, has served two full terms. In contrast to earlier days, when Presidents could lead based on their own strong conviction of what had to be done, the tendency in the era of television is for a President to feel compelled to keep in step with public opinion as the people follow the major events on television day in and day out."
Unlike Federalists like Alexander Hamilton, who warned that "the people are turbulent and changing; they seldom judge and determine right," Mr. Grossman says that recent studies (like "The Rational Public," a 1992 analysis of national policy preferences by Benjamin I. Page and Robert Y. Shapiro) have convinced him that "public judgments have tended to be no worse than the judgments of the political elite." His worries about the rising power of public opinion have less to do, then, with the public's innate wisdom than with concerns about the sort of information it is routinely exposed to.
Mr. Grossman points out that the telecommunications industry is increasingly controlled by a shrinking number of global companies that can act as "gatekeepers to the flow of ideas and information," a development underscored by the recent announcement of Westinghouse's intent to acquire CBS and Disney's to purchase Capital Cities/ABC. Mr. Grossman also observes that wealthy politicians and special interest groups have an unfair advantage in buying influential television ad time and that " 'immediate reward news' -- stories involving corruption, accidents, disasters, crime, sexual deviance and social gossip -- has largely displaced 'delayed reward news' -- stories involving critically important economic, social and political issues."
So what is to be done about life in the emerging "electronic republic"? Echoing Mr. Gingrich, who suggested that the poorest Americans be given a tax credit to buy laptop computers, Mr. Grossman argues that Government might have to provide subsidies to insure that all citizens have access to the "basic telecommunications equipment they will need to participate in the public sphere." He suggests that noncommercial radio and television be "converted into a vigorous, independent, well-supported local and national interactive public telecommunications system" and that all political candidates accepting matching taxpayer campaign funds be required to participate in televised debates.
The reader may not agree with all of Mr. Grossman's suggestions, but he lays them out in strong, clear language, eschewing both the naive optimism about technology that has colored so much American thinking in the past and the doom-saying of many contemporary critics. His book not only illustrates Marshall McLuhan's belief that "as the speed of information increases," politics tends to move toward the "immediate involvement of the entire community in the central acts of decision," but also Toqueville's prescient observation that American democracy "is constantly in the process of democratizing itself further."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Drop in Yen's Value Heartens Japanese Exporters

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 18

 BODY:
A decade ago, Japan began coping with the effects of the Plaza Accord, an agreement reached by the major industrial nations that caused the yen's value against the dollar to double in only two years. The agreement, still seared in the nation's memory, made Japanese exports less competitive and began an exodus of factories to less expensive sites abroad.
So perhaps it is no surprise that Japan now feels as if a giant weight has been lifted from its shoulders by what some analysts are calling a reverse Plaza Accord -- the concerted intervention in the currency markets this week by the central banks of the United States, Japan and Germany that has helped weaken the yen and strengthen the dollar to its highest levels since February. 
 Analysts and executives said that if the dollar stabilized at around its current level of nearly 100 yen, Japan's meager corporate profits would expand, exports would rise and the nation's recovery from a four-year economic slump would resume -- a recovery sidelined by the dollar's sharp fall and the yen's rise earlier this year.
Such expectations have fueled a steep rally on the Tokyo stock market this week. Although stocks took a breather Thursday and this morning, with the key Nikkei average of 225 issues slipping 9.03 points and 117.21 points respectively, the average jumped 706.01 points, or 4.1 percent, on Wednesday -- the second-largest daily gain this year -- and 536.15 points, or 3.2 percent, on Tuesday. The index stands above 18,000 for the first time since February.
Spurred by the central banks' intervention on Tuesday, the dollar has traded as high as 99.05 yen in Tokyo, its best level since Feb. 10 and 24 percent above an intraday low of 79.80 yen reached on April 19. In late Tokyo trading, it was quoted at 97.88 yen. Weakened by the latest American trade data, the dollar settled at 97.25 yen in New York on Thursday.
A weaker yen helps Japanese companies two ways: by making their exports less expensive in terms of other currencies, and by increasing the number of yen produced when sales made in other currencies are converted into yen.
For many of Japan's big electronics, automobile and steel companies, the difference between 85 yen to the dollar and a stronger 98 yen to the dollar is the difference between loss and profit on their exports.
A recent survey by Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading financial newspaper, found that the typical break-even rate for exports by large manufacturers is 95 yen to the dollar.
The dollar is hardly expected to return to its levels of 1985, when $1 could buy 264 yen. That was the year of the Plaza Accord -- named for the New York hotel where the deal to reduce the dollar's value was reached by the big economic powers. So the dollar's recent rebound has nowhere near the ramifications of that agreement, which quickly cut the value of the dollar -- reaching as low as 122 yen by 1987.
While the weaker yen is helpful to Japanese industry, analysts and executives cautioned that even if the dollar rose above 100 yen, which many consider possible in the near future, such a rise would not be a cure-all for the economy. Japanese financial institutions are still mired in bad debt. And many industries, particularly the auto makers, suffer from excess production capacity.
"It's not going to be the magic bullet," Jesper Koll, economist for J. P. Morgan in Tokyo, said of the dollar's rise. "It's not going to propel Japan toward 2.8 percent to 3 percent growth." He estimated that Japan's economy would grow only four-tenths of 1 percent in 1995 and 1.5 percent in 1996.
In addition, the current exchange rates look good only in comparison with the dollar's basement levels of earlier this year. In the middle of 1994, when the dollar first dropped below 100 yen, even that level was considered extremely troublesome for Japanese industry.
Last year, "when the yen hit 100, everybody screamed" because the Japanese currency was so strong, said Yukio Ozawa, deputy general manager for investor relations at the Sony Corporation. "Now the yen goes down to 98 or 99, and people are asking, 'What do you think about that cheap yen?' "
At 100 yen to the dollar, many Japanese exports would still be uncompetitive abroad. And foreign beef, cars and clothing would still have a price advantage over domestic products in the Japanese market, meaning that imports could continue to make inroads.
Nor are Japanese companies likely to alter their strategies of moving manufacturing offshore, though the pace might slow a little. At 100 yen to the dollar, Japanese wages are far higher than those in Southeast Asia. And the industrial migration is being driven not just by cost considerations but by a desire to more easily serve the emerging markets of Asia.
Japanese companies are not likely to sharply lower their export prices, even if they become convinced that the new currency rates are here to stay. Fearful of losing market share, they never raised their prices far enough to fully compensate for the yen's rise.
Still, the recent weakening of the yen could sharply improve the profit of Japan's export-focused auto and electronics companies, which can gain or lose millions of dollars in revenue and profit for each one yen shift in the exchange rate.
Sony, for instance, reported last week that operating profit in the most recent quarter fell 50 percent from a year earlier because of the yen's sharp rise. Had exchange rates remained constant, the company estimated, operating profit would instead have increased 85 percent.
Of course, a declining yen is not good for everyone. Companies that depend on imports, such as electric utilities, which buy imported oil in now more valuable dollars, will have to deal with rising costs.
For Japan Airlines, which began hiring foreign flight attendants and pilots because Japanese ones were too expensive, the high yen has made it difficult to compete with foreign airlines. But it has also meant that record numbers of Japanese are flying abroad on Japan Airlines because taking a vacation overseas has become less expensive than staying in Japan.
The profitability of exports varies widely by company and product. At Hitachi Ltd., for instance, equipment for electric power plants cannot be exported profitably at 100 yen to the dollar, but computer memory chips, now in short supply, were profitable at 80 yen.
Japanese companies have been working feverishly to cut costs, so that companies that could not make money last year at 100 yen to the dollar might be able to record profits in 1995. Indeed, Japanese companies, given enough time, have been remarkably adept at adjusting to an almost constant rise of the yen since 1970, when $1 bought 360 yen.
Ultimately, the fall of the yen could lead to a renewed rise in Japan's huge trade surplus by making Japanese exports more attractive. But Mr. Koll, the economist at J. P. Morgan, said he did not think the surplus would balloon again because the high yen had already carved a path into Japan for imports.

HEADLINE: 2 Associated With Clintons Face Charges

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
A Federal grand jury today indicted two Whitewater business partners of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, as well as the Governor of Arkansas, on 21 counts of fraud, conspiracy and making false statements in obtaining millions of dollars of federally backed loans in the 1980's.
The indictment, handed up by a Federal grand jury in Little Rock, Ark., charged that the two partners, James B. McDougal and his former wife, Susan, had concocted a series of fraudulent loans from Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan, an Arkansas savings association at the center of the investigation into the Whitewater land venture. Madison, which was owned and operated by the McDougals, collapsed in 1989 at a cost to taxpayers of more than $60 million. 
Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas, who was indicted in June on separate charges, was named in 11 new counts today. In the 1980's, Mr. Tucker was a lawyer and businessman who did legal work for Madison and borrowed money from it.
Neither President Clinton nor Mrs. Clinton were named in the indictment. In a statement issued in Little Rock, the independent counsel in the Whitewater inquiry, Kenneth W. Starr, noted that the indictment "does not charge criminal wrongdoing by President William Jefferson Clinton or First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton." Prosecutors in the counsel's office declined to say whether there would be any further indictments, noting that the investigation was continuing.
Part of today's indictment involves a $300,000 federally backed loan made by a former municipal judge who has accused Mr. Clinton of improperly pressuring him twice into making the 1986 loan to Mrs. McDougal. The judge, David L. Hale, has already pleaded guilty on two felony counts in the case and has been cooperating with investigators.
Mr. Hale is expected to be one of the Government's most important witnesses against the McDougals and Mr. Tucker, and his account that Mr. Clinton pressed him to make the loan is likely to arise at any trial. Mr. Clinton has disputed Mr. Hale's version of events. The President has said he does not recall meeting with Mr. Hale, and he has denied putting any pressure on him.
The White House issued a statement after the indictment was released, noting what Mr. Starr said concerning the Clintons and adding, "We continue to cooperate fully and hope that the independent counsel will conclude his inquiry expeditiously."
The Clintons sold their interest in Whitewater to Mr. McDougal in 1992. In recently concluded House hearings on the subject, Republicans said the couple had been the beneficiaries of a corrupt scheme run by Arkansas insiders at taxpayers' expense.
Whatever the outcome of his investigation, Mr. Starr is expected to give the special court that appointed him a report about what prosecutors have discovered about the Clintons' financial dealings in Arkansas.
The inquiry is rooted in questions raised in the 1992 campaign about whether Mr. McDougal had improperly used money from his savings association to prop up Whitewater, a land development venture begun in the summer before Mr. Clinton was first elected Governor. The investment quickly turned sour.
The indictment today, however, focused not on Whitewater but on Madison and on a series of loans issued by Mr. Hale's company, Capital Management Services, including a $300,000 loan to Mrs. McDougal.
That loan, which was never repaid and had to be absorbed by the Federal Government, indirectly helped the Whitewater Development Company. It went to repay other debts that Mr. McDougal had drawn on to prop up the Whitewater Development Company, which had been hemorrhaging in the 1980's, investigators said.
The indictment is silent about what role, if any, Mr. Clinton played in securing the loan.
"In or about March and April 1986, defendant James B. McDougal, and others known to the grand jury, including David L. Hale, prepared paperwork and took other steps to arrange for defendant Susan H. McDougal to receive the proceeds from a false and fraudulent loan," the indictment said.
Mr. Hale's lending company was part of a program of the Small Business Administration designed to lend money to socially and economically disadvantaged borrowers. But he has said it became "a piggy bank" for a clique of Democratic insiders in Arkansas in the mid-1980's.
Mr. McDougal once told one of his lending officers that he considered Madison "a candy store," Federal records say. Mr. McDougal was acquitted in 1990 on bank fraud charges related to his control of Madison, but those involved transactions not in today's indictment.
Mr. McDougal said today that he would vigorously contest the charges. "I've been expecting it for a long time," he said in a brief telephone interview today. "I intend to defend myself vigorously and to prove myself innocent of any crimes whatsoever."
Mr. Tucker's spokeswoman, Max Parker, said he would have no comment about the new indictment. Bobby McDaniel, Mrs. McDougal's lawyer, said that his client had expected the indictment and that she intended to contest the charges.
Mr. McDougal was named in 19 counts and Mrs. McDougal was named in 8. Some of the counts named more than one defendant, and almost all carry maximum sentences of five years in prison each and fines of up to $250,000.
As described in the indictment, Madison and Capital Management were improperly used to reward the defendants or those who would help help them out. The defendants reaped the benefits, while the lending institutions, insured by the Federal government, bore all the risks.
The indictment said the financial dealings of the McDougals and Mr. Tucker had been concealed through a series of fraudulently structured transactions that hid the true owners of various assets.
It portrays the three as requiring a "continuous stream of loans and financing" of their investments and to pay off other business loans. To keep their dealings from being criticized by Federal examiners or to insure that they not appear to violate state or Federal regulations, the indictment said, the "defendants structured transactions and generated fraudulent paperwork."
The fraudulent transactions at issue in the indictment include eight loans of more than $3 million from Madison and Capital in the mid-1980's. One deal involves property in Little Rock, where various fronts were used "for the purpose of generating false profits, and providing cash benefits to defendant Jim Guy Tucker," the indictment said.
As Madison spun out of control, Mr. McDougal was particularly concerned about an examination of Madison in late 1985 and early 1986 and took steps to conceal the true condition of the institution from Federal examiners, the indictment said.

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Should Sit Out Beijing Meeting;
Talk, Don't Shove

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Walter Russell Mead's "Danger of Bigger Trouble With the Chinese" (Op-Ed, Aug. 15) is one of the few balanced, thoughtful pieces on China in your paper in the last few months. 
 Recent China-bashing, led in Congress by a curious coalition of extreme right- and left-wingers and fueled by biased reporting and editorializing, has not only made the Beijing Government more defensive and xenophobic, but has also alienated an overwhelming majority of a new generation of Western-trained Chinese scholars and scientists.
It is high time United States political leaders recognize that the deterioration of United States-China relations is hurting the prospects of political liberalization in China and pushing this generation of Chinese elites to the embrace of nationalism. To most of us, calls for containment of China cannot help reinforce our suspicion of a deep-rooted Western unwillingness to accept China's rise to great-power status.
While my generation recognizes the imperative for China to liberalize its political and economic systems further, we know from experience that the most effective way of accomplishing this is through cooperation and dialogue, not threats and confrontation.
 
MINXIN PEI
Asst. Prof. of Politics, Princeton
Princeton, N.J., Aug. 15, 1995

HEADLINE: A Coup for the King

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 16

 BODY:
The defection of a top Iraqi military official to Jordan last week may tantalize the West with the possibility of Iraqi military secrets, but it has already handed numerous tangible rewards to King Hussein. Aside from expressions of good will from President Clinton and deep gratitude from Israel there are signs that Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries are poised to end their five-year boycott of Jordan.
The King -- who has run this country for 43 years, escaped two dozen assassination attempts and maneuvered skillfully through the byzantine world of Middle Eastern politics -- has played the defection of a caravan from Iraq's ruling family for all it's worth. Indeed, in opening the door to the Iraqi defectors, King Hussein seems to have let in all sorts of political and economic opportunities at virtually no risk. 
 By calling President Clinton immediately to inform him that he had granted political asylum to Lieut. Gen. Hussein Kamel, his wife, and other family members and aides, the King earned points with Washington whose economic support he sorely needs.
And in suggesting that Jordan may need protection in the highly unlikely event Iraq should attack in response to the defections, the Jordanian monarch handed Mr. Clinton a free chance to show, once more, how tough the American President can be on Iraq.
The fact that Iraq is falling apart economically and militarily and is in no position to attack anyone, let alone Jordan, which has become its lifeline to the world during Iraq's isolation under United Nations economic sanctions, matters very little for all parties concerned.
On Sunday, the King turned around to give Yediot Aharonot, Israel's largest circulation newspaper, his first public comment on the episode, including his account of persuading General Kamel of the need for Iraq and the whole Arab world to make peace with Israel. This unquestionably further endeared the King to Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, whose lobbying in Washington has already brought Jordan economic relief from debts it owed the United States Government.
On Tuesday the Israeli Interior Minister, Moshe Shahal, said his country would do what was necessary to defend Jordan "with great pleasure."
King Hussein also received Prince Turki al-Faisal, the Saudi chief of intelligence, who flew in a hurry to Amman over the weekend to seek the monarch's permission to talk to General Kamel, who is both son-in-law and cousin to the Iraqi President and who was in charge of Iraq's war machine for several years. Permission was, of course, granted with royal dispatch, marking a new-found warmth in Jordanian-Saudi relations.
Only a month ago, the Saudis were responding with open contempt to Jordan's relentless effort to mend fences after its support of Iraq during the Gulf war. When the Jordanian Foreign Minister, Abdul Karim al-Kabariti, flew to Saudi Arabia to meet the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saudi al-Faisal, the Prince pointedly told reporters at the airport that the Jordanian official was not invited but rather had asked if he might come.
This week it was announced in Amman that Mr. Kabariti flew back to Saudi Arabia, this time arrange what has been billed as "the first summit meeting" between King Fahd and King Hussein since the Persian Gulf war. Jordan has desperately been seeking to reopen the Arab Gulf markets for the goods and services it once sold to a now largely bankrupt Iraq.
Further "reconciliations," as the Arab press calls these episodes, are expected with the Emir of Kuwait and other Arab Gulf rulers who have also not been on speaking terms with the King since the Gulf war.
These maneuvers "prove King Hussein is still the political 'professional,' " Galal Dwedar, editor in chief of the Egyptian mass circulation daily Al Akhbar, wrote this week.
"His mistakes in the Gulf war have not prevented him from practicing this skill with great intelligence and determination to make up for his losses, and he has succeeded," Mr. Dwedar wrote in a front page editorial.
Back in 1990 and 1991 during the Gulf crisis, the King whose kingdom survives largely on the kindness of others, was Iraq's closest strategic, economic and political ally. At that time, the alliance brought Jordan tens of billions of dollars in financial aid from and trade with Iraq. But Iraq's defeat in the war left both countries isolated.
But today, the talk among average citizens in Jordan, not to mention foreign diplomats and the King's top advisers, is that Iraq is hardly capable of maintaining internal order, let alone either aiding or attacking Jordan.
"It is nice to be loved by the Americans," a former political adviser to the King said in a conversation, on condition of anonymity. "We need the American embrace to impress the Israelis and the Arabs. It helps in the quest to improve our image in the region, so what's wrong with that."
The catalyst of this conversion, General Kamel, continues to remain in hiding after a news conference on Saturday in which he vowed to try to overthrow his father-in-law, Saddam Hussein. Since he left with his wife, Raghad, and his brother, Col. Saddam Kamel, another military aide who is married to another of President Hussein's daughters, Rana, infighting in Iraq's extended first family appears to be worsening, if unconfirmed reports from the Iraqi opposition are true.
Jordanian officials say that, if anything, King Hussein is betting that the end is near for Saddam Hussein's Government and is preparing to reap any benefits of a fall by positioning himself now as a champion of reform in Iraq, despite the two countries' history as strategic allies.

HEADLINE: CHINA WAR GAMES VIEWED AS TACTIC TO PRESS TAIWAN

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 18

 BODY:
With its second military exercise near Taiwan this summer under way, China is preparing an escalating series of naval, air and missile force maneuvers intended to bring Taiwan's political leadership to heel, American military officials and foreign diplomats say.
Plans for the new exercises over the coming weeks and months have broad support among Chinese military and civilian officials and represent a distinct turn away from a resumption of dialogue with Taiwan, which China believes is forsaking its adherence to the principle of "one China" and pursuing world recognition as an independent nation. 
 China is putting more emphasis on military options because its leaders have concluded -- wrongly in the view of many analysts -- that President Lee Teng-hui, who has pursued a more visible and independent global role for Taiwan, can be weakened politically by such a campaign.
"It's foolish, but that is where they are headed," said a China specialist who recently completed consultations in Taiwan, Beijing and Washington. "China is determined to remove Lee Teng-hui from power and they are going to ratchet up the military pressure until they accomplish that."
Western military analysts and diplomats fear that events could spiral out of control, leading to deliberate or accidental military conflict between China and Taiwan. This in turn would create dangerous political and military choices for the United States, which seeks good relations with both Taiwan and China but would find it difficult to abandon Taiwan.
At risk also is the economic integration between the economies of Taiwan and China, where Taiwanese businessmen have invested $20 billion in industries, part of a booming trading relationship that would be costly to unhinge.
On Tuesday, China opened its second round of military exercises off Taiwan with air and naval missile firings in the East China Sea as well as naval artillery tests. They were conducted in an area 80 to 100 miles north of Taiwan.
"The exercise this time is different," Taiwan's Defense Minister, Chiang Chung-ling, said in Taipei. "They have air and sea forces in joint combat exercises in addition to guided-missile tests and artillery firing."
In addition, more than 100 Chinese fishing boats were reported this week to be entering Taiwan waters off Matsu Island, just off the mainland province of Fujian. Such provocations in the past have drawn fire from Taiwan military forces.
China's neighbors already are nervous over the territorial of Beijing in the South China Sea and the buildup of its rapid-response military forces intended to fight small-scale wars away from its borders.
Prime Minister Li Peng of China, in a meeting on Thursday with Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Louisiana Democrat, continued Beijing's hard line on Taiwan, referring to China's sovereignty over the island as a "core principle" involving China's "territorial integrity and the cause of reunification."
Details gleaned of Chinese military planning are being held closely by United States officials, but they have forced Pentagon planners to consider what military response American forces in the Pacific would make if an inadvertent or deliberate clash occurred between Chinese and Taiwanese forces, or if China sought to disrupt Taiwan's trade by blocking its sea lanes, American officials say.
"Accidents happen when armed forces are maneuvering near each other and they run the risk of war by inadvertent surprises," said CharlesW. Freeman Jr., who until last year was an Assistant Secretary of Defense in charge of Asian policy.
Open conflict in the Taiwan Strait would also force Japan and South Korea to weigh their own responses since American military units on their soil could become involved in resupplying Taiwan.
"Put simply," said John W. Lewis, a longtime China scholar at Stanford University who has consulted with Chinese military leaders here this summer, "the stakes for peace and stability in Asia are quite high."
"The danger is the risk of a full-blown military crisis that arises from escalating military bluster on both sides of the Taiwan Strait or from some accident or miscalculation among military forces that are no longer communicating well in an increasingly inflamed political environment."
Even as the threat of a military crisis increases, American officials are worried about other factors that could add to the tension.
*Continued Chinese military pressure is likely to lead to requests from Taiwan to its allies in Congress for major new arms sales, including submarines and ballistic missile defense systems.
*United States officials believe they may be only weeks or months away from proving irrefutably that China shipped M-11 ballistic missiles to Pakistan in violation of its commitment not to do so, thereby triggering a legal requirement for the Clinton Administration to impose new sanctions on China.
*The continued detention of Harry Wu, the Chinese-American human rights advocate, and increasing repression aimed at China's dissidents, is working against the restoration of normal communication and ambassadorial relations, which were effectively downgraded in June when ambassadors were called home from both capitals.
*If Mr. Lee becomes the first democratically elected President of Taiwan in elections next March, Clinton Administration officials believe they will face irresistible pressure from Congress to invite him to Washington, an act that would enrage Beijing further.
With concern deepening over possible military conflict in the Taiwan Strait, a number of China specialists and former Government officials from the Carter, Reagan and Bush Administrations are mobilizing efforts to urge Congress and the Clinton Administration to come to terms on a common strategy toward China and Taiwan.
Such efforts are being complicated by the growing ideological debate over China policy, as a number of members of Congress see irreconcilable differences with Beijing over its human rights record and weapons proliferation activities. Some have called for "containment" strategies and for elevated relations with Taipei.
"United States policy since 1972 has sought to build peace, stability and prosperity between China and Taiwan, and this policy has yielded tremendous results in nurturing economic and political reforms and in creating an environment for Beijing and Taipei to integrate their economies, set aside 45 years of enmity and negotiate their own future under the 'one-China' banner." said Professor Lewis, an informal adviser to Defense Secretary William J. Perry.
"This policy is now dangerously close to being reversed."
Yet at the same time, a growing number of Americans and members of Congress believe that the United States cannot morally ignore the democratic flowering on Taiwan, which only began to emerge a decade ago from a long period of political repression and human rights abuses.

HEADLINE: U.S. Action in Persian Gulf Is Said to Seek Iraqi's Ouster

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
American military preparations in the Persian Gulf and a high-level diplomatic mission to the Middle East are aimed at speeding the ouster of President Saddam Hussein as well as responding to recent Iraqi troop movements, Administration officials said today.
The Pentagon said today that it was moving up a scheduled training exercise in Kuwait to later this month. About 1,400 soldiers from the First Cavalry Division at Fort Hood, Tex., will deploy to Kuwait, where M1-A1 battle tanks and Bradley fighting vehicles are in place. 
 The American troops will join Kuwaiti forces for about three weeks of live-fire training in the desert. The exercise, which is conducted twice annually, had been scheduled for late October.
Administration officials said that the military precautions and a mission by two senior American diplomats to Jordan, Egypt and other Middle East countries are being undertaken in the hope of bringing pressure Mr. Hussein.
"If I were sitting in Baghdad that's what I'd be thinking," said one American official who follows Iraq.
But Administration officials said the United States has no preference for a successor to Mr. Hussein, and would have little influence even if it did. While the defection of the Iraqi leader's two sons-in-law to Jordan last week certainly damaged his political base, Mr. Hussein has faced political pressures many times before and survived.
"We're trying to speed the downfall of Saddam Hussein," said Phebe Marr, a Middle East specialist at the National Defense University. "But we can't go in there and do this. We're not in a position to pull strings. The only thing we can do is develop an atmosphere."
United States officials acknowledge they walk a fine line in their attempts to hasten Mr. Hussein's ouster without leading to the disintegration of Iraq.
One goal of the American delegation, which includes Assistant Secretary of State Robert Pelletreau and Mark Parris, the National Security Council's senior aide on the Middle East, will be to speed a reconciliation between Saudi Arabia and Jordan, a move that would make it easier for King Hussein to curtail economic links with Iraq.
American officials said today that the two diplomats had urged Jordan to stop accepting supplies of Iraqi oil that provides Baghdad with hard currency. It is unclear, however, whether the Jordanian leader will agree since Amman must rely on Iraqi oil shipments because of the King's rift with Saudi Arabia.
Kuwait and Saudi Arabia cut off trade with Jordan after the King supported Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.
After meeting with Jordanian officials earlier this week, the American delegation flew to Cairo today for talks with Egyptian officials. It is expected to travel to the Persian Gulf region this weekend.
The Pentagon's decision to move up the training exercise by more than a month came after Gen. J. H. Binford Peay 3d, the head of the United States Central Command, received approval from the Kuwaiti Prime Minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdulla al-Sabah, this week.
A senior military official said the exercise will start in the next 10 days at Camp Doha, a training site on the outskirts of Kuwait City. "It takes about a week to draw the equipment," he said. "We exercise for about three weeks. We take the equipment, wash it down, put it back from whence we got it in its storage facilities and redeploy. So the whole thing takes in the neighborhood of four to six weeks."
The exercise is one of several steps the Pentagon has ordered since the Iraqi defections. Others include sending ships with tanks and equipment for 22,000 marines and soldiers to the gulf and moving warships closer to the region.
American military officials have expressed growing concern since the defections that a series of "unusual training activities" involving Iraqi Army, air defense, special forces and Republican Guard units could presage an attack on Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.
Two Republican Guard units, the Hammurabi and Medina divisions, have been practicing mobilizing their garrisoned forces more effectively, something the forces did poorly last fall when more than 10,000 Iraqi troops menaced the Kuwaiti border before eventually withdrawing.
American intelligence officials said today there were only minor changes in the Iraqi troop movements within the last 24 hours.
In Baghdad today, the top United Nations weapons inspector said Iraq had revealed new details about its clandestine weapons program. The official, Rolf Ekeus, said sudden cooperation appeared to be linked to the defection of the country's leading weapons official.
Mr. Hussein earlier threatened to cut off all contact with the United Nations inspectors and send forces into Kuwait and Saudi Arabia if the United Nations did not lift its sanctions against Iraq when they come up for renewal next month.

HEADLINE: HOW EVENTS DREW U.S. INTO BALKANS

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Early on a hot July night President Bill Clinton was bent over the practice green in the backyard of the White House, missing putts and once again venting his frustration over Bosnia.
The Administration was already in the middle of a high-level review of its policy, and Mr. Clinton was impatient for some results. Looking ahead to September, and the likely withdrawal of United Nations peacekeeping forces, Mr. Clinton told a small group of aides: "The status quo is not acceptable. We've got to really dig in and think about this." 
 That episode, and a series of conversations in July between the President and his senior aides, signaled something new. After nearly three years of allowing the European allies to define the limits of American policy, Mr. Clinton was ready for a new approach that has suddenly transformed the United States into the acknowledged leader in shaping a settlement.
On Aug. 7, a day after Croatia's blitzkrieg offensive overwhelmed the Serbian army occupying Krajina, Mr. Clinton approved a new plan for Bosnia that offered enticements to the combatants if they signed a peace accord and threatened punishments for all sides if they chose to fight on.
Senior Administration officials said the more intense American involvement stems both from the political imperatives of the upcoming Presidential campaign and from the shifting balance of power in the Balkans. It marks a new personal engagement by Mr. Clinton on an issue that has seized his attention only episodically, but that aides say has come to bedevil him in recent months.
"The bottom line is: If the United States doesn't lead, it doesn't happen," said one official.
Prospects for the Administration's peace plan remain uncertain, but it has quickly become the only negotiation taken seriously by the parties. Bosnian officials in Sarajevo this week refused to meet with Carl Bildt, the European envoy. The President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, has told diplomats that he will deal only with the Americans. Britain has praised the American plan, and even France, where President Jacques Chirac a few weeks ago stole the spotlight by demanding tougher action against the Serbs, has welcomed the American initiative.
Under the proposal, Serbia would get relief from crippling Western economic sanctions in exchange for recognizing Bosnia, Croatia and Macedonia. The Bosnian-Croatian federation, which controls only 30 percent of the country, would end up with about 50 percent of the territory and would receive reconstruction aid. If the Bosnian Serbs balked, the West would arm the Bosnian Government forces, launch air strikes, and permit soldiers from Islamic nations to replace the departing United Nations peacekeepers.
The Clinton Administration's new approach on Bosnia has ended three years in which Washington largely deferred to its European allies on how to cope with the conflict.
Time and again, the United States proposed tougher military steps. Most times, the European allies resisted, noting that the United States did not have peacekeeping troops in Bosnia facing retaliation from the Serbs. As long as the United States had no troops in Bosnia, a senior official said, Mr. Clinton was left in the uncomfortable position of "leading from behind."
Several factors have combined to change that dynamic. Croatia's recent victory over the Serbian rebels in Krajina sowed disarray in the Serbian ranks, and opened the door to a possible settlement. The prospect of spending yet another winter hunkered down in Bosnia made the Europeans less willing to continue their approach of "muddle through."
And Mr. Clinton's senior advisers have come to see the Bosnia issue as a political time bomb that could go off in the 1996 campaign. Some fear the Administration's entire foreign policy record will ultimately be judged on the outcome of the Bosnia crisis.
Senior Administration officials believe Mr. Clinton is likely to be forced to send American troops to Bosnia within the next year, either to help the United Nations force withdraw or to police a peace plan.
With that in mind, Administration officials have sought to forge a policy that puts the United States more in control of events. If American troops are going to Bosnia, the officials said, their deployment should be under circumstances and timing dictated by Washington, not the European allies or the Bosnian Serbs.
The nightmare scenario for the White House, several officials said, would be for the United Nations force to stagger through another winter and then ask for American help with its withdrawal next spring, just as the presidential campaign is heating up.
"I don't think the President relishes going into the 1996 election hostage to fortune in the Balkans, with the Bosnian Serbs able to bring us deeper into a war," one senior official said.
The White House also sees another pressing reason for action. Administration officials hope to show significant progress toward a settlement by early September -- before Congress returns from its summer recess and moves to override Mr. Clinton's veto of legislation lifting the embargo on arms sales to the Bosnian Government.
Senate Majority Leader Bob Dole, the measure's chief advocate, is a front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination and has vociferously criticized Mr. Clinton for vacillating on Bosnia. On Thursday Mr. Dole asked the Clinton Administration to abandon its peace efforts because he believed the plan was too generous to Serbia.
Administration officials said the new policy has its roots in late May, when the Bosnian Serbs seized foreign peacekeepers as hostages and prevented NATO from continuing what was meant to be a punishing campaign of air strikes begun on May 25. Soon after, aides say, Mr. Clinton began demanding a new approach that would force the combatants to the bargaining table.
"He saw that this was having real costs for us," said one senior official. "He said: I want for us to be more on top of this thing, more shaping of it. If we were going to be blamed for the failures, it should at least be for concrete decisions that we had taken."
In early July, Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, began a series of weekly breakfast meetings that included Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations; General John Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; William J. Perry, the Defense Secretary, and Warren Christopher, the Secretary of State. The conversation, officials said, often focused on the "end game" to bring about a final settlement of the Bosnia conflict, a subject Mr. Lake had directed National Security officials to begin studying.
Ms. Albright's inclusion was significant. She had been the Administration's most consistent advocate of the United States pushing its European allies to adopt a more muscular policy in Bosnia.
As senior officials were beginning that review, there was more bad news from Bosnia. United Nations troops and NATO air power were unable to prevent the Serbs from overrunning Srebrenica, one of six United Nations-designated "safe areas," on July 11, deepening Mr. Clinton's anxiety over what one official termed "the situation of drift."
In response the allies gathered in London on July 21 and a new American attitude seemed evident. President Jacques Chirac of France had asked the United States to supply more than 100 helicopters for a nighttime operation to ferry thousands of French troops to Gorazde.
American officials countered with a proposal to threaten massive bombing against the Bosnian Serb troops attacking the encircled town, a plan accepted by the allies and later broadened to include all of the safe areas. Before that could be done, however, the safe area of Zepa fell to the Serbs on July 25.
When Croatia defied all predictions of Pentagon analysts and easily routed the Serbian rebels in the first days of August, Mr. Lake immediately asked the President's senior advisers for memos on what should be done next. All agreed on the value of a diplomatic initiative, though they differed significantly on the details. Mr. Perry suggested pushing for a cease-fire along the existing battlefronts, giving the Bosnian-Croatian federation only 30 percent of the territory. Mr. Lake, Ms. Albright and Mr. Christopher favored giving the Bosnians 51 percent.
According to the White House, the Administration's senior foreign policy advisers had met to discuss Bosnia 17 times in July and August. The President joined them in meetings on August 2, 7, and 8.
Hours later, Mr. Lake was on his way to Europe, leading a mission whose tenor illustrates the changed climate. Two years ago, Secretary of State Warren Christopher set out on a similar trip to consult the allies about a Clinton Administration proposal to arm the Bosnian Government and bomb the Serbs. The Europeans rebelled, and then darkly muttered about Mr. Clinton's failure to lead.
This time Mr. Lake did not ask -- he informed. An Administration official said that in his meetings in Bonn, Paris and London, Mr. Lake declared: "The President has made the following decisions. We want you to be with us."

HEADLINE: United Way Holds Steady In Donations

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
The United Way, which raises money for local charities through payroll checkoff plans, yesterday reported a 1 percent gain in contributions across the country, for a total of $3.08 billion for 1994. After adjusting for inflation of 2.6 percent, that represented a small decrease from the previous year.
Elaine Chao, president of United Way of America, called the figures a "very respectable showing," noting that they came during an overall decrease in contributions to human services. 
 Although charitable giving in the United States rose 3.6 percent last year, donations to human service charities fell 6 percent, according to "Giving USA," the annual report on private giving by the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel's Trust for Philanthropy.
For United Way, total giving has still not returned to the $3.17 billion peak reached in 1991, before problems began to surface involving misuse of funds by William Aramony, the longtime president of United Way of America. The organization provides marketing, technical and other services to the independent local United Way fund-raising organizations. Mr. Aramony and two other high-level executives were convicted on fraud and tax charges in April and sentenced to jail terms.
United Way of America installed new executives in 1992 and imposed stiff ethical rules. But, as the 1994 figures show, it still faces challenges in figuring out how to increase giving at a time when Government financing for the social service agencies it supports is likely to be flat or decreasing.
"The plain-vanilla social services have a real problem," said Robert Bothwell, president of the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, a watchdog group in Washington. "They're not arousing people's passions. You can't simply go out and tell people to give to charity the way you could 25 years ago. That's why we've seen the rise of very, very targeted marketing to niche audiences by nonprofits."
Ms. Chao said that under a new strategic plan developed by McKinsey & Company, local United Way organizations have been trying to play more active roles in their communities beyond fund-raising. In Phoenix, for example, United Way officials coordinated a meeting of many agencies to figure out how they could improve education. United Way is also considering more fund-raising in small businesses and using direct marketing.
Fund-raising results varied sharply across the country. The biggest gains among the 2,000 independent United Way drives were in Darlington, S.C., which was up 122 percent last year, and Bentonville, Ark., which showed a 95 percent gain.
One of the biggest declines was in Frederick, Md., which showed an 82 percent drop. Osceola, Ark., showed a decline of 35 percent.
Among the 10 cities that raise the most money, Washington showed the biggest gain, with a 4.1 percent increase, to $75.8 million. St. Louis was up 2.7 percent, to $50.3 million, and Atlanta was up 2.2 percent, to $56.7 million. Contributions in San Francisco, Houston and Chicago were mainly flat.
Large cities showing decreases included Detroit, which fell 3.6 percent, to $59.5 million, and Los Angeles, which slipped 3.1 percent, to $57.2 million.
New York City fell 1.5 percent, to $69.7 million. The New York fund-raising drive showed a 5 percent increase in giving from companies based in New York City, but a 10 percent decrease from companies with multiple offices in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, which are covered by the Tri-State United Way Campaign.
Ralph Dickerson Jr., president of United Way of New York City, said that the continued loss of jobs among large Fortune 500 companies where United Way has traditionally been strongest, continued to hurt fund-raising. But he said his group had had some "good success" getting into more medium-sized companies with 100 to 500 employees.
A continuing refrain among United Way leaders, Mr. Dickerson said, is: "It's tough out there. We all have to look for other fund-raising approaches."
"There's no question there are still questions over the past Aramony controversy," he said. "All of the wounds have not healed yet. But someone has got to help the social service agencies get through the tough times and cutbacks, and United Way has got to take that leadership position.

HEADLINE: World's Last Baby Seal Hunt Is Jobs for Namibians

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: CAPE CROSS, Namibia, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Before the early-morning fog had lifted here, more than 200 seal pups were lined up in rows on the concrete quay behind Aldert Brink's tumble-down factory, some with eyes bulging, others with bloody snouts, the result of being clubbed to death.
Workers moved among the lifeless animals performing different tasks. First, the males' bellies were slit open and their penises were removed to be sold as aphrodisiacs in the Far East. Then, cuts were made around the fins and heads, readying the pups for the skinning machine. 
 The harvesting of seals began this week on Namibia's desolate coast, once again triggering fierce debate over the practice. The Namibian Government, which sets a limit on the number of seals killed, says that sealing -- like fishing -- is a legitimate industry in a poor country that can ill afford to sneer at jobs.
Sealing generates about $500,000 a year and employs about 100 people, Government officials say, in a country with a total working population of about 150,000. "In this country 100 jobs is a lot," said Dr. Burger W. Oelossen, an official of Namibia's Ministry of Fisheries and Marine Resources. "The money is .04 percent of our G.N.P., about the equivalent of $120 billion in the U.S. economy. It's not a trivial thing for us."
But animal rights groups argue that the killings are inhumane and unnecessary. They are particularly incensed by the market for seal genitals, which can fetch as much as $1,200 a pound in Hong Kong. And they say the killing itself -- the clubbing of the young seals and the shooting of the bulls -- is often cruelly bungled.
"To see the process would just bring tears to anyone's eyes," said David Barritt, the African coordinator for the International Fund for Animal Welfare. "The rules say that they are supposed to club them and then stab them in the heart within 20 seconds," he said, referring to Government regulations. "But they club them six, seven, nine times before they are stunned, and then they leave them on the sand while they go on to the next one. It's just horrible."
The sealers insist that clubbing is the most efficient and humane method of killing pups; the young seals' skulls are so soft that bullets would pass right through, hitting other animals and endangering the hunters.
This is the world's only remaining large-scale commercial seal hunt. The practice virtually ended in the 1980's after environmental groups focused attention on the brutality of such hunts in Canada, leading both the United States and the European Union to ban imports of baby seal skins.
But in Namibia, sealing goes on, as it has for nearly a century, with the Government setting quotas every year. This year, with an estimated colony of about 500,000 seals, the Government will allow 12,500 pups and 4,000 bulls to be killed.
Mr. Brink, a South African who lives at the factory at Cape Cross, just up the coast from the Henties Bay hamlet, is one of Namibia's two seal concessionaires.
Apart from the Asian market for genitals, he said, he sells pelts locally where they are made into shoes, wallets, handbags and other accessories, and in limited numbers to European destinations he would not identify for use in coats.
He rolls his eyes at the "greenies" -- environmentalists -- who would stop this business. He does not understand why seals should be considered any different from fish or cattle or chickens. Sure, he says, they have nice eyes and big eyelashes, but they are still animals, still predators.
"As long as the animal is being utilized and not endangered, then it is the same as every other animal," he said. "People have this tendency to humanize them, that's all."
The Namibian Government, however, has decided that no one may see the actual kill.
Only later in the year, when the bulls come down the coast to mate, will Mr. Brink shoot them. For now, he is after only the pups, which have extremely fragile skulls and can be knocked out with a single well-placed blow. Mr. Brink said his men shepherd several hundred seals away from the herd, form a human funnel the seals must pass through and then smash the heads of any pups they can reach.
Mr. Brink doesn't get too sentimental about the process. He said he has seen the mothers come back looking for their pups, but never "sitting there crying like they always say in the animal rights groups."
"I have seen a mother tear her pup to pieces -- in fighting -- and then get on with her life," he added. "Especially, the big bulls. If a big bull approaches a cow and a small pup is hindering him -- he will tear it to bits. It's the way of nature."
His 75-year-old factory -- its machinery coated black by a mix of coal dust and the grease and steam of boiling meat -- sits on the edge of a seal reserve where, along the surf, sometimes as far as the eye can see, seals nestle against each other, barking and cavorting.
When Mr. Brink takes his four-wheel drive truck out to the beach, he looks at the herds with a trained eye, spotting the runts that will not survive and the aging, wounded bulls. He rails against the fishermen for the many seals he sees that have pieces of net looped around their necks -- especially the young ones that will grow and strangle themselves, horribly slowly.
"What do they want with me," he asked. "Why don't they stop that?"
The seal factory here is separated from the nearest village by more than 30 miles of desert, and it is another 40 miles after that before a town of any size. But enough tourists come to see the seals that Mr. Brink has opened a small store here where he sells shoes, wallets, book covers and handbags made of seal pelts. A hand-painted sign at the entrance pleads his case: Stop Ignorance. Listen to the Other Side.
His guest book bears hundreds of signatures and most entries comment only on how much the seals stink, even from a great distance. Mr. Brink said he rarely meets angry visitors. On a recent morning, a handful of tourists stopped in, bought two pairs of shoes and chatted amiably before moving on.
Still, Mr. Brink was expecting trouble. He said he believed that animal rights activists would soon come to try to hide in the sand to photograph the killing. He would have the police take them away, as he did last year, she said.
A man with a weathered face and an easy smile, Mr. Brink is always on the look out for a new way to market seal products. He is experimenting with producing quality oil for cosmetics, and he would like to see more seal leather goods made. The leather, he says, will not stiffen if it gets wet.
But he thinks those who pay high prices for seal penises are foolish, if welcome to make him rich. He tried it once himself. Having heard the custom was to soak the dried genitals in rice wine for several months and then drink it, he instead bought a case of whisky and tried to make the potion there.
"Fastest way to waste a case of good whisky," Mr. Brink allowed. "Didn't do anything but turn the stuff just awful."

These juvenile seals were slaughtered for their skins and the male genitals, which are dried and sold for use as aphrodisiacs in the Far East. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Survey Finds 6 Million, Fewer Than Thought, in Temporary Jobs

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Six million Americans hold jobs they do not consider permanent, far fewer than experts expected, the first Government survey of its kind has found. These workers are markedly youthful and slightly more likely than workers over all to be female and black.
 Only a third of these so-called contingent workers, a group that includes students, were satisfied with their situation, while the rest said they would prefer permanent jobs, according to the survey, released today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And relatively few had their own health insurance. 
 But while the study confirmed that such workers are much more common in the United States than in Europe and other industrial countries, specialists said the results tended to undermine a popular conception that the number of workers with indeterminate job futures was growing rampantly.
 Some estimates have placed the share of contingent workers, who are not necessarily part-time employees, as high as 35 percent instead of the 4.9 percent found by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Time magazine, for example, estimated in a prominent 1993 article entitled "The Temping of America" that contingent workers would make up half of the labor force by the year 2000.
 Speaking of the Labor Department survey, Mitchell S. Fromstein, chairman of Manpower Inc., the Milwaukee-based temporary-help company, said, "It sets to rest a lot of notions of a work force dominated by temporary and contingent workers." His company sent W-2 tax statements to 750,000 people last year. Mr. Fromstein said the Government figures, collected in February 1994 and analyzed over the last six months, closely matched those of his own company.
 But while others acknowledged the importance of the Federal effort to tally such workers, they insisted that even the broadest of the Federal survey's three definitions of contingent workers was too narrow and thus undercounted them.
 "Most labor market analysts will find these levels of contingent employment surprisingly low," said Eileen Appelbaum, associate research director of the Economic Policy Institute in Washington, a research group with a liberal orientation. She noted that the Government deemed workers contingent only if they expected their jobs to end within a year or, under the broadest definition, "some time in the future."
 The survey would have shown a considerably higher contingent work force had it included part-time workers who wanted full-time jobs, regardless of expectations about how long their employment might last, Ms. Appelbaum said. Still, she praised the Government's effort as "very important" and said she eagerly awaited a chance to examine the data in detail.
 Since this was the first survey of its kind, asking workers directly whether their jobs were intended for a limited period, it produced no information about trends. But Thomas Nardone, a supervisor of the project, said the bureau hoped to repeat the study at two-year intervals, a schedule similar to its survey on displaced workers -- those who have lost jobs -- that began in 1984.
 Underlying the debate over definitions is disagreement about the desirability of contingent employment. Audrey Freedman, a New York consultant and Manpower director who is credited with coining the phrase, stressed the role of such jobs in enhancing a worker's skills and giving businesses a flexibility that raises the nation's productivity.
 One happy contingent worker is Julie Leis, a 21-year-old Ohio University student, who is earning $11 an hour this summer working as a receptionist for Manpower itself in Washington.
 "I knew temporary jobs are the highest-paying jobs for a college student," said Ms. Leis, who previously worked at a travel agency, an insurance agency and a bank.
 Others, however, fret about possibly low wage levels, underemployment and a lack of health insurance and other benefits.
 Among the other findings, the report concluded that the educational attainment of adults in contingent jobs was quite similar to those with secure futures; about 29 percent of those in each group have college degrees. Somewhat fewer contingent workers, however, have high school diplomas.
 The proportion of contingent workers with health insurance from any source ranged from 57 to 65 percent, the study found. This was 17 to 25 points less than for secure workers, and the contingents were less likely to get their coverage from their employers.
 Over all, the ranks of contingent workers were estimated to range from 2.7 million to 6 million workers. The higher total would account for 4.9 percent of all those with jobs.
 The survey also concluded that 8.3 million workers were independent contractors, 2 million worked "on call," 1.2 million worked for temporary-help agencies and 652,000 worked for companies that provide services under contract at their customers' sites.
A person's employment could be both contingent and overlap into one of the alternate categories.
 The number working at temporary-help agencies was about one-half the total shown in the Labor Department's monthly report by business establishments. That suggested, Ms. Appelbaum said, that many temps lose track of whose employees they are.
