HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

HEALTH CARE
Who Can Heal New York?
Here's the question: Is there a place in the brave new world of managed health care for municipal hospitals like New York's? Can they possibly survive? The answer, from a mayoral advisory panel, was a resounding no. The panel, saying the hospitals delivered inefficient, low-quality care, called last week for abolition of the whole system. The obvious question, from a 43-year-old Bellevue patient with AIDS, was this: "Where will the poor people go for medical care?" The mayor's panel, though, insisted that the poor will get better care at revamped hospitals or at private medical centers.
 
LAWSUITS
Promises, Costly Promises
It happens all the time: some big company, on the prowl for bargain labor, closes one plant and opens another elsewhere. As long as it goes by the book and gives 60 days' notice, the company's nose is clean. Or so Maytag thought when, in 1991, it shut a vending-machine plant in West Virginia and opened one in South Carolina. Workers say Maytag assured them this would never happen, and the workers -- first one, then a class-action parade -- decided this was a legal promise and sued. And last week Maytag settled the case by agreeing to pay $16.5 million -- it was "risk avoidance," mind you; the company remained pure as a new-laundered sheet. Lawyers, bless their billable souls, will devour $5 million of that, but that still leaves a tidy sum for 800 workers.
 
ENTERTAINMENT
Rocking Hollywood's Boat
Think of Hollywood as a huge rowboat, managing a delicate balance even under its heavy load of ego and money -- mighty agents on one side, mighty studios on the other. Then, without warning, a giant among giants leaps from one side to the other, sending everyone else scampering for equilibrium. That's basically what happened last week when Michael Ovitz, agent to the gods and just about everyone else, decided that, well, working for a studio might not be that bad. MCA hadn't worked out, so the buzz (sorry, but Hollywoodspeak is de rigueur) was that nothing would shake him from Creative Artists. But then Disney came calling -- its new jewel, ABC, in hand -- and Mr. Ovitz couldn't resist, even though he'll play second fiddle to Michael Eisner, Disney's chairman. You can bet he'll be a loud second fiddle.
 
GUIDING NATURE
Writing E-Mail in the Sand
Beaches are big business -- people go to unholy lengths to sit on them and fry, and pay unholy prices for shelter and hot dogs nearby. But only God can make a beach -- well, God and the Army Corps of Engineers. The big difference: when engineers do it, it costs hundreds of millions of dollars. And when God then washes away man's sand, there's hell to pay -- and more sand to cart in. Take, say, New Jersey. Man built beaches recently at vast expense -- Federal money that miraculously flowed freely -- but (of all the nerve!) water barged in and took much of it away. And so the debate heats up, with some insisting that, yes, man can shape the earth, but other heretical souls (they probably don't even like running barefoot on the sand) talking about pouring tax dollars into the ocean.
 
REGULATION
A Tobacco-Country Judge
The battle is joined. The F.D.A. wants to regulate the sale and promotion of cigarettes -- because it wants fewer teen-agers to start smoking. The tobacco industry doesn't like that idea, possibly because if people don't get the habit young, they usually don't get it. So the industry sued, and by all signs got just the arbiter it would want last week -- a North Carolina judge who had ruled pro-tobacco in a suit involving the E.P.A. and had, as a lawyer, defended an R.J. Reynolds heir. Why North Carolina? It's "the only jurisdiction that makes any sense," Reynolds said. But the head of an anti-smoking group said, "Among Southern lawyers, it's called home cooking, helping out the friends and neighbors."
 
ROCKEFELLER CENTER
What Price Location Now?
What next? Just when you thought you'd figured out who owns Rockefeller Center -- no simple matter, in case you've missed it all; the overlapping trusts and groups and holding companies create a dazzling financial maze -- here come two more investors battling for a piece of it. First was Sam Zell of Chicago, who, like others drawn to the fabled towers, is all gaga about "location, location, location," a rule he learned "when my daddy put me on his knee." (Well, at least his daddy didn't say, "Plastics.") And the very next day this bankruptcy-smudged landmark got a rival offer, from Tishman Speyer Properties of New York. Don't even ask what the ownership chart might look like now; the family tree of British royalty is a sapling in comparison.
 
THE FED
A Rate Cut? Probably Not
Oh, yes -- interest rates. Is the Federal Reserve going to give borrowers another break, as it did a month or so ago, when it cut rates slightly after that endless string of increases? The Fed gathers on Tuesday, but people who think they know such things expect no more rate cuts just yet. True, official rates still hover farther than usual above inflation -- which the Fed is slapping itself gleefully on the back for taming. But Fed officials seem to think things are going just fine, with a sharp rise in housing starts last week just the latest bit of strength. Or perhaps it's just too hot for them to think about anything so strenuous as tinkering with those all-powerful rates. Maybe in September.
 
EQUALITY
Women of Value
Life is unfair: Any 12-year-old denied extra dessert or a new computer will tell you that. But for the world's women, life is truly unfair -- as a United Nations report out last week made vividly and statistically clear. Among the findings: 70 percent of the world's poor are women, and women hold just 14 percent of top managerial jobs. Not that women don't do their fair share of the world's work -- far from it. One of the study's more intriguing findings is the extreme economic undervaluation of women's work. They pull their weight; they just don't get paid for it.
 
WORK FORCE
Employees, by Another Name
No one wants employees anymore. Employees want pesky things like health benefits. (Health benefits?) They want companies to be loyal to them. (A quaint idea.) You have to pay payroll taxes so they can get stuff like Social Security. It's all such a nuisance! More and more, companies prefer "independent contractors" -- not too independent, mind you -- and the ranks of such semi-employees have soared with all the layoffs lately. But there are rules about who can be called a contractor -- rules, no doubt, often stretched to, and past, the limit -- and last week Texas A&M University admitted that it had illegally paid 400 farm workers as contractors, cheating the Government out of $86,000 in payroll taxes. The Republicans, meanwhile, have a solution: they're pushing a bill that would liberalize the use of contractors.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Knowing When to Say 'Sell'

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
THERE are theories galore about the best time to buy a stock -- when earnings are growing rapidly or the stock is trading below book value, even one that relates to which team wins the Super Bowl. And you can't pick up a personal-finance magazine these days without being bombarded with the 10 -- or 15, or 20 -- mutual funds that are absolutely, positively hot, right now!
But wait a second. When it comes to selling -- which goes hand in hand with buying -- there is almost total silence. For all sorts of reasons, investors don't like to think about selling, and many on Wall Street are more than happy to oblige by ignoring it, too. Often, the best the financial pundits have to offer is vague and contradictory conventional wisdom: Don't sell winning investments, but be sure to take profits. 
 Sometimes, though, you must sell -- for tuition, a house, a wedding, retirement. And this year's rip-snorting bull market has nearly everyone wondering if now is the time to cash in at least some investments, before it's too late.
All too often, though, the silence that surrounds selling makes the act haphazard at best. A stock drops, investors panic and sell when they should hold. Investors get attached to particular stocks -- or want to avoid capital-gains taxes -- and hold when they should sell.
But panic selling and blind devotion can be hazardous to net worth. Whether buying or selling, put emotion aside, get a plan and stick with it, the experts say. While there's no guarantee that you still won't make a mistake, your odds of getting out at the right time are a lot better.
Which is why plenty of astute professionals pay a great deal of attention to selling. Most pros try to follow general rules, and they tend to agree that if you wouldn't buy a stock at its current price, it's probably time to unload it. Some sell when a stock rises a certain percentage. Others pick a target value and sell when the stock nears that level.
Take Robert Sanborn, manager of the Oakmark Fund, among the top mutual funds recently. Mr. Sanborn sells a stock as soon as it hits 90 percent of the value he places on it, an estimate that he continually updates based on his appraisal of the company's underlying business.
Other successful investors, whatever their specific strategies, share a faith in rules that govern sell decisions.
"The sell discipline is probably more important than the buy discipline," agreed Paul Greenwood, a senior research analyst at the Frank Russell Company, the Tacoma, Wash., pension fund consultants who follow more than 1,700 portfolio managers. "If there's a common thread among the best managers, it's a strong sell discipline."
 
Panic Selling
 But such discipline is in short supply, and the psychological forces surrounding selling are strong. People are reluctant to engage in the kind of soul searching that goes on when buying, and it's not hard to see why. When people buy a stock or mutual fund, they are usually full of optimism -- about a company's prospects or a manager's stock-picking abilities.
When it comes time to sell, the opposite is true. "There's a whole attitude of defeat associated with selling," noted Eugene Lerner, a former finance professor who now runs Disciplined Investment Advisors, an Evanston, Ill., money management firm. "It's an act of rejection."
Because people tend to identify themselves so closely with their investments, they become unable to sell under any circumstance. "People use the market to validate their self-esteem," Mr. Geist explained. If a stock or mutual fund goes up, they're so busy patting themselves on the back for being smart that they miss signs of trouble. If the investment goes down, they don't want to admit to having made a mistake.
Many individual investors, and even some pros, sell only in a panic. They are whipsawed by the market, selling only when their stocks or funds are down. During last year's bond market debacle, bond fund investors rushed for the exits just as prices were touching bottom, according to a study by the David L. Babson Company, the Cambridge, Mass., investment management firm. By the time these investors thought it was safe to venture back, prices had already rebounded. "This was a classic mistake of buying high and selling low," noted H. Bradlee Perry, Babson's former chairman, who now serves as a consultant to the company.
The same was true during the long and gruesome bear stock market of 1973 and 1974, said Robert Bacarella, manager of the Monetta Fund. When he studied which money managers best survived that grizzly downturn, he discovered that those with strict selling rules avoided bailing out at the market's low.
Some people sell as soon as they are faced with a loss, even if their stock or fund would probably have recovered. "They're feeling terrible about themselves so they get out as soon as the stock drops," explained Richard Geist, a Waban, Mass., psychologist who studies the psychology of investing. Mr. Geist said one patient panicked whenever his stocks fell because those losses stirred up childhood feelings of deprivation. "He would just sell immediately and feel much better," Mr. Geist said.
Investors who sell because they are disappointed with short-term results are often acting impulsively. Ken Gregory, editor of the No-Load Fund Analyst newsletter in Orinda, Calif., said that can happen with decisions about fund investments. "Every manager has a bad year," he said. "If a fund manager has an off year, there's an assumption the manager has lost it."
For example, Mr. Gregory said, investors would have been mistaken if they had grown impatient with Michael Price's Mutual Beacon or Mutual Qualified funds after three dismal years. If they had sold during those years, when the stocks Mr. Price likes to buy were out of favor, they would have missed the fund's spectacular 20-percent-plus gains in 1992 and 1993.
 
Blind Devotion
 Other investors hold on even when there are good reasons to unload. People who inherit a stock or fund may find it difficult to sell because the investment represents a tie to a loved one.
Lewis Altfest, a financial planner in Manhattan, recalls a widow who came into his office three years after her husband died, refusing to sell any stocks he had chosen. Kathleen Delany, who lives in Rockford, Ill., has held onto the Ford stock her father, an investment banker, gave her for more than 40 years -- "out of respect for my father's expertise and honesty and basic economic philosophy," she said.
One solution, said Frederick Raffety, a financial planner at Robert Lawrenz Consulting Services in Rockford, may be to donate at least some of the investment to charity. "The concept that it's doing good and is something that the parent would approve makes it palatable," he said.
People also refuse to sell because they become too enamored of an investment. "I don't think there's anybody alive who hasn't been so in love with an individual stock who wasn't blind to terrible problems at the company," said Kenneth Jessen, an engineer in Loveland, Colo.
Richard Strong, who heads his own mutual fund company in Milwaukee, recalled hanging on to shares of Home Shopping Network, despite nagging doubts about the quality of the company's management. "I kept waiting for management to evolve," he said. When he finally did sell the stock, it was trading at roughly half its high.
Anytime you forget why you bought a stock, you're likely to regret it. Phillip Moery, an economics professor in Gainesville, Ga., learned that lesson after buying Checkers Drive-In Restaurants stock in early 1994 at around $12 after hearing a rumor that the company would be acquired. "The takeover didn't occur," he said. "I should have gotten out at that point, but I didn't." The stock fell to $2.25.
Greed will almost always get investors in trouble. "If the only reason not to sell is that the market is going to the moon, it may be time to rotate into other industries," Mr. Altfest said.
And then there are taxes -- which no investors like to pay. "One of the most common mistakes is to worry too much about the tax impact," Mr. Raffety said. "When faced with a large capital gain, they become paralyzed and hold onto it."
But by refusing to sell, they end up with a stock that is well past its prime. "We've had a lot of people delay, waiting" for capital-gains taxes to fall, said Joseph Toce Jr., a partner at Arthur Andersen in New York. "Instead, their capital gains went away."
 
Rules for Selling
 Knowing how easily emotions can lead to bad decisions, many managers, like Mr. Sanborn, construct rules about when to get out. These rules, which usually vary with a manager's investment style, focus on factors surrounding the price movement of a stock, its market value or company fundamentals. Monetta's Mr. Bacarella, for example, takes the gain if a stock moves up 30 percent, even when he thinks it will keep rising. He then waits a month to re-evaluate the stock.
"It's very healthy for the fund," he said, noting that he may buy a stock two or three times if it keeps going up. "You don't fall asleep here."
Mr. Bacarella employs the same strategy to limit his losses. Because stocks tend to move in groups, he will first compare a losing equity with other stocks in the industry. If they're all down, he doesn't sell. But if any stock drops 30 percent or more, he sells without question. "I always take the stance that I'm the last person to know" if there's something wrong, he said.
Eugene Lerner of Disciplined Investment Advisors focuses on company fundamentals because he believes the market isn't precise in determining a stock's value. Since he buys only stocks whose earnings are increasing, he sells whenever earnings have declined over the previous 12 months by 5 percent or more. He reasons that a company will do nearly anything to report earnings growth -- whether it's selling an asset or manipulating its accounting -- so falling profits are a sure sign that a company's in trouble.
By following these rules, managers are less likely to let greed or fear dictate their decisions. Mr. Sanborn says he has never regretted selling too soon. If a company announces it is going to be taken over, he doesn't wait around for a higher bid. He has seen too many takeovers fail at the last minute, leaving investors who wanted to eke out that last bit of profit with much less of a profit. Mr. Bacarella is using his 30 percent rule to sell some technology holdings, making his portfolio less vulnerable to a downturn there.
Although most managers use some variation of those rules, investors can employ a variety of selling techniques. Some determine a target price based on a stock's price-to-earnings multiple as compared with its earnings growth rate. Others sell when Wall Street lowers its estimates about how much the company will make in the coming year.
Investors can also sell based on an asset-allocation strategy. Portfolio managers, for example, will limit the percentage any one stock or industry group can constitute of their holdings. Because the market has had such a good run, investors may find that equity holdings are now too large a part of their portfolio.
What's also important to remember is that investors don't have to make all-or-nothing decisions. Mr. Strong manages to have his cake and sell it too by taking profits on only some of his shares in a particular stock and giving the rest a chance to keep rising.
As for a mutual fund, investors should track performance against other funds that buy similar stocks. "What investors don't sell or take a long time to sell are funds that are consistently below average by a little," said John Rekenthaler, editor of the Morningstar Investor newsletter, published by the Chicago mutual fund research firm. "There's no reason to settle for average if there are 7,000 funds." He also recommends that investors watch closely for any changes in a fund's investment style, portfolio manager and expenses.
What makes the sell decision so hard is the dearth of advice. Wall Street analysts resort to euphemisms like "hold" or "market performer" rather than just telling investors to sell a stock. Financial magazines and newspapers rarely publish articles on the topic.
The few sell strategies that are discussed are hardly proven successes, and managers don't rely on any one technique. "None of them individually seem to be valid enough to hang a hat on," said John Markese, president of the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago. But that doesn't mean investors shouldn't constantly reassess whether their investments are sound. "What I tell people simply is if you would not buy a stock today, it's a sell candidate," Mr. Markese said.
Having nearly any sell strategy in place can save investors lots of grief. "People assume once you buy a stock that you don't have to do anything more," Mr. Geist said. But that's one of the worst assumptions you can make.
Take the case of Anne Carey, who teaches political science at a college in Birmingham, Ala. "I don't do a lot of selling," she said. Without a firm idea of when to cash out of international bond funds she bought a few years ago, she was slow to act. By the time she got around to selling, all the funds had gone down significantly in value. "I think I wasn't watching them," she said. "I wasn't paying enough attention."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Art of the Sell: Three Strategies -- VALUE: Some investors try to uncover bargains in the market by comparing a stock's price to its underlying value. A natural strategy for these "value" investors is to cash out when a stock's price approaches its assessed worth. Robert Sanborn, above, manager of the Oakmark Fund, sells a stock as soon as it reaches 90 percent of its value, which he calculates by studying the underlying business. Other measures, such as a specific price-to-earnings multiple, can be used to decide if a stock is fully valued. PRICE: Some investors rely on the price movement of a stock to determine whether to sell. Robert Bacarella, right, the manager of the Monetta Fund, sells a stock after it rises 30 percent, and before he buys the same stock again, he waits at least 30 days. Mr. Bacarella uses the same strategy to limit his losses. If a stock drops 30 percent, he automatically unloads it. FUNDAMENTALS: Some investors study company fundamentals, like profitability, and for them a suitable sell strategy is to monitor those fundamentals for signs of trouble. Eugene Lerner, president of Disciplined Investment Advisors, sells whenever a company reports that its earnings have decreased by 5 percent or more over the last 12 months. Other investors who focus on fundamentals will sell if a company's sales growth is slowing. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)(pg. 4)

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Will Japan's Surplus Disappear?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Japanese trade surplus has been one of the wonders of the modern world. Now it may be coming to an end.
The persistent surplus has been supported by two pillars, both now crumbling. On the export side, there was the determination of Japanese manufacturers to keep production in the home country. If it was moved, what would be done with all those workers who were supposed to get lifetime employment? And on the import side, there were all those informal barriers that American companies like to complain about. 
 Last week brought the news that Japan's imports are still soaring. Through July, expressed in dollar terms, they are up more than 25 percent. And this is happening when the Japanese economy is stumbling along, a period when one might expect import demand to stagnate.
What's going on? Import barriers are starting to fall, and more and more foreign goods are getting into the country, and finding eager buyers. The leading beneficiaries of this are other Asian countries, who are busy selling consumer goods to Japan. Those Asian countries are, in turn, importing capital equipment from Japan, a trend that is -- temporarily -- holding up Japanese export figures. Ed Guay, Cigna's chief economist, tells of seeing a Japanese consumer electronics plant taken apart, with each piece labeled so that it could be sent overseas and reassembled.
The overvalued yen, which is finally in retreat, is behind much of this. And the decisions by manufacturers are not going to be reversed, even if the dollar keeps rising. Bob Barbera, the chief economist at Capital Investments International, hauls out "hysteresis," a word from physics, to explain what is likely to happen. That word refers to the perseverance of an effect even after its cause is removed. The high yen has sufficiently scared Japan Inc., he says, forecasting that with all the changes, Japan's trade surplus will be gone by late next year.
That is, it should be noted, not the conventional wisdom, which holds that Japan will run trade surpluses forever. For the surpluses to end, it will be necessary for import barriers to continue to erode, something that is far from certain.
The experience of Japan -- in the wake of allowing the yen to soar so far -- may be reminiscent of what happened here a decade ago. Then, a ridiculously overvalued buck drove out of business -- or out of the country -- some companies that might have held on otherwise.
After the Japanese surpluses vanish, Japan will be revealed as another high-cost area, able to compete with brains and innovation, not the brawn of hourly labor that can be hired more cheaply somewhere else.
Unfortunately, Japan's decline as an export machine will not solve this country's problems. The American trade deficit is growing with the Mexicos and Chinas of the world. Some of that can be traced to Mexico's current economic woes, but a lot of it reflects the fact that it is impossible for a high-wage economy to compete with a low-wage one in a product that both can make with similar quality. It is that reality that has put a damper on wages in recent years, and that trend is likely to endure.
Don't be surprised if the next round of world trade talks has Japan, Europe and the United States as allies on most issues, opposing the developing countries, most of which will be pursuing export-oriented strategies. If so, this year's car wars with Japan will seem like a quaint memory.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:

Meatloaf and the 50's Style In New Village Eating Place
E. J.'s Luncheonettes have proved to be popular gathering spots for young singles on the Upper East Side and Upper West Side. Now, the owners hope that a new outlet in the West Village, at 432 Avenue of the Americas, between Ninth and 10th Streets, will become a mecca for neighborhood residents. 
 "We found another strong residential community to open our neighborhood restaurant," said Howard Eisenberg, one of five partners who own the 50's-style diners, and the manager of the newest one, which opened on July 27.
E. J.'s serves large portions of diner food (an array of breakfast items as well as home-style meatloaf, skinless fried chicken, roast turkey platters, grilled fresh fish and salads) at prices ranging from $3 for two eggs, toast and home fries to $14 for New York strip steak.
 
Low-Interest Loans for Owners Of Historic Homes in Queens
The New York Landmarks Conservancy has $1.5 million in low-interest loans available for owners of historic residences in Queens.
"It's a five-borough program that has been going on for at least six years," said Joshua Schaff, a conservancy spokesman, "but residents in Queens have not been taking advantage."
The borough's historic districts are Ridgewood, Hunters Point, Jackson Heights, Richmond Hill, Steinway, Old Astoria and Kew Gardens. The loans, which carry interest rates that start at 3 percent, can be used for exterior restoration and repairs.
There are no income limits for applicants, Mr. Schaff said, although it is hoped that the bulk of the money will be lent to low-income and middle-income residents of the historic districts.
 
Cluster of Italian Restaurants Growing on West 44th Street
An Italian restaurant, L'Allegria, opened recently on the northwest corner of 44th Street and Ninth Avenue, in what is becoming a small outpost of Italian cuisine.
L'Allegria, in 2,500 square feet of space, serves fare like a salad of arugula, radicchio and endive ($4) and lombata di vitello alla griglia (grilled veal chop, $14.50). The pastas (all $7.50) range from fettuccine with sausage, artichokes and tomatoes to linguini alla vongole (with tiny clams).
Nicola Coladonato, the owner and chef, sold his other restaurant, Mangia e Bevi, at 53d Street and Ninth Avenue, three months ago.
Opposite L'Allegria on West 44th Street, 44 Southwest also serves moderately priced Italian cuisine. This establishment has been on the southwest corner of 44th and Ninth for four years; five weeks ago, it put up a large maroon awning that says, "44 Southwest Italian Continental."
Just a few yards east across Ninth Avenue, a brick-oven pizzeria, Don Giovanni, is scheduled to open in about three weeks, at 358 West 44th Street.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
The Pathmark Wars, Part Three

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM 

 BODY:
Starting last year, the battleground was 125th Street: local retailers fought tooth and nail -- without success -- to stop Pathmark from building a superstore. Then the scene shifted to Springfield Gardens, Queens: last week the City Council approved a plan for a Pathmark store, but angry local store owners have not given up their fight.
Now Pathmark has returned to Harlem with a proposal to build a store on 145th Street between Bradhurst and Eighth Avenues -- and local supermarket owners are up in arms. They have hired the same consultant who led the struggle against the 125th Street market, and they are trying to persuade city officials that one of their number should be allowed to put up a market on the site, not Pathmark. 
 A Pathmark spokesman, Stan Sorkin, said the company is "in the initial stages of trying to get the site approved." Most of the land, a rubbly lot with four long-condemned brick buildings in one corner, is owned by the city. Asked why his company wants a second store in Harlem, Mr. Sorkin said: "We are interested in sites in New York City that meet the criteria of population, disposable income and size of property."
A spokeswoman for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development said that Pathmark officials had met with the agency. And members of Community Board 10 said they will debate Pathmark's request for a zoning change next month. The board has questioned Pathmark on such topics as traffic and parking. "Because of what happened with 125th Street, it's going to draw a lot of attention," said Barbara Askins, chairwoman of the board.
Richard Lipsky, the consultant who organized supermarket owners against the East Harlem Pathmark proposal, said: "Now that we have been told in no uncertain terms that Pathmark is going into 125th Street, we think it would be fair for one of the independent stores to go in there, like a C-town or a Bravo."
Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields, who represents north Harlem and has met with Mr. Lipsky, said she hoped to avoid another long battle over a Pathmark by including the business community and local developers in the early planning stages. "We are going to work this one out," Ms. Fields said. (For a roll call of the City Council's Pathmark vote in Queens, see page 7.)
One of the attractions of the 145th Street site for a supermarket developer is the Bradhurst project, under which the city is renovating 2,200 abandoned apartments in the neighborhood for low- and moderate-income residents. The 145th site itself is among the locations scheduled to be redeveloped under another urban renewal plan.
On 145th Street, some residents were enthusiastic about the idea of a new Pathmark. "That's good for the neighborhood," said Sallh Mohammed, who owns a small convenience store across the street from the proposed site. An assistant, Raul Mojica, agreed. "We don't need another C-town," he said. JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Reading the Hidden City

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
TO Hope Cooke, New York is a palimpsest. The word, from the Greek, describes a parchment that has been inscribed and erased several times, still bearing hints of old, faded messages. As the city builds and rebuilds itself, barely legible remnants of its past are left behind. Those remnants -- the faded signs, anomalous buildings and crooked streets -- are the clues that Ms. Cooke, a self-described urban historian, tries to decipher.
Ms. Cooke herself is something of a palimpsest. In her 55 years she has been a debutante, a princess, a queen, a mother, a walking tour guide, a teacher and an author. 
 "I've learned that it's really important to be terribly attentive to where I am, wherever it is, because if you get numb to space, numb to habitat, you don't live wisely or well" said Ms. Cooke, whose discoveries of New York's spaces was published this spring in her "Seeing New York: History Walks for Armchair and Footloose Travelers" (Temple University Press).
Raised by wealthy relatives on the Upper East Side, she graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1963 and instantly became the heroine of a national fairy tale when she married the Crown Prince of the tiny Himalayan kingdom of Sikkim. Eventually, she became Sikkim's Queen. But the characters in this fairy tale did not live happily ever after. After 10 years, Ms. Cooke's marriage shattered. Then came uprisings, with thousands of Sikkimese protesting the monarchy and besieging the palace. After the tumult, Sikkim was annexed by India.
Ms. Cooke returned to New York, a city that because of her privileged but highly circumscribed childhood, she hardly knew. "When I was little, I thought the Grand Central building at the end of Park Avenue was the end of the earth," she recalls. "The place where ships fell off."
Back from Sikkim -- a single mother with two children to raise -- she found herself fighting a powerful sense of dislocation. "I needed grounding for my feet," she recalled over lunch in the backyard of her Brooklyn brownstone. "I needed roots, I needed to learn about my surroundings."
So she began exploring the city, walking widely and reading broadly. She studied the waves of immigration that shaped the Lower East Side: from the Canarsie Indians to the Irish, to the Jews of Eastern Europe, to the Chinese. "Going around the Lower East Side," she said, "you often get some old union organizer who can tell you about pre-reform labor, reform and the rollbacks of reform. In Chatham Square you can see steam coming out of every vent," a sure marker of illegal sweatshops.
One neighborhood she finds especially fascinating is downtown Flushing, which she thinks of as a miniature pan-Asia. Chinese and Korean merchants sell red-bean popsicles and ginseng root on Main Street, just steps from Taiwanese banks. On Union Street, intricate Japanese kimonos are offered, while just east on Bowne Street, Hindus worship at the Gujarati Temple only yards from the Sikh Gurdwara, another place of worship.
In "Seeing New York," she maps 14 walking tours ranging over Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens -- from Victorian Brooklyn Heights to Dominican Washington Heights.
"In lower Manhattan, to recreate the early colonial era when you're face to face with banks, you have to become quite a good story teller," she said. "It's more like radio than television." It is easier when the subject is Brownstone Brooklyn, with block after block of intact Civil War-era houses.
One of her favorite neighborhoods is Brooklyn Heights, not far from the home she shares with her husband, Michael Wallace, a history professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. She revels in the Heights' "seeming fixity, the lush environs of longer durations and reposeful streets."
One that has her worried is Ladies Mile, the stretch of Avenue of the Americas from 14th to 23d Streets. At the turn of the century it was city's premiere shopping area for elegant women, with famous emporiums like B. Altman and Siegel-Cooper. But most closed or moved uptown, and the neighborhood declined. Recently, the old buildings have been renovated to house new stores, many of them giants like Bed, Bath and Beyond and Today's Man. Ms. Cooke worries, though, that few of these have their roots in the city. Most are indistinguishable from their suburban mall branches, a fact she finds especially distressing, and the bulk of their profits go elsewhere. "We've written off the notion of New York as a production town," she said, adding that the city has also lost more than 100,000 retailing jobs since 1965. "It's a little scary if you write off consumption as well."
Since returning from Sikkim two decades ago, she has never tired of scouring the city. "I began to see the connections between things," she said. "If you learn about the struggle over Tompkins Square, from the 1830's on, the present struggle over Tompkins Square makes more sense."
A flashpoint of that struggle -- among squatters, the poor, young professionals, the police and anarchists -- was the 1988 clash over a curfew for Tompkins Square Park. Ms. Cooke said worse riots erupted in 1874, when 10,000 unemployed workers battled mounted police officers.
Even before that, she notes, the neighborhood was divided between the rich who lived in town houses on the park's north side and who scorned tenement dwellers to the south, calling their homes "rag pickers' row."
Ms. Cooke enjoys the nitty-gritty of neighborhood disputes that have shaped the city: for example, how the battle between the Pierponts and the Hickses over how to develop Brooklyn in the 19th century helped define the borough's present downtown.
"That is always the illumination: to find the context," she said in her slightly whispery voice, which still retains a light Scottish accent she inherited from a nanny. "Once you bring past to present, that turns into an epiphany."
 
CITYSCAPE
Cooke's Tour
 
In 22 years of walking the city's streets and researching their history, Hope Cooke has found some favorite nooks and crannies:
 
Minetta Brook An underground stream that runs beneath Greenwich Village and that can be seen in a glass tube in the lobby of 2 Fifth Avenue.
 
Stuyvesant Street Cutting diagonally from Ninth to 10th Streets in the East Village, it is the city's only street on a true east-west axis. It was mapped to the compass points by Peter Stuyvesant's great-grandson, Petrus, before the city laid its own grid to conform to the shape of Manhattan Island.
 
Secret Tunnel This once connected the old Police Headquarters, at 240 Centre Street, to a walnut-paneled tavern on Grand Street in Little Italy.

HEADLINE: Debt Trap

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The example of Providian Bancorp makes a most effective case for reimposition of usury restrictions in the credit card market ("Merchants of Debt," Spending It, July 2). 
 Providian and other credit card issuers understand that American society is so overwhelmed by consumerism that the average family is desperate for any additional source of credit. Many of Providian's customers will be paying off their loans at interest rates close to 20 percent for the rest of their lives.
Why should credit card issuers face usury restrictions when people freely choose to enter in debt?
First, the realities of modern life place pressures on the American family that our grandparents never would have dreamed of. We are marketed to incessantly, and our list of needs grows faster than our paychecks.
Furthermore, our bonds of community and family have been stretched so thin that when illness, job loss or divorce occur, many people can only turn to their credit cards. Easy credit at high rates of interest is the American version of a social welfare safety net.
Second, though our cultural traditions have long taught us that the practice of lending money at astronomical rates is abhorrent, usury has become acceptable as good business. Does an activity deserve sanction simply because it generates a big profit? We have become so beholden to the language of "choice" and the concept of free markets that we are increasingly unable as a society to set limits on behavior.
Controls on interest rates would mean that many people would not get credit or would have substantially less, but most consumers would be better off in the long run if they learned to live within their means. The issue that we all seem to be avoiding is that there are many middle-class Americans who cannot survive on what they earn, no matter how hard they work.
 
VINCENT D. ROUGEAU
Chicago, July 11
 
The writer is an assistant law professor at Loyola University-Chicago.

HEADLINE: How an Economic Miracle Can Ruin New Jersey

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 23 article ("The Day the Jobs Got Up and Moved Away") discusses the loss of employment in Mercer County and elsewhere in the state. But in fact a kind of economic miracle is happening in New Jersey.
According to a recent Rutgers University study, the state will recover all the jobs it has lost in the 1990 recession within two years. What makes this more remarkable is that it happens as the state throws off the yoke of manufacturing, mining and construction. Service-sector jobs have climbed 17 percent in the first five months of this year alone. 
 Our annual merchandise trade deficit is $150 billion. It will inexorably rise as we amplify the industries and technology of Japan and the Pacific rim. Of course, that will go on only as long as our country can continue to borrow money, sliding into greater and greater debt. The "good news" about our state's economy is actually bad news for our future.
THEODORE METAXAS
Toms River

LENGTH: 3341 words

HEADLINE: The Comfort Zones Of the Young, Black Professional

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
A STEPHANIE MILLS song washes over the room's exposed brick walls as clusters of denim-clad people strain to be heard over the din. Every bar stool is occupied, every corner clogged, forcing people headed upstairs to the dining room to navigate the crush.
The Shark Bar on a typical Friday night. 
 Standing at the far end of the softly lit bar is Michael Shanks, 34, a municipal bond accountant. "I haven't missed a Friday night in four months," Mr. Shanks said of the Upper West Side restaurant, a mecca for young black professionals. "I feel a sense of warmth here. I feel at home around my people." He paused, grasping for the right words. "I feel fulfilled."
For many middle-class blacks, the bars, restaurants and cafes that cater to them are more than places to meet friends before catching the latest release at the multiplex, more than spots to find next weekend's date or a future spouse. Jazz spots, salons and the dozens of black reading groups that are popping up throughout the city are more than social venues.
They are havens from the mainstream world that many young African-Americans and their parents fought so hard to enter. For some successful blacks, seeing people like themselves, walking examples of civil rights progress, helps to sustain them in an outside world from which they often feel alienated.
Such settings represent "a retreat to a comfortable and nurturing place," said Ellis Cose, author of "The Rage of a Privileged Class" (HarperCollins, 1994), which argues that although the ranks of the black middle class have grown rapidly in the past two decades, its members are frustrated by glass ceilings in corporations, racial slights from strangers and discrimination in housing and other walks of life.
The city's rising black middle class is substantial, even if its presence is often obscured by the focus on underclass poverty and crime. In 1990, 18 percent of working, non-Hispanic blacks in the city between the ages of 25 and 65 held managerial or professional jobs, according to Andrew A. Beveridge, a Queens College sociologist who conducted an analysis of the 1990 census for The New York Times. Another 28.7 percent held technical, sales and administrative support positions. And 30 percent were living in households with incomes of $50,000 or more, many of them in Queens, where the median household income of blacks exceeds that of whites.
Despite such inroads, for many blacks, the workplace is a source of racial unease. "One of the things that struck me as I was researching 'Rage' was that blacks kept saying how hard they had to work to make white people comfortable around them at work," Mr. Cose said. "They had to present a face that was not their natural face. A lot of black men, for instance, told me they had to be more meek than normal. If they were assertive or loud at all, people would perceive them as somehow stereotypical or perhaps even violent."
It should surprise no one, then, that many young upwardly mobile blacks -- sometimes called buppies (a label rejected by some because it connotes intraracial stratification) -- choose to spend happy hour with other blacks. And it's not just happy hour. There are black ski and scuba-diving groups and black bulletin boards on the Internet and mega-parties like the "Summer Sizzler at the Roxy," a July bash that drew more than 3,500 men and women from 10 black professional groups.
Of course, affluent blacks and whites do not lead completely bifurcated post-work lives. "It's not as segregated as you might think," said Nelson George, the cultural critic, adding that at most predominately black establishments, there will be at least a smattering of whites. "These are people who hang out with black friends at these places or are just down with blacks."
Still, says Lawrence Otis Graham, a black, Harvard-educated lawyer and a frequent commentator on race relations, when black professionals get together, they often choose to do so in "places that are accustomed to serving a large black clientele."
Why is that? Mr. Graham, the author of "Member of the Club: Reflections on Life in a Racially Polarized World" (HarperCollins, 1995), asserts that based on his experience, blacks not in the company of whites run the risk of being ignored or treated rudely or seated next to the bathroom or kitchen in many of the city's top restaurants.
But Earl Caldwell, the former Daily News columnist, has another explanation for the popularity of places like B. Smith's and the Shark Bar. They represent something "exotic" to younger blacks raised in the era of integration, he said. "The music is different, the language is different," he said. "Isn't it just more exciting?"
For Alison N. King, 34, a television producer and consultant, being a member of a black salon offers a gratifying sense of community as well as a venue for intellectual discourse. "It's good to know that there are others like yourself out there," said Ms. King, a member of the Brooklyn Black Belt Salon Brunch, which brings together Fort Greene and Clinton Hill artists and professionals to schmooze and discuss everything from fashion and literature to affirmative action. "Often, you think you're the only one out there with certain thoughts and experiences."
Not that successful blacks are a homogenous lot. There exists, says Mr. George, "an internal gamesmanship" based on educational and social pedigree. Second- and third-generation members of the black middle class -- those who vacationed on Martha's Vineyard as children, attended debutante balls as teen-agers and, later, graduated from exclusive colleges and universities -- may not fully welcome the newly arrived.
"You get a certain vibe from some of the Harvard and Yale blacks," said Mr. George, author of "Buppies, B-Boys, Baps and Bohos: Notes on a Post-Soul Black Culture" (HarperCollins, 1993). "But then there is also a cockiness among the up-by-the-bootstraps buppies. Those who came up from the streets will pull rank on the people who have the pedigree. They won't claim to be more authentically black, but they'll say I had to go through so much more than you, so therefore I am stronger."
For many decades, Manhattan has been the primary after-hours playground for black professionals. In the 60's, lawyers, doctors and politicians sipped cocktails at Frank's Restaurant, the Flash Inn, Jock's Place and the Red Rooster, Harlem restaurants and bars that closed as accommodations opened up to blacks downtown. In the 70's and 80's, the Cellar and Mikel's, now defunct rhythm and blues and jazz clubs on the Upper West Side, were the haunts.
Manhattan remains the social nexus for black professionals, although Fort Greene, often called the home of the new black renaissance, continues to grow in popularity and is now drawing black revelers from beyond Brooklyn's borders.
From a salon to soul food restaurants, herewith a look at a few of the places the city's black professionals find one another and themselves.
 
SALONS, POETRY READINGS,
BOOK DISCUSSION GROUPS
 The topic was media coverage of African-Americans. There were three featured panelists, but Ann Tripp, the 98.7 KISS-FM radio reporter, owned the floor at this Sunday afternoon assembly of the Brooklyn Black Belt Salon Brunch. "Why is it that every time there is a story about affirmative action in the news, blacks are called upon to defend it?" she asked. "Why don't they find white women, Asians, Latinos to defend it? They've benefited from it!"
A 30ish woman offered an "Amen." Someone else encouraged Ms. Tripp to "Tell it!" And so she continued. She noted in stories about Adarand Constructors v. Pena, the recent Supreme Court decision that imposed strict constitutional limits on affirmative action, she saw only blacks interviewed on the news. "The name was Pena, folks. He was not a black man."
Ms. Tripp also fumed about what she called excessive media coverage of black male celebrities accused of crimes, from Mike Tyson to Michael Jackson, and now O. J. Simpson.
"If you black women would turn off the O. J. trial," she said, "you could put CNBC out of business. I don't know why you're watching it. O. J. would rather die than date you."
Over lobsters, crab cakes and salads at the Chesapeake Oyster Grill in Fort Greene, the largely female crowd, ranging in age from post-grad to sub-50, blasted the news media for bias. In the past, entertainment and literature as well as art, politics and community affairs have been discussed.
The salon was born five years ago after three record publicists shared a cab from Manhattan to Fort Greene only to discover that they lived within blocks of one another.
"We realized that we lived so close together, but we had never been to one another's house," said Jacqueline Rhinehart, 37, national director of publicity for Arista Records. "We wondered, 'Well, who else lives in the hood?' "
The initial gathering was small. But eight people soon mushroomed into 60, and the salon moved from informal potlucks in individual homes to large brunches in local black-owned restaurants. Now 1,000 names appear on the salon's mailing list.
Entertainment is included in the $10 fee. (A poet and comedian appeared at the Oyster Grill.) The brunches draw an average of 100 people. But salon organizers say they do not make a profit.
"This gives us an opportunity to learn more about each other, share viewpoints and make new friends," said Gwendolyn Quinn, 34, a salon organizer. "If you know and respect your neighbors, I think it makes for a much healthier environment, socially and economically."
Though African-American salons are rare, black reading groups have been growing rapidly, according to the owners of several black bookstores.
With 85 members, the Literary Society may be the largest black reading group in the city. Founded by Lana Turner, a Harlem real estate broker, in 1982, this group of lawyers, educators, social workers and doctors meet monthly. They assemble in one another's homes and, so, feel blessed that only 20 to 25 people show up at most meetings. The group is not looking for new recruits. "When you have 25 clear-thinking, articulate people at a meeting and everyone wants to talk, it gets difficult," Ms. Turner said.
Women outnumber men, 7 to 1. Why this is is subject to debate. But Ms. Turner said, laughing, "The three or four who show up do carry the banner for their gender."
At a recent meeting of the Brooklyn-based Awareness Book Club, David Lamb, a 29-year-old Park Slope resident, found himself doing just that -- carrying the banner for black men.
Bell Hooks's book "Ain't I a Woman?" (South End Press, 1981) was on the agenda. There was consensus on some points, among them that white feminists tend to romanticize black women's "strength" and that black women are often asked to choose between black nationalism and feminism.
But Mr. Lamb, a lawyer who recently self-published a novel ("Do Platanos Go With Collard Greens?") took issue with the author's contention that slavery, while wretched for both sexes, was worse for women because not only did they endure savage beatings, but they were sometimes sexually exploited by slave owners and overseers.
"I think it's dangerous to get into who suffered more," Mr. Lamb said. "Black men were sexually exploited too. They were used to breed. They were bucks." Sometimes, he said, "They were forced to have sex with their own mothers and sisters." A momentary hush blanketed the room.
Seven months ago, when a friend told Mr. Lamb about the reading group, he jumped at the chance to become a member. "I'm the only black male attorney at my law firm," he said. "And that's a lonely position to be in. At the book club, there's camaraderie with other blacks. It's a way of renewing your spirit."
There's no shortage of spirit at the Brooklyn Moon Cafe in Fort Greene. Bohemians -- and buppies with "boho" souls -- clog the small, seven-month-old coffee house on Friday nights, when the main course is open-mike poetry.
Those not early enough to get a bistro table sit side by side in folding chairs. A few pile onto slightly frayed Victorian sofas. But many are left standing, not a few outside peering over the baseball caps, dreadlocks and braids of those who beat them in.
David Larrick Smith, 24, owner of an in-line skating school, is a regular.
"People up there are expressing the frustrations of the race," he said, nodding to the front of the room where twentysomething poets and would-be bards recited original verse about love, racism, revolution, O. J. and black women's thighs. "You hear other people express how you feel, and you want to scream, 'I can relate!' There's a healing process that takes place."
Recently, Brad Walrond, 24, a director of a youth program, recited a poem that captures the essence of the place: "People of Color Affirming Each Other."
It is so beautiful to see people of color affirming each other
I'm not waiting for ivory-tainted fame to come a'knocking at my door
I feel famous now cause I can hear the glorious sound of ebony talking back to me, saying, 'Go on baby, Go on.'
The raucous, patented laughter and spirited applause
Jovial injunction and adulation that resound in a mighty chorus
of a circle that cannot be broken . . .
"There's a need to be nurtured by your own," Mr. Walrond later said. Booing is verboten at Brooklyn Moon.
 
MUSIC, CLUBS
AND RESTAURANTS
 Dance clubs may be on the wane. But sometimes the dancing happens anyway.
Tuesday is funk night at Cafe Wha?. The dimly lit cellar in the West Village that draws predominantly white crowds most evenings attracts black professionals in their 20's and 30's who come to lose themselves in the retro-funk of the Slam Clinic, which plays old favorites by groups like the Ohio Players, Parliament-Funkadelic, and Earth Wind & Fire. Clubgoers are transported to a 70's basement house party, a place, in the words of the emcee, William Stephenson, "where your Afro shriveled all up" from dance-induced perspiration.
There is no dance floor, so clubgoers make do, moving with abandon in the narrow aisles, forcing waitresses to snake between shimmying hips, bobbing heads and flailing arms (the latter almost touch the wires that traverse the low ceilings). Surprisingly, management encourages the dancing.
"The more they dance, the more they drink," Mr. Stephenson explained. "It's that simple."
There is no dancing on Sunday at Chaz & Wilson, a cavernous Upper West Side supper club, when the R & B band, Ron Grant & Friends, shares the stage with budding performers during open mike night. Located on the northwest corner of 79th and Amsterdam, the usually predominantly white restaurant becomes a de facto Ebony Fashion Fair. Beautiful women with aerobicized bodies sport elegant silk pants suits, gold lame halters and dresses that are either very long or very, very short.
"I date black women exclusively," said a 33-year-old engineer, who insisted on anonymity. "Why would I go to a white club?" The celebrities are another draw. Salt, of Salt-N-Pepa fame, and Kevin Willis, of the Miami Heat, were recently spotted. Knicks players are said to be regulars.
There are a growing number of restaurants that draw largely black crowds, most of them owned, or co-owned, by blacks. Places like Kwanzaa, Pepper's and Mekka have opened in the last few years but B. Smith's and the Shark Bar have continued to attract legions of black professionals from across the city and neighboring suburbs for nine and four years respectively.
Sam Allen, 34, a real estate broker, is a Shark Bar partisan. "The crowd is professional, but they're down to earth, not snobbish and pretentious like the crowd at B. Smith's," he said.
Herbert Moreira-Brown, 40, a public school teacher, explained his enduring affection for B. Smith's. "We treat one another as individuals," he said, looking at the throng of people, overwhelming black and male and handsomely suited, at the bar. "I don't feel like I have to prove myself here the way I do when I walk into a white restaurant. Here, I'm not a black man, I'm a man."
 
 
 
Cyber-Hangouts With a Distinctly Urban Feel
 Sign on to New York Online, the nation's largest black-owned computer bulletin board system, and arguably its hippest, and suddenly a transit token materializes on the screen, followed by a digitized jazz trumpet riff. It doesn't take a techie to realize this is a cyberspace community with a decidedly urban flavor.
The subway is a metaphor for New York Online, a service focusing on the arts, created as a bridge between people of different cultures and races, the same way the subway connects people in the city's diverse precincts "who might not otherwise meet," explained Omar Wasow, 24. Mr. Wasow, with fellow Stanford grad, Peta Hoyes, 25, founded the company in a Fort Greene brownstone a year and a half ago.
But it is also a way for tristate black professionals to connect through black-themed chat rooms, to discuss, say, the recent Whitney Museum exhibit on African-American men or reactions to the movie "Panther" or black conservatives. Forty percent of New York Online's 1,100 users are black, 50 percent female, and most between the ages of 18 and 35.
There are at least 100 black-owned or black-oriented bulletin board systems on the Internet, according to Essence magazine, which, along with Shade, Vibe, Paper and Out, are published on New York Online.
John Knight Smith, 28, talks politics with other African-Americans and keeps abreast of upcoming black social and professional events using New York Online's black chat rooms, Society and Black Talk, as well as America Online's Ebony Room.
Users sometimes get together off-line, said Mr. Smith, a Park Slope marketing coordinator and married father of three, who recently attended an "Ebony Room" party aboard the Mystique yacht as it cruised around Manhattan.
"Sometimes people meet just to satisfy a sense of curiosity," Mr. Smith said. "There's also a lot of networking at these events. People bring their portfolios and hand out product and service information. There's a lot of talent out there."
Meeting off-line has advantages, Mr. Smith added. Online services like America Online, which reach a mass audience, leave users vulnerable to race-baiting from outsiders.
"Sometimes people with a screen name like 'hateblacks' will come into the Ebony Room just to be disruptive," Mr. Smith said. "Others will come in and say, 'I don't understand why you need this room.' Anybody with a computer has access."

HEADLINE: No Cheap Shots at Mexico, Please

BYLINE: By George W. Bush; George W. Bush is Governor of Texas.

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
Remember who your friends are. Always good advice in life. And now, words to keep in mind as the rhetoric of the 1996 election begins. Mexico currently wears the bright red bulls-eye in the ongoing political crossfire.
 The issues of the 1996 campaign will be emotional. There should be lively debate and discussion. But discussion about immigration and Mexico can turn ugly and destructive very quickly, severely damaging a positive and beneficial relationship. So when it comes to the debates over trade, immigration and other border concerns, the candidates must not try to build themselves up by tearing our friends down. 
 I have a unique interest in the subject of United States-Mexico relations. My state shares a 1,248-mile border with Mexico. The cultural, historical and economic ties between Texas and Mexico run deep. Texas is a richer place because of this relationship.
 Thanks in great part to the North American Free Trade Agreement, more than $20 billion worth of goods enter Mexico through Texas. The Texas economy directly benefits from Mexican trade. Trade means jobs. Trade means wealth to our state.
 But Texas is not the only beneficiary of the economic benefits of the trade agreement. Other governors know the growing importance of trade between their states and Mexico. Across our country, Mexico is proving to be a strong economic friend.
 Our economic bond with Mexico carries with it some very positive long-term results. An isolated United States will not be able to compete successfully in a world economy where Europe and Asia are united into common-market partnerships. The trade agreement wisely affords our country the opportunity to join forces with Canada and our neighbors to the south -- first Mexico, then Chile, then other emerging capitalist countries in Latin America. Within a united alliance, America will be economically stronger. We must not allow isolationist rhetoric or bad trade policy to alienate our trading partners.
 Not only will free trade help us, it provides a much-needed boost for Mexico. As capitalism takes hold in that country, wages will begin to climb. As wages begin to climb, Mexico will strengthen its middle class. Then, and only then, will the problem of illegal immigration subside. Most people who cross the border are hoping to make a living and provide for their families. The more economic opportunity and growth inside of Mexico, the less of an incentive to enter our country illegally.
 The United States has immigration laws in place. I strongly support them. Every nation has a right and responsibility to secure its borders. The Government simply must do a better job of enforcing ours. All of my fellow border governors have called for more equipment and more personnel.
 We must expand projects such as Operation Hold the Line, a highly successful program in El Paso, Tex. Under this innovative operation, Border Patrol officers regularly patrol known crossing points so that illegal immigrants are deterred or apprehended before they disappear into our communities. Even though it has been successful, it has not been carried out at other high-traffic corridors along the border.
 Despite the problems faced by the United States and Mexico, solutions will be forged in the fire of friendship and respect, not in the heated sparks of emotionally charged words.
 Our trade policy, coupled with the way we treat our neighbors, must be viewed as an integral component of the immigration debate. Growing economies and an expanding middle class in Mexico create a more attractive market for American products and services. They also make for more manageable southern borders.
 The United States and Mexico are linked through history and geography. The free trade agreement has linked us through economics, job creation and competition. If problems arise, they are best solved through friendship, not angry rhetoric. Friends help each other and bring out the best in one another. Friends can solve problems together. Indeed, the United States and Mexico remain friends. Now, more than ever, it is truly time for the candidates to remember who our friends are.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Conversations / Robert B. Reich;
How an American Industry Gets Away With Slave Labor

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
JUST 10 days after about 70 illegal immigrants from Thailand were freed from a prison-like California garment factory, where they had worked in virtual slavery, Federal labor officials notified more than a dozen large retailers last week that goods from the sweatshop may have ended up in their stores.
 Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said the retailers had been asked to attend a meeting in Washington next month to discuss ways of preventing apparel made by slave labor from being sold in American stores. The invitation came amid a widening investigation of the garment shop in El Monte, Calif., and debate about the many other, more traditional sweatshops that still fail to pay minimum wage or overtime and often ignore health and safety laws. 
 In an interview, Mr. Reich elaborated on what the Government, retailers and garment manufacturers can do to curb abusive labor practices. ALAN FINDER
 
Q. Do stores know from whom they have purchased apparel or under what conditions it has been been produced?
 
A. The garment "food chain" is fairly complicated. Manufacturers often subcontract with cutting and sewing shops. The retailers contract with the manufacturers. Retailers increasingly specify what kinds of garments and the particular designs they need. Manufacturers using just-in-time inventory techniques deal with a whole set of subcontractors. It's often difficult for retailers to know precisely where a garment is cut or sewn.
 
Q. Was the women's garment industry fragmented this way so manufacturers could avoid responsibility for working conditions in shops? Or were economic conditions behind the creation of these complex networks?
 
A. We see the same pattern in many other industries. Increasingly, industries are fragmenting into networks of contractors and specialized subcontractors. The old model of a large, vertically integrated mass-production enterprise is becoming outmoded simply because consumers can now have goods tailored to their particular needs. Technology permits a wider array of enterprises to create niche markets and to supply one another with specialized services.
 
Q. Do you think consumers care whether clothing that they buy was made in a sweatshop or a factory that was abiding by all the labor laws?
 
A. Undoubtedly consumers are interested first and foremost in price and quality. But most American consumers probably don't want to buy clothes made by slave laborers in the United States.
 
Q. What can the Government do to make consumers more aware and force retailers and manufacturers to be more vigilant?
 
A. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 authorizes the Department of Labor to bar interstate shipments of goods made in violation of the act, such as in sweatshops. That power was used rarely in the past. But it has proved to be an important instrument to get an industry to take responsibility for preventing these kinds of abuses. By barring shipments or threatening to bar them, we've managed to make significant progress. The numbers of workers who have been identified as working in sweatshop conditions and whose employers have been fined has grown by 50 percent over the last 2 1/2 years.
 Now in this instance we traced the invoices to several national retail chains, Mays department stores and so on. There's no evidence that these retailers knew that the garments that they bought were cut and sewn by slave laborers in the United States, but I don't think it's too much to ask them to take greater responsibility for helping prevent these kinds of abuses in the future.
 
Q. You're planning to meet with a number of these national retailers. What do you want them to do?
 
A. Let me give you an example. In June, we got the agreement of many brand-name manufacturers operating in Los Angeles County, representing about a third of the garment industry in Los Angeles, to voluntarily audit their cutting and sewing contractors for compliance with labor laws. This was a direct result of our enforcement efforts. Obviously the manufacturers did not want to run the risk of having their shipments impounded. By the same token I would expect that retailers don't want to run the risk of not having their orders filled because the garments they ordered were produced by sweatshops.
 Retailers are also concerned about their public images. They want to be good corporate citizens, I assume. The national retailers and brand-name manufacturers working together can police this industry because they are directly in the food chain.
 
Q. The number of Federal labor investigators declined by about 20 percent in the last six years. Do you have enough resources to crack down on sweatshops?
 
A. No. We've done a great deal with relatively few resources, because we've enlisted the help of manufacturers and we've used the legal authority in the Fair Labor Standards Act, which had rarely been used before. But obviously the industry has got to start taking a greater responsibility. There are nearly one million employees in the industry who are cutting and sewing garments. Almost 80 percent are women. In Los Angeles County alone there are 100,000 cutters and sewers in 4,000 separate cutting and sewing shops. It's extremely difficult for Federal inspectors to root out sweatshops. Manufacturers, however, know whom they are contracting with. Retailers are able to follow the invoice trail and assert some pressure on manufacturers and their subcontractors.
 
Q. American manufacturers are often competing with foreign manufacturers who pay much lower labor rates. Is it reasonable to expect American companies to remain competitive, or should we consider abolishing laws like the minimum wage and allow the international marketplace to determine labor rates here?
 
A. The garment industry in the United States is alive and well despite foreign competition. That's because there is an increasing demand for quick turnaround. Fashions change quickly, retailers want certain models, patterns, designs, immediately. It's often difficult for retailers to get the quick turnaround from foreign-sourced manufacturers.
 The amount of money we're talking about here, the difference between a sweatshop and a legitimate cutting and sewing operation, is relatively small considering the cost of the final garment. Remember, retailers are often marking up 60 to 100 percent.
 
Q. Are you reasonably optimistic that the American garment industry will do a better job of policing itself?
 
A. The cutting and sewing end of the garment industry in the United States has had a sad history of worker abuses for more than a century. Immigrants, some of them legal, some illegal, crowded together in unsafe, unsanitary conditions working for very little money have characterized cutting and sewing shops since the turn of the century. Sometimes there's a calamity like the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire in New York at the turn of the century, in which hundreds are killed. Laws are then enacted. But enforcement is always difficult.
 Unscrupulous employers and vulnerable workers in fly-by-night operations that can move from one location to another within days or hours make a difficult target for enforcement. The question is whether national brand-name manufacturers who contract with these small enterprises and large national retailers can have an impact. I'm cautiously optimistic.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary Reich: a plan to prod manufacturers and retailers. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: DONKEY DROP;
Bradley's Exit Is Not Just the Democrats' Problem

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TAKEN alone, Senator Bill Bradley's decision to leave Congress, perhaps for an independent run for the White House, is just a straw in the wind, an isolated instance of a respected man's disenchantment with his party and politics. The problem is, Mr. Bradley is anything but alone. American politics in the '90's is becoming a haystack caught in a whirlwind, the inchoate product of party alliances shattering and reforming, old orders crumbling, voters clutching here, then there for an ideology to cling to.
 So Mr. Bradley's departure is more than just a straw. It foreshadows the end of the Democratic Party as Americans know it today -- if not now, within a matter of years. Whether it signals a greater upheaval in the entire system is a matter of some dispute. 
 For Democrats, the signs of decay are irrefutable. Mr. Bradley, who is 52, is the sixth Senate Democrat to announce his retirement this year, a modern record. One and possibly two more retirees, Senators Caliborne Pell of Rhode Island and Sam Nunn of Georgia, are in the wings. Two other Democratic senators defected to the Republican cause earlier this year. Should Democrats lose even four races in the next election -- a not unreasonable prospect -- they will claim but 42 Senate seats, the lowest number since Calvin Coolidge took office more than 70 years ago.

 
 
Realignment
 Three Democrats already have defected to the Republicans this year in the House, and more are widely anticipated, especially in the conservative South. The Democratic share of House seats, already the lowest since 1947, could also dip to Coolidge levels if Republicans pick up even nine seats in 1996.
 "The Democratic Party has essentially run out of options," said Walter Dean Burnham, a scholar of political parties at the University of Texas. "This is part of a realignment sequence, one of those rare events most of us see maybe twice in a lifetime. It entails a collapse of their credibility, as far as I can judge."
 Unfortunately for Democrats, however, the numbers are more like digits on a thermometer, merely a way to gauge a worsening fever. The true collapse has occurred in the party's ideology, the core belief that Government has a duty and the means to lift the oppressed and better the working man.
 It has guided the party for 60 years, and Democrats by and large still believe in it. But a deficit-hobbled Government no longer has the means to deliver endless benefits. And voters, seeing the results of Democratic efforts to tame crime and eradicate poverty and its ills, are rejecting it outright.
 Bill Daley, of the Democratic Daley family that used to dominate Illinois politics, is blistering in his assessment. "Whatever we thought the Democratic Party was, that's over," he said, "and I don't know what the next phase of it is.
 "The only message we've got is the same one we had in November: the Republicans are going to cut Social Security and Medicare. People look at it and say, 'Forget it. We don't buy that. The sky isn't falling.' "
 Sick as the Democrats are, the greater worry is whether what ails them is a disease of their party or the system. For the Republicans share some of their rivals' most ominous symptoms.
 Both political parties claim to represent that vast, mostly moderate body of middle-class voters who tend to determine elections, but both have been moving away from the center for years. The uncertain economy, the growing cynicism of sound-bite politics and the explosion of press coverage probably promote that drift; so, oddly, has both parties' commitment to civil rights. The well-intended redrawing of state and Congressional districts to create black and Hispanic seats has had unintended consequences: their mostly Democratic minority voters must be carved out of surrounding districts, leaving those districts more conservative and more Republican. Most of the new minority seats, meanwhile, are lopsidedly liberal and Democratic. Both trends have helped to kill off conservative Democrats in the South and on the fringes of big cities, and they have been a boon to Republicans.
How long the boon lasts is another matter. The new Republican hierarchy was largely installed by the moderate middle, but it is anchored by a solid right wing of populists and Christian stalwarts in the House and, increasingly, the Senate. Democrats proved unable to hold the extreme and the center; Republicans will have no easier time of it.
 Beyond that, it's not clear whether the Republican ascendancy means that the voters were hungry for their policies or just fed up with a broken Democratic regime. If the latter, then the new majority may soon get its own comeuppance.
 Republicans have made good on some pledges to shrink Government and upend the Washington aristocracy. But already polls hint at disaffection with their progress. Angry voters who fueled Ross Perot's independent candidacy in 1992 are now fuming over the party's failure to enact term limits and a balanced-budget amendment. The Republicans' open attempts to extract political money from big business and lobbyists rankle voters who expected the new Congress to change the town's greased-palm culture.
 More than a few experts believe the Republicans will amount to a political flavor-of-the-month unless they deliver the goods to the electorate, and quick.

 
 
Party Power
"The system is now saying that something must be done, that neither political party is being responsive or is viewed as responsible," said Kenneth M. Duberstein, former chief of staff to President Ronald Reagan. "The best analogy I can give you is a remote control device: people are clicking off politicians, the President, the speaker, the majority leader. In '92 they clicked off George Bush. In '94, they said they were clicking off Bill Clinton and the Democrats. The next channel we may turn to is an independent channel."
 It is true that an unusually thick flock of mavericks is mulling independent runs for the White House -- Lowell Weicker, Jesse Jackson, Colin Powell, Mr. Perot, and Mr. Bradley of New Jersey -- and that most of them are eyeing the restless center. The odds are against them. No third-party movement has survived without a leader in the White House, and not since Abraham Lincoln stopped leading the Whigs and took the new Republican Party to victory in 1860 has that occurred.
 Whatever storms they face, Republicans are united by a small-government, pro-business ideology. Even the splintered Democrats retain an organization, access to money and a proud tradition that make a powerful franchise.
 And political parties, like people, are capable of astonishing change. Republicans had ruled politics for 30 years, and Democrats were a husk of a party, too feeble even to repudiate the Ku Klux Klan, only eight years before Franklin D. Roosevelt founded a political dynasty in 1932. Democrats could well retain the White House next year. If Republican budget cuts and social crusades turn out to be missteps, they could surge back to power in the House, too.
 At least that is the optimistic Democratic view. In this decade of political windstorms, most experts believe the party has two options: either build a strong new house, based on new ideas, or hunker down in the cellar, committed liberals all, for a long, dark wait. The departure of the centrist Mr. Bradley could speed that day.
 "Few people remember it," the Democratic strategist David Doak said last week, "but Ronald Reagan's conservative revolution, the one that runs through Newt Gingrich now, began in the debacle of Barry Goldwater's loss in 1964."
