HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
He Who Has Pulpit Preaches

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

 BODY:
BEFORE Mike Tyson ever laid a glove on Peter McNeeley last night, the former heavyweight champion from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn unleashed a two-fisted attack on the news media last week.
Tyson, who served three years in prison for a rape conviction, called one writer an assassin and referred to members of the media, in so many words, as vultures feeding on the misfortunes of others. 
 The same day Tyson unleashed his verbal attack in Las Vegas, Nev., Gene Atkins, a tightly wound but congenial defensive back for the Miami Dolphins, expressed his displeasure in more concrete way in Florida: He floored a reporter with a body slam.
Atkins objected to a column that Jason Cole had written three days earlier in The Fort Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel. The column was about Atkins's renegotiated contract and quoted an unnamed Dolphin teammate wondering why Atkins, a newcomer to the team, had received special treatment.
Tyson's outburst and Atkins's body block reflects a growing tension in sports between "them" -- athletes, coaches and agents -- and "us" -- the journalists who cover them.
My concern is not over the loss of access, not about confrontation. It's whether there is any merit in the mounting charges of unfairness, bias and whatever-it-takes journalism.
Outside the mainstream there is a heated, multifaceted debate about Tyson among African-Americans, among women, among nearly everyone. Some against him, but many backing him.
Yet the prevailing representation casts Tyson as a demon and calls for him to repent. There have been similar, though less strident, calls for Darryl Strawberry of the Yankees to apologize.
To whom? For what? And who sits in judgment?
The majority of journalists who cover baseball, football, basketball and boxing find themselves in an unusual Wonderland in which black and Hispanic males are the innovators, the celebrities to be dealt with largely on their own terms.
Instead, the media insist on their terms, on ascribing mainstream values to an industry that is largely made of people who come from the working class at best and often from economically deprived backgrounds.
Much of the animus between "them" and "us" stems from an inability to equitably reconcile those two worlds. The rest of it comes from an overwhelming, nonnegotiable need to get The Story. By any means necessary.
In her book "The Journalist and The Murder" (Knopf, 1990), Janet Malcolm writes, harshly, but perceptively: "Every journalist who is not too stupid or too full of himself to notice what is going on knows that what he does is morally indefensible. He is a kind of confidence man, preying on people's vanity, ignorance, or loneliness, gaining their trust and betraying them without remorse."
Alice McDermott, the writer, simply cautioned, "A good writer sells out everybody he knows sooner or later."
As a result of the knockdown, Atkins, who apologized, will surely now be cast as a surly ingrate.
But was he angry about seeing his salary plastered in the newspaper? Could he have actually been concerned about the safety of his family? Doesn't he have the right to privacy?
Sports journalists rarely engage in formal discussions of these issues -- too busy meeting deadlines, traipsing from one event to the next. We are thousands of nomads, traveling in small bands, each with its own set of rules and regulations. Some of us shoot and ask questions later, some of us never shoot, some of us never ask.
What is troubling about the tension is not simply the obliteration of privacy but the underlying rationale for treading on privacy. In sports, we often reduce athletes to objects who -- as objects -- forfeit their right to privacy.
And because they use their bodies and physical skills to make a living, their work is deemed less important. Thus their performances, their skills, can be mocked and derided in clever, entertaining ways.
In any event, the athlete has no commensurate vehicle through which to rebut. Deion Sanders has his buckets of water; Bret Saberhagen has his solution of bleach and water. Tyson limits access to selected members of the media.
Sometime soon, athletes might exploit the information superhighway by making their case directly to fans via the Internet, effectively circumventing mainstream media outlets. But meanwhile, the gap in understanding between "them" and "us" widens. Neither side understands the other, both are stuck in a mode of muscle-flexing.
But while the dispute has become more intense and more hostile, it's not new.
As Yogi Berra, the former Yankee, complained in the mid-60's, "Why do I have to talk to all these guys who make $6,000 a year when I make $40,000 a year?"

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

Monday
 
Federal District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who is reviewing Microsoft's antitrust settlement with the Justice Department, meets with parties in the case.
 
The board of Turner Broadcasting System is expected to hold a special meeting to discuss a bid for King World Productions. Analysts said the board was also likely to discuss joining with Microsoft on a possible bid for CBS.
 
Tuesday
 
The Federal Open Market Committee meets, and all signs point to the committee's leaving interest rates unchanged. The committee is the policy-making arm of the Federal Reserve. Economic reports continue to show signs of economic health and officials at the Fed indicated last week that they were pleased with the current economic outlook.
 
A committee of the California Senate holds an emergency hearing to develop a compromise recovery plan for bankrupt Orange County, Calif.
 
Jiangling Motors in China is expected to announce an alliance with Ford.
 
American Stores is expected to report second-quarter earnings of 51 cents a share.
 
Wednesday
 
The Mortgage Bankers Association of America releases its weekly report on mortgage applications.
 
Thursday
 
Windows 95, Microsoft's new operating system for personal computers, goes on sale. Analysts said the company could sell as many as 30 million copies by the end of the year.
 
The policy-making committee of the Bundesbank meets. The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, allowed money-market rates to fall last week, leading analysts to predict that it might cut the discount rate.
 
The Commerce Department releases durable goods orders for July.
 
Forecast: up 1.4 percent, after an increase of one-tenth of 1 percent in June.
 
Friday
 
The National Association of Realtors reports existing-home sales for July.
 
Forecast: up 1.6 percent, to 3.84 million units. Home sales rose 6.5 percent, to 3.78 million units, in June.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS: FUNDS WATCH;
A Squeeze In Junk Bonds

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
JUNK bonds are generally not attractive, with the exception of emerging-market debt, Susan Belden wrote recently in the No-Load Fund Analyst, a newsletter published in Orinda, Calif.
The yield for unrated -- hence, junk -- bonds has been running three to four percentage points above that for 10-year Treasury notes, to account for their greater risk. Junk-bond yields now average about 10 percent, and 10-year Treasury yields are about 6.5 percent. 
 But that spread is not particularly big by standards of the last decade. It is greater than in the early 1980's, before the leveraged-buyout boom, but lower than in the subsequent crash in the junk-bond market, when spreads exceeded nine percentage points. Given the risk of a recession or at least some slowdown in economic growth, junk bonds are not very appealing now, Ms. Belden concluded.
But bonds of emerging markets -- also in the junk category -- have yields of more than 14 percent. Latin American issues could be very volatile in the short term, Ms. Belden said, but there is considerable potential for attractive long-term returns.
For long-term investors who can ride out declines in the market, she recommends the Scudder Emerging Markets Income Fund.
 
Too Little, Too Late?
A majority of employed Americans believe that they will be forced to continue working after they reach retirement age, according to findings of a recent poll by Roper Starch Worldwide for Kemper Financial Services. The main reasons cited: They are not saving enough, and Social Security will not make up for the shortfall.
 The poll, of 2,086 Americans, offered hints for younger workers. When asked to give advice to younger generations about saving for retirement, many retirees suggested that they start saving early and take advantage of company retirement plans.
 Among all respondents, the preferred retirement saving choices were 401(k) plans, 52 percent; savings accounts, 44 percent; mutual funds, 40 percent; life insurance, 39 percent, and Keogh plans or individual retirement accounts, 39 percent. Respondents could list more than one choice.

HEADLINE: The World;
A Global Guage of Greased Palms

BYLINE: By Barbara Crossette 

 BODY:
A German engineer sent to eastern India to help set up a factory a few years ago was honored when officials visited his home and admired his stereo and other imported items. But what they wanted to talk about was money: illegal "commissions" to insure that the project would start. He turned them down and went home to Europe to report to his company. In his absence, his house was stripped of valuables worth about what he had refused to pony up in bribes.
 At the World Bank and in boardrooms everywhere, such stories are legion. Several years ago, Peter Eigen, a former World Bank director in Africa and Latin America, decided enough was enough. He united business leaders, politicians and academics from different countries around a common purpose: curbing the increasingly rampant corruption stunting the development of poor countries. 
 In May 1993 Transparency International, a Berlin-based watchdog organization, was born of that initiative. It has been working on two fronts: helping interested citizens set up national chapters of Transparency International -- there are now more than 40 -- and compiling an annual international corruption index. The first was released this summer.
 The 1995 index is a "poll of polls," drawing on seven published surveys, which were analyzed by Johann Graf Lambsdorff, an economist at Gottingen University in Germany. It is comprehensive on Asia, where, paradoxically, Transparency International has not found many takers for its workshops or affiliation, and very short on Africa, where corruption also flourishes but many corporations do not venture and so risk analysts do not follow. Local groups there will help the organization compile future surveys, says Karen Hussman, a program officer at Transparency International's Berlin headquarters.
 For browsers, the list has a surprise or two. Singapore, for example, is perceived internationally to be a lot less corrupt than the United States. The iron hand of Lee Kuan Yew, better known for destroying political opponents, has come down hard on the corrupt because, Mr. Lee says, the tiny country with no natural resources has to rely on its good name to remain a banking and technology center.
 Mid-ranking Hong Kong, on the edge of notoriously corrupt Southeast Asia, has been watched over by a British colonial police force and a court system not easily bought. In 1997, however, the colony reverts to China, which figures on the 1995 list as the second-most corrupt country. Future indexes will bear watching. BARBARA CROSSETTE

HEADLINE: Middle Class Works Overtime to Stay Afloat;
Income Gap Children

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I was happy to see "Rich Nation, Poor Children" (editorial, Aug. 15), on the plight of poor children in America, a plight worse than that in 15 of 17 other industrial countries. 
 You do not mention a crucial finding of the Luxembourg Income Study: the income gap between poor families with children and affluent families with children. That gap is greater by far in the United States than in any other country studied.
 All these statistics are generated by income only. They do not take into account health insurance or any other facet of the social safety net that is so secure in Europe and so lacking (and getting more so) here. The income gap, which the party in power seems determined to widen further, is more significant than comparison of figures. Switzerland, for instance, has very high incomes among its well-off population, but its poorer families have relatively high incomes too.
 Israel and Ireland, whose poor children live in families with incomes even lower than our own poor, have much smaller gaps between rich and poor.
 Those who do not believe that capitalism and democracy are best served by a growing population of the uneducated, ill fed and ill clothed must speak out. Those of us favored by society have the power to change things. We cannot let ourselves off the hook.
 
CAROL WHEELER
New York, Aug. 17, 1995

HEADLINE: Middle Class Works Overtime to Stay Afloat;
What the Song Means

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 David Frum (Op-Ed, Aug. 14) offers as an example of 1950's "hostility to the new mass middle class" that "Pete Seeger complained in one of his songs that they lived in 'boxes made of ticky tacky,' and people who flew over them on their way to Europe emphatically agreed." 
 The song was written by Malvina Reynolds, not Pete Seeger, but neither songwriter deserves to be dragged into guilt by association.
 Ms. Reynolds's song satirizes the conformity urged on Americans during post-World War II expansion. Only by twisting its meaning beyond recognition can it be equaled with hostility to the middle class itself.
 Mr. Frum attempts to reduce criticism of the increasing gap between rich and poor in America to a matter of snobbery. By this method, political issues disappear, and all that is left is personal.
 
DEBORAH LYONS
Rochester, Aug. 15, 1995

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
The Pathmark Wars, Part Three

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM

 BODY:
Starting last year, the battleground was 125th Street: local retailers fought tooth and nail -- without success -- to stop Pathmark from building a superstore. Then the scene shifted to Springfield Gardens, Queens: last week the City Council approved a plan for a Pathmark store, but angry local store owners have not given up their fight.
Now Pathmark has returned to Harlem with a proposal to build a store on 145th Street between Bradhurst and Eighth Avenues -- and local supermarket owners are up in arms. They have hired the same consultant who led the struggle against the 125th Street market, and they are trying to persuade city officials that one of their number should be allowed to put up a market on the site, not Pathmark. 
 A Pathmark spokesman, Stan Sorkin, said the company is "in the initial stages of trying to get the site approved." Most of the land, a rubbly lot with four long-condemned brick buildings in one corner, is owned by the city. Asked why his company wants a second store in Harlem, Mr. Sorkin said: "We are interested in sites in New York City that meet the criteria of population, disposable income and size of property."
A spokeswoman for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development said that Pathmark officials had met with the agency. And members of Community Board 10 said they will debate Pathmark's request for a zoning change next month. The board has questioned Pathmark on such topics as traffic and parking. "Because of what happened with 125th Street, it's going to draw a lot of attention," said Barbara Askins, chairwoman of the board.
Richard Lipsky, the consultant who organized supermarket owners against the East Harlem Pathmark proposal, said: "Now that we have been told in no uncertain terms that Pathmark is going into 125th Street, we think it would be fair for one of the independent stores to go in there, like a C-town or a Bravo."
Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields, who represents north Harlem and has met with Mr. Lipsky, said she hoped to avoid another long battle over a Pathmark by including the business community and local developers in the early planning stages. "We are going to work this one out," Ms. Fields said. (For a roll call of the City Council's Pathmark vote in Queens, see page 21.)
One of the attractions of the 145th Street site for a supermarket developer is the Bradhurst project, under which the city is renovating 2,200 abandoned apartments in the neighborhood for low- and moderate-income residents. The 145th site itself is among the locations scheduled to be redeveloped under another urban renewal plan.
On 145th Street, some residents were enthusiastic about the idea of a new Pathmark. "That's good for the neighborhood," said Sallh Mohammed, who owns a small convenience store across the street from the proposed site. An assistant, Raul Mojica, agreed. "We don't need another C-town," he said. JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Reading the Hidden City

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
TO Hope Cooke, New York is a palimpsest. The word, from the Greek, describes a parchment that has been inscribed and erased several times, still bearing hints of old, faded messages. As the city builds and rebuilds itself, barely legible remnants of its past are left behind. Those remnants -- the faded signs, anomalous buildings and crooked streets -- are the clues that Ms. Cooke, a self-described urban historian, tries to decipher.
 Ms. Cooke herself is something of a palimpsest. In her 55 years she has been a debutante, a princess, a queen, a mother, a walking tour guide, a teacher and an author. 
I've learned that it's really important to be terribly attentive to where I am, wherever it is, because if you get numb to space, numb to habitat, you don't live wisely or well" said Ms. Cooke, whose discoveries of New York's spaces was published this spring in her "Seeing New York: History Walks for Armchair and Footloose Travelers" (Temple University Press).
 Raised by wealthy relatives on the Upper East Side, she graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1963 and instantly became the heroine of a national fairy tale when she married the Crown Prince of the tiny Himalayan kingdom of Sikkim. Eventually, she became Sikkim's Queen. But the characters in this fairy tale did not live happily ever after. After 10 years, Ms. Cooke's marriage shattered. Then came uprisings, with thousands of Sikkimese protesting the monarchy and besieging the palace. After the tumult, Sikkim was annexed by India.
 Ms. Cooke returned to New York, a city that because of her privileged but highly circumscribed childhood, she hardly knew. "When I was little, I thought the Grand Central building at the end of Park Avenue was the end of the earth," she recalls. "The place where ships fell off."
 Back from Sikkim -- a single mother with two children to raise -- she found herself fighting a powerful sense of dislocation. "I needed grounding for my feet," she recalled over lunch in the backyard of her Brooklyn brownstone. "I needed roots, I needed to learn about my surroundings."
 So she began exploring the city, walking widely and reading broadly. She studied the waves of immigration that shaped the Lower East Side: from the Canarsie Indians to the Irish, to the Jews of Eastern Europe, to the Chinese. "Going around the Lower East Side," she said, "you often get some old union organizer who can tell you about pre-reform labor, reform and the rollbacks of reform. In Chatham Square you can see steam coming out of every vent," a sure marker of illegal sweatshops.
 One neighborhood she finds especially fascinating is downtown Flushing, which she thinks of as a miniature pan-Asia. Chinese and Korean merchants sell red-bean popsicles and ginseng root on Main Street, just steps from Taiwanese banks. On Union Street, intricate Japanese kimonos are offered, while just east on Bowne Street, Hindus worship at the Gujarati Temple only yards from the Sikh Gurdwara, another place of worship.
 In "Seeing New York," she maps 14 walking tours ranging over Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens -- from Victorian Brooklyn Heights to Dominican Washington Heights.
 "In lower Manhattan, to recreate the early colonial era when you're face to face with banks, you have to become quite a good story teller," she said. "It's more like radio than television." It is easier when the subject is Brownstone Brooklyn, with block after block of intact Civil War-era houses.
 One of her favorite neighborhoods is Brooklyn Heights, not far from the home she shares with her husband, Michael Wallace, a history professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. She revels in the Heights' "seeming fixity, the lush environs of longer durations and reposeful streets."
 One that has her worried is Ladies Mile, the stretch of Avenue of the Americas from 14th to 23d Streets. At the turn of the century it was city's premiere shopping area for elegant women, with famous emporiums like B. Altman and Siegel-Cooper. But most closed or moved uptown, and the neighborhood declined. Recently, the old buildings have been renovated to house new stores, many of them giants like Bed, Bath and Beyond and Today's Man. Ms. Cooke worries, though, that few of these have their roots in the city. Most are indistinguishable from their suburban mall branches, a fact she finds especially distressing, and the bulk of their profits go elsewhere. "We've written off the notion of New York as a production town," she said, adding that the city has also lost more than 100,000 retailing jobs since 1965. "It's a little scary if you write off consumption as well."
 Since returning from Sikkim two decades ago, she has never tired of scouring the city. "I began to see the connections between things," she said. "If you learn about the struggle over Tompkins Square, from the 1830's on, the present struggle over Tompkins Square makes more sense."
 A flashpoint of that struggle -- among squatters, the poor, young professionals, the police and anarchists -- was the 1988 clash over a curfew for Tompkins Square Park. Ms. Cooke said worse riots erupted in 1874, when 10,000 unemployed workers battled mounted police officers.
 Even before that, she notes, the neighborhood was divided between the rich who lived in town houses on the park's north side and who scorned tenement dwellers to the south, calling their homes "rag pickers' row."
 Ms. Cooke enjoys the nitty-gritty of neighborhood disputes that have shaped the city: for example, how the battle between the Pierponts and the Hickses over how to develop Brooklyn in the 19th century helped define the borough's present downtown.
 "That is always the illumination: to find the context," she said in her slightly whispery voice, which still retains a light Scottish accent she inherited from a nanny. "Once you bring past to present, that turns into an epiphany."
 
CITYSCAPE
 
Cooke's Tour
In 22 years of walking the city's streets and researching their history, Hope Cooke has found some favorite nooks and crannies:
Minetta Brook An underground stream that runs beneath Greenwich Village and that can be seen in a glass tube in the lobby of 2 Fifth Avenue.
Stuyvesant Street Cutting diagonally from Ninth to 10th Streets in the East Village, it is the city's only street on a true east-west axis. It was mapped to the compass points by Peter Stuyvesant's great-grandson, Petrus, before the city laid its own grid to conform to the shape of Manhattan Island.
Secret Tunnel This once connected the old Police Headquarters, at 240 Centre Street, to a walnut-paneled tavern on Grand Street in Little Italy.

HEADLINE: The Comfort Zones Of the Young, Black Professional

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS

 BODY:
A STEPHANIE MILLS song washes over the room's exposed brick walls as clusters of denim-clad people strain to be heard over the din. Every bar stool is occupied, every corner clogged, forcing people headed upstairs to the dining room to navigate the crush.
 The Shark Bar on a typical Friday night. 
Standing at the far end of the softly lit bar is Michael Shanks, 34, a municipal bond accountant. "I haven't missed a Friday night in four months," Mr. Shanks said of the Upper West Side restaurant, a mecca for young black professionals. "I feel a sense of warmth here. I feel at home around my people." He paused, grasping for the right words. "I feel fulfilled."
 For many middle-class blacks, the bars, restaurants and cafes that cater to them are more than places to meet friends before catching the latest release at the multiplex, more than spots to find next weekend's date or a future spouse. Jazz spots, salons and the dozens of black reading groups that are popping up throughout the city are more than social venues.
 They are havens from the mainstream world that many young African-Americans and their parents fought so hard to enter. For some successful blacks, seeing people like themselves, walking examples of civil rights progress, helps to sustain them in an outside world from which they often feel alienated.
 Such settings represent "a retreat to a comfortable and nurturing place," said Ellis Cose, author of "The Rage of a Privileged Class" (HarperCollins, 1994), which argues that although the ranks of the black middle class have grown rapidly in the past two decades, its members are frustrated by glass ceilings in corporations, racial slights from strangers and discrimination in housing and other walks of life.
 The city's rising black middle class is substantial, even if its presence is often obscured by the focus on underclass poverty and crime. In 1990, 18 percent of working, non-Hispanic blacks in the city between the ages of 25 and 65 held managerial or professional jobs, according to Andrew A. Beveridge, a Queens College sociologist who conducted an analysis of the 1990 census for The New York Times. Another 28.7 percent held technical, sales and administrative support positions. And 30 percent were living in households with incomes of $50,000 or more, many of them in Queens, where the median household income of blacks exceeds that of whites.
 Despite such inroads, for many blacks, the workplace is a source of racial unease. "One of the things that struck me as I was researching 'Rage' was that blacks kept saying how hard they had to work to make white people comfortable around them at work," Mr. Cose said. "They had to present a face that was not their natural face. A lot of black men, for instance, told me they had to be more meek than normal. If they were assertive or loud at all, people would perceive them as somehow stereotypical or perhaps even violent."
 It should surprise no one, then, that many young upwardly mobile blacks --sometimes called buppies (a label rejected by some because it connotes intraracial stratification) -- choose to spend happy hour with other blacks. And it's not just happy hour. There are black ski and scuba-diving groups and black bulletin boards on the Internet and mega-parties like the "Summer Sizzler at the Roxy," a July bash that drew more than 3,500 men and women from 10 black professional groups.
 Of course, affluent blacks and whites do not lead completely bifurcated post-work lives. "It's not as segregated as you might think," said Nelson George, the cultural critic, adding that at most predominately black establishments, there will be at least a smattering of whites. "These are people who hang out with black friends at these places or are just down with blacks."
 Still, says Lawrence Otis Graham, a black, Harvard-educated lawyer and a frequent commentator on race relations, when black professionals get together, they often choose to do so in "places that are accustomed to serving a large black clientele."
 Why is that? Mr. Graham, the author of "Member of the Club: Reflections on Life in a Racially Polarized World" (HarperCollins, 1995), asserts that based on his experience, blacks not in the company of whites run the risk of being ignored or treated rudely or seated next to the bathroom or kitchen in many of the city's top restaurants.
 But Earl Caldwell, the former Daily News columnist, has another explanation for the popularity of places like B. Smith's and the Shark Bar. They represent something "exotic" to younger blacks raised in the era of integration, he said. "The music is different, the language is different," he said. "Isn't it just more exciting?"
 For Alison N. King, 34, a television producer and consultant, being a member of a black salon offers a gratifying sense of community as well as a venue for intellectual discourse. "It's good to know that there are others like yourself out there," said Ms. King, a member of the Brooklyn Black Belt Salon Brunch, which brings together Fort Greene and Clinton Hill artists and professionals to schmooze and discuss everything from fashion and literature to affirmative action. "Often, you think you're the only one out there with certain thoughts and experiences."
 Not that successful blacks are a homogenous lot. There exists, says Mr. George, "an internal gamesmanship" based on educational and social pedigree. Second- and third-generation members of the black middle class -- those who vacationed on Martha's Vineyard as children, attended debutante balls as teen-agers and, later, graduated from exclusive colleges and universities -- may not fully welcome the newly arrived.
 "You get a certain vibe from some of the Harvard and Yale blacks," said Mr. George, author of "Buppies, B-Boys, Baps and Bohos: Notes on a Post-Soul Black Culture" (HarperCollins, 1993). "But then there is also a cockiness among the up-by-the-bootstraps buppies. Those who came up from the streets will pull rank on the people who have the pedigree. They won't claim to be more authentically black, but they'll say I had to go through so much more than you, so therefore I am stronger."
 For many decades, Manhattan has been the primary after-hours playground for black professionals. In the 60's, lawyers, doctors and politicians sipped cocktails at Frank's Restaurant, the Flash Inn, Jock's Place and the Red Rooster, Harlem restaurants and bars that closed as accommodations opened up to blacks downtown. In the 70's and 80's, the Cellar and Mikel's, now defunct rhythm and blues and jazz clubs on the Upper West Side, were the haunts.
 Manhattan remains the social nexus for black professionals, although Fort Greene, often called the home of the new black renaissance, continues to grow in popularity and is now drawing black revelers from beyond Brooklyn's borders.
 From a salon to soul food restaurants, herewith a look at a few of the places the city's black professionals find one another and themselves.
 
SALONS, POETRY READINGS, BOOK DISCUSSION GROUPS
 The topic was media coverage of African-Americans. There were three featured panelists, but Ann Tripp, the 98.7 KISS-FM radio reporter, owned the floor at this Sunday afternoon assembly of the Brooklyn Black Belt Salon Brunch. "Why is it that every time there is a story about affirmative action in the news, blacks are called upon to defend it?" she asked. "Why don't they find white women, Asians, Latinos to defend it? They've benefited from it!"
 A 30ish woman offered an "Amen." Someone else encouraged Ms. Tripp to "Tell it!" And so she continued. She noted in stories about Adarand Constructors v. Pena, the recent Supreme Court decision that imposed strict constitutional limits on affirmative action, she saw only blacks interviewed on the news. "The name was Pena, folks. He was not a black man."
 Ms. Tripp also fumed about what she called excessive media coverage of black male celebrities accused of crimes, from Mike Tyson to Michael Jackson, and now O. J. Simpson.
 "If you black women would turn off the O. J. trial," she said, "you could put CNBC out of business. I don't know why you're watching it. O. J. would rather die than date you."
 Over lobsters, crab cakes and salads at the Chesapeake Oyster Grill in Fort Greene, the largely female crowd, ranging in age from post-grad to sub-50, blasted the news media for bias. In the past, entertainment and literature as well as art, politics and community affairs have been discussed.
 The salon was born five years ago after three record publicists shared a cab from Manhattan to Fort Greene only to discover that they lived within blocks of one another.
 "We realized that we lived so close together, but we had never been to one another's house," said Jacqueline Rhinehart, 37, national director of publicity for Arista Records. "We wondered, 'Well, who else lives in the hood?' "
 The initial gathering was small. But eight people soon mushroomed into 60, and the salon moved from informal potlucks in individual homes to large brunches in local black-owned restaurants. Now 1,000 names appear on the salon's mailing list.
 Entertainment is included in the $10 fee. (A poet and comedian appeared at the Oyster Grill.) The brunches draw an average of 100 people. But salon organizers say they do not make a profit.
 "This gives us an opportunity to learn more about each other, share viewpoints and make new friends," said Gwendolyn Quinn, 34, a salon organizer. "If you know and respect your neighbors, I think it makes for a much healthier environment, socially and economically."
 Though African-American salons are rare, black reading groups have been growing rapidly, according to the owners of several black bookstores.
 With 85 members, the Literary Society may be the largest black reading group in the city. Founded by Lana Turner, a Harlem real estate broker, in 1982, this group of lawyers, educators, social workers and doctors meet monthly. They assemble in one another's homes and, so, feel blessed that only 20 to 25 people show up at most meetings. The group is not looking for new recruits. "When you have 25 clear-thinking, articulate people at a meeting and everyone wants to talk, it gets difficult," Ms. Turner said.
 Women outnumber men, 7 to 1. Why this is is subject to debate. But Ms. Turner said, laughing, "The three or four who show up do carry the banner for their gender."
 At a recent meeting of the Brooklyn-based Awareness Book Club, David Lamb, a 29-year-old Park Slope resident, found himself doing just that -- carrying the banner for black men.
 Bell Hooks's book "Ain't I a Woman?" (South End Press, 1981) was on the agenda. There was consensus on some points, among them that white feminists tend to romanticize black women's "strength" and that black women are often asked to choose between black nationalism and feminism.
 But Mr. Lamb, a lawyer who recently self-published a novel ("Do Platanos Go With Collard Greens?") took issue with the author's contention that slavery, while wretched for both sexes, was worse for women because not only did they endure savage beatings, but they were sometimes sexually exploited by slave owners and overseers.
 "I think it's dangerous to get into who suffered more," Mr. Lamb said. "Black men were sexually exploited too. They were used to breed. They were bucks." Sometimes, he said, "They were forced to have sex with their own mothers and sisters." A momentary hush blanketed the room.
 Seven months ago, when a friend told Mr. Lamb about the reading group, he jumped at the chance to become a member. "I'm the only black male attorney at my law firm," he said. "And that's a lonely position to be in. At the book club, there's camaraderie with other blacks. It's a way of renewing your spirit."
 There's no shortage of spirit at the Brooklyn Moon Cafe in Fort Greene. Bohemians -- and buppies with "boho" souls -- clog the small, seven-month-old coffee house on Friday nights, when the main course is open-mike poetry.
 Those not early enough to get a bistro table sit side by side in folding chairs. A few pile onto slightly frayed Victorian sofas. But many are left standing, not a few outside peering over the baseball caps, dreadlocks and braids of those who beat them in.
 David Larrick Smith, 24, owner of an in-line skating school, is a regular.
 "People up there are expressing the frustrations of the race," he said, nodding to the front of the room where twentysomething poets and would-be bards recited original verse about love, racism, revolution, O. J. and black women's thighs. "You hear other people express how you feel, and you want to scream, 'I can relate!' There's a healing process that takes place."
 Recently, Brad Walrond, 24, a director of a youth program, recited a poem that captures the essence of the place: "People of Color Affirming Each Other."
 It is so beautiful to see people of color affirming each other
 I'm not waiting for ivory-tainted fame to come a'knocking at my door
 I feel famous now cause I can hear the glorious sound of ebony talking back to me, saying, 'Go on baby, Go on.'
 The raucous, patented laughter and spirited applause
 Jovial injunction and adulation that resound in a mighty chorus
 of a circle that cannot be broken . . .
 "There's a need to be nurtured by your own," Mr. Walrond later said. Booing is verboten at Brooklyn Moon.
 
MUSIC, CLUBS AND RESTAURANTS
 Dance clubs may be on the wane. But sometimes the dancing happens anyway.
 Tuesday is funk night at Cafe Wha?. The dimly lit cellar in the West Village that draws predominantly white crowds most evenings attracts black professionals in their 20's and 30's who come to lose themselves in the retro-funk of the Slam Clinic, which plays old favorites by groups like the Ohio Players, Parliament-Funkadelic, and Earth Wind & Fire. Clubgoers are transported to a 70's basement house party, a place, in the words of the emcee, William Stephenson, "where your Afro shriveled all up" from dance-induced perspiration.
 There is no dance floor, so clubgoers make do, moving with abandon in the narrow aisles, forcing waitresses to snake between shimmying hips, bobbing heads and flailing arms (the latter almost touch the wires that traverse the low ceilings). Surprisingly, management encourages the dancing.
 "The more they dance, the more they drink," Mr. Stephenson explained. "It's that simple."
 There is no dancing on Sunday at Chaz & Wilson, a cavernous Upper West Side supper club, when the R & B band, Ron Grant & Friends, shares the stage with budding performers during open mike night. Located on the northwest corner of 79th and Amsterdam, the usually predominantly white restaurant becomes a de facto Ebony Fashion Fair. Beautiful women with aerobicized bodies sport elegant silk pants suits, gold lame halters and dresses that are either very long or very, very short.
 "I date black women exclusively," said a 33-year-old engineer, who insisted on anonymity. "Why would I go to a white club?" The celebrities are another draw. Salt, of Salt-N-Pepa fame, and Kevin Willis, of the Miami Heat, were recently spotted. Knicks players are said to be regulars.
 There are a growing number of restaurants that draw largely black crowds, most of them owned, or co-owned, by blacks. Places like Kwanzaa, Pepper's and Mekka have opened in the last few years but B. Smith's and the Shark Bar have continued to attract legions of black professionals from across the city and neighboring suburbs for nine and four years respectively.
 Sam Allen, 34, a real estate broker, is a Shark Bar partisan. "The crowd is professional, but they're down to earth, not snobbish and pretentious like the crowd at B. Smith's," he said.
 Herbert Moreira-Brown, 40, a public school teacher, explained his enduring affection for B. Smith's. "We treat one another as individuals," he said, looking at the throng of people, overwhelming black and male and handsomely suited, at the bar. "I don't feel like I have to prove myself here the way I do when I walk into a white restaurant. Here, I'm not a black man, I'm a man."
Cyber-Hangouts With a Distinctly Urban Feel
 Sign on to New York Online, the nation's largest black-owned computer bulletin board system, and arguably its hippest, and suddenly a transit token materializes on the screen, followed by a digitized jazz trumpet riff. It doesn't take a techie to realize this is a cyberspace community with a decidedly urban flavor.
 The subway is a metaphor for New York Online, a service focusing on the arts, created as a bridge between people of different cultures and races, the same way the subway connects people in the city's diverse precincts "who might not otherwise meet," explained Omar Wasow, 24. Mr. Wasow, with fellow Stanford grad, Peta Hoyes, 25, founded the company in a Fort Greene brownstone a year and a half ago.
 But it is also a way for tristate black professionals to connect through black-themed chat rooms, to discuss, say, the recent Whitney Museum exhibit on African-American men or reactions to the movie "Panther" or black conservatives. Forty percent of New York Online's 1,100 users are black, 50 percent female, and most between the ages of 18 and 35.
 There are at least 100 black-owned or black-oriented bulletin board systems on the Internet, according to Essence magazine, which, along with Shade, Vibe, Paper and Out, are published on New York Online.
 John Knight Smith, 28, talks politics with other African-Americans and keeps abreast of upcoming black social and professional events using New York Online's black chat rooms, Society and Black Talk, as well as America Online's Ebony Room.
 Users sometimes get together off-line, said Mr. Smith, a Park Slope marketing coordinator and married father of three, who recently attended an "Ebony Room" party aboard the Mystique yacht as it cruised around Manhattan.
 "Sometimes people meet just to satisfy a sense of curiosity," Mr. Smith said. "There's also a lot of networking at these events. People bring their portfolios and hand out product and service information. There's a lot of talent out there."
 Meeting off-line has advantages, Mr. Smith added. Online services like America Online, which reach a mass audience, leave users vulnerable to race-baiting from outsiders.
 "Sometimes people with a screen name like 'hateblacks' will come into the Ebony Room just to be disruptive," Mr. Smith said. "Others will come in and say, 'I don't understand why you need this room.' Anybody with a computer has access."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS NOTES

 BODY:

Meatloaf and the 50's Style In New Village Eating Place
 E.J.'s Luncheonettes have proved to be popular gathering spots for young singles on the Upper East Side and Upper West Side. Now, the owners hope that a new outlet in the West Village, at 432 Avenue of the Americas, between Ninth and 10th Streets, will become a mecca for neighborhood residents. 
 "We found another strong residential community to open our neighborhood restaurant," said Howard Eisenberg, one of five partners who own the 50's-diners, and the manager of the newest one, which opened on July 27.
 E.J.'s serves large portions of dinner food (an array of breakfast items as well as home-style meatloaf, roast turkey platters, grilled fresh fish and salads) at prices ranging from $3 for two eggs, toast and home fries to $14 for New York strip steak.
 
Low-Interest Loans for Owners Of Historic Homes in Queens
 The New York Landmarks Conservancy has $1.5 million in low-interest loans available for owners of historic residences in Queens.
 "It's a five-borough program that has been going on for at least six years," said Joshua Schaff, a conservancy spokesman, "but residents in Queens have not been taking advantage." The borough's historic districts are Ridgewood, Hunters Point, Jackson Heights, Richmond Hill, Steinway, Old Astoria and Kew Gardens. The loans carry interest rates starting at 3 percent and can be used for exterior restoration and repairs.
 There are no income limits for applicants, Mr. Schaff said, although it is hoped that most of the money will be lent to low- and middle-income residents of the historic districts.
 
Cluster of Italian Restaurants Grows on West 44th Street
 An Italian restaurant, L'Allegria, opened recently on the northwest corner of 44th Street and Ninth Avenue, in what is becoming a small outpost of Italian cuisine.
 L'Allegria, in 2,500 square feet of space, serves fare like a salad of arugula, raicchio and endive ($4) and lombata di vitello alla griglia (grilled vel chop, $14.50). The pastas are all $7.50.
 Nicola Coladonato, the owner and chef, sold his other restaurant, Mangia e Bevi, at 53d Street and Ninth Avenue, three months ago.
 Opposite L'Allegria on West 44th and Ninth for four years; five weeks ago, it put up a large maroon awning that says, "44 Southwest Italian Continental."
 Just a few yards east across Ninth Avenue, a pizzeria, Don Giovanni, is scheduled to open in about three weeks, at 358 West 44th Street.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Cleveland

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STOFFEL; JENNIFER STOFFEL is the author of "The Cleveland Discovery Guide."

 BODY:
When a housewarming party is a decade in the making, it has to be pretty spectacular to live up to the hype. But the festivities surrounding the opening of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland over Labor Day weekend may just be equal to the task.
For one thing, the party music will be provided by the likes of Bruce Springsteen and Martha and the Vandellas. And the museum that's being celebrated dramatically transforms Cleveland's skyline. 
 The $84-million building, designed by I. M. Pei, hugs the Lake Erie shoreline. Its striking pyramid-shaped tent of concrete, glass and steel rises over the lobby and its concrete wings jut into the harbor. With plans proposed and dropped over a 10-year period, fund-raising efforts that faltered, and even talk at one point of selecting another city, it is no wonder that the opening has inspired a party that will cover the Labor Day weekend.
The museum is the most stunning structure in a recent spate of downtown development. It joins the Gateway complex, with its baseball stadium and arena completed last year, as the city's newest attractions.
For maps and information contact the Convention and Visitors Bureau of Greater Cleveland, (800) 321-1004.
 
Events
 Opening ceremonies for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, Sept. 1 to 4, will include a Rockin' in the Streets procession starting from downtown at 11:30 A.M., Sept. 1, culminating in a 12:30 P.M. ribbon-cutting ceremony at the museum, and a concert, Sept. 2, starting 7:30 P.M. at Cleveland Municipal Stadium, with Bruce Springsteen, Chuck Berry, Little Richard, Al Green, The Pretenders, Melissa Etheridge, Jon Bon Jovi, Aretha Franklin, Dr. Dre, John Mellencamp, Martha and the Vandellas, among others. Ticket prices range from $30 to $540. Call Ticketmaster at (216) 241-5555.
The collection to be opened at the 150,000-square-foot museum includes film, videos, excerpts from radio programs, photographs, posters and interactive computer displays, creating what the museum is heralding as the definitive archive of rock. The collection of rock artifacts includes the original equipment from Sam Phillips' Sun Records Memphis recording studio, one of Jimi Hendrix's Fender Stratocasters and John Lennon's Sergeant Pepper uniform. And, of course, there is the music. Hand-written sheet music and recordings from the 123 Hall of Famers -- including Elvis Presley, Chuck Berry and Janis Joplin -- chronicle rock from its roots to punk, rap and grunge.
On Labor Day weekend, the museum will be open 10 A.M. to 9 P.M., with tickets sold for specific entry times. Regular hours, beginning Sept. 5, are 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., Tuesday through Sunday and until 9 P.M. Wednesday; the museum will be closed Monday and major holidays. Admission is $10.90, $7.65 for seniors and those aged 4 to 11. The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum is at 1 Key Plaza. For information and an updated opening-event schedule, call (216) 781-7625. For tickets, call (800) 493-7655.
To ease opening-weekend traffic, shuttle buses will link remote parking areas. For information, call the Convention and Visitors Bureau.
In conjunction with the opening of the Hall of Fame, "Elvis + Marilyn: 2X Immortal" runs through Sept. 24 at the Cleveland Museum of Art, 11150 East Boulevard, (216) 421-7340. The museum is open Tuesday, Thursday and Friday, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M., and Wednesdays until 9:45 P.M.; Saturday from 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M., and Sunday 1 to 5:45 P.M. Admission is free; the "Elvis + Marilyn" exhibit, which consists of 100 different objects, photographs and artworks, is $6.
Nearby, the Cleveland Orchestra's regular season opens Sept. 14 at Severance Hall, 11001 Euclid Avenue, with Mahler's Symphony No. 5, conducted by Christoph von Dohnanyi. Call (216) 231-1111. Ticket prices range from $21 to $39.
Severance Hall and the art museum are five miles east of downtown in University Circle. For a map of the area, including a guide to Circlelink, a free shuttle connecting the two sites with seven other museums, call University Circle, (216) 791-3900.
Tickets for many entertainment and sporting events can be purchased through Advantix, (800) 766-6048; the service charge averages $2.75 a ticket.
 
 
Sightseeing
 For the first-time visitor, an excursion aboard the Goodtime III presents a languid, two-hour narrated tour. Along with the view of the city's changing downtown skyline from Lake Erie, the Cuyahoga River portion goes by factories and nightclubs in the so-called Flats along the river. A schedule is available from Goodtime Cruise Lines, 825 East Ninth Street Pier; (216) 861-5110. Tickets: $8.50, $6 for children. Sailings May through September.
For a quicker overview, ride the elevator 42 stories to the Terminal Tower Observation Deck atop Tower City Center, 50 Public Square, (216) 621-7981. Open Saturday and Sunday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $2, $1 ages 6 to 16.
Another reason to visit northeast Ohio in the late summer and fall is for the outdoor festivals that celebrate the largely rural character of the rest of the state. Visitors needn't venture far to find hiking trails, orchards and farms.
Just 30 minutes south of downtown, adjacent to the 33,000-acre wooded and serene Cuyahoga Valley National Recreation Area, glassblowers, spinners and weavers practice their crafts at Hale Farm and Village. The 21-building village is preserved by the Western Reserve Historical Society to show life as it was when Ohio was settled in the mid-1800's. Hayrides, cider pressing and live music are part of the Harvest Festival, Oct. 7, 8, 14 and 15. Hale Farm, 2686 Oak Hill Road, Bath, Ohio, (216) 666-3711, is open late May through October. Hours are Tuesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., and Sundays noon to 5 P.M. Admission is $9, $7.50 for seniors and $5.50 for children 6 to 12.
Rollerbladers might want to head for the Cleveland Metroparks' well-marked and well-maintained trail system. One rental spot is in the Hinckley Reservation. The trail here winds 3.4 miles through woods around the man-made lake. Hinckley Lake Boat House rents Rollerblades as well as protective pads and helmets for $5 an hour to $15 a day. Open 7 A.M. to 8 P.M., West Drive, Hinckley, (216) 278-2122.
For a map of all 12 reservations of the Cleveland Metroparks, call (216) 351-6300.
 
Where to Stay
 The contemporary 14-story Wyndham Hotel Playhouse Square, 1260 Euclid Avenue, (216) 615-7500, fax (216) 615-3355, just opened in the downtown theater district with 205 rooms, an indoor pool and health club. Construction is still under way on a large park and plaza that will connect the theater district with the hotel. Singles $119 to $189; an additional adult pays $20.
The 60-room Glidden House, 1901 Ford Drive, (216) 231-8900, fax (216) 231-2130, is in a restored University Circle French Gothic mansion listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The 52 guest rooms are comfortably furnished with a country touch. Singles $111, doubles $121; suites from $140 to $165. Rates include Continental breakfast.
Downtown, the 370 rooms at the Holiday Inn Lakeside, 1111 Lakeside Avenue, (216) 241-5100, fax (216) 241-7437, were refurbished earlier this year. Rates begin at $119 for a double. Amenities include an indoor pool and exercise equipment.
Budget: At the conveniently situated 130-room Comfort Inn, 1800 Euclid Avenue, a standard double is $67. Phone and fax (216) 861-0001.
All 104 rooms are suites with full kitchens at the Residence Inn by Marriott, 30100 Clemens Road, (216) 892-2254, fax (216) 892-3709, in the west side suburb of Westlake. Rates: $119 to $149 per suite. Amenities at the traditional hotel include a health club and a two-mile wooded running path on the grounds of the Bonne Bell offices next door.
Luxury: The Ritz Carlton Hotel, 1515 West Third Street, (216) 623-1300, fax (216) 623-1492, is part of the multilevel enclosed shopping and entertainment complex at Tower City Center, which was renovated in 1990. Many of the hotel's elegant 208 rooms boast superb views of the Cuyahoga River, the lake and downtown. Rates: $159 to $219; suites from $255 to $950 for up to four guests. Rates include the use of an indoor pool and health club.
Thirty miles east of the city, the Quail Hollow Resort, 11080 Concord Hambden Road, Concord, (216) 352-6201, fax (216) 639-1647, is a popular getaway with its golf course, tennis and bicycle rentals. The 170 contemporary rooms range from $131 to $151; amenities include indoor and outdoor pools, whirlpool and sauna.
 
 
Where to Eat
 Dinner prices include a moderate bottle of wine, but not tax and tip.
Sergio's, 1903 Ford Drive (University Circle), in a restored turn-of-the-century carriage house, has a delightful menu reflecting the spicy influences of Brazil. Entrees include beef tenderloin marinated in garlic, black pepper and port and served with black beans, rice and farofa along with fried spinach ($16.95). Of the many side dishes, a spicy green sauce is made with scallion, green chilis and parsley ($2). Dinner for two: $65 to $75. Reservations are necessary; Call (216) 231-1234. Open Monday through Saturday for lunch and dinner; closed Sundays.
At Johnny's Bar, 3164 Fulton Road, (216) 281-0055, the extensive menu includes traditional northern Italian dishes with a French flair. With seasonal changes, the summer menu includes seared swordfish with fresh mussels over porcini mushrooms and roasted garlic spaetzle ($28.95). Dinner for two: $75 to $90. Reservations necessary. Open Monday through Friday for lunch and dinner; closed Sunday.
The changing menu at Marlin, 1952 East Sixth Street, (216) 589-0051, might feature scallops sauteed in a watercress vinaigrette and served on cous cous with pine nuts ($17), or spinach ravioli stuffed with artichoke and feta ($11.50). Or you can choose the three-course Chef's Whim dinner ($22 a person) and not know what you'll be served. Dinner for two: $45 to $55. Lunch and dinner daily except Sunday.
Piccolo Mondo, 1352 West Sixth Street, (216) 241-1300, brings an old warehouse to life with its restaurant and Italian grocery. At the delicatessen counter, a quick takeout lunch or dinner can be assembled from foccacia bread or a baguette, grilled chicken and vegetable pasta ($3.75 the half-pound) and lemon twists for dessert. The restaurant is often crowded after work. Takeout lunch for two about $10, dinner $15. Open daily except Sunday.
Aladdin's Eatery, with its hearty soups, salads and ample pita sandwiches at two locations, is popular with families. Dinner for two: $30. Aladdin's Eatery East Side, 12447 Cedar Road, (216) 932-4333; West Side, 14536 Detroit Avenue, Lakewood, (216) 521-4005.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
The Doubts About Japan's New Surge

BYLINE: By KEN BROWN 

 BODY:
TO hear some describe it, Japan's stock market may have turned a corner this week. But many analysts say the signs are in no way conclusive.
For five long years, ever since the Nikkei began its descent from 38,916 as the real estate bubble burst, bank loans went bad and the Liberal Democratic Party was ousted from power, American investors have hoped for a turnaround in that nation's huge stock market. But no luck. 
 So far this year alone, for instance, the $500 million Japan Fund is down 12 percent, in dollar terms.
Still, last week did provide some grounds for hope. Thanks to concerted action by the central banks of Germany, Japan and the United States, the yen fell from 93.9 to the dollar on Aug. 11 to 97.61 on Friday. The news sent the Nikkei up 4.1 percent in just one day, Wednesday.
For dollar-based investors, the yen's fall also held out the prospect of getting more in Japanese investment for their money. And some believe this summer's bailout of the Cosmo credit union -- the nation's fifth largest -- revealed Japan's resolve to clean up the troubled lending industry.
These and other good signs have drawn investment dollars to Japan. In July, foreigners invested a net 667 billion yen there, according to Salomon Brothers. And for the week ended Wednesday, the assets of the 10 largest United States mutual funds with 40 percent or more of their money invested in Japan inched ahead by $2 million, after asset reductions of $77 million in the previous two weeks alone, according to AMG Data Services.
But skeptics arch their eyebrows at these numbers. "If the market was correcting for a few months and this happens, it is exciting," said Craig Chudler, equities strategist for Salomon Brothers in Japan. "But this has been happening for six years." The Nikkei closed at 18,032 last week -- still less than half its 1989 high. The market would have to push past 21,500, Mr. Chudler said, to prove the slump was over.
And the Nikkei has touched four false bottoms, in April 1990, September 1990, August 1992 and November 1993. Rather than soaring from those spots, each time the market rose just a few thousand points only to fall again.
Nevertheless, individual investors or their fund managers need not shun Japan.
"I do think the weather is changing," said George Foot, a partner at Newgate Management Associates. "Again, no one in their right mind would predict a bottom but you better get ready to get back in Japan because Japan is getting ready to get back to earth after five years of being out of play."
If they are not cowed by the risks and uncertainties, investors might well profit from a cautious, gradual entry into the Japanese market through mutual funds or roughly 30 American depository receipts for Japanese stocks that are actively traded here. A.D.R.'s, which are bought and sold in dollars through American brokerage houses, represent shares of foreign companies and are traded much as stocks are.
"If I were an investor right now starting from zero, I would look to take about 30 percent to 50 percent of my intended position in Japan now and wait with the balance," said Stephen Neville, vice president of Yamaichi International in Canada.
Many solid prospects can be found among Japan's technology stocks, which like their American counterparts are market leaders. Rohm, a semiconductor maker, is up 50 percent this year, for example. David Thomas, who manages the Putnam Asia Pacific Growth Fund, likes Kyocera, which makes coatings for semiconductors. That stock is up 23 percent so far in 1995 -- second only to Nintendo, up 31 percent, as the best performer among Japanese A.D.R.'s.
Many investors are using this pinpoint approach. "I think overseas investors are being very cagey and smart because they are not buying the whole market," Mr. Chudler said. "The latest flows from overseas have been very targeted in the high-tech area."
Dollar-based investors must also realize that, to profit, their Japanese stocks must not only rise, but also outpace any further gains by the dollar against the yen. One strategy, analysts say, is to go with companies in particularly healthy industries, like pharmaceuticals and engineering. Banyu Pharmaceuticals is one example.
Another strategy is to buy exporters. While a falling yen means the shares of these Japanese companies are worth less in dollars, their products become cheaper abroad. Moreover, as the dollar fell below 80 yen in April, many exporters cut their costs greatly in order to remain competitive. With the yen hitting 97.61 to the dollar this week, the profits of these now-lean companies may grow greatly.
Seung Kwak, the lead portfolio manager of the $500 million Japan Fund, is focusing on small and medium-sized exporters like SMC, which makes pneumatic equipment, and large corporations like Hitachi and Canon. Large exporters -- Nikon, Nintendo and NEC, for instance -- also tend to be among the most liquid of Japanese A.D.R.'s.
Nevertheless, many analysts are far from bullish about Japan. They say there are deep problems with the economy, companies and Government, and until these are solved, any rise in the Japanese stock market will be temporary.
There is pessimism to overcome, too. "Until we see some sort of action that overcomes the rather pessimistic perspective of most people -- and a lot of it is psychological -- I suspect the economy is not going to come back very fast," said Hugh Patrick, a professor at Columbia Business School and director of the Center on Japanese Economy and Business.
He said the onus is on the Government to come up with an effective fiscal stimulus package this fall, and that depends in part on whether the current governing coalition falls and elections are held. "In some sense economic activities probably are prisoner of the political process over the next month and a half, two months," Mr. Patrick said.
Others point to the continuing banking crisis in Japan. True, the Government, breaking a longstanding taboo, bailed out the Cosmo credit union after creditors withdrew $915 million. But that's just the tip of the iceberg; the nation's banks have $570 billion of bad loans on their books.
Finally, some of Japan's bullish signs don't stand up to close inspection. Mr. Thomas of Putnam said many international and Asia funds are buying more Japanese stocks in part because other Asian markets are performing poorly or seem risky. And while foreigners bought 667 billion yen worth of Japanese equities in July, Japanese individuals, companies, banks and insurers were net sellers of about 722 billion.
In other words, investors must keep the current rally in perspective. "This is nothing relative to the five- to six-year correction the market is going through," Mr. Chudler said. "This is baby steps. The market is trying to get back up on its feet."

LENGTH: 1412 words

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Rear Adm. Richard A. Buchanan;
The Submarine Fleet, After the Closures

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
SUBMARINE GROUP TWO, two squadrons comprising some two dozen nuclear attack submarines and headquartered at the Naval Submarine Base in Groton, was spared by the Federal Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission this year.
As a result, Rear Adm. Richard A. Buchanan, its commander, has found himself in charge of all Navy affairs north of Virginia, as one of the few flag officers assigned to the region. 
 Admiral Buchanan graduated from the United States Naval Academy in 1968, and has served on five submarines, including the U.S.S. Ohio, the first of the modern class of ballistic missile submarines.
The Admiral discussed the importance of the Navy in Connecticut, and the future of the submarine force here, during an interview at his office in Groton recently. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q: Why do you think the Groton base survived this last round of cuts?
A: There was a recognition that the amount of waterfront property, the amount of capability available in our Atlantic Fleet operational assets was as small as we could go without leaving ourselves vulnerable.
I think specifically, here in Groton, there was a very effective explanation of what this area had in the way of capability. We have the training, the maintenance, and the operational support pieces all in a very compact and efficiently operated facility.
Q. Why was southeastern Connecticut viewed as strategically important in the base review process?
A. One, by virtue of being a day closer to the Mediterranean and a day closer to the northern Atlantic than other Navy bases. We also have the ability to get out to sea with a limited amount of conflicting traffic, which would not be the case in busier port areas.
Q. How much of the Navy's attachment to Groton is nostalgia, since it was the first submarine base?
A. I think there's always some of that that's part of the equation, and I think that's good. This is a very historical site, and I think some of the value of that tradition was recognized. When push comes to shove, and you have no money and something has to go out, that might fall by the wayside. But assuming that you aren't forced to make that decision, it's wonderful to recognize the historic nature of what we possess here.
Q. Will there come a point where it's no longer viable to keep a submarine base here?
A. I don't think so. You never can tell, but Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, chief of naval operations has said he thinks 55 submarines is the right number for the force. And having that number of submarines means we will need the base in Groton.
Q. With the demise of the cold war, do we need a submarine force?
A. Yes. The submarine is both a covert sensor platform, and a covert weapons launch platform. That means you can do things others don't know you're doing, or be places that others don't know where you are, so they may do things that they don't know are being observed.
We can provide information that others can't gather, whether it's acoustic information, visual information, electronic information or communications information -- and we're doing it around the world.
We also have the ability to launch the Tomahawk land strike missile, the harpoon antiship missile, the torpedo against submarines or surface ships. When you talk about weapons launch you also have to add things like the special forces. The Seals really appreciate our ability to get them in close, covertly.
Q. Has the "silent service" become less silent?
A. There's no question. We are responsible, in the submarine force as we are in the whole military, to market ourselves -- to the Congress, to the taxpayers, so they know they're getting value for their tax dollars. We need to market ourselves to the young people of our country because we need good young men and women to be the sailors and officers of the future, and we need to market ourselves to the sailors and officers of today because we need to have them stay in our business.
Q. Most submarines have a relationship with their namesake cities. Why have you pushed for new relationships with local towns as well?
A. Our partnership program complements their sister city relationships. U.S.S. Dallas, for instance, has a good relationship with the city of Dallas, but that's awfully far away, so it has a relationship with a local community, it sends sailors in to work with citizens, then shows off the ship to these people.
We have partnerships with communities where our people live, ranging from Old Saybrook to Stonington. One of the main benefits of the base realignment and closure process has been that it enhanced the awareness of the community of the Navy in their midst.
Q. What economic impact does the base have on Connecticut?
A. About $1 billion a year, based on data gathering for the base closure process. And some of the benefit goes beyond the money. The submarine business is very technically oriented, so it attracts people to provide support services. Also, our submariners are very interested in furthering their education, so they're taking courses on the base and in the community. All those aspects have a cumulative effect that's very valuable to the state.
Q. Does the community support continue now that the base closure process is over?
A. I think it should, I think it can, and I think it really has to. We need to make sure we never take for granted that the community will be there to support us, and we need to make sure the community doesn't take us for granted.
Q. Is there evidence the base has a significant role in the future of the submarine force?
A. The Navy continues to say Groton is its preferred homeport for the Seawolf, our newest class of submarine, which will be put into service next year. With all of the the technology, the maintenance and training capabilities, as well as the tactical support that's in place here, as well as the shipyard that built the ships (the Electric Boat Company), I think it's the right decision to homeport the three -- hopefully, three -- Seawolfs in Groton.
Q. Was the Navy influenced by the fact that Connecticut offered to pay to dredge the Thames River so the Seawolf could be based here?
A. It was a very generous offer, well-timed, and very much appreciated. Having that as an underpinning as the financial part of this project was helpful. The decision was made on its own merits, however, because we wanted to make it clear to all sites that the Navy is not accepting bribes to bring the Seawolf here. Groton was picked on its merits.
Q. You're recently became the first flag officer in your job to be designated the regional coordinator for the Navy. How does that work?
A. When they made the decision to close the Navy base in Philadelphia, there was no shore facility commander able to take responsibility for the Northeast.
The only operational flag officers north of Norfolk, Va., are myself, and two in Newport, R.I. -- one is the president of the War College and the other is commander of the Naval Undersea Warfare Center, responsible for a lot of research and development and technical initiatives.
I was tasked with the responsibility of taking over shore coordination in New Jersey, New York and the New England states. The responsibilities come from numerous commands -- from the Bureau of Personnel for casualty assistance and funeral honors, from the Bureau of Medicine for medical treatment facilities, from the Judge Advocate General's office where we have general court martial authority, from Naval Sea Systems Command for inspections, and from Facilities Engineering Command for environmental coordination. Then of course we're trying to coordinate with the Reserves and the recruiting offices.
Regionally, we can take advantage of economies of scale, and better utilize and apply our resources. For instance, though I am not yet totally responsible for all of the medical facilities in the Northeast, our hospital commanding officer here in Groton has been working with the hospital commanding officer in Newport, so that specialists in one place can move back and forth.
Since I've taken over, in the middle of the region rather than as far south as Philadelphia, there's been a growing sense of responsibility and coordination and enthusiasm for the job. It hasn't been without some pain, because the staff has been stretched, but they've been very helpful, and I'm hopeful we can ultimately get a couple of extra billets.
