HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Marlene Post;
Leading Hadassah in Assisting Jewish and Non-Jewish Causes

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT its 83 years Hadassah has become the largest women's Zionist organization in the world and the largest women's volunteer organization in the United States. Hadassah, Hebrew for Esther, was founded in New York in 1912 by Henrietta Szold to provide health care for people in Palestine.
The founders were looking for the name of a Jewish heroine who had done something important for her people. The organization was named after Queen Esther, who saved the Jews in Persia. Hadassah is now comprised of 385,000 volunteer women in 1,500 chapters in all 50 states and Puerto Rico, including 17,000 members on Long Island. 
 In the United States, Hadassah teaches its members and the American public about the needs of Israel and about Jewish traditions in order to provide leadership for the American Jewish community.
Last week in Jerusalem, Marlene Post was installed as the 21st national president of Hadassah. As the organization's national treasurer since 1991, she has led Hadassah in raising more than $80 million.
Committed to programs of medical research, health care and educational development, Hadassah operates its own medical and educational institutions in Israel, including the Hadassah Medical Organization and the Hadassah College of Technology.
Mrs. Post, who lives in Manhasset Hills, was born and raised in Monticello, N.Y., in a traditional Jewish but non-Zionist home. A graduate of the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing and Teachers College of Columbia University, Mrs. Post taught nursing before becoming involved full time in Hadassah. In recent years, her responsibilities in Hadassah have taken her on more than 70 trips to Israel. Like all members and officers of Hadassah, Mrs. Post receives no income for her services.
Q. Israel has changed greatly over the years and now has its own viable economy. Why should Americans give their money to Israel?
A. There's no question that Israel has seen a substantial change in its economy, particularly in the last few years. The reason anyone should give to Israel has less to do with money and more to do with the centrality of Israel for the Jewish people. Although many of us gave large sums of money to build the state and Hadassah has provided large sums to improve the quality of life for the people living there, the real tie has come because every time we give money to Israel, we are building a connection. It gives us a psychological tie to what is basically the Jewish homeland.
Q. How does Hadassah raise so much money?
A. One of the major sources of revenue is private donations. Hadassah has large contributors from all over the world who give money to finance projects like genetic research or to start a school of optometry in our College of Technology. These donors want to give their money to help their people or to promote research that will benefit mankind. We also get large contributions through major gifts fund raising and planned giving. Fifty percent of the people who leave money to Hadassah in their wills and bequests are not even members. They are looking for an organization that they trust, that does important work and recognizes the importance of Israel, and that is an organization that will last forever. In every community, grass roots fundraising takes place. We've also been receiving Federal Government grants for specific work and equipment in our hospital in Israel. Of all the monies received, 94 cents of every dollar goes to the projects in Israel. We are able to do that because Hadassah is run by volunteers.
Q. What projects will the money go to?
A. We're now building a new Mother and Child Pavilion. We'll be financing different aspects of that project with monies raised this year. We're also launching a major genetic-research project. At the hospital, plans include redoing the Cancer Institute, and starting a Human Biology Research Project, which will be important for diagnosis and treatment. In the field of education, Hadassah is introducing a course of optometry in the College of Technology, and upgrading the commnunity college to a higher academic level. Work is ongoing with immigrants from Ethiopia, training and educating them to prepare them for the Israeli Army.
Q. How has Hadassah changed over the years?
A. Hadassah has refocused its efforts to do more within the communities in the United States, with an emphasis on service and Jewish education. With many more working women and single mothers, Hadassah members need communal Jewish programming and services that fit into their crowded schedules. We've also recognized the crisis of continuity faced by the American Jewish community because of soaring rates of intermarriage. Study groups have changed to focus on topics that are more relevant to life today. One of our newer programs, Training Wheels, provides books and tapes for families to teach their children about Jewish holidays and traditions.
Q. With so many women in the work force and less time for volunteering, how has Hadassah continued to attract young members?
A. Hadassah thrives on the premise that if you have a good product, it's going to sell. We have changed over the years to accommodate today's woman. To attract younger women, we have created special interest groups: groups specifically for nurses, for lawyers, for Spanish-speaking women, Russian-speaking women, social workers, singles, you name it. If several women feel a need for a group, we will tailor make any special interest group they ask for.
Q.As a women's organization, how does Hadassah address contemporary women's issues?
A. Women's health care issues are a major concern for Hadassah. We want women to not only feel healthy, but to be healthy and to have the opportunity to know more about their bodies. We have a breast cancer-awareness program that stresses preventive care, provides breast self-examination and other educational materials. Legislatively, we have been active in Washington on issues that affect women. It was the Long Island region of Hadassah that spearheaded the campaign to start examining the water tables on Long Island because the incidence of breast cancer is higher here than elsewhere in the country. Hadassah also provides education about menopause, osteoporosis, nutrition, and stress related illnesses like heart conditions and ulcers.
Q. What can Hadassah volunteers do who are not interested in fund raising?
A. Where do I begin? There are a multitude of opportunities in every area, from education to community services. We have volunteers who work with high school students on our breast cancer-awareness program, others who are trained in our Curriculum Watch program to analyze a school's curriculum and check for the accuracy of materials and textbooks with regard to the history of the Jewish people. In Great Neck, Hadassah volunteers are involved in an amblyopia testing program in the schools. Last year in New York City Hadassah decided that not enough was being done for voter registration, and volunteers started an outreach program.
Q. How did you become involved with Hadassah?
A. I first joined for social reasons. I was home with two babies, ready to get out of the house and somebody rang my doorbell and asked if I wanted to come to a luncheon. I said yes. As I became more involved, I saw the important health care connection and the difference we were making in Israel. We were the forerunners -- the first schools of nursing and dentistry, provided the first major hospitals and did the first important research in Israel. This organization gave me an opportunity to connect with world Jewry and with women all over the United states like myself who wanted more Jewish education, and to be able to feel that we were doing something important.
Q. What are your personal goals as president of Hadassah?
A. I would like to think more in terms of world Jewry. There are two important things now going on in Hadassah. One is a strategic plan to examine the organization. Where should Hadassah be in the next generation? We need to be in the right position for the next century to attract women, keep them interested and keep Israel the centrality. Part of the strategic plan is a study by the National Commission on American Jewish Women in conjunction with Brandeis University, to examine and analyze the most in-depth and current information about Jewish women in the United States. At the same time, in Israel, we've hired a professional firm to do a major study to determine what the needs are of the country and what the institutions are doing to meet these needs. In about a year, the strategic plan and the Israeli study will meet, and we will have to sit down and write, create and then administer our new vision for the next century.
Q. Have any of the findings of the recent study of American Jewish women surprised you?
A. In two areas. Everyone has heard of Hadassah, even if it's just from a Jackie Mason joke. But while people know the name and think we do good work, many don't really know what Hadassah does. Some women who might have become involved in Hadassah have chosen instead to work with breast cancer awareness, but they didn't realize that breast cancer awareness is part of what Hadassah does. There are pieces of Hadassah's work that many women may be interested in, but they don't make the connection. The second surprise for me was the issue of women's spirituality. I didn't realize how important it is to American Jewish women today. While they are busier than ever, the need for a spiritual connection is high on their agenda. At Hadassah, we're going to have to change to address some of these spiritual needs and to provide experiences that allow for women to connect on a spiritual level.
Q. As the mother of three daughters, do you see a loss of volunteer spirit in the next generation?
A.My three daughters are all lifelong members of Hadassah. They have the volunteer spirit but it is channeled differently. In their own way, they are all involved in some form of volunteer activity. I believe that in the next generation the spirit is there, you just have to offer the right opportunities.
Q. As Hadassah's national president, you are the ultimate volunteer. What are the rewards of this nonsalaried position?
A. There is no salary that could provide the rewards I get from this position, which allows me to offer Jewish leadership, a connection with Israel and pride in the community. Each day is a new challenge. When I go to bed every night, I feel three things: I feel I've done something for the continuity of the Jewish people; I feel I've made a difference in the quality of life of my members, even if it's in a small way, and I feel that it is my obligation as a Jewish woman to insure that Israel is the centrality and that it will be there forever. Hadassah is my vehicle that does that for me. And I sleep very well at night!

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marlene Post, new national head of Hadassah, in her office. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)
